We got here at 7:30 AM before it opened and we're first in line. I'm glad we did because it got busy very quick. Once inside, we realized how small and quaint this place was. We ordered Swedish French toast and cinnamon French toast. We had a chocolate crumb cake as sort of an appetizer before meals came. 

One tip: definitely get here early. It gets crowded and the line goes out the door. But, the wait is certainly worth it. The food is very good and very filling. Also, you cannot use credit cards here but you can use debit cards or cash. Keep that in mind upon arrival.

If you're ever in San Francisco and looking for a very very good breakfast definitely swing by here. You will not regret it!
author: Emmin M.

description:
Came here at 11am and waited in line for almost 1.5 hours. What makes the wait seem even longer and more torturous... is THE DAMN SUN. I'm literally glistening of sweat as I wait in that line!! 

-Monte Cristo: Our favorite dish! This is basically an egg-battered grilled cheese (cheddar & gruyere) with turkey and ham, served with a tub of their delicious homemade jam. I decided to take a bite with and without the jam, just to try how both compares. Let me tell ya... EAT IT WITH THE JAM!! I totally regret that I wasted a bite without the jam! This is a must order when you're here! (I will add that there was a little bug on our plate (see pic); I'm guessing it came from the salad that came with this dish. Luckily we saw it resting in peace on the side and was able to dodge it from going into our mouths! Take this how you want to take it...) 

-Norwegian Benedict: Eggs poached perfectly. This was good, nothing special... there was an overall tanginess to this dish that we didn't really enjoy. The potatoes were also a little of a let-down.  

-French Toast Sampler: Meh. Nothing special. Typical french toast. Wasn't bad, wasn't great either.

Service was wonderful and friendly! Aside from the Monte Cristo, everything was just mediocre. (Maybe give pancakes a try?? We saw majority of the tables order it and it looked delicious!) We were planning on ordering the beef hash, but was told that they don't have it today. That was a little disappointing, taking into consideration the long and sweaty wait... haha

How strange that this restaurant is listed as a tourist attraction... fellow tourists, there are far more better brunch places in the city that are worth trying (not to mention waiting 1.5+ hours for...)!
author: Kris C.

description:
I came across Mama's on Utrip while looking for activities and places too eat. I noticed Mama's was a well known breakfast spot and I liked that it seemed really "mom & pop"ish so I had to try it. We went on a Sunday and they opened at 8:00 AM. If you are not there by 7:15-7:30 AM you will be waiting if you get there after 8:00 AM. We waited approximately 1 hour 20 min to be seated. It's a true mom and pop restaurant so it's smaller on the inside. At first I didn't want to wait but I'm glad we waited. They are closed on Mondays and we are leaving on Tuesday. One thing I really loved about this restaurant was that one of the owner's was greeting customers at the door and going over the menu and best options. I love when restaurants give you a more personal experience. However, I will say for a breakfast place they are a little more on the expensive side. One dish is like $13.95, a small OJ or Apple Juice is $3.95 and a large is $4.95. 

The food was worth the wait. I ordered the Monte Cristo and my husband ordered the French Toast Sampler and an Omelette. They give you plenty of food. One thing I liked about the Monte Cristo was that it was Grilled like French Toast instead of deep fried so it didn't feel as heavy. The jam it was served with was amazing and made in house. The Grilled Potatoes that came with it were good as well. They could have used a tad more seasoning and/or salt but overall good. Overall a good dish. My husband's French Toast was good and his omelette was good as well. All their food was good. Really on complaints on the food. 

Overall, I'm glad  we got to try Mama's. The food was very good. My only things I would suggest to be concerned about is the wait time and make sure you don't mind spending $35-$50 for 2 for breakfast. Other than that give them a try.
author: Tiffany D.

description: Food was GREAT! The line was so long but it was worth the wait. The only downside to place was the amount of fruit flies all over the food and where they prepare it. Your mostly swatting flies left and right the whole time
author: Ashtar B.

description: Mama's was on my list of must eats in San Fran and it did not disappoint! I was ready to stand in the inevitable two hour line for some amazing brunch but was lucky enough to only wait 30 minutes... and the food is definitely worth any wait. The Apple Crumb Cake was absolutely delicious and the Farmer's Omelette was one of the best I have had. My friend ordered the Crab Cake Benedict as well and we were all apart of the clean plate club today! The homemade jam is a must tooIt was so good, we bought a jar to take home. I definitely recommend coming here for breakfast and brunch. I'm already planning my trip back to San Fran and my trip back to Mama's on Washington.
author: Carissa V.

description:
1st time visiting San Fran and everyone recommended this place. We showed up on a Sunday 11am-ish and there was a line approx 40 mins. We decided to wait it out and try the food. The inside is really cozy and the food was of quality. I really wanted hash browns but they only had potatoes which I didn't really care for. Tried the Monte Cristo and it was really really good, the jam paired with the sandwich was very unique to Mamas. 

Overall good fun place, long line for good breakfast.
author: Matt P.

description:
My first "wait in line" brunch experience in SF! My friend is awesome and did most of the waiting, so I can't comment on how long she waited.

We were a group of 4 and after a bit, got sent inside where we placed our order and waited to be seated. Note this place is cash only or debit card. We managed to get the cute booth in the front corner.

I shared the egg white omelette, chicken sausage, and coffee cake with a friend. I also got to try the French toast. I don't usually go for sweet items for breakfast but everything was delicious. Glad I got to eat here!
author: Tiffany Y.

description:
After reading all the reviews, I was preparing for an 1 hour wait. Luckily, I waited only 30 minutes. Score! 

Mamas is a small quaint restaurant on the corner across the street from Washington Square Park. Big surprise right?? There are windows around the restaurant giving you a nice view of the square and street/people waiting in line. Great for people watching. 

After you wait a while while trying to catch Pokemon, you will be asked to enter and order at the register. Make sure you bring cash because only debit cards are accepted if the bill is $15 or more. Afterwards, you'll be seated.

Montecristo sandwich - turkey, honey baked ham, cheddar and Gruyere cheese battered in egg, grilled and served with homemade jam. I thought the sandwich itself was okay. I did love how the bread was super soft like a cloud. What really gave the sandwich that flavor was the homemade jam. Holy crap was that jam fantastic!

North Beach Benedict - prosciutto and grilled tomato. I like tomatoes, prosciutto, and benedicts, so naturally I'm going to enjoy this entree.
author: James B.

description: Okay okay okay... so the other reviews on this place are pretty spot on. We came here based off the 3.5k reviews and 4 Stars on yelp. The line was long but we met locals in line who gave us suggestions on what to order. The French toast sampler is basically to die for. Who ever thought to make banana bread into French toast!!?!?! This place was yummy and worth the wait. Kinda sucks that they don't take credit cards though... especially for the price of all the meals (~$14 a plate).... I'm sure they make a lot of money based on the line and business but they could make a lot more if they accepted credit cards. We wanted to order more food to go (their pastures) but didn't have enough cash.
author: Marissa C.

description:
I have been wanting to go here for a LONG time. The last time I was here the line was too long. We just got off a plane and we're starving!!! 

We got there around 9am and the line wasn't long. We waited about about 30-45 minutes, which is understandable because the food is amazing!!!! Plus that isn't long at all if you think about it. When you go out to dinner you end up waiting that long. Just don't go hungry because you can see other people eating. 

I had the cinnamon french toast with a side of potatoes, and it was amazing! My boyfriend had scrambled eggs, sausage, and Canadian bacon. I took a few bites when he wasn't looking and it was all SO good. Especially the Canadian bacon!! 

The service and the employees were all so nice and helpful. Great service! I will definitely be going there again whenever the next time I'll be in the city!
author: Star A.

description:
Mama's is a must! This place never seems to disappoint me. Every time I've visited San Fran I made it a point to come here. 

This place is a well known place and is extremely tiny on the inside with limited seating so make sure you freed up a few hours of your morning. Place opens at 8am be there by 7:30am in line and ready! If you come late you're going to be waiting in line. Don't worry if you're late, they take drink orders and you can have coffee while waiting. 

My overall experience here is great. Great food, GREAT JAM, great employees..etc. Highly recommend coming here and trying out different menu items with friends and family and just splitting the plates!  

Also, don't be shy to ask for more jam after you finish yours haha I always do, it's so yummy! If you're unsure what to get the Monte Cristo is always safe and delicious! 

Only thing I would want different is their coffee, it's really basic coffee, no flavored creamers, no other sweetener than sugar, but you can't complain because it's a regular coffee at a breakfast place.
author: Jeremy G.

description: Amazing as everyone says. This place is worth the wait. We can here on Mother's day and waited about an hour. I had the Monte Cristo and my wife had the Norweogian scramble. Both were delicious. Will def be back.
author: Chris L.

description:
Mama Mia!! This place is breakfast and brunch heaven. Located in beautiful North Beach (Little Italy) this cozy and quaint sits on a corner lot just across from Washington Square Park. The three times I have stopped in for breakfast I have always been met with long lines. I think the longest I waited was about 20 minutes. Yes that is crazy, but really not that much different that your average restaurant on a Friday or Saturday night. The french toast is exceptional. I have never opted for any of their other options because French toast is my go to breakfast. They use a beautiful brioche which is divine. You have a nice helping of fresh fruit and the and eggs and bacon if you want to add a little extra to your plate. 

I decided on the banana walnut French toast this time around and was not disappointed. It was cooked perfectly. 

The staff here has this down to a science.  Because the location is so small you have to wait outside until a table clears up. Then it up to the counter to place your order and then wait to be seated. The staff is always pleasant and you never feel rushed. This is a must for me every time I'm in San Francisco.
author: Argelia M.

description:
Prepare for a long wait before being seated.  Crazy system. Its not a sit down, server takes
your order restaurant. When you see a loooong line of people waiting outside the restaurant then you know its going to be at least an hour wait.  And even after you have waited an hour
on line and get inside the restaurant you place your order with the cashier and then wait inside
the restaurant for an open table.  I said crazy.  Its a very small corner building and I estimate it can seat 30-40 people max. Their bathroom facility is crazy too. They tell & direct you go through the kitchen and then down some steps outside the building.  The toilet is enclose 
in this big white wooden box. Like I said crazy. 
But when we finally got seated at a table the service was very good. Server was friendly and accommodating.

Now review of their food. I ordered their French Toast sampler plate which really gives you the opportunity to try their 3 French toast dishes they have on their menu. Server gave us home made raspberry jam which was deelish.  I read other reviews stating the Monte Cristo was the best and I did see it being eaten by other people and it did look good. 

Overall  worth waiting 1 hour? Not sure depends. Mama's only open for Breakfast & Lunch. So get there by 3p. Bring cash. There is a sign in the window stating takes cash only. I deducted a couple stars because of the wait but based on food taste it is very good.
author: Joni I.

description: Arrived at 8 am in a Saturday morning, wait 30mins before came in the restaurant. Great Dungeness Crab Benedict, lots of crab, yummy!
author: Queen C.

description:
DON'T WASTE YOUR TIME!!!
We arrived here before their opening time (it's 8 o'clock) and there already was a line outside their door. It was 8.10 when they opened their doors to customers even though we can see their waiting staff from the windows, just sitting around and having their coffee leisurely. I think they became too popular now that they just don't care for the people waiting extra 10 min outside of their door for no reason. Disrespectful at the very least. 

Also the line outside their door is NOT because they are best at breakfast but they worked out a clever scheme, where they don't sit you at your table until all the people front of you order their food at the counter and pay for it and wait some more for an available table. Even tho there are tables to sit, you can't go and sit. So the line outside never ends, as it takes a long time to do same thing with every customer. Just BAD
author: Ebru C.

description: I'm always on a hunt for my favorite sandwich and they had the best Monte Cristo sandwich ever. Although there was a line when we got there, we only waited for about 30 min which isn't bad because the food is worth it! I will definitely come back whenever we're in San Francisco!
author: Faith J.

description:
No clue why people wait 1-2 hours for this place. I suppose their French toasts are slightly unique, but otherwise it's a pretty basic breakfast. Sooo many other places to go in the city. 

On a personal note, I could not eat the food there: Once you are inside at the cashier, you watch all the men in the open kitchen. They do not wear gloves to make the food and, after watching all of their hands repeatedly dunk into the vat of egg batter, and all over everything, I became super grossed out and couldn't eat. It felt really dirty to me. I realize some people don't care, but I had no appetite after watching their hands all over my food.
author: Lynne M.

description:
Disclaimer** - came in a party of two around noon on a Thursday and waited for an hour and a half. YES. It was worth it. I would do it again. 5/5. 

My cousin, who is a local, recommended this brunch place to me. It was fantastic!!! I will now recommend this place to anyone and everyone who is local or plans on visiting the bay sometime soon!

I ordered "Mama's Monte Cristo" which was the perfect combination of sweet and savory. The dish is served with a side of potatoes and some fresh fruit. The grilled (not fried!) French toast-esque sandwich dipped in their homemade jam was truly something else!! If you're like me, brunch is where the money's at because breakfast is much too early and there are way too many things to do when traveling to stop for lunch! I would highly recommend this Monte Cristo sandwich or their other one, "Our Famous Monte Cristo!" --not only is it better than Disneyland's...but it is also approximately $6 cheaper!! (ha ha HA)

My friend ordered the Washington Square Omelette with egg whites. Something worth mentioning: it costs a little extra to sub for egg whites. But yoooooooo...the Italian sausage in her omelette was SO flavorful. 

We initially wanted to share a slice of one of their delicious cakes out on display but were glad that we didn't after our meal. The portions here were perfect for brunch.

One more thing to note! They do not accept Credit Cards! However, they do accept Debit Cards with a minimum purchase of $15.

10/10 would recommend!!!
author: Juliana P.

description:
It's a solid brunch spot in San Francisco. The monte cristo was perfection! 

I came with a large group so it did take a little longer to be seated. The wait here is a long line you must physically wait in line for. After waiting outside, you step inside the small restaurant and there's another line.... You order and pay first then you're seated. Not your traditional sit eat and pay restaurant. We ordered a side of bacon when seated and they didn't charge us for it!

It was nice to try it once but sf has a lot of brunch spots to hit with less of a wait.
author: Tracy V.

description: Yes, the line is loooooong to get in this small and bustling place BUT it's soooooo worth it!  Every time my family travels to San Fran, this is the 1st place we stop for an absolute treat of delicious breakfast dishes smothered in pure satisfaction!  So this time around I had the Dungeness Crab Omelette (it's the season right now) and let me tell you, it was completely bursting with flava (step above flavOR) and packed with Dungeness Crab (definitely not skimpy).  Then I squeezed in the Swedish Cinnamon French Toast (cuz why not I had on leggings) and they were fluffy with a little crispiness on the edges (just like my mama used to make) and just smothered in sweet cinnamon scrumptiousness!  Yah I had to back away from the table like a semi-truck but it's San Fran so off we went for a walk to Chinatown a few blocks away.  Great location + amazing food = back again!
author: Trish M.

description:
Saturday morning. Arrived at 9:06, seated at 11:13, left at 11:54. After nearly spending THREE hours to have breakfast, we felt full but empty at the same time. 

The food: 
Monte Cristo, the best thing on the freaking menu. 
French toast sampler, the lemon blueberry was the best- next time just ordering the plates of those, the other two on the plate were bland. 
Washington square omelette, the pepper and sausage had great flavor.
North Beach Benedict, the idea of prosciutto on eggs Benny was brilliant but it was chopped up into very small pieces like shredded carrots which made the texture of the delicate prosciutto tough. 

Coffee is priced per cup apparently which I found strange, but the waitress filled up my cup more than once. 

The service was great but the wait was a bit outrageous. Total time of THREE HOURS from start to finish... That's a bit extreme.
author: Angela Y.

description: The only downside to this restaurant was the long wait and the fast table turn around. also, no credit cards allowed (cash/ATM card). i recommend getting there early. great selection in breakfast foods. loved the banana pancakes. also awesome service
author: Sanjna V.

description:
I tend to think that places where waits are incredibly long (especially in touristy areas) are likely to be overrated. Also -- perhaps because I'm often a skeptic -- when places are built up so much by people I usually walk in with doubt from the start. Now, Mama's was pretty good. Was it worth the value and worth the wait? No. This is solidly a 3-star joint: not bad, not fantastic. It's alright. 

I went it on Tuesday afternoon around 1. My boyfriend and I stood in line for about 20-ish minutes which is apparently awesome given that Mama's is known for hours-long waits particularly on weekends. Once you're let inside, you pay for your food up front. There is a large menu of brunch/lunch items and beverages. Pay attention to the area near the register because there are specials and cocktails taped to the glass wall that aren't on the paper menus. While in line you'll see their various pound cakes, crumb cakes, and other goodies to entice you while you wait. 

The space itself is rather small which is another reason why the waits are long. It's a charming and cozy corner spot -- very old school San Francisco. Mama's is adorned with kitsch and newspaper clippings and photos from the distant past. In terms of service: rather efficient and friendly.

We ordered the Monte Cristo. Oh, yes. It *is* delicious and probably one of the better Monte Cristos I've had. Portion-wise: it's a disappointingly small for the price tag ($12.95). The bread is beautifully eggy and rich and the homemade jam to dip the sandwich in is lovely. We also had the Pan Dore ($10.95): a sourdough baguette French toast that is also eggy and is lightly covered with a wonderfully not-too-sweet lemon butter sauce. I also had a basic iced tea with my meal. In all, from the point we stood in line to our first bite, we waited about 45 minutes which wasn't too bad. 

In the end, Mama's is worth trying once. It's a San Francisco institution. We decided that we probably won't go back any time soon since we walked away with a reaction of "meh." Long lines (again we went on a Tuesday afternoon which seems to be the way to go!) coupled with a higher price point for middle-of-the-road food... eh, we'll pass.
author: James Z.

description: This is my favorite brunch place  on the south side of SF proper. The line is long and on the weekends you have to start getting here by 8-9am to get seated. I got the ham hollandaise munchie sandwich along with the usual breakfast style goods, and the amount and quantity of food is very adequate. The chives add a lot of flavor to the omelets, which carry a nice aioli French-Prussian flavor without the actual gravy or sauce. My friend had more la carbonaise style crepes which he said had very delicate texture with the small sautéed hen. The service is also great here and the setting is classy enough for good conversation with other clientele but doesn't scream out tech/venture capitalism suited up environment. I would come here again absolutely!
author: Han S.

description: I wanted to love this place as it came highly recommended. Mama's was not all that it was made out to be. Our French toast was cold when it came out and way too eggy for my taste, my potato's were not fully cooked either. Vegetarian eggs benny was tasty and lots of veggies which is a plus. We did wait outside but once they opened the line moved quick.
author: Lisandra T.

description:
My cousin was dying to try this place for a while; she didn't manage to eat at Mamas the last time she came to San Fran because of the queue. So we tried again this time; woke up really early, & took a slow walk down, reached at 745, only to find out that a small queue had already formed. 

Well, the queue was definitely worth the wait! Had their crab cake Benedict, which was practically handcrafted by Demeter herself! We also had the French toast platter (banana x cranberry x cinnamon) - the banana was awesome, found the cranberry a bit too sour for my liking. 

Do note they only take cash, and the wait can be super long. Would recommend to go early!
author: Alyssa Chloe T.

description:
DRESS CODE: Elastic Pants or Mumu

BRING: Completely empty stomach and at least an hour of reading material and/or cellular data for mindless time killing if your dining companions are not entertaining enough while waiting on a line that looks like a Vegas club entrance (complete with bouncer at the door for traffic control). And also like Vegas, but cheaper, bring cold hard cash (~$20-40 per person depending on how greedy you're feeling).

WHEN: Ideally on a weekday at an hour no human being would logically want to eat, or if the weather is heinous (since almost the entire line is outside). We got lucky on a sunday right after some rain so we only had a half block wait and we're seated within 45 mins of getting on the shortest line I've ever seen there. 

WHAT TO EAT: Monte Cristo & Dungeness Benedict. The Carrot cake and French Toast Sampler are skipable,  other than the original the others were too dense, and you're already getting French Toast with your Monte Christo. 

WHAT TO DO AFTERWARDS: Tip well, the people are great. Go check your glucometer. Do not weigh thyself.   Beach like a whale.
author: Snuffles B.

description:
Prepare To Fall in line  ..Around 30 mins
(Bring a jacket.. In San Francisco is always Chilly  even on SUMMER)

Soon as get in there's another line to order your Meal .. Trick here is while waiting outside there's a menu plastered on the window to browse your food then soon as u get in you fall in line .. Pay and wait for 15 mins to be sat Down..

Overall it worth the experience .. I salute the servers with AWW!!! After I paid my order the Cashier guy ask how many .. We sat down to our table .. And wallah !!! Still manage to bring the right order to US.. Considering it's a pack restaurant (well organized Crew) 

Food wise !! It's good ..it's the Intrigue of me that made to try this place .. Everyday there's always a huge line ...
author: Donovan L.

description:
Brunch, brunch, brunch, brunch, brunch, brunch
They see me eating,
Brunch, brunch, brunch, brunch, brunch, brunch...

Just like I can't seem to get RiRi's newest hit out of my head, my quest to find the hottest brunch places in the Bay Area continues with full steam ahead! Finally I can cross the famous Mama's on Washington Square off my brunch list, but sadly I have to say that I don't think I'll be coming back.

While the interior of the restaurant is very homey and makes you feel like you're eating food made with love from your mama (the restaurant name is spot on folks), the ridiculous wait times compared to the quality of food simply don't match up.

I came here for Sunday brunch, which is arguably the most crowded day for brunch to begin with, but we waited in line outside of the restaurant for over an hour and a half, waited another 20 minutes in line to order and pay for the food, and then waited another half hour at our table to finally be served our food. That was a 2.5 hour wait for food, and I regretted not eating something light beforehand to endure this brunch journey.

I decided to be bold and order the shockingly expensive special, the Crab Cake Benedict ($23!!) -- I waited that long, so might as well go big or go home. I don't really understand why this benedict was so expensive as all the benedicts on the regular menu were around $13-15; I suppose the cost was due to the fact that they used real crab, but even so, that is a huge price increase compared to the regular benedicts.

The Crab Cake Benedict was definitely tasty, but was it a mind-blowing, life-changing, 2.5 hour wait worthy benedict? Sadly, no. In fact, I had some issues with cutting into the English muffin portion of the benedict. Even though I was given a serrated knife, I had to put in some serious upper arm work to cut through the muffin -- luckily I work out or I would have been sore the next day from how much effort I had to put in. My friend who also ordered a benedict was also struggling to cut through his English muffin, so at least I have some peace of mind that it wasn't my (lack of) upper arm strength that failed me in trying to cut through the muffin.

What I did enjoy about the benedict was how juicy the crab cakes were and the fact that the hollandaise sauce had a bit of spice to it which complemented the dish perfectly. I am normally not a fan of spice due to my low spice tolerance, but the spice on this sauce was a perfect amount to give something different and unexpected to an otherwise ordinary benedict.

While Mama's on Washington has good food, the wait and service time to enjoy the food are simply not worth it. Unfortunately for Mama's, this is one famous brunch place that doesn't live up to the hype.
author: Pooja M.

description: Lines were long but moved fast. They seat you after your food is ordered. So you will get a table. Pancakes were good. Daughter enjoyed her chocolate waffle.
author: Reginae M.

description: The best breakfast! You must order the monte cristo it's delicious and very filling. Yes, the wait is long and outside so bring layers. I don't come here often because of the wait so when I get the chance to I really enjoy it!
author: Ravina Y.

description: Just ate here and the wait is long but omg is it worth it. I had the kugelhopf which was really like regular French toast and hindsight I would've ordered something else BUT my bf ordered the monte cristo, the classic, and boy was it amazing and worth the wait. Hurray for bfs and them letting us eat their food!! So I will definitely come back despite the weight and the Montecristo will be mine!
author: Heather G.

description:
Having lived in SF for 9 months, some friends and I decided we finally HAD to try Mama's. One Saturday morning, we woke up early and arrived 30 minutes before they opened (at 7:30 AM) to a line already down the block. We were not too surprised by this wait and used the opportunity to go pick up coffee. 

We were seated at 8:20AM (only 20 minutes past opening!) which was much faster than expected. Mama's is very cute and pretty small. When you wait in line to order, you get to look in on the griddle and see all of the homemade breads and cakes Mama's uses for French Toast and serves. It definitely whetted our appetites. We waited about 30 minutes for our food and had 4 entrees between the three of us. Hey, it's the weekend; don't judge us!!

We split the French Toast Sampler. This was pretty good. The bread Mama's uses is delicious and really makes this special. Each of the varieties was good in its own way. I think I may have had better french toast at other places but being able to try different varieties in one plate pretty cool.

I had the Veggie Benedict without Hollandaise and with Fruit. I know, it's weird, but I love avocado and poached eggs and really hate Hollandaise. This was okay, not too much to mess up or set this apart. The eggs were poached perfectly though! The only thing is I wish I hadn't paid up for fruit since the portion served was TINY and not worth the $2. 

My friends had the Egg White Scramble and the Smoked Salmon Benedict and seemed happy with their choices. I think we all liked our food but didn't think it was worth the wait and fame Mama's has.

Overall, I thought Mama's was good, if not overhyped. I would go back and maybe try their famous Monte Cristo but if you have to wait an hour+, I would keep walking as you will end up disappointed.
author: Carrie W.

description: Washington Square Omelette with spicy Italian sausage was excellent. The French toast sampler was nice to try 3 different types. My favorite was the cranberry orange with walnuts. This place could use a good cleaning though. The dust on overhead fans looked to have been there for years. It was very hot and no a/c either. The line was about a 40 minute wait but well worth it.  Our server was very sweet but cashier (long brown hair) seemed more focused on laughing/talking with the cooks than taking orders.
author: Melissa L.

description:
My ambition got the best of me today or let me rephrase this and say that my ambition gave me the opportunity to discover new culinary lands today. 

So many friends have raved about the food in San Francisco and today I got the opportunity to put them to the test. Yelp have declared Mama's On Washington the next worth contender for this heavy weight bout and with no further delay and a few hours of hunger training I jumped in a cab from my flight from LAX to San Fran and headed straight to Mama's. 

There were about 15-20 people waiting on line. On a Tuesday at 11:30am? This place must be just as good. A young lady on the line from London expressed her excitement at coming here from a recommendation of her uncle. I don't think I can afford to miss my flight back with only an hours and a half to spare I decided to settle for takeout. 

The place is warm and cozy. The waiters are dressed in all black. And all wear a smile that almost says " Welcome to the best damn breakfast spot in SF."  I admire the enthusiasm. 

I ordered the crab cake egg Benedict. The fresh with a combination of jam and jelly " that shit is legit " and home fries. I also got the fresh squeezed  orange juice and lemonade. 

The order took about 30 mins to come but worth the wait. I wish the home fried were a little more crisp. 

All in all I give this place 5 stars. Def check it out if you in SF. Do yourself a favor and get here early or else you may just have to settle for bfast in the park like I did.

Oh I forgot to mention that the patron are in no hurry to finish their meals. I mean with food this good - can you blame them? This too contributed to the long wait.
author: Adrian F.

description: This is a most over=rated   tourist trap. For people  who don't really know good food. The wait in line is ridiculous and certainly avoid it if you are a senior this is no place for you.  I was told the french toast was unbelievable. I have had much better french toast elsewhere for a far less price. Going to the bathroom here is an obstacle course. Caters to a young crowd who don't really know better.
author: vera m.

description:
Been to Mama's a few times now. Waited once in the rain.

I have to admit, the first time I went here I was not that impressed. I did decide to give it another shot, and have not been disappoint since.

I'm a HUGE eggs benedict fan and was happy with my order. This place is great for classic American breakfast.
author: Amanda B.

description: I had the chocolate cinnamon french toast and it was amazing! The service was also really good and fast. The place is closing at 3 and I got there around 2:30 ish? And there was no line so I just went straight in and ordered.
author: Jay I.

description: One of my favorites in the city. Minus one star because of the time it takes to wait in line for a table as there's always a crowd waiting outside. Awesome food!
author: Michelle K.

description: This has to be one of the best breakfast spots I've been to in a very long time. Maybe THE best! My husband and I had the Dungeoness Crab Benedict, French Toast Sampler,  Monte Cristo and Green Tea. EVERYTHING was AMAZING!! We also heard that the pancakes were to die for but I'll have to come back real soon to verify that for myself. Be warned this place is not cheap but well worth the price. The waiter was pleasant and the young lady at the door was friendly and greeted everyone right away.
author: Jeanae K.

description:
Had a day off work on Weds and finally came to see what the hype was all about. We got here around 9:30am and there were 2 parties ahead of us waiting outside. We waited a total of 20mins to be seated.

Verdict: 
Overhyped? - yes. 
Would I wait 2hrs on a weekend for this? - no
How's their Monte Cristo? - delicious especially with their housemade jam. But I've actually had a lightly better version in Sac (Tower Cafe)  

SERVICE: 
The whole process goes like this: 
1) wait outside 
2) wait in line inside to order food
3) be seated
4) food comes to you 

AMBIANCE:
Has a really homie feeling. Almost like a diner or kitchen in a traditional american house. Very bright interior with a lot of framed pictures and decor. 

FOOD:
The food was good, but nothing mouthgasmic. We ordered 2 dishes: 
1) Classic Benedict: runny yolk. check! Canadian bacon went perfect with the muffin and egg used. Only compliant, I could taste the salt they used to poached the eggs. 
2) Monte Cristo: I enjoyed this dish better. Basically a grilled cheese french toast combo This dish is carbs overload - made of 6 pieces of bread total and potatos! In between each toast are cheese and turkey slices. The toast tasted perfect with their housemade jam! The only thing I didn't really enjoy were their dry potatoes. 
I actually prefer the monte cristo I've tried in Tower Cafe in Sac, but I would say they are pretty close!
author: Samantha F.

description:
This place is a gem! I wasn't planning on writing a review since 3,000 other people have, but the food was AMAZING. 

So the stories about the wait are true, but the food is still worth it. Plan accordingly and try to get there before opening if you can. There will still be a line then, but you can minimize your wait time that way. Our party got there around 8am and we ended up waiting about 30 minutes. I've read reviews about longer waits, so we may have been lucky that day. Once we got inside, we continued waiting in line to order at the counter. At this point, the line runs right by the open kitchen so you get an up front view of the staff preparing the food and the extensive selection of fresh baked pastries!

I ordered the Monte Cristo sandwich...ham, cheese, dipped in batter and grilled. It came with a side of potatoes, their seasonal house-made jam, and was absolutely amazing. BEST MONTE CRISTO EVER. I could get that every time and would be absolutely happy. The fresh squeezed orange juice also complemented the meal well. 

If you are lucky enough to try Mama's, remember to bring cash or debit. It would be a tragedy if you were turned away for only having a credit card on hand.j
author: Rosalie N.

description:
Yelp 2017 100 Challenge:
2017 Review 16/100

Being from LA, I'm used to the hype and waiting for things; but with the amount of hype and waiting- I am that much more expecting of the food and quality.

We waited about two hours in line. Once we got inside the small restaurant, the process was unexpected where we got to a counter, order and pay for our food. 

We got the popular Monte Cristo, pancakes, omelette, and Benedict dishes. Honestly for the price, the food was mediocre. The monte cristo dish was very very good, but the only thing good. 

For the food and especially the wait, it is not worth it. I would not come here again if I had to wait to pay for overpriced mediocre food.
author: Linda S.

description:
OH MAMA!!! I only had one chance at getting brunch right on my trip to SF and it's safe to say I made the right choice. I can see why people are willing to line up for over an hour to eat here. Would I do it every weekend? Probably not. But I would definitely do it once in a blue moon if I lived in SF. We got there around 11 AM on Sunday morning and ended up waiting about an hour until we finally got it. Keep in mind people....once you get in the restaurant, you aren't immediately seated. You have to wait in another line to place your order and then you are seated. Debit card/cash only though.

I got an order of the Norwegian eggs benedict (smoked salmon) and it was off the charts good!! That egg was phenomenal. The yolk just oozing out right after I took a stab at it...it was delicious to say the least. The English muffin was properly toasted and the Hollandaise sauce was perfect. I'm salivating just thinking about it. We also got an order of the famous Monte Cristo and it was fantastic. Everything about it..the presentation, taste, jam....all went perfectly together. It comes loaded with turkey, ham and cheese. My favorite part was the jam. Count me in for anything homemade.

Are you looking for a delicious, old-school brunch spot? Look no further than Mama's.
author: Jason L.

description:
I was really excited to try this place with my friend for a weekday brunch. I was super shocked at how long the line was on a Friday morning. We definitely waited outside in the cold for at least an hour before getting inside. When we walked inside, we only had a little time to decide what to order before we found ourselves at the cashier. The cashier was really friendly!

My friend ordered the Monte Cristo and I ordered the french toast and homefries to share. Our food took FOREVER to come, but I guess that made sense considering how many people they had to serve, but it seemed like people who got there after us were getting served before us. In terms of the food, the french toast was great but pretty average and the homefries were delicious but a little too oily. I am not a very big fan of ham but I managed to also really enjoy the Monte Cristo, and I would definitely recommend others to order the Monte Cristo. The presentation of the Monte Cristo is very very nice as well.

Overall, it was a nice restaurant, but I think the place is a bit overhyped other than the Monte Cristo. I would definitely come back here if the wait isn't too long!
author: Catherine S.

description: Did not live up to the yelp hype. Waited over an hour in line for mediocre food. French toast was average and the side of bacon was burnt. Serving was big. My husband tried the blackstone benedict and it was nothing to write home about.
author: Patricia H.

description: YOU NEED TO EAT HERE! This place is incredible! Came here on a Tuesday morning and there was definitely a line wrapped around the building but not as bad as I have seen in other reviews. We waited about 30-45 minutes to be seated but it was well worth the wait. The omelettes and French toast are beyond delicious, not to mention the fresh squeezed orange juiced! The staff is very friendly and the food is out of this world.
author: Rachael P.

description:
Waited in line for 2 hours for Sunday brunch, was it really worth the wait? Maybe once to try the food. I ordered the French Toast platter and my friend got the Monte Cristo. We both thought the food was really good, but definitely not worth the wait of 2 hours! 

The main reason why the wait is so terrible is because there is no proper system of how guests are seated. There is no sign in sheet so you have to wait the entire time around the block of the restaurant in a line, AND once you're inside, you're seated at any empty table. 

My friend and I noticed so many people sitting in a table for 5 or 6 with only a party of 2! And that was exactly how we were seated! 
I felt bad that we were using up a large table for just a party of two but I guess that's why the line is 2 hours! The party of 7 behind us had to wait an extra 30 minutes inside until a table opened up for them. 

I suggest coming on a weekday to try the food, not worth the long wait!
author: Jhankhana J.

description: DEFINITELY A LONG WAIT FOR SURE... BUT WORTH IT! The omelette I got is amazing! I got the NORTHWEST OMELETTE!!! SO GOOD!!! But the wait is usually 1 hour- 1 hour 30. After going once, probably won't go again because of the wait but it was really good! The homemade jam they have is actually pretty good! The waiters are super friendly and the place itself is nice.
author: Tiffany C.

description: It's a small restaurant. Long line but you order and pay before getting seated, so it moves fast. Ordered Dungeness Crab Benedict it was amazing and cranberry orange French toast.
author: Sara P.

description:
Have you ever waited two hours for brunch? Well, I have now! Mama's has a line starting right at 8 AM and it doesn't let up for pretty much the entire day. Arriving at 10 sticks you with about a two hour wait time--typical for all days of the week, according to the affable owner who greeted us at the front of the line. However, they do hand out water to guests in line!

After waiting in line, you're let inside to order and pay before being seated. It's a fairly small place, but they cram in a fair amount of people! This whole segmented ordering process is to assure that your food arrives quickly once you're seated, since you probably don't want to wait any longer after waiting outside. 

Now, the food! I'd recommend going with an egg dish because the plates my friends ordered seemed much more worth the cost. Any of the eggs Benedict dishes are a must, as their hollandaise is super flavorful; normally hollandaise doesn't taste like anything to me, but this hollandaise is ~special~.  My other friend got one of the special omelets and everything melted together inside beautifully. 

I got the French toast sampler which was well worth the opportunity to check out different types of French toast, but was definitely not filling. Luckily one of my friends eats like a bird so I helped her finish her omelet. The egg was cooked very well in the toast and the cinnamon one was especially good! Their syrup also isn't overly sweet. 

Overall, Mama's is a bit pricey, but if you order the right plates it's totally worth the wait! I'll probs update my review after having one of their egg dishes to myself~
author: Emiko K.

description:
2 hours wait. Hmm. Pricey too. But going to taste the food. If this blows everything else I have tasted so far, I'll give them 5 stars if not. We stay with the 3 star "okay" rating. 

Cinnamon chocolate toast , Washington  omellete, and scrambled florentine. 3 dish to try. Time to dig in!

#willUpdateInALaterTime

Update : 

This place is off the hook the food is extraordinary. I got some high standards when it comes to food, but this place hits all the mark. I suggest the foods that I wrote above and try them all. Anyways nothing I can say that has been said before. Just try it.

Just a few criticism. The water they serve is not filtered. The toast, that comes with the food theythey serve is not the best I have tasted, got other place that gave better toast, their french toast however is one of the best I tasted.
author: Francis S.

description:
As tourists in San Francisco, we arrived at 7:45 AM on a Thursday morning, hoping to start off our day early, and knowing that a wait was ahead. No kidding - when we arrived, there was already a significant lineup! We ended up waiting for about an hour, and were seated around 8:45 AM.

Probably one of the best breakfasts we had in San Francisco. We ordered a corned beef eggs benny (which I believe was a special that day), a Mama's M'omelette (the S.O.B., Spanish Chorizo, Black Beans, Homemade Salsa and Pepper Jack Cheese), and two teas. We also had bites of the french toast, and buttermilk pancakes, which our friends had ordered. Everything was perfectly cooked and an absolute delight - service was attentive, food was very hearty, heavy, and delicious. They also have the most amazing homemade jam on the tables, which you can use with your toast. If you're a tourist in San Francisco - brave the wait, it's worth it.

For two people, we spent $41.07, tip inclusive.
author: Barbara D.

description: Nothing better to do for breakfast in SF, be prepare to wait for 1-2 hrs, but believe me worth at the end, Omelets, Benedict Eggs, French Toats, attention, everything is fantastic!!!!!!
author: Yancomilanes ..

description: Hands down my favorite place for brunch. I've been a handful of times, yes there is a huge line with around an 1-2 hour waiting (depending on when you go) BUT it is so worth it! Their Monte Cristo has to be the best thing I've ever tasted. They have the best French toast too!! I've had their banana French toast and chocolate cinnamon, both phenomenal choices. Staff members always so welcoming and friendly. Mama's is a must when in the city!
author: Victoria K.

description:
The waiting in Line is merely part of the process, locals and patrons have been doing it since the 1950s. Mamas then was a burger, fries and shake/malt shop. Now it's a scrumptious breads, jams, breakfast and Lunch spot with amazing food and awesome customer service! We had the omelette and the French toast sampler and it did not disappoint. I would choose the Mimosas over their Bellinis. The location is a stride from the Coit Tower 
well worth the views. Cannot wait to return to this gem!
author: Dan M.

description:
I visit SF 2-3x a year. On every occasion, I have been able to do 3 things. 

1. Get a Salted caramel hot chocolate from Ghirardelli
2. Eat crab on the Wharf station #2 
3. Brunch at Mama's

Yes! I have stood in the 2-3 hour line to get the best damn monte cristo you will ever eat in your life. If you know anywhere else that can top their monte cristo please message me and let me know. 

If you're going to stand in a line for a place..... get what their known for! Not just what you get everywhere else. Here it's the Monte Cristo with the delicious jam! 

Other items:
Their crumb cakes are amazing, I favor the blueberry sour cream. 

Can't go wrong with their French toast as well. 

Drive by, check out the line and visit the Coit tower after eating here.
author: Rosalynn E.

description:
As we walked up to Mama's, we were introduced to a long line of hungry customers. We expected to wait in line, so it wasn't a huge deal. Food servers checked in on the line every so often, offering coffee (to purchase) and cups of water. Also, bring cash or a debit card. No credit cards are swiped at Mama's. 
Make sure to ask for a menu so you can study the options as you wait. As soon as you defeat the long line, you're expected to know what you want and order prior to being seated. We waited 45 or so minutes outside. 
Now onto the food (the reason people wait down the block!) As you wait to be seated inside, fresh baked coffee cakes, carrot cakes, and apple crisp stare at you with an "I dare you not to order me to go" look. We ordered one of each, and I definitely encourage everyone to do the same. 
Once seated, I ordered the Petaluma Eggs breakfast, cooked to my choice with potatoes and bacon. I also had to try Mama's pancakes and a fresh squeezed OJ. 
Bottom line: I loved the environment. I loved the options. I may have ordered wrong, as we overheard people saying the monte cristo sandwich is the way to go. The eggs were good, the potatoes were good, the bacon was a bit cold, and the pancakes weren't anything over the top. It was a solid breakfast, but I expected to be "wowed." 
Everyone should try it. It's a fun place to eat.
author: Mark W.

description:
Oh Dear Neptune, where have I been all my life? I freaking loved this place! Please be advised - CASH OR DEBIT ONLY!!! Also be advised - WAIT CAN EXCEED 2+ HOURS!!!

My friend and I came around at 10:30am on a rainy day. We thought "oh it's raining and it's cold and it's windy, no one would want to get out of the comfort of their bed and wait in line for this". WRONG. Everyone was carrying umbrellas in the line and we didn't get our food until almost 12:40pm. 

At this point, you may be wondering "well, is the wait worth it?". If you have never been here ~ then yes! If you have, then it's debatable. The food is really really good, and I think waiting under a hour is so worth it. But when the wait is 2-3 hours, my stomach starts complaining. And when it complains, I start losing patience.
On to the food!

We ordered the French Toast sampler (which consists of a bananna, cinnamon raisin and cranberry bread French Toast topped with bananas and strawberries). The toasts themselves are already super sweet, so I didn't add the maple syrup. We also ordered the dungeness crab egg benedict with the spinach, with a side of potatoes. 
Overall, the food was a little on the heavy side. We also got a glass of hot chocolate. Perfect for rainy and cold weather, yumm! 

The food, service, and ambience here are all a definite 5/5 for me. The downside is the ridiculous wait and no parking.
author: Xin W.

description: First time in San Francisco, and my girlfriend and I, who are big brunch fans, decided to try this place out. After waiting about 2 hours (got there just before noon, seated a little before 2pm), we ordered a large fresh pressed orange juice, a vegetarian eggs Benedict, and the cinnamon chocolate French toast. The Eggs Benedict were on the bland side, and the potatoes they came with were undercooked and starchy. The cinnamon chocolate French toast, while a generous portion, was pretty standard, and topped with a chocolate sauce drizzle and fresh fruits (banana, strawberries, and blueberries) Note: chocolate sauce drizzle looked and tasted like Hershey's syrup rather than something homemade, I recommend ordering a side of the raspberry sauce, as it improved the toast substantially. Price was reasonable, and service was pleasant. However, for a 2 hour wait, the food can simply be described as standard. Nothing about the food was memorable, and there are far better brunch spots around town.
author: Michael O.

description: So worth the wait!!! Amazing carrot cake and breakfast is just on point! I've been here several times and every time try something different and everything is delicious!!
author: Peggy A.

description: Long wait, expensive, but great coffee. The breakfast food is pretty good but I can make it for 1/5 of the cost of the order, but I guess when the median price of a house in SF is 1M, what's a $30 breakfast
author: Danny G.

description:
This was the only real breakfast joint I ate at the whole time I stayed in sf. What can I say other then when you show up the line shows it all. I can see why now when I ordered my very first famous monte cristo. I don't think I've ever had anything like this before its so good!

I would describe it as a French toast enclosed with cheese turkey and ham. Reminds me of a ham and cheese crossaint just without the crossaint it's been substituted with a three layer French toast. 

The first bite I took blew me away I dipped it with their homemade strawberry jam sure hit the spot. 

Wish I came here earlier than on the day I was going back home  well now I know the hype is foreal 

I recommend coming 30 mins before this place opens and start forming the line because this place will be lined up with people waiting 30-20 min before it opens. It is well worth it though. You can also enjoy watching older Chinese women performing a synchronized tai chi exercise across the street.
author: Keniff K.

description: Long long wait over two hours to get inside cute small restaurant very family oriented so much tradition and love the authentic and food from scratch delicious it's a bummer you wait so long but it's a must experience walking distance from my hotel ordered breakfast and lunch excellent .
author: Paula B.

description: Get there early! Wonderful food and atmosphere. If you like stepping outside the chain restaurants, this is for you.
author: Ben V.

description: Be prepared to wait in line a while here, even on weekdays at what might seem like an odd time - this place is always packed, and for good reason. There aren't a lot of tables inside, so the line goes out the door. An employee will poke their head out to ask you how many are in your party and will tell you when you can come in. Once inside, you order at the register and sit down and wait until your food is ready. I ordered the cinnamon chocolate French toast. It was topped with bananas, strawberries and blueberries and finished off with drizzled chocolate on top. I'm not a big breakfast person but I could literally eat that every day. They give you syrup on the side, but you honestly don't need it. The portion was large, I didn't finish it all. They only take cash so be prepared for that. If you don't have anywhere to be on any given day, come here for breakfast but plan on waiting up to 30 minutes or so.
author: Kathleen L.

description:
Mama's is definitely worth the hype - scrumptious breakfasts and reasonable prices given the huge portions. The coffee cake is certifiably delicious, and you can't go wrong with standard breakfast items like eggs benedict or a super-sized omelet. Service is decent, with a slight twist in that you have to wait in line inside to place your order on top of having already waited anywhere from half an hour (if you show up before opening) to two outside. 

Indeed, I suspect that Mama's popularity feeds upon itself. It's such a "must do" thing for both tourists and locals that you get lulled into thinking that "if it's soooo popular with everyone, then it must be fantabulous." Moreover, having waited for an hour or two outside, most folks are going to be soooo hungry by the time they sit down that anything's going to taste great.

Don't get me wrong. I'm not a hater. I quite enjoyed the food here. But for me, the whole experience would be much better if the space was larger and the waits less insane. Indeed, that's apparently the plan. If so, I look forward to coming back more often, thereby helping Mama's see continued, if not even greater, success in the future.
author: Vincent L.

description:
Excellent food.
Opens at 8. Arrived at 7:10. 15th in line. By 8a, the line was up the block. 
Bay shrimp omelet and Dungeness crab omelet were absolutely fantastic. 
Wish I could have weighed the crab in there. It was stuffed. 
The French toast sampler was great.
Would have been awesome if we had delayed it so it was hot when we ate it.
If you can get there by 7/710, well worth the wait.
author: Allen R.

description:
YAAAAAAS. So much yaaaaas. I LOVE this brunch spot. It is simply amazing. I'm just gonna tell you now, the line is worth the wait. This is where the famous line comes in, "PATIENCE IS A VIRTUE" !!! 

Parking- So, parking here is ridiculous. It took us 35 minutes to find a parking spot. There is a bunch of parking meters, you just need to find an open spot! :/

Wait time- It's about a 30 min - 2hr wait depending on what time you get there and how many are in your party. Obviously you wanna get there before it opens, but if it's not possible, don't worry, it's not that bad! Like I said, "Patience is a Virtue". 

When you finally get to the front of the line, the host asks how many are in your party and then lets you in. You stand in a line to order your food, and while you're standing in line there are a bunch of pastries and bread behind the glass. Makes you just wanna try EVERYTHING!! I tried the carrot cake. It sure was yummy!

We were very excited to try our food. I ordered the Monte Cristo and my boyfriend got the French Toast Sampler. HOLY COW. Sure enough, it was great. I wish the serving amount for the Monte Cristo was a little bit bigger though! That's how good it was. It made me want more  lol 
Anyway, the French Toast sampler was yummy as well. I loved the different types of toasts. (Blueberries, Strawberries, etc). The home-made peach jam and syrups were delicious as well. 

I will definitely be back!
author: Kristenne A.

description: such good food!! The line was a little long, but to be fair it was wrapped all the way around the building! We waited around 45 minutes, once we were finally inside it only took around another 10 to be sat / receive our food. Keep in mind this is on a Saturday, so i'm sure the wait would be shorter on the weekend. The restaurant provides a host at the front of the door permitting a few people in at a time when others leave, and describing the menu choices in extreme detail. I don't have enough good things to say about this place!
author: Emily L.

description: For us, it was worth the hype. We got there at about 7:35 & were 3rd in line on a Wednesday morning- so we got in with the first group. Cute little place, great breakfast! We had Mama's breakfast sandwich & the French toast sampler- both were delicious. By the time we left, the line was up the block. It's not a huge place- but it's a well oiled machine. Try it!
author: Cathy W.

description:
Good brunch food, but dude it's not worth the wait. If you've never had brunch before, then I guess you can wait and try this place. We came on a Friday around 10:30am and waited about an hour before we were allowed into the hizzhouse! After you're in, you line up again to order food and then the staff seat you. The portions were huge and the food was good, but don't waste your vacation time lining up. 

Also, another poster mentioned the cashier works in slow motion. This is true, she reminds me of the DMV sloth in Zootopia.
author: Roll N.

description: Everything we ate we loved! We waited an hour and would do it again. We had the Monte Cristo which honestly was the best version of that sandwich I'd ever had, the crab Benedict which was just as outstanding and the French toast! They bake the bread they use for the French toast daily and it works! Try Mamas you won't be disappointed!
author: Ian B.

description: The wait isn't too bad even if the line looks long. Pretty good food and cutest place. Would def go again.
author: Roma K.

description:
Been this place b/c of I saw ppl
Always wait there since that place is very small not enough room to seat ppl. I pick a weekday instead of a weekend day, however it still a long line. I did some research about this place, from the picture the most attract me is their toast, it looks very delicious. After 1 hour wait I get into the inside, very small, looks like you stay a very old days home, which make you feel warm, anyway it makes me feel like I'm missing my grandma. I order their toast, and a porch egg. I really really like their toast, for the egg it's ok. I prefer scramble better than other style. If you guys came to SF, this is one of the breakfast place for you to try if you don't mind wait in the line.
author: Yueming G.

description: Brunch is a must when my friends and I are in town and wanting to catch up. We arrived at around 10:30 on a Wednesday, thinking the line might be shorter since it was a weekday, but even then, there was a good wait just to get inside. The wait took around an hour, and by then, we were all starving and couldn't wait to get inside and order. We ordered our dishes and paid before we were seated. I got the vegetarian omelette which came with toast (your choice of bread) and potatoes and an orange juice, which they all tasted really good, especially the potatoes because I'm a huge potato fan. The portions were a good size, and I definitely left full and satisfied.
author: Lisa C.

description:
This little hidden (not really) is located at the corner of Washington square and is not too hard to spot. Easy to get to once you walk your dog or go for a run at the park. One thing about this location is the wait... It's at least an hour long... So be prepared to wait.

Parking wise around there I'm guessing would be horrible. Luckily I took the bus over. Small short and easy walk to the place from Columbus.

Mocha comes in one of those tall and skinny glass which masks really how much coffee there really is. Taste wise, it is pretty decent. Nice aroma with a robust flavor of coffee with a nice kick of chocolate too it. The cream makes a nice addition as it softens the whole thing. Small little deco to top it off.

Now for the main course... The Monte Cristo! Nice decoration. It better taste better than it looks... And it does! You got the choice to either eat your sandwich sweet or salty. What I gotta say is the berry jam addition to give you the choice is a great idea. If the sandwich at any point becomes bland, you can just dip it in the jam and it just creates an alternate flavor that is pretty good to the palate. In itself the sandwich is just one big sandwich cut into 4 triangles and battered French toast style but yeah, if it does get bland to eat it plain, just dip it! Additionally, the potatoes were made right as the outside was nice and crunchy and the inside was still golden soft. 

Addition of the strawberry and oranges makes a good exclamation point to end the breakfast/brunch. 

Service was pretty decent and food comes pretty fast. The staff tries to get you seated asap and makes sure to try to accommodate.

Overall I would give this place a 4.5/5 stars (wait and parking not included into consideration as this would bring the rating down to may be 3 stars). Food and service is good and very tasty. Now, I'll be looking forward to the next visit. Time for you guys to come and try it! Bonne appetite!
author: Roger P.

description:
Short review: Past it's heyday. Long lines and mediocre food. Only saving grace is the wonderful staff.

Long Review: If you need two hours to listen to a friend talk about her breakup with a married man (I apologize to the So Cal folks behind me) this is an awesome place. However if you are waiting in line in anticipation of amazing, mind blowing, taste bud tingling food...you will be sorely disappointed.

The french toast sampler was down right disappointing: Clumsy pieces of dense bread lightly doused in a batter. Textually  unappealing and void of any flavor save the fruit on top.

The eggs Benedict were slightly better but the muffin was as stale as  the latest Saturday night live skits. Eggs were good but the rest meh.

Mama's potatoes were good, as was the bacon and sausage. If you can't get these right you should not be in biz!

Pancakes were average.

My personal suggestion is to leave this place to the tourists that flock to it and head down the street to the Park Tavern  for a lovely brunch with no wait!!!
author: David G.

description: I live a block from here, so I went to check it out one day. I walk by all the time and there's always a ridiculous line outside. But I went on a Saturday at 2 PM (their brunch ends at 3PM), so I didn't have to wait too long, maybe 20-30 minutes. My friend ordered french toast and I had the benedict. Tasty, but just regular brunch, not mind-blowing. Not worth hours of waiting (is anything ever worth that? lol). We also had brunch drinks, which is pretty standard although they tried to be creative with it - white wine with lemonade (my friend didn't like it, but I thought it was decent). Our cashier gave us more french toast complimentary to welcome us to SF, since we both just relocated here. Friendly, but slow service. It was also a little frustrating how you have to stand in line to order, wait and then get seated and wait some more for your food to come out. And when you're waiting outside, you see several empty tables inside and it's like, why aren't they seating more people? They are creating a line on purpose. I hate that. Or maybe just slow and inefficient operation. Decent food, but not worth the hype. I think this is the situation with most places with long waits, though!
author: Marie D.

description: 1 word: PANCETTA. Northern Italian. Nothing else will blow your taste buds than than the pancetta. I wish I had more pancetta in it. Long wait but worth every minute. They will take your drink orders while youre in line. Listen to the host at the door. He gives great recommendations.
author: january l.

description: I didn't realize that waiting outside in the sun for an hour could be so filling. But this restaurant has really figured out how humans can use photosynthesis to fill up while waiting for animal food. After you've gotten your fill on light, you then walk inside and have to somehow make room for French toast and brunch food, which is difficult because you have so much adenosine triphosphate running through your system from all the chemical light energy. Truly a miracle was performed here. Their French toast is good.
author: Parker K.

description: As soon as we land in SF we had to come check this place out. We waited about an hour in line, and lets say it was well worth the wait. I ordered the Famous Monte Cristo and boy was I surprised. It was perfectly grilled and the flavor was off the roof. I had to go back to get some more of it before we left SF. I recommend this to anybody and everybody!
author: Dima K.

description: Arrived 50 minutes before the place opened, was the 9th person in line. By 7:30 there was atleast 30 people in line, which happens to look like the max capacity of this tiny restaurant. No credit cards accepted so bring cash before you wait in the long line. Don't be surprised when other people save a spot in line for a large party or get inside before anyone else who waited in line does because they have connections. I got one of the specials (listed on the window)Mama's sampler french toast: lemon berry,  cranberry orange walnut, and Swedish cinnamon topped with berries and bananas for $14.50. It was nothing out of this world, the wait wasn't worth it for me, unless you're into that sort of thing. I have yet to find a restaurant that is worth waiting in line for. Overall good but not worth it.
author: Ana + Eric D.

description: I love this place. There are so many dishes I want to try but to this day I always crave the monte cristo (I was last there 5 years ago!) It's perfection in every way. Booking my SF trip soon just to get my fix!
author: Samantha S.

description: The line/wait was worth it! Had the French toast sampler and the pancetta eggs Benedict. So delicious. The staff was great! It's a small cozy restaurant that makes you feel right at home
author: Kara S.

description: We got into the line outside around 10am and didn't get into the restaurant till about 11-11:15 to order our food on the inside line. The staff was very nice when we ordered our food, but we still had to wait a bit to get seated, but kind of expected that. After being seated, we got our food after about 10-15 mins or so. I got the Chocolate Cinnamon French Toast with a side of eggs and sausage and while the food was good, I would say personally not spectacular and definitely not worth the long wait. Definitely try it, but not some place I would stay and wait for.
author: Peter M.

description: Everything was great from the service up front, to ordering your food, and the wait staff. Everything we had there was delicious and very fresh! We will be back next trip!
author: Ashley W.

description:
Is the food good? why YES.  Is it worth 1hr wait? possibly.   Is it worth 1hr+ wait? Not quite.  

We tried the dungeness crab Benedict AND omelet and wow just PACKED with crab meat.  it was awesome.  My wife and i have had WAY better benedicts.  I say this because the sauce wasnt the best and bread was already soggy.  I shall be honest, but it tasted like an ihop Benedict packed with quality crab.  Same goes for the omelet.  

Try it at least once yes.  But never wait more than an hour.  SF has so many places to offer that an hour wasted waiting could be spent better somewhere else.

Happy eating!
author: Jordan J.

description:
Mama's has the best breakfast food in North Beach hands down. They have many versions of eggs benedict including a daily special or two. Today we had the spanish chorizo benedict with salsa and avocado. The poached eggs were perfectly cooked and sat on tortillas. The chorizo was spicy and just perfect with the hollandaise. The potatoes are wonderful as well. 

Typically there is a line running down the block and I was looking forward to playing pokemon go in the square while "we" waited in line. Today, we got right in and were only about third in line. Amazing!!! I would have loved to get in a couple laps around the square... Maybe next time.

NOTE: It is cash only and it's not cheap. We spent $40 plus tip on two benedicts, one coffee and a latte but so worth it!
author: Suzanne W.

description:
I arrived at 8:10AM on a Tuesday and waited about 15 minutes before the "bouncer" allowed me to enter and join the line inside the establishment.  The baked goods looked amazing but given the carbtastic nature of the Monte Cristo sandwich, I reined myself in to focus on the main objective, sandwich and a side of grilled potatoes.

Grilled Potatoes
Mediocre. It was a little dry but they're just potatoes.  No one cares.

Monte Cristo
I went for the version with gruyere since it's a better melting cheese (often used in quiche and fondue).  To my surprise, compared to my childhood memory of the Monte Cristo at Bennigans, Mama's version is less greasy. This is definitely a plus for my waistline!  The sandwich was dipped in an egg batter and pan fried.  It reminded me of a triple layered french toast with ham and cheese.  However, after digging into it, it's was just that--simply a french toast with a thin slice of gruyere, cheddar and ham. I expect the cheese within a Monte Cristo to be melted but it was clearly not the case at Mama's.  While the presentation with homemade jam, 3 slices of oranges dotted with a strawberry half, dusted with powdered sugar was pleasant to the eye, it was poorly executed.  

Verdict
The Monte Cristo fell short of expectations.  I left filled with food envy since the omelettes looked a lot better.  Because amazing loaded omelettes are ubiquitous in the SF brunch scene, I would not wait over 30 minutes in line at Mama's for it. 

Lastly, Comments on Operations
The line outside feels artificial when nearly all the tables inside were empty upon my arrival.  It is entirely the result of an inefficient ordering process.  The line goes directly to a single cashier and she moves in slo-mo, pausing about 3-5 minutes between each order to direct the kitchen and wait staff and assign tables.  The queue was not terrible for me but the bottleneck can be intense if you are stuck behind a lot of indecisive diners.
author: Amy J.

description: Perfect spot for breakfast!! Found this place on Yelp and noticed pictures of long lines so we went early at opening. No lines but I guess it was because we went on a weekday while everyone is working. You order first then you find a table to sit at. I felt the food took long being that it wasn't busy and we were the second group to order food.  Fresh squeeze Orange was really good and not fake at all. My boyfriend and I both enjoyed our food but we both said it was over priced. We each both got a small OJ and we both got a meal. With tip we dished out about $50. Yes, that's only for 2 adults and we didn't order any sides or extra food.  Overall food was good but expensive
author: Shelley K.

description:
Food - 3 stars
Service-??? Where is the service? 0.5 stars for servers 
Venue- 1 star
As another yelper stated a few min ago the bathroom is appalling and for the patrons to squeeze past the cooks is gross and unsanitary. They keep their doors locked so you can't get in to loot their food . Odd antics like these warrant Michelin star rated food, which of course isn't the case.
The food:
The chocolate crumb cake - yum
Northwest omelette - good
Bay Area shrimp and avocado eggs Benedict- pathetic, bland and poorly executed.
author: Sameet S.

description: It's worth the wait!  Our time was only 30 minutes.  Fresh oj was great.  The raspberry preserves are tasty on the sourdough toast (next time I'm getting the mama cristo).  My partner loved the French toast
author: Just K.

description: At first when you see the line which is pretty long it's kinda scary but isn't that a good sign? Meaning this place it worth waiting for? let me tell you def worth the waiting for. the food down to the services was amazing I ordered the Swedish French toast And OMG melts you you're mouth! Also we order the Northern Californian omelette. This is a place is a must go breakfast spot!
author: Sarah P.

description:
Is it worth it?  The answer to that question depends how long you are willing to wait and how hungry you are.  The food is your typical egg omelet, scrambles, and various other American style breakfast that you can think of with a hint of creativity behind each plate.  

We came on a Sunday morning before heading back to Los Angeles, and there was a small line, but because the restaurant is small, seating is extremely limited.  I ended up having to wait 45 mins while running back to my car to put coins in for parking. 

While in line, we admired the many food awards that had been bestowed on the restaurant.  Ordered two egg omelettes and pancakes with fresh fruit on top, and oh my god did the food look beautiful and delicious when it came.  Each bite into the egg was just full of flavor and I was overwhelmed with each lingering bite.  

So would I come back here again? I probably would depending on the wait and how parking is.  But if you never tried this place, definitely give it a shot, portions are huge and your belly will pleased!
author: David L.

description:
I risked getting a parking ticket just to eat here (2 hour parking). The wait was about 1.5 hours. It was cold outside, but there was a waitress that came out and asked people if they wanted to order coffee/beverages. When you finally get inside the door, there is another line where you order and pay for your food before being seated. 

Thankfully, the food came out quickly. My friend and I shared the Monte Cristo and Dungeness Crab Benedict ($$$). Both came with a side of potatoes. The food was good, but I wouldn't say it was memorable. I'm glad I crossed this place off my bookmarks, but I would not wait in such a long line to eat here again.
author: Helen H.

description: What can I say, the food is delicious and it is worth waiting in line. The Monte Cristo Sandwich is my first vote with Shrimp Benedict being my second choice.
author: Martin S.

description: We asked for a table for 5 but got a table for 4 and the 5th had to seat in a narrow place between our table ant the neighbor's without any room to pass between them. We ordered pancake which was good and eggs Benedict which were not tasty at all. I will not go there again.
author: Maya C.

description:
HEADS UP!! No groups larger than 4 otherwise you way extend your wait time!! And there is always a wait line. Got there 40 min prior to opening and was still seated in second wave of diners. 
Excellent food worth the wait, ask what breads are special today not always listed.  
Northern Italian omelette is the bomb, better than Washington Square omelette
author: Angela C.

description:
Lined up at 9am and waited 2 hours just to be able to order our food. Perhaps this is one of their marketing strategies to get the customers hungry so any food that enters into their mouth will taste good. 

I like to order Eggs Benedict from all the brunch spots I visit for the first time. Was it worth the two hour wait? Sadly, not. The eggs were cold by the time it was served and the quality was similar to a typical diner. 

I was also turned off by the uncleanliness & service of the place. I saw fruit flies buzzing around the fruits while I was lining up to place my order. The cashier only accepted cash and the service was very slow.

The Monte Cristo seems like what they're known for. Perhaps I will try this on my next visit just so I have the "true Mama's experience" but if the wait is more than an hour long, I'll pass.
author: Linda K.

description:
The only drawback is the wait...if you can be patient, you will be rewarded.

The Monte Cristo is all that...it lives up to the hype...it truly does.  The crab cake Benedict is realllllly good as well...chaser it down down with a latte why don't ya?!

Wanted to get some of the carrot cake to go, but the first 25 patrons scarfed down the whole lot...took some crumb cake instead...some day I'll get some of that carrot cake (no raisins in the carrot cake here...there's no reason to ever put raisins in carrot cake).

Worked off my breakfast by joining the Chinese ladies for a sidewalk dance across the way in Washington Square afterward.
author: C S.

description:
Don't tell anyone, but I've figured out Mama's secret to financial success!  After a 1.5-2 hour wait in line, customers are soo hungry that they end up ordering TWICE the amount of food they would normally.  Or is it just us?   

4 out of 5 stars due to long wait and a few "non outstanding" food items.  

Today was another crazy long wait in line for Mama's deliciousness!  We clocked in just under two hours before making it to the register to order our brunch.  Hubby and I had the Californian omelet (eggs, thick bacon, avocado and Monterey jack cheese).  Hands down, BEST omelet either of us have tasted!
