Then after another forever, the friends that just woke up started to join their friends at the front of the line, adding another 30minute to the wait. Finally at 1PM, we find ourselves seated in a nice and cozy restaurant. 

The food:
-crab benedict
-french toast sampler
-mama's benedict

I was beyond starved and tired from the wait. But even under those circumstances, I can still consciously say that it was just Aiitezzz. Too hyped. Probably from tourists (like me). This is just a decent brunch place with standard breakfast foods. I'd say the most rewarding thing that I had there that was surprisingly good was their homemade jam. That really set them apart from other jams I've tried. Everything else was just decent. Maybe I'd give their french toast brownie points but other than that, nothing else was that phenomenal. 


Don't think I'd wait another 3 hours for this place. Not unless I happen to be here super early where there's not much of a wait, otherwise, been there done that. 

Check out my pics :  )
author: Josie C.

description:
On our weekend trip to SF, we stopped by Mama's for brunch. We got there around 830am on Saturday and waited about 45 minutes to order. 

We ordered the Crab Benedict, North Beach Benedict, Chocolate Crumb Cake, Bacon, and a Bloody Mary. The North Beach Benedict was amazing. I would definitely come back just for this. The crumb cake was very good as well. The Crab Benedict was good but nothing to rave about. And the Bloody Mary was so spicy, we couldn't really finish it. But overall, very good brunch and next time we are back in SF, we will definitely be back!
author: Kayla B.

description: This is an amazing place for Breakfast, really large portions and wonderful friendly staff. They have a good selection of sweet and savoury breakfast meal options. My only issue was the lack of space, which lead to relatively large wait times for a table. Get here early to get a good seat. We had the stuffed omelettes which was served with choice of toast and hash. Definitely a must visit place in the bay area.
author: Varun C.

description:
I came here last Saturday when most of the kiddies were on spring break. The owner says that it'll probably die down after the week. The food looks wonderful and tastes just as good as it looks, but the major downside is that you have to wait FOREVER! I don't think it's worth the 2.5 hours I waited on that Saturday morning. We arrived at 10:30am and didn't get seated until 1:00PM.

We were starving by then and the once the food got to our table, we didn't really get to enjoy it because we gobbled it all up in minutes. There are only 8 tables inside the restaurant. I'd say you should only go if you're the first one there when it opens, otherwise..there are plenty of other places such as Tony's Pizzeria right across the street.

We ordered the monte cristo, crab benedict, banana pancakes, and french toast sampler. My favorite of the french toast was cinnamon, if I ever do come back here again, I'd get a plate of cinnamon french toast. The monte cristo was delicious, it's like a sealed french toast sandwich with ham and turkey. The homemade jam is very yummy too. The crab benedict was okay, but that's because I'm not into hollandaise sauce and there simply is not enough crab for me. If you like that kind of thing, go for it! It's also a bit pricey. The banana pancakes though YUM, every bite was SO flavorful. I think I'll just call ahead for a to go order next time of banana pancakes to eat while I'm walking to Fisherman's Wharf. That's the way to do it! :D

I'd suggest not to come if you have to wait over an hour..which is most likely what'll happen, especially on a weekend!
author: Angelina L.

description:
My boyfriend and I woke up early and were in line 20 minutes before they opened. Luckily, we were seated in the first wave of people. Was it worth the wait? DEFINITELY! My boyfriend used to go to grade school at St. Peter's and Paul and has always known of this restaurant because of the lines and it was finally his first time trying it.

I ordered the Norwegian Benedict, which is smoked salmon, the eggs benedict, and hollandaise sauce. It also came with some potatoes and a sliced orange. OMG. My mouth and tummy was so happy! I really liked that the hollandaise sauce had a kick of spice to it with either cayenne pepper or pepprika. 

My boyfriend ordered the Blackstone Benedict, which has bacon and a tomato. He really liked the bacon and said it was well cooked and crispy. 

The English muffin might have been made with sour dough because you could taste it! Not sure if it is homemade or storebought but it was good.

I wish we ordered some toast because I wanted to spread the strawberry jam on something!! BE SURE TO TRY THE JAM THOUGH! IT'S THE BOMB!
author: Cathie N.

description:
For the first time in a real LONG time I decided to wait one hour to eat at Mama's cause everyone is so crazy about it.

Well the food is very good so can't complain, but don't think is worth the wait. 

I had Mama's Breakfast Sandwich out from the Special Menu and it was VERY GOOD. Nevertheless, the French toast sampler was not at all my favorite.

Don't think I'll come back because of the line but it's a nice spot to visit and eat.
author: Leslie C.

description:
I've tried to come to Mama's on off-days/hours, but there is always a line, so my friend and I decided to experience the authentic Mama's wait. We came at 12:30PM on a Sunday and waited 2 hours to get in. The line is a standing line only (no texting/waitlist), so you should come with someone you're comfortable talking to for 2 hours.

While the food at Mama's is by no means bad, it is not as good or innovative as most other brunch spots in San Francisco. I do appreciate the emphasis on home-cooked, comforting food, but not enough that I would say it's worth the wait. The setup inside is a bit confusing because you order at the counter and then sit down, and I'm surprised they're able to manage the tables/crowd control inside.

- Monte Cristo ($11.95): I guess I've never had a monte cristo in general before, but I really liked the texture here. The toast was very fluffy and did not overpower the thin ham and cheese in between. This was a unique experience, and the better dish of the two.

- French Toast Sampler ($11.25): This comes with a slice each of the Cranberry-Orange, Banana Walnut, and one other that did not have much distinctive flavor. I enjoyed the Cranberry-Orange best. The toast really is nothing very special (the ingredients are all pre-made into the bread, which is on display in the glass case when you order), and I don't think it's any better than a toast I could make at home.

Despite mediocre food, the raspberry jam that is at every table is fantastic. I was bathing my french toast in that stuff. Come for the novelty sake once, but this is definitely not a regular ritual for me.
author: Jessica F.

description:
OMG the place has such a ridiculously long line and such a tiny space.  I think we waited for an hour or so to eat here.

They should really consider handing us samples for waiting our asses here so long and being so freaking dedicated.  There was actually a tour going by showing us off.  Weird..

First, wait in line.  Then you wait in another line inside to order your food.  Usually that takes about 10 mins.  Pay.  Finally, you find a seat and sit your ass down.  They will bring you your food. 

Homemade jam: Oh dear lord....I can bath in this stuff...You have to buy toast so you can lather that baby with jam.  It is a must.
Dungeness Crab Benedict: The crab is super fresh here. The sauce is super creamy.  
Dungeness Crab Breakfast Sandwiches: This is absolutely mind-blowing.  I can't even describe it.  

If you got time to kill or you're a super early bird, I highly recommend you come here.  The line is the only downfall/obstacle you need to conquer to have an amazing brunch.  Or you can just order take-out....I should have done that...
author: Jackie N.

description:
Let me tell you what to order:

Savory: Monte Cristo (either the Our famous or Mama's version, i personally like the our famous more), potatoes are great and the monte cristo are delicious with the jam.

sweet: French Toast Sampler, comes with their variety of bread choices for the day with syrup.

rich and savory: Dungeness crab eggs benedict, sort of expensive but very good.
author: Dylan T.

description: We waited for about an hour and a half on a Saturday afternoon. It's definitely worth the wait. I'm not usually big on breakfast and can care less to skip it or replace breakfast foods with something else... But this place is one not to miss. Holladaise sauce on Dungeoness crab egg Benedict was amazing. I usually don't like benedicts. French toast sampler is a MUST. Each toast was different. One had cranberries, one had blueberries, one was like a banana bread. Monte Cristo was delicious. So was the smoked salmon scrambler! Ugh. I was so full and couldn't stop but to eat myself into a coma. I don't regret it. I'd do it all over again!
author: Trish T.

description: Delish! We had the veggie eggs Benedict and the prosciutto eggs Benedict. Great way to start the day
author: Jay S.

description:
I live right around the corner, and had been wanting to try Mama's but had consistently been intimidated by the long lines. I finally got a chance to go one weekday about an hour before they closed, and because it was later in the day, I was able to order and be seated in about half an hour.

The waiters and servers were friendly, and service was fast - which I appreciate. I ordered their Monte Cristo, a cappuccino, and fresh orange juice. The OJ was nice and fresh, cappuccino was good, and the Monte Cristo was good...but nothing to really write home about. I wasn't too disappointed given that I didn't have to wait that long to get my food, but if I had been made to wait in line over an hour, I would have been disappointed. 

Maybe their other menu items might be better...? I'm willing to try some of their other dishes if a visitor from out of town wants to go to Mama's, but otherwise I don't think I'll be back. I think there are better brunch options in the city.
author: Anna H.

description:
It's good breakfast fare.  Nothing particularly amazing, but nothing particularly bad either.  Not entirely sure why there is such a line for this restaurant during brunch hours, as their food and service quality, which fine, isn't spectacular.  It's just....  good.

But hey, if you want to do the line thing, go ahead.  No judgements.  Especially not from me, as I watch you while eating delicious pancakes across the street that I waited 10 mins for.
author: Michael D.

description: 4 stars because the food was really great. -1 star for the price & long wait. for as much money as they're making they should buy some outdoor seating. the food was good though. i added a hot chocolate which was delicious. for the meal i had the smoked salmon omelette (served open faced). not the best meal i've ever had but a pretty good one. wish there were more ingredients on my dish. the potatoes were delicious. my friend had crab cakes egg benedict - she wasn't impressed. the biscuit was overcooked and so was the egg which kind of ruined it for her.
author: Christian C.

description:
Best. Breakfast. Ive. Ever. Had.

Yes. I had to wait in line. Worth it. 

All the staff was so friendly and my food came out super quick.

I'd go back in a heartbeat.
author: Cody F.

description: I've been living in SF for a while and I've always seen a huge line in front, and with that said I never even wanted to try this place. Today, on Wednesday at 1:30 there was no wait and I was seated promptly in a 3/4 full restaurant. Service was friendly and I paid by card, so I wouldn't say it's cash only. I had crab cake benedict and it was just alright, not really worth 23$ but since it was in "Specials" I gave it a try. Coffee is strong and the waitress (younger Asian lady) kept if full.
author: Milica B.

description:
Today was really cool!  The 2 hour wait was well worth it!!  The pancakes are the best. Ever. Period. They are like clouds, and they burst with flair.  I didn't even need the syrup or berries.

We got to talking with the door man, and he explained how they are made.  He said the key (besides the family recipe) is that the batter is made in small batches, and that the dry ingredients are not mixed in until the last minute.  Pretty cool of him to explain it, and it explained why they taste unlike any pancake you will ever have.

The Monte Cristo is really good too.
author: Keke S.

description:
Crab Cake Eggs Benedict and Monte Cristo are my favorite! Yummy, yummy, yummy!
Usually need to wait for an hour before being served. I would recommend go there early before it opens or late before it closes. They may continue to service customers even after its normal hours, just make sure to arrive before 3 PM.
author: Poon D.

description:
Came to SF for an interview from east coast and was running with jet lag. Thus was able to get up at 6am western time (9 am ET) and get to Mama's by 7:30 in order to avoid the line. Otherwise I think I would've had to wait some ridiculous hour and half for this. 

Tried shrimp eggs benedict. Best. eggs. benedict. ever. The egg was cooked just right so some yolk oozed out. It was just delicious and for a grand 30 minutes I was in pure food heaven. 

Made me want to move to SF just for this.
author: Amy X.

description:
Call me crazy, I'm not impressed. 

To start, the website says cash only but they do accept debit. 

You walk into the restaurant, there is no one at the door, which I don't necessarily care about, but it would have been nice to informed that you stand in line first to order and then seat yourself. Again, not a huge deal, but there wasn't a sign either. 

I'm short, so I couldn't see most of the menu which is posted on the walls next to the cash register and above the grills. The specials sign is written in tiny chalk letters that you can't see until you get to the cash register, which holds up the line. 

I ordered a coffee ($2.75), an apple crumble pastry, and and the vegetarian omelet. When I received the coffee, there was no half and half and the coffee was burnt. Or it was probably maxwell house, which has the same horrible flavor. It comes in a tiny mug, which bothered me at first because you can get a cheaper black, drip coffee from most chains.  The omelet came with tons of cheese though I specified for a small amount. The egg omelet portion was dry. The potatoes that came with the dish were too oily. 

The best part about the meal was the apple crumble --which was absolutely delightful-- and the multigrain toast that undoubtedly came from a package. 

And probably the orange slice garnish. 

I think this place does sweet pretty well, but needs a little more assistance with the savory. Altogether, it was definitively "meh."
author: Jane C.

description:
With just 3 days in San Francisco, I was determined to make the most of this short trip and Mama's made the list.  We took advantaged that we were still on east coast time and woke up at like 6:30AM, showered and out the door by 7:15AM.  We got in line around 7:30AM with just a few people ahead of us.  

The doors opened promptly at 8AM and we were the last ones in before they cut the line off.  The restaurant is so small with no more than probably 20 seats, that they constantly have a line outside. 

The fiancé and I seriously love to brunch (or just eat in general) and ordered enough food for a small family of 4, but hey- when in Rome? Anyways, we quickly scanned the menu and ordered the 2 farm eggs any style, scrambled with bacon, the Cranberry-Orange French Toast and the Monte Cristo.  

I absolutely loved the French Toast, you could taste all the cranberry and orange bits inside every bite. It didn't even need any syrup; it was just sweet enough alone. I liked that It wasn't just cranberry and orange slices piled on top, but baked inside it already. 

The Monte Cristo was interesting.  It is essentially a turkey, ham and cheese sandwich that has been battered and grilled.  The combination with the gruyere cheese inside makes it melt in your mouth soft with a slight crisp from the grill on the outside.  Add on their home-made jam and syrup, it really is a delicious sandwich with a perfect sweet/salty combo.  I was impressed that the sandwich was built so well, it was not sloppily put together and battered and held up its shape just fine for handling and dripping into the jam. 

The only odd thing is the bathroom.  I peeked around the corner of the kitchen and asked a man where the restroom was.  He pointed a door that opened up to the back side of the place.  I was a little confused and initially thought it was trying to be funny and was kidding.  I followed his instructions.  I walked through the small kitchen, through the door and was outside.  On my left was this make-shift tiny bathroom outside. 

Anyways, I am so glad I woke the fiancé up that early because by the time we were out of there around 10, the line was so long up the block!   Advice (an oblivious one too): Come early and come hungry!

Honestly, it did live up to the hype.  I think if I had to wait over an hour in line though, that definitely would have tinted the Mama's experience.  While the friendly and quick service was excellent, it was the warm, sweet french toast that won my heart. Mama's, we will be back again!
author: Jenny S.

description:
We got there at 7:40 and had to wait about an hour to get food and sit down. we got the chocolate cinnamon French toast, crab Benedict and the pan dore. 
Everything tasted okay. it wasn't super delicious. Although I do love how the potatoes that came with the crab Benedict were made. They were perfectly crunchy and delicious. I would suggest going here but make sure to go as early as you can!
author: Vivian T.

description: I always love eating here when I am in SF. The food is delicious and the service is excellent. Brought my family with me and wait is a very long line. But my family agreed it was well worth the wait..
author: Lamont H.

description:
Mama's definitely lived up to the hype and wait (1.5 hrs wasn't bad).

Having read sooo many glowing reviews, I had very very high Mt Everest type expectations and Mama's delivered.

My dining companions and I shared the following - dungeness crab eggs benedict (seasonal), the french toast sampler, california omelet, and the monte cristo.  Everything was just "perfect"... not too heavy, not too thick, not too gooey, not too salty... PERFECTION.

My recommendation would be to order a french toast sampler and share-this way you won't miss out :)

Overall words can't describe how delicious everything was ... it's one of those things you have to experience for yourself.
author: Dennis H.

description: Original coffee crumb cake gets ordered every visit, but this trip I also had the Dungeness crab cake Benedict and that's become a new favorite! After all, where else can you order that delicious of a heart attack? We've been coming since we were toddlers (now we're 29 and 26,) the quality and service has never wavered! Neither has the line!
author: Elizabeth G.

description:
Solid 4.5 stars for service (they are fast! Got the system down!) and quality of food. Very quaint place--love the yellow painted walls. Definitely would love to come here more often, but not worth the 1.5 hour wait. We came here on a Sunday morning around 11am. 

YUM!!! This has been on my yelp list for at least 4 years!!! 

Secret: Get a friend in SF to stand in line for you and by the time you get up to SF, you will be in the front of the line. (Better yet, have a friend drop you RIGHT in front of the restaurant so you don't need to find parking!) My game plan worked out. Nice to have awesome friends :)

Ordered: 
1) French Toast sampler: 4/5 Delicious :)
2) Monte Cristo: 4/5 Very unique presentation--worth trying, esp if you love ham and cheese.
author: Jen H.

description:
uh...This place was not worth the 1.5 hour wait. I repeat, it is not worth the 1.5 hour wait! Don't do it, just don't.  I'm still trying to figure out what the big deal is. Yes we waited, yes I was curious, and no I will never come back again.  

Don't get me wrong, the food is OK (just OK). It wasn't bad, but there are plenty of other places in SF that would actually be worth the wait. I guess I expected a level of wow factor since this place is always so jammed packed. You've failed me this time, Yelp. I feel like this is somewhat of a tourist trap as I know my friends that actually live in SF stay away from here.

1) French toast sampler : Meh, at best. No real specialty about it. 
2) Mama's breakfast sandwich: it was crab with cheese and tomato on a toasted bun. The crab was bland, again, it was just ok.
3) Bloody mary was spicy but it's made with Soju and it's a bit watery.
4) Mimosa comes in a tiny glass, not worth the price.
5) The best thing about this place is their homemade jam, so if you do decide to eat here, make sure to try that. 

Oh and lastly, the chef had a super dirty apron, it was a bit disturbing to look at.
author: Annie L.

description:
Definitely worth the hour long wait! Pro tip: send your partner or someone in your party to get everyone coffee while you wait to make the whole process a little less painful :)  Also, get there before opening!
My boyfriend got the smoked salmon scramble, I got the farmer's omelette, and we split the French toast (I forget the name, but it had chopped dates, raisins, almonds, and honey). The hardest part about eating here isn't waiting in line; it's choosing what to eat!
author: Rachel S.

description: 1.5 hour line. Kinda worth it. Had Northern Italian Omelette and Coffee Cake. Loved both.
author: Jonathan C.

description:
Well it's true about the line. There was a long line and people were all casually waiting. Ever so patiently. I was among one of them. I made sure to have a light snack with me and was there to talk with my friend for an hour and a few more minutes. We made it to the front and although we had seen the menu multiple times, we were still not sure what to get. Everything seemed so delicious!

Note: there is ANOTHER line inside but it's okay, you can see the action before your eyes. I ended up getting the Monte Cristo with a delicious sandwich, battered so perfectly with a delicious jam to finish it off. It was the perfect amount. Mimosa? Don't mind if I do.

My friend got some blueberry pancakes which she raved about. It was just a delightful brunch! I would definitely go back again!
author: Natalie M.

description: Be prepared to wait up to 2 hours to get in here, but don't worry it's totally worth it! My sister and I came here last weekend. She got the Blackstone Benedict. The eggs were cooked perfectly, and the Hollandaise sauce was delicious with just enough acidity. I got 2 poached eggs on a sourdough baguette with a side of bacon and potatoes. Their spiked lemonade is the perfect cocktail for brunch, and service is fast and friendly once you make it through the doors. You can watch the chefs make everything fresh in front of you when you walk in, and see all of the delicious baked goods that they have to offer as well. Worth the wait for a perfect brunch. Don't forget to bring cash!!!!!!
author: Hannah N.

description:
This place is quite a treat.  The line can be a little intimidating, but totally worth it.  The moment you step inside you'll start darting your eyes from table to table, seeing what everyone's ordered.  Dang, it all looks so good.  By the time you are peering through the glass to the kitchen, you probably would have second or triple guessed your mental order.  And by the time you finally order at the register, you'll feel tormented into making that final choice.  

When all's said and done, you probably didn't go wrong with whatever you ordered.  I enjoyed their broad benedict selection and chose accordingly.  My group loved their pancakes and the epic strawberry jam.

Not a fan of the crazy line and cramped dining quarters, but everything else is awesome.
author: Al C.

description:
Cash and debit card only place..  I just thought this place was okay..didn't blow me out of the water or anything.  We waited in line for 1 1/2 hours  and we got there about 1:45pm.  Maybe people thought this place is so good cuz by time u get a table, u are so hungry that everything taste really good.  

We got the crab breakfast sandwich and the French toast sampler.  As I said earlier, good..but, not great.  There are may other places in San Francisco for brunch where the wait is not that long.

I believe most people come here because there are over 2000 reviews and attract many tourist due to the number of review and high rating.  

The service was friendly and the food fresh since they are always serving and turn over is fast.  Don't think I will be back unless I don't see a line.
author: James L.

description:
You have to go to this place really early or really late. The lines are out of this world but just wait it's worth it. 
You absolutely have to order the Monte Cristo. No joke. Its basically French Toast stuffed with cheese and ham. Spread a little bit of jam on piece and you have a bite of pure heaven.
I've had the Crab Benedict, french toast and pancakes but nothing beats the Monte Cristo.
Parking is a little bit hard in the area but you might get lucky with the free parking in the neighborhood or metered parking.
Enjoy!
author: Nguyen L.

description:
Put this at the TOP of your to-do list while in SF. Can't say enough wonderful things about this quaint breakfast place. The bad: Yes the wait is crazy (I've waited up to an hour) The good: it is absolutely worth it, and the staff is a joy. 
Try to get there by 7:30am. The food is superb. Generous portions, delicious options. If you are looking for a healthier option get their special apple french toast- you will not be disappointed. When I come later in the day I get the Monte Cristo. It's everything everyone says it is. The homemade Ollalieberry Jam will freak you out it's so good. 
I make it a point to always visit this breakfast spot when I visit SF, especially when I go with friends who have never been. The location can't be beat either. Enjoy!
author: Nerusia B.

description: I must admit when my fiancé told me that we needed to stand in line at 7:30am on a Friday to visit this restaurant I was skeptical. Would the food at this restaurant really be worth the wait? In my opinion it was. Wait aside, the restaurant although rather small was cozy. The ordering process was simple: stand in line first and then get seated. Since they have an open kitchen, you could view all the items being prepared and pick one that you would enjoy. I chose the egg white scramble and added salmon to it. The salmon was smoked and tasted so fresh and paired well with the egg white. The vegetables were clearly sautéed in the preparation process and had a ton of flavor, but were not as tart as when they are eaten raw (a good thing for this dish). The grilled potatoes were also the perfect texture. The outside was crispy and the inside was a bit soft. Not only was the food delicious, but well plated each dish came with fresh orange slices that complimented the other foods served. This restaurant is definitely worth the wait and makes me happy to come home to Mama's again.
author: Dawn B.

description: I consider myself a patient person now that I've experienced mama's!! The food was good but I don't know if it was worth the 2 hour wait for. Although if you have not been here before and are wondering about the hype, I would recommend coming on a weekday to at least experience it once. To my surprise the wait didn't feel quite as long as I expected it to, maybe because I came here with a friend that I had some catching up with to do! (a little tip). I ordered the french toast sampler and she ordered the infamous monte cristo. We shared both and I must say they are pretty unique from the usual brunch dishes!! overall I'd say it was worth the one-time visit but I don't know when I'd come back simply because I don't have 2 hours to spare to wait for a meal!
author: Vonny C.

description:
Worth the wait? NO. Straight up gonna tell you right now, this is NOT worth the 2 hours wait. It's ridiculous. It was decent but totally not worth wasting your time in line for this! 

I don't know what they are known for but my friends and I got the French toast and added fresh fruit to it, the smoked salmon benedict and a bloody Mary. The smoked salmon was definitely delicious, you can tell the salmon is fresh and plenty of it on the benedict (aka not stingy with the portions) we asked for the hollandaise sauce on the side, which was a really smart idea because our bread didn't get soggy! It isn't the best smoke salmon benedict I've tried, but it's probably one of the best options on their menu. The French toast on the other hand was nothing special. It was lame, it came with 3 slices of regular thin bread. The bread was nothing special, it was not crunchy, totally soggy and tasted like something I could make at home! And we added fresh fruit for an extra $2... (We tried Mymy coffee down the street the next day, and we compared French toast, and Mymy definitely have better, crunchy, thick, free fresh fruit, and just right French toast then this place--and NO WAIT!) This French toast was below par, I guess people around here haven't eaten out in LA for brunch. LA definitely have the best French toast at Blu Jam Café. Comparing LA to Mama's, definitely wasn't worth that wait. The Bloody Mary that we ordered was good, but was realllllly spicy at the end... Anyway once you get pass the wait outside, there's a wait inside, then you get seated and you have to wait even more for your food. I think we got there at 10, and we left at 1. Yes, 3 hours for brunch. Really, don't waste your time. The food was okay, you can get anywhere else. Or maybe we ordered the wrong thing? But I don't think I would want to wait to order another thing.
author: Lisa W.

description: There is always a line here. The wait was about 40 minutes on a weekday around 10am. It seemed like most of the people waiting were tourists (the selfie sticks were a giveaway). They tend to seat people in waves, so they'll clear the whole restaurant and bring a bunch of people in all at once. You order up at the counter, then they bring the food to your table. I got the corn beef eggs Benedict and French toast sampler which were both pretty good. Honestly, the food is good but definitely not worth the wait. I wasn't blown away by anything.
author: Tanya Y.

description:
Worthwhile! The wait was about 1-1.5 hours but the time went by super quick as my friend and I chatted & watched other people... A chica in front of us kept taking selfies of herself via a selfie stick; she was not discreet about it and likely took over 100 snaps. Anyhow, getting back to Mama's... 

Talk about good service and hospitality! The gentleman who led us into the restaurant (once we made it to the front of the line) was very kind! He gave us an overview of some of their popular items and made recommendations. The house baked breads for French toast are made daily - so fresh! And, so many varieties of breads (i.e., with cranberries / blueberries / lemon / cinnamon - the latter was my fave)! Most of the menu items sounded fantastic - I wanted to order everything! I was excited to see listings of vegetarian-friendly items! Major points! My friend and I ordered several items and shared... Mama's French Toast with fresh fruit = yum! (Note - you must get the fresh fruit or seasonal berries!) Mama's Benedict - specifically the one titled 'Vegetarian' - w/ sautéed mushrooms (not overpowering), avocado, baby spinach and grilled tomato = DELICIOUS! The poached eggs were perfect. The grilled potatoes that came on the side were OK. In addition, they had a number of crumb cakes - we chose the apple, and it was delectable! My friend ordered a bellini which she was pleased with. The fresh-squeezed mimosa with fresh ruby red grapefruit juice was refreshing. 

Again, worth the wait; come when you have the extra time to wait - and when you're not incredibly starving (as you don't want to be grumpy while waiting). I wish to return - I want to try the M'Omelette's! 

Btw, cash only, and they accept debit with a $1 fee - you pay right after ordering.
author: Pina U.

description:
DROOOOLLLLSSSS.. All over the place. 

This dainty little restaurant is located on the corner of Washington Avenue. Be aware that you will have to give it some time until you are seated. I came on a Friday morning around 10am and there was already a long line. I waited about an hour until I was seated with my sister. 

Once you get to the front, you will be asked to enter and fall in line where you will be ordering. I was determined to order one of their famous eggs Benedict dishes. The nice Asian lady that took my order recommended the smoked salmon eggs Benedict. Along side with that, I ordered a spiked lemonade because of the cool mason jar it comes with. 

We were seated after we placed our order. Our dishes came out very quick and I was pleased about that. The smoked salmon eggs Benedict was cooked to perfection. The poached egg had the right consistency. As I sliced through the egg through the salmon and muffin, the yolk oozes out. It was a simple dish with a great taste! I had my fair share of eggs Benedict dishes and this by far is the best! The only downside I would say are the potatoes. I prefer them to be much crispier. The spiked lemonade is a mixture of white wine and fresh squeezed lemonade. It's very refreshing, but will still leave you with a little buzz. Paired with the dish, it's a party in my palette. 

Awesome breakfast!! Worth the wait!! Can't wait to go back for more!!
author: Karla Marie D.

description: Arrived right before they opened on a Saturday and I didn't read the reviews that said "long lines or arrive early". We waited 1 1/2 hours before we got into the restaurant.  But it was worth the wait! So next time we will arrive early!  My boyfriends daughter who LOVES French toast said this was the best French toast she's ever had.  The vegetarian omelette was excellent, the potatoes were crispy and the homemade jam for the toast was awesome.  I understand why people (like me) are willing to stand in line for over an hour for breakfast.  A restaurant with a lot of history and a great start to enjoying the weekend.
author: M G.

description: Wait time was kind of a bummer but it was super worth it! I tried the French toast sampler and the eggs Benedict, both awesome dishes! The staff was super friendly and seemed happy to be working there, which always makes for such a better experience! I would definitely make this a stop if you're in San Fran!
author: Abbey M.

description:
About a year ago, I saw Mama's while trying to find parking in Chinatown. Mama's had an extremely long line, so long I wondered if there was something going on that day. I didn't know what Mama's was, so I quickly saved a note on my phone with the name and the streets it is located at. When I went home, I Yelped this place then saw it on Check Please and knew I had to come here someday. That someday was a few Fridays ago. When I arrived around 2:20PM, there wasn't a line woohoo. I was bit confused when I walked in. Do I sit first? Do I order? The waitress was kind enough to tell us to order at the counter. We ordered:

$8.95 Chocolate French Toast with Fresh Berries http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/MvAo0hj9FXOeNL5PwBZ0fQ?select=QAoOOVNNHmCKim7uKqH5sg: lots of berries & banana slices, covered in chocolate syrup with 3 slices of battered swirled bread. Very sweet and very delicious. They also give you homemade ollalieberry jam http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/MvAo0hj9FXOeNL5PwBZ0fQ?select=16CWYIfbCydJQ5mkiG2jmw to add to your french toast which was really good. The jam has a lot of seeds in it, so you know it's real.

$7.95 Swedish Cinnamon French Toast & add additional $2 for Fresh Berries http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/MvAo0hj9FXOeNL5PwBZ0fQ?select=GoPVK_psbHjVWZAQ2bH0zQ: didn't get much fruit for $2 more, felt jipped compared to the amount of berries the Chocolate French Toast got. I liked this one a lot more than the Chocolate French Toast. The Swedish French Toast is less sweet and more tolerable. I think it's basically the same as the Chocolate French Toast without the chocolate. I'm not sure why it costs more though when you add the fruit.

I don't think I would get the Chocolate French Toast, it's too sweet but it looks so good. Yes, I would get the Swedish Cinnamon French Toast if I ever come back or maybe the Monte Crisco????
author: Kylie L.

description:
Cute tiny restaurant that always has a super long line , it goes by fairly fast though. 

It's supposed to be this famous place in sf that's been around for years . 

The wait is completely worth it though. I got the crab omelette and it was amazing . So good . The monte Cristo was just as amazing ( which also what they are known for ) def . A place you need to try in sf . They only open till 3 an are closed on Mondays . So plan wisely !
author: Jessica C.

description: Yummy breakfast, but not sure it's worth the wait.  Very cute place and if the wait is short, worth the stop.  However, we waited (with 2 youngs kids) for about 45 minutes.  Luckily, there's a park across the street that mom took the kids to while dad stood in line.
author: Michi D.

description: Walking inside, it hit me. The decor and homeyness, the name "Mama's" totally fits this place. First of all, they won me over early on when I was lucky enough to wait in line for 15 minutes, versus the hour+ wait I've been hearing from fellow reviewers on yelp. Granted it was 12pm in the middle of the week (psst hint hint for those who don't like waiting in lines). Service was quick and very polite. The kind waitress briefly refused service to us saying that they only served parties of 2. Of course she was kidding, otherwise we would have been pretty bummed out lol. The big Mama's Cristo, not to be confused with their famous Monte Cristo, was my pick of the day. Served on a plate that screams colorful brunch, the four cuts of the sandwich, placed with slices of orange and strawberry, potato salad, and their delicious jam in the middle. The sandwich was grilled to perfection. And topped with their jam, an absolutely terrific brunch for a 15 minutes wait. It is however on the pricey side, and less on the filling side, so be sure to account for that when ordering. Other than that, I can only say great things about this place and am sure to come back, hopefully when the wait isn't too long.
author: Ryan C.

description:
I've been here twice, once yesterday, and the first time years ago. The wait is ridiculous, especially on weekends, it can easily top 2 hours. My suggestion, get here before they open, or dont bother at all...shoot for a weekday.

The food was delicious, but it took us less than half the wait time to eat the food, so in my books, the math doesnt quite at up. If you must wait, and it happens to be a NON-sunday, walk across the street to the foccacia bakery and help stave off the hunger, they have great/fresh bread. 

Mama's is cash/debit only. You order, pay, then you seat. What happened was all I had was a debit card (which btw comes with a $1 surcharge), paid, seated, ate, had no cash to leave on the table for tips. What a very poor and inefficient system.
author: Long C.

description:
Mama's was amazing!!!!! Best Restaurant Breakfast spot I have been to in my life!!! 
The flavors, oh the flavors!!! We went with the Shrimp and Avocado Benedict served with a side of potatoes. We also enjoyed the Swiss and Cinnamon French Toast with a side of fresh fruit!! So deliciously sweet with added  House made Mama's Raspberry Jelly!!! Oh and to drink it all down a serving of a foamy latte and a last minute Hot Chocolate!! THIS WAS AMAZING AND A VERY DESERVED WAIT!! I must add that the wait outside in the long line was for about 45 minutes and It was raining lightly, but still very worthy of the wait!!
YOU MUST TRY If you haven't yet!!!
author: Lizeth M.

description: Absolutely delicious!!!!!!! The cinnamon French toast with berries on top is a must!!!!
author: Pam H.

description: The food is great but I'm not so sure I would wait in this line again. Probably took 2 hours for us to get seated. My boyfriend and I both ordered from the specials menu. The portions are big and we all left satisfied but def annoyed by the line.
author: Sandra S.

description:
Solid breakfast place though it has a huge line always. Getting there at 7:30am on a weekday is the safest way to make sure you don't wait more than 30 minutes. Otherwise, expect to wait 1 hour (maybe more).

The bread and jams here are great. The French Toast is an easy crowd pleaser. The omelettes aren't cooked with everything mixed together. It's more of a stuff with eggs folded around it setup. The Northern Italian omelet was a tad salty for my taste but definitely creative with its Italian bacon, tomatoes, mushrooms, and basil.

The staff is really friendly and efficient. Probably worth trying once but you got to decide for yourself if the line is worth it.
author: Victor W.

description:
Tremendously long lines!! OMMMGGERD =/
Living in SF for all my life, I've passed by this place hundreds of times but never went in there to eat. 

I went recently with my BF and we waited about an hour just to get through the doors. I mean an hour wait isn't that long when you entertain yourself by people watching. Luckily for us, we had a bunch of Chinese tourists who couldn't stop taking pictures in those funny cute asian poses. When we got through the doors, we waited another 10 minutes to place our orders and to be seated. 

I got the crab egg benedict, which was in my opinion okay. I mean it was yummy but just too pricey to be worth it. 

BF got the monte cristo and it was sooo yummy! That jam is just sooo delish! I'd say it was better than my benedict!

Overall, it was nice little brunch and made me feel very touristy!
author: Kelly L.

description:
Good brunch, but is it worth the two hour wait?

A mixture of locals and tourists start lining up for Mama's at 7am. You will definitely have to wait 1-2 hours to finally get a table, but luckily you get to meet a lot of characters on the line to keep you entertained. 

During my wait, there was a group of ladies from New Jersey having quite an interesting internal dispute, a minor accident with a senior falling off her scooter, a visit by some local musicians, and plenty of fun conversation. Quite eventful. 

Once you make it inside, the restaurant is quite comfortable and spacious. They sit the next group at any available table, so it really is a first-come-first-serve queue regardless of group size. The decor is quite cute and homely, though the mean glares from the people waiting in line outside will make you think twice about really taking your time eating. 

Onto the food. The crab Benedict was pretty good and the crab definitely fresh, but it did not blow me away. It had spinach in it which partially covered the more delicate flavor of the fresh crab meat. It was also not cheap. 

The famous Montecristo is definitely a must-try if you come here. It was a quite nicely crafted sandwich, different from other incarnations which can get very messy. Was it worth coming here just for the sandwich though? I am not sure I would call it the definitive Montecristo. 

The blueberry pancakes were good pancakes, but not good blueberry pancakes. They were fluffy, but were lacking in the blueberriness. The blueberries, can't just be on the outside, they have to be in the batter and get cooked along with the pancake. 

Overall, I had a fun experience and a pretty good brunch, but was it worth the wait? I don't think so. Come on a weekday.
author: Augusto T.

description:
This is a good place to go if you want to try a new breakfast/brunch place. Or if you're from out of town and you want to try something different. Once is good enough. I mean, you get there and there's a line, ALWAYS a line and it's at LEAST an hour wait. First time you go, it's totally worth it. It's what everyone's doing...by the looks of all the the freakn people in line. I enjoyed my brunch. It was a change up from what I usually get, but not so much for me to ever want to get into that line again. If I wanted to wait in line for food, I'd wait for Brenda's Soul Food.

What we got:
What everyone else gets- The Monte Cristo. It's different. Good, have it once.
Swedish Cinnamon French toast with fruit-Not too sweet. Probably will try a different french toast if I ever go back.
Norwegian eggs bene- perfect. I love hollandaise and it's delicious here. 

Be prepared to be hanging out with a ton of people while you eat...but you won't feel too rushed by the servers. That was nice.
author: Chou Y.

description:
It's worth the wait!!! My wife and I went on a Saturday during Labor Day weekend and we waited for 2 hours before we got in. It was the best food we had our entire trip and we went to a lot of restaurants. 
We ordered the Cinnamon chocolate French toast, the traditional eggs Benedict and the Apple pan dore. All of it was amazing but the apple pan dore was the best. We definitely recommend getting it.
author: Brian N.

description:
A must visit brunch place in SF. And first thing you see is always the line. I've been there couple times and the wait was 1.5 hours and 2 hours. Worth the wait? Yes and No. 

Yes, I would wait in line if I'm bringing someone who's never tried the place before
No, I would not go and wait in line by myself or with someone who's already been there before.

What was ordered:
Dungeness Crab Benedict: 5/5 - a little pricey, but it's a must order
Monte Cristo: 5/5 - another one of my favorite. Almost like a savory french toast
Crumbs Cake: 5/5 - It is heated up prior to serving. Delicious
Mama's smoothie: 3/5 - Not worth the money and very gritty for my taste

Added bonus:
After eating all that food, hike up to Coit Tower to work off the calories. Enjoy the view while having food coma.
author: Patty L.

description:
If u really hungry and thirsty  at a sunny Wednesday afternoon, then it may be not a good idea for wait about one and half hour to get a bite. But the food was great! 
I think I only will take the line once. If I don't have friend with me to go together next time.
They only accept Cash now. Kinda inconvenient. We have Apple Pay and so many other options now, they are still keep the way like in 1950s.
author: Blair Z.

description:
Finally after having this place bookmarked on Yelp for two years, I finally made it out to North Beach for brunch at Mama's!

We probably waited about 20-30 minutes after arriving at 10:45am on a Wednesday. Once you get in the doors, you have a small line as you pass by the open kitchen and order at the register. From there, you're seated at your table.

Somehow one of my friends brought up the fact that my birthday is next week and the guy asked me if I wanted the restaurant to sing me Happy Birthday. I shrugged it off and the guy announced my birthday and indeed got the whole restaurant to sing me Happy Birthday. Haha.

Here's the rundown of the food and drinks:

1. Orange Juice - looked like fresh squeezed OJ and my friends seemed happy with it!
2. Monte Cristo Sandwich - pretty good rendition of the classic sandwich. Not as heavily fried as the one from Disneyland, but that's probably a good thing. They serve it with a jam that tastes homemade. The sandwich itself probably could use some more filling since I didn't really taste any of the ham or cheese.
3. Crab Benedict - they're doing it right. It's one of the pricier options, but they put a fair amount of crab under a buttered english muffin, topped with a perfectly cooked poached egg, and a rich hollandaise sauce. It was so filling I couldn't finish the entire english muffin.
4. French Toast Sampler - three different pieces of bread dipped in an egg batter and cooked to perfection. It's topped with sliced bananas, strawberries, and blueberries. The cranberry orange walnut bread was probably my favorite. Nice and sweet. The banana bread was also nice, but quite dense to be made into french toast. The Swedish cinnamon bread was just okay, with a slight cinnamon flavor, but not much else.

Other items that looked pretty good were the omelets and the bacon (nice thick cut strips).

The service was excellent and the food was tasty and rather filling. Would I return? It's a cute spot, but waiting any longer than 30 minutes might be a bit much. They do have a lot of options that I would not be making myself for brunch, so I think it's worth the trip to at least try once!
author: Leana L.

description: This place is good but I wouldn't give it a 5 star. And there's usually always a long line, so be prepared to wait some time before sitting down.
author: Johnny N.

description: Showed up 10mins before opening. We had about an hours wait in line. Ordered salmon scramble which was good but unfortunately they do not accommodate changing items on the menu such as swapping a bagel for avocado... small portions on menu are kids size so just order large! All in all it was a tasty experience so get there early....!
author: Shehan T.

description: My friend came here to visit me last week. I took him to this restaurant, we were enjoy theirs food. It needs took one hour to wait!!!! But still worth it.:)))
author: Julie H.

description:
The line outside says it all, it's a San Francisco "must have." 

You mustn't get intimidated by the line outside, but expect to wait an hour for this breakfast necessity. Here in line you will change your mind on what you're going to order, everything sounds and actually is great, but might I suggest you order the Monte Cristo. This Monte Cristo is absolutely the best breakfast sandwich money can buy. The service is excellent, and the food is phenomenal. This will be my goto every San Francisco trip.
author: Joey M.

description:
Whenever I have a friend or relative visiting from out of town, Mama's is the no brainer choice for where to go for breakfast/brunch in the city. The harder decision always is, when I decide to come by myself, whether or not that if that morning I am willing to stand in line for over an hour next to someone reading an Alcatraz map out loud. Usually common sense will win out 9 times out of 10, but that one time I do make the sacrifice, I have always patiently endured the wait with hunger (secretly smiling to myself when someone in front of me in line bows out and leaves before getting inside), but have always left satisfied and rewarded with a solid treat that gives me a special start to the rest of my day.

Everything on the menu here is solid, and the quality is always consistent. My favorites depend on my mood, I usually order the eggs benedict. The way they make it here is just head and shoulders over anywhere else, the hollandaise is just the right consistency with a little kick, the fact that they make it with real Canadian bacon that is harder and harder to find these days, and the eggs are always perfectly poached. If I'm feeling like something more substantial, the French toast here cannot be beat, and the ultimate combination of French toast with everything else that goes well with it is the Monte Cristo sandwich, which I can never finish in one sitting because the Havarti cheese is so rich, but would recommend sharing if coming with larger groups. A lot of my friends from out of town prefer ordering the Dungeness crab and shrimp related items, which are also great choices.

Love this place.
author: Mark Y.

description:
Enjoyed a trio of delicious options: Dungeness Crab Eggs Benedict, French Toast Sampler Plate and the Infamous Monte Cristo.  We also started with a chocolate covered crumb cake.

Great options available in a unique & fresh way.
author: Michael D.

description: I wouldn't come here all the time, just because the wait is a bit ridiculous.  But once in a blue moon, sure why not.  Food is amazing and service is attentive.  Love their monte cristo, chocolate french toast, and pancakes.
author: Samantha C.

description:
I came here for lunch yesterday and was excited to try the food after reading all the great Yelp reviews. I was also hoping for a shorter line since it was noon on Tuesday. 
Well I'll start with the wait..about an hour outside. On a random day I was a bit surprised. But not only did I wait outside, but they only let a few people in at a time so you wait inside to order. Then you wait for one of the 12 or so tables once you order. Then you wait for your food. Be prepared to wait...a lot. 
The food was average. We got the Monte Cristo (mind you I've never tried this before) and the Blackstone eggs Benedict. The Monte Cristo came with a really yummy jam & tasted pretty good. The Eggs Benedict were good but nothing to rave about. We also got the crumb cake to share & that was good. They warmed it up before serving it. 
Would I go here again...maybe if there was not such a horrible wait.
author: Sarika S.

description: Hard to make a standard breakfast anything spectacular. Overall this place was fair food with a cute atmosphere. Definitely over priced and over hyped. Probably wouldn't revisit on another trip to SF.
author: Shelby F.

description:
beautiful. I dont know how else to describe the food here. 

an hour wait in the cold. totally worth it. 

mama's is very small. great for couples and group sizes no larger than 4. 

the bf and I ordered three dishes to share. we didnt know how else to get what we wanted, so we simply ordered more. but dont worry, we finished it all. french toast, french toast with chocolate and shrimp egg benedicts. the house jam is good on EVERTHING. raspberry? who knows, its good. 

great service. the restroom is outside...an out house. dont walk into the kitchen like I did, they'll try to make you cook with them!
author: Serena L.

description: I give this place 2 stars strictly for the amazing service. Waited in line for over 2 hours and it was a complete waste of our time. Tried the famous "Monte Cristo," and it was the most bland tasting thing EVER!!! My friend had the "Californian Omelette," and again, nothing to write home about. Mama's has established its name due to its history. Julia Child once visited this place and since then it's become a hit. Its  like the modern day Guy Fieri. Take it from me, a foodie, do not attempt to stand in this line for a average IHOP/Denny's breakfast. Sorry Mama's.
author: Mary S.

description:
You wait an hour just to get in the door.  Then you wait another 15 minutes to get seated, and that is on a good day.  IT IS SO WORTH IT!!!   

The food is so fresh and sooo good.  

The monte cristo comes with a home made jam that is so delicious.   The eggs benedict are just right with an incredible hollandaise sauce.  I could go on an on, but suffice it to say.  The place is amazing.
author: Spencer R.

description: 1.5 hour wait to get in the door but it was delicious. I'm not sure what sets it apart so distinctly from other breakfast spots but the French toast sampler seemed to be their most original thing. I had the smoked salmon scramble which comes with a yummy piece baguette. Overall good experience besides the crazy wait.
author: Colby O.

description:
We were first in line but seeing how we arrived before they opened I guess its not an amazing feat. Surprisingly, the lines never got as long as I thought it would. It was a Tuesday morning.

You order at the register and you pay in CASH upfront before receiving your food. Pick a table and they will bring you your food. The food comes out really fast! I was pleasantly surprised. 

I ordered 

Mocha - It wasn't as good as other places. 

Shrimp and Avocado Benedict With Grilled Tomatoes - Came with a side of skillet potatoes. LOVE! I love skillet potatoes! The hollandais was perfectly favored and was the perfect compliment to the shrimp and English muffin. You get a bountiful of shrimp and a good helping of avocado. 

My friend ordered

Northern Italian
Pancetta (Italian Cured Bacon), Mushroom, Fresh Basil, Tomato, and Garlic Jack Cheese $10.25 - It is an omelet. I think everything went well together but I only had a bite. The cheese made it very hearty and my friend was too full to finish the potatoes afterwards. Come with a two pieces of bread. Unfortunately, it didn't look too appealing. 

Overall, I was very happy with this experience because the service here is very prompt and friendly. They refilled my friend's water and coffee often. It is kind of pricy. Total was 30 for the food, not including tip. But I was full for a while so I guess it was worth the money.
author: Sarah C.

description: Breakfast of champions.  Wow!  Don't really get up that early for breakfast, but heard how crowded it gets.  So I promised my wife I would make the effort.  Man did that pay off.  We got there 15min before they opened and there was already a line, but we still were apart of the 1st group that got a table.  Their Monte Cristo is choice, and my wifes smoked salmon omelet was rediculous!  Highly recommend
author: Ryan S.

description:
The wait was about an hour even though we started our line up at around 8. It got worse the later it got though. 
This place was so cute and well worth the wait! I went with my two little sisters who are BIG on pancakes so they ordered Old Fashioned Buttermilk Pancakes while I stuck with the Vegetarian Benedict. My sisters loved the pancakes and spreading Mama's famous homemade jam on them was just the cherry on top!

All I can say was the staff was fun but a bit slow, the food was great, and I was happy with my experience.
author: Krystle T.

description:
My favorite breakfast place so far in San Fran!

I got their Monte Cristo sandwich which is amazing with the jam! 
Their French toast was also amazing .
The staff their was great. We waited an hour but it was DEF worth it.
On top of that one of the owners I think( he's the brother in-law of the other owners) is one of the most charismatic people and my parents enjoyed talking to him. My mom asked him to make a special Sandwich in a way no one their had heard of before lol.

Def go to Mama's.
author: Cecilia B.

description:
The 3 "top" breakfast places in the city according to Yelpers: 

1. Brenda's 
2. Dottie's 
3. Mama's 

As of today, I have eaten at all 3. I can die victorious, because some of us make shorter than 100-place lists. (I don't want to name names.) (But I'm looking at you, 6+1 times 6+1). 

Knowing it was going to be a LONG wait, Jenna F. and I woke up and navigated Muni somewhat unsuccessfully to North Beach at 8am this morning. 

We got there at 8:20 and there was... NO LINE. NO. FREAKING LINE! WOW! 

So we went in and ordered- Lowfat apple french toast for me, egg white omelet for Jenna F., and a classic crumb cake to split. 

The crumb cake was heaven. It made me stop talking. Literally- I stopped mid-sentence. There were no words coming out of my mouth as I tasted the first bite. 

My LOWFAT (but high in sugar so its not calorie free kids, sorry) french toast was quite scrumptious. Scrumdiddlyumptious, actually. 

After eating at the top three in the city, which do I think is best? Dotties. 

While this is good, it's not "wait for an hour with your tourist friends" good. Its "you live nearby and you got a craving" good.
author: Emily D.

description:
On a recent trip to San Francisco, we decided to try out Mama's after seeing great reviews.  We knew to expect a line and we were not disappointed!  It was about 90 minutes from the time we got in line to the time we got to sit down to eat, but it actually wasn't too bad!  We had a fabulous SF resident in line behind us who was a wealth of information!  She gave us some great tips for our trip and we had a lot of interesting conversations in general about SF.  

We were so excited when we finally got to enter the door to the restaurant, only to find that there was another line to stand in and then after ordering we had to stand for a while to wait for a table to open up to accommodate our party of 4.

Once the food arrived, it made the standing and waiting all worthwhile!  

I ordered the Chocolate Cinnamon French Toast and the rest of my party ordered the French Toast Platter (several types on one plate).  My food was AMAZING!  I would not mind standing in line all over again to try out something else!
author: Crystal P.

description: I waited two n a half hours for the breakfast and it was worth every second! So if you are coming get there when it first opens! This is the best breakfast I've had in my life! I had the monte Cristo which just was so flavorful and fluffy. The cheese in the fluffy French toast style breading was tasty and went so well with the dish. The sausage links were huge! And there was fresh squeezed lemonade.  I will definitely be coming back here.
author: Hannah H.

description:
Arrived at 7:40 AM on a Saturday morning and still had to wait 1.5 hours!!

Have to say, I have had better french toast elsewhere and at a much shorter wait.  We ordered the sampler, consisting of cranberry-orange, cinnamon, and brioche.  The french toast was a bit more lightly battered than I had hoped (not as moist/eggy).

However, the hubby's crab eggs benedict was spot on.  Oozy eggs, hollandaise, and plenty of crab chunks.

So I guess your experience here depends on what you order, but I probably won't return on a weekend again.
author: Tracy K.

description: Monte cristo is just amazing but if could get just the cinnamon bread that would of been even better!I ordered the veggie omelette and OMG the goat cheese inside did it for me! I have been craving it since! BOMB
author: Nessy N.

description: The waitress here excused us of stealing her $10 tip off the table. If she would take the time to look back at the cameras she would be ashamed of how we were treated after our two hour wait for a decent brunch. Never recommending to friends and never going back.
author: Grace L.

description: We waited 2 hours in line but I can honestly say it was worth it. The food was delicious and the service was A+
author: Patty R.

description:
Last weekend was my first time ever visiting San Francisco. I had a stacked schedule, and the wait time at Mama's was just too long for me. This weekend I had some time on my hands, so I got to Mama's around 10:30, and the wait was a little over an hour. One of the women working there was kind enough to come out and give some of us hungry patrons a little water while we stood outside looking at a bunch of people dressed up in Santa costumes walk around the are; SantaCon I believe they were headed.

Anyway, now I'm at the front of the line, time to find out what the hype is all about. I get inside, wait in another, but much smaller line. You walk past the grill and all the freshly baked bread and desserts, and then order before sitting down, which I always love doing, because when I'm ready to go then I can just head out.
I sit down, and when the gentleman delivers my food, he gives me a tip to put the homemade raspberry preserves on my French toast. After finishing up half of my eggs, bacon, and home fries, I get into the French toast. Now, if you're a fan of Smucker's raspberry preserves, prepare to have your world turned upside down. The jam was magnificent, but I was bummed out to find that they don't sell it. I was; however, able to get a small to-go cup of it.

The hour wait was definitely a bit long, but it's not their fault; it's just a popular spot, and understandably so. Just be prepared to have to make a bit of time for it if you're on a schedule. It was well worth it in my opinion, and when I return to California next month I will certainly be returning here. I was told that if you can make it there around 8AM, then you may avoid a crazy line, but I could not confirm that myself.

For food, I ordered the Swedish cinnamon French toast, which is their default, along with scrambled eggs with Swiss cheese, home fries and a side of bacon. I usually like my French toast crispy around the edges, but I often find that this will cause the inside to be a bit soggy. Mama's French toast isn't very crispy on the outside, but the inside was perfectly fluffy, which was a find trade-off in my opinion. The bacon: three very big, crispy, and delicious slices. The swiss cheese eggs were excellent, and while I'm not a huge home fries fan, these were crispy enough for my liking. I also ordered silver dollar pancakes and an apple crumb cake-type dessert to go, but I didn't eat the pancakes until about nine hours later; they were still pretty delicious. The verdict is still out on the crumb cake, but I will get to that at some point.
author: Melvin D.

description:
Just one more overrated place in San Francisco, that everyone loves and when you try it you have that feeling of "that's it???".
The food isn't bad, but it isn't all that, people, come on now.
If you have time to spare and want to wait at least 45 minutes in line, and want to try a " traditional brunch place" in SF, go try it. I've already tried it and I most likely won't go again.
author: Ana Carolina J.

description: Although the wait is pretty terrible, the food is actually very good. Not really sure why its super super popular. I mean their food is great but have you seen the line at this place. Is it worth it? Its unbelievable. I feel like you can have the same great food at many other places that will let you make reservations, like Epic, Perrys, chef and butler, sweet maple.... Etc. i feel like its a big hype. I mean its breakfast people!
author: Anudari K.

description:
I had the Farmers Omelet at Mamas which was pretty good but I've tasted better. I also got to try the Northern Omelet which was juicier and oily and I liked it. The food wasn't bad, it wasn't also over the top amazing.

With the hour and half wait outside, I was expecting amazing omelets. I would go back and try the other foods on the menu but not for the wait that long. 

The service was great. The people were friendly and attended well to the customers.
author: Jerome N.

description:
Came here on my birthday after watching an early morning soccer game at a pub. By early, I mean 5:30am but hey, it's 5 o'clock somewhere, right? Still wasn't opened at 7:30, but there was still a line. I remember thinking, "Jesus, this place is REALLY that good, huh?" Then again, I remembered that waiting in line is one of SF's beloved pastimes. Waited 35 minutes, which probably is an extremely short wait to get into Mama's.

The man at the door was really nice and when we came in, he told us about the different breads they bake and the processes they use. Just for kicks, I asked him what's the best thing I could get at Mama's. He suggested the Monte Carlo.

I went with the Monte Carlo. I had my mind set on the Dungeness Crab Benedict, but unfortunately my wallet didn't seem to be on the same page. However, the Monte Carlo was very good! Hot and crispy on the outside, nice and fluffy in the inside. Maybe it's not 2-hour wait-good, but I'd wait at least 20 minutes for it.

I probably wouldn't come here again because of the wait and craziness of it all, but it's a good place to go at least once if you have the chance to. Try to go earlier than 8am. Or, ya know, you can start religiously following soccer to the point where you go to a nearby pub at 5:30am on a weekend.
author: Jay E.

description:
I have the pleasure now of having two Mamas: one lives in Hayward and the other one resides on 1701 Stockton St!

There's going to be a line of some sort. Let's just get that out of the way, the girlfriend and I waited about 40-60 minutes on a Saturday (was told by a waitress that "today is NOTHIN', the line can stretch as far as the other block!)

I felt like this place embodied exclusivity. Like this is a secret breakfast haven for the Free Masons or something. Once we got through the line and the 'members only door', you stare into Martha Stewart's dream kitchen. 

Look up. Grand menu board displays innovative takes on traditional American breakfast, albeit the magic word here is quality. 

Cinnamon swirl french toast with blueberries and strawberries, warm syrup and canadian bacon cut into medallions.

Holy shit -- Succulent. 

Creepy story time: A waiter walked passed me, but before he did, he whispered "try the jam on the toast." I look back, and he was gone. I did his bidding anyway.

Moral: try the jam on your french toast.
author: Matt B.

description:
Occasion: Brunch with Susan 

What I Had: 
Shrimp Eggs Benedict Special 
Blueberry Pancake Single

Food Review: The Shrimp Eggs Benedict Special would have been better if they had seasoned the shrimps or grilled them, but it was tasty nonetheless. The blueberry pancake was fluffy and delicious, although not as good as the blueberry wheat germ pancake at Stacks! Maybe that's just me and my love affair with wheat germ (hey it does have health value!). 

Service Review: Our server was very friendly and delivered our food as soon as it was ready. We were a little nervous we wouldn't be able to make it in before their 3pm close with the crazy line, but admins assured us we would make it and they were right. 

Venue Review: Looking for parking consumed all of 20 minutes, but eventually we ended up parking at the Catholic school on the same block just down the street...and no one towed! The school parking lot was open, no one there had permits, and people seemed to be simply parking and then going elsewhere so why not. 

The restaurant itself is tiny: maybe a dozen small tables in this itsy bitsy corner brunch place at Washington Square. The line, however, stretches the length of the restaurant. We ended up waiting about an hour in line for a table for 2...but it was well worth the wait! 

Overall Impression: There were so many people taking photos that we are convinced this is an SF tourist attraction. Their food overall is up-there in the rankings, but I think Stacks beats them on blueberry pancakes and Sarabeth's kills on their eggs benedicts. Still, Mama's is certainly a spectacular SF brunch (if you can get in by 3pm!). Long wait aside, this place is adorable and we really enjoyed our brunch!
author: Rachael K.

description:
Synopsis: Iconic place found near the northeast corner of Washington Square. Expect to wait an hour to get in, and then another 10-15 minute line to order and wait to be seated once you're inside. The wait is soon forgiven as the service and food is really excellent. The restroom, if you can call it that is worth seeing for a laugh. The place is really small, not really good for big groups, especially to all the people who are still waiting in line. Best for brunch or lunch I think, couples will like the intimate seating but in reality, quarters are a little tight... 

Waiting in line to get into Mama's, one is afforded a view of North Beach on Stockton and Filbert, I remember some things.  In the original movie 'Dirty Harry' when Scorpio was looking for his next potential victim, he was about to shoot the gay, black man in a pancho, who was waiting for his partner that came out of Mama's holding an ice cream cone! (LOL!)  Check out the Youtube video starting around the 3:59 mark...

http://www.youtube.com/watch?feature=player_detailpage&v=iV3YBbe3xW0#t=239s

We thought we had it made once they beckoned us inside the front door, but then there is a second line to order, pay, and be seated.  Different, but effective I guess.

I had the Monte Cristo sandwich:  turkey, ham,  cheddar, and havarti all between slices of cheese bread, dipped in egg batter and pan fried like French Toast.  Served on a plate with homemade jam, strawberry and orange slices, country potatoes, and then dusted with confectioners sugar.  I found that dipping the sandwich in the jam made this taste soooo gooood!!!...

My better half had the excellent Eggs Florentine:  2 poached eggs with spinach and mushrooms and Hollandaise sauce,  the mushrooms and spinach were really fresh.  I tried a bit, and it was one of the best Egg Florentines that I have tasted in a long time...

The waiters and servers were very nice and attentive.  If you need to use the restroom, watch your step as it is little more than a water closet, literally,  down a couple of steps outside the back and back up a couple of steps.  Go see for yourself...

I've been here a long time ago but I don't remember much of my first experience.  This most recent time was very satisfying, I think Mama's is well deserving of its accolades...
author: Lawrence L.

description: Worth the wait! Not only was the breakfast delicious, the staff was friendly and warm, which was impressive considering the high volume of customers. Chocolate Cinnamon French Toast did not disappoint!
author: Joceline A.

description:
I got there about 15 minutes before open on a Wednesday and there was already a long line. It took me 40 minutes to make it inside and about another 10-15 to get through the counter line. Once I sat down though my food was almost instant. I got a really  tasty "farmer's omelette" with goat cheese and bacon I think. I'm not really sure, but it was really good. The place is teeny tiny, and since I was a party of one I had to wait for a two person table to open up before being seated. 

Really that's the trick. Get there early and only have 3-4 people in your party. If you are a two person party they will only seat you at the two-seat tables. And if you are a party of say 5 they will make you wait until a large table opens even if you are already inside. All the couples behind you walk past grinning as your huge party waits for a table, and that's pretty obnoxious. 

Good luck!
author: Channa P.

description:
Wow, waiting in line has never been so awkward. Standing outside on the street, you think that once you get in you can be seated but NOPE - you're waiting in line again to pay for your food first and THEN you get to find a table, if you're lucky. Otherwise, you're standing there either staring down the cooks or drooling at other people's food while your knees are quivering from the hunger.

My experience at Mama's was pretty underwhelming. Waited in line for maybe 30-45 minutes which I thought was perfectly a-ok as I was expecting the food to seriously blow us away. We got the eggs benedict and I was not impressed.... my egg yolks were completely cooked through, leaning towards the dry side! blech..... I got to try a bit of my bf's eggs bene as they were closer to being properly cooked (but still not that runny) and it was better, but not the best. If I go again I'd definitely go for the french toast or pancakes instead.

Prices were pretty steep for what I thought was a mediocre brunch. Service was.. whatever. The two folks who were serving were complaining about how slow it was -- sorry, is the line outside the door not enough for you? The decor was pretty cute but meh that's about it.
author: Laura L.

description:
The wait was pretty long to get in thankfully my brother and I took turns standing in line. The staff was very nice and could not have been better. The man taking orders told me to get the French toast sampler which I did which came with assorted baked bread such as banana nut and berry bread. 

The French toast came with plenty of fresh berries on top which were very good I also got a side of bacon which was a very thick and crispy side which was probably the best party of my meal. The French toast was good but if I went back I would get a more traditional style French toast

My brother got the California omelet which was delicious 

While my mother got the monte cristo which was different but very good! I should've gotten this

We also got chocolate crumb cake and the carrot cake and both were to die for
author: Dylan L.

description: If a 2 hour wait seems unreasonable try the Hollywood Cafe. We did and could not have been happier!
author: Louise P.

description:
I had high expectations for this place especially when I saw the lonnnnnng line paired with the many positive reviews. That's why I was willing to wait for 3 hours in line! (9am-1pm) Went for the intention of breakfast and basically got lunch. 

I ordered the salmon scramble and it was just ok. There was not much eggs and barely any salmon. My friend who ordered the Monte Cristo really liked it. Maybe it's just because I ordered the wrong thing? I'm from SoCal and I thought Mama's would be unique but I have had way better American style breakfast. 

+ friendly staff & service 
+ you order as you wait in line inside & pay at the register before being seated 
- there is another wait once you get into the place! 
- limited seating
author: Cindy L.

description:
Short & sweet: 

Service: 5
Food: 5
Wait time: 3, but we knew it was popular. 
Price: 5
Cleanliness of bathroom: 3 (it's tiny). 


So you've walked up Telegraph Hill, up the millions of stairs, hit Coit Tower, looked out at the beautiful city that is San Francisco, and you think, Oh shucks, I'm famished! (said in hillbilly voice, because what other voice would utter 'oh shucks'?) 

Worry no more. Walk down Coit Tower steps and head on over to Washington Park where you will see Mama's situated on the corner. 

And then you will stand in line for a good twenty or thirty minutes (perhaps longer). Lucky you, you probably have an i-something gadget to keep you company; I didn't so I said, "I'm hungry I'm hungry I'm hungry," until my companion told me to shove it. 

"I'm waiting outside the restaurant, partially in the sun, to get into this restaurant the size of my left nostril.... is it even worth it?" 

YES, yes it is. 

Our Monte Cristo sandwich was sweet and perfect (the way it ought to be) and was great foil to our other entree, a Salmon Eggs Benedict. 

We walked out stuffed and happy.
author: Alice K.

description: Waited about 90 minutes on Sunday for some serious brunch action. We each ordered two entrees, coffee, and coffee cake to go (which they recommended we microwave a bit when ready to consume). It was worth every calorie, and service was friendly, although not flawless. I would definitely make the trek again.
author: Kelly P.

description:
"I hope we only have to wait an hour," says my roommate before we walk over to Mama's on a Saturday morning for brunch. "Wow, I don't think I've ever said that I'd be happy to wait only an hour for food before," she added.

Yeaaa...we waited for an hour and a half or so. That's pretty typical on a Saturday morning. So really, be prepared to wait and bring something to read, an iPhone to play games on, or good company to talk to. I was recommended to come try this place for brunch, and since I was staying close enough to Mama's, I figured I shouldn't pass up this golden opportunity. 

As other reviews have said, there are just a couple things to keep in mind:
1. WAIT. A long time. Unless you come at like 7:30 or something crazy probably.
2. CASH ONLY. Don't depend on their ATM machine.
3. ORDER/PAY FIRST. 
4. Daily/Weekend Specials. Amazing.

Onto the food...

ORDERED:
[Dungeness Crab and Spinach Eggs Benedict]--weekend special. This was sooo delicious! I normally don't like too much liquid yolky egg, but wow these eggs benedict were so good! The spinach and crab went well together!
