At 10AM on a Friday morning, we tried eating at Mama's to only be met with a long line.  After five minutes, we decided to leave because the locals behind us kept ranting about about how "tourists really suck because it means locals have to wait in line" (except much more crude).  

We came back the next day at 7:55AM (before they opened) and there was already a line!  However we got in easily and was able to put in an order at the counter.  We sat down and the waitresses brought us our food and beverages.  
  
I ended up ordering the Brioche French Toast with fresh berries, where the brioche bread contained pecans, walnuts, and raisins.  Unfortunately, it was a little disappointing because the bread itself was dry.  The saving grace was their homemade olallieberry jam -- I recommend putting that on top instead of the syrup.    

The chocolate crumb cake on the other hand was magnificent!  It had wonderful texture -- moist cake that was chewy and crumbly all at once.  

Although I adored their olallieberry jam and crumb cake, plus the wait staff was helpful and attentive, I can't justify the wait in line or the extra trip.
author: Calvin Y.

description:
What is up with this hype? I came here in the hopes of having a mind blowing experience like everyone says and after waiting in an hour+ line, this was just a typical basic brunch place. The food was on par with the chain Stack's so why is everyone freaking out? 

If you are looking for awesome Brunch, you are better off going to Ella's or Zazie.
author: Molly G.

description:
Very good solid brunch but I'm not sure if I would ever wait 2 hours for it. We came here for brunch on Sunday at 1:30pm and still had to wait over an hour...there's only about 10 tables.  I like the efficient system of customers ordering at the counter and then getting seated so that by the time you get seated, your food will come out shortly (this didn't really work for us because we ended up having to wait 15-20 mins for our food after we got seated). The prices are reasonable for San Francisco but they give very generous portions and the food is delicious.

Egg White Scramble - $9.50
-Large serving of eggs (I ordered egg whites...extra $1.50) with spinach and mushrooms. Comes with slices of tomatoes. Their rye bread is great and goes well with their homemade marionberry jam. 

Kugelhopf - $7.95
-Brioche french toast. My boyfriend ordered this and seemed to enjoy it. Good brioche but average french toast. Dish becomes $9.50 if you want fresh fruits on it.

Shrimp Omelette - $12.50
-Delicious! Lots of shrimp in the omelette. 

Overall, solid brunch but nothing spectacular...the typical one to two hour wait will deter me from coming here regularly.
author: Angela F.

description:
Average food. Cute interior. Huge line at opening. Long wait most of the time. 

The best time to go if you live nearby is right around 3pm weekdays. Get in right before they close. That's the only time I've been able to get in under 30 minutes.
author: Emily R.

description: This super cute joint is totally the place to make your inner breakfast fantasies a reality.  My sister and I waited for over an hour for brunch on Saturday and our frost bitten fingers are not complaining.  The French toasts are so amazing that I think I will dream of them often.  The waiter will bring you this fruit preserve dip that is to die for.  The eggs in the eggs benedict were perfectly done and so fresh.  It's cash only and they don't take rsvps.  Seriously a must do when in San Fran!!!
author: Nisha D.

description: We tried french toast sampler and veggie bene and the food was yum.I would give 4* for food. However, would I wait again for 1.5 hr in line to get inside - probably not. They take no reservations and have no way of taking down name to text/call you when your turn comes so if you wanna get in you have to stay in queue. I would deduct 1* for wait and service.
author: A S.

description: Yes the wait is long. ~1 hour wait on Saturday 11:30am but it was worth it. We ordered a few things but the winner is most definitely their famous Monte Cristo. You dip the warm ham/cheese filled sandwich in their homemade strawberry jam and the flavors work so well together. Love the service and people there. Seems like this restaurant dates way back in the days when they sold smoothies for $1. Also their old fashioned crumb cake they sold where you order was really yummy!!!
author: Sandy C.

description:
A minimum 1-2 hour wait.  Worth it? Crazily enough, yes. 
 
Beyond the hype, the food and service at Mama's was amazing.  Their servers and staff are super friendly and warm despite hoardes of irate tourists and wannabe food bloggers streaming through for hours on end.

The little sis and I went overboard and sampled their French Toast, Blueberry Pancakes and Salmon Eggs Benedict.  Every dish was incredible, but the pancakes took the 'cake'!

Best pancakes I've ever had.  Fluffy yet substantial, not overly doughy.  The blueberry compote and syrup was delicious.

If you have the time, get in line and enjoy yourself.  Doors open at 8, from memory.  If you turn up at 8.15am, expect to wait at least an hour ;).  If you arrive after 9am, the line is a GOOD 2 hour wait.
author: Jon Z.

description: Great place! I've lived on the corner of Filbert and Stockton for 7 plus years and come here at least once a month.. High recommended, the wait is worth every bite!
author: Victor V.

description: Two lines, one outside to get in, one inside to order at the counter. Then a line to wait for your table to open up. Then, a long wait to get your food. I mean, I understand why tourists would wait for something that's popular, but the food isn't spectacular. I prefer Zazie over this, and the wait isn't half as bad. My friend and I shared a M'Omelette and Crab Benedict, and I have nothing to say beyond that. Maybe the french toast is better, but this didn't seem worth the wait. Oh, and that order came out to $41.60. Oi.
author: Danny C.

description: Skip. Food is ok, line is usually not worth the wait. Touristy spot, so if you are not a fan of that vibe, move on.
author: Robert W.

description: The food was really good I will be back just prepare to stand in line to get in the build for at least 30 minutes or more and in line once you get inside for another 10 to 20 minutes before you pay and get seated. Other then the excessive standing and waiting it was worth it.
author: Love G.

description:
The line is ridiculous, even on a cold and rainy day!  Once you get in, the French Toast Sampler is a must-try.  It includes 3 different types of breads covered in egg batter and grilled.  The sampler breads vary from week to week, but all are light, fluffy, and delicious.  They use breads that I never thought of in making into a French toast, like banana nut bread or cinnamon bread.  The French toasts are delicious enough that additional syrup or jam is not necessary.  I also tried a dungeness crab and avocado brioche sandwich, which was a special that day, and it was very satisfying too.

1/2 star off: They only take cash.  When you order several items from an enticing menu, the bill can surely add up.  Be sure to check your wallet before ordering.
1/2 star off: To get to the bathroom, you have to walk past the guys cooking in the kitchen, go outside, go downstairs, and close an old sliding door.  It is somewhat inconvenient and unhygienic, especially on a cold and rainy day.  You would think that a restaurant where folks gather to stuff themselves will have a better bathroom set-up...
author: Ally W.

description: Wow! Such good brunch food. The south of the border omelette was delicious (a little greasy) but hey what do you expect with chorizo. My boyfriend got the Monte Cristo, i  tasted it, and I honestly might have to get this dish the next time I come here. Both plates came with seasoned potatoes and those were also yum. My favorite part about the food was the fresh jam!!! DAMN, it was fresh, tangy and tasted like raspberries. The French toast looked beautiful and I'll have to try it soon. The ambiance of the place was cute, super hip. Besides the long wait, it was awesome, the server was sweet and so was the pretty blonde girl who took our order at the register. A little pricey if you're on a short budget but nevertheless very worth it!!!
author: Homa K.

description:
Worth the wait no matter how long you gotta wait. I was starving but waited for approximately 2 hours before I got into the restaurant. The biggest take away from this experience would be: BE PATIENT AND WAIT. I simply loved, enjoyed, and appreciated every single plate I had here. 

Tip: Come with several friends and share so you get to try different plates. :)
author: Cmi H.

description:
"Hey hon, there's a place that I wanna try for breakfast tomorrow morning, they open at 8 am"  That's how it all started, a search on Yelp for a breakfast place on Sunday morning before heading out to the 9er's game. My wife had the great idea of walking to Mama's on Sunday morning, not a problem, it was only about 1.6 miles from our hotel in DTSF, BUT we left the hotel at 9:20 am! When we arrived at about 10 am, there was a line, wasn't too bad, BUT I didn't realize how small Mama's is!
I know most locals think it's over rated (had a few passersby that yelled out "It's over rated!" We waited in line for 2 HOURS!!!! I am so glad I ate that banana before we left the hotel!
I must admit, I am a tourist and I like to visit the touristy spots, but I need to know if the food is worth it, I can honestly say, the food is good enough to wait in line for, BUT not for 2 hours. If I ever went back, I would wait 30 minutes max. This review is for food only, because a business shouldn't be dinged because I was stupid enough to wait in line for 2 hours or that there is no parking, etc.
So for the food:
I ordered the original crumb cake. The cake was moist and the crumb part was not too dry nor was it overtly sweet. A really good crumb cake=4.5
I was debating on so many choices, but went with the Farmers Omelette: 
Smoked Bacon, Baby Spinach, Grilled Leeks and Sonoma Goat Cheese $10.50, I opted for egg whites. The Omelette was well balance with all the ingredients, very tasty and the egg whites were made perfect. The Mama's Grilled Potatoes were bit crunchy outside, but nice and soft inside. I chose the sourdough baguette and it was really great sourdough bread. Farmers Omelette=4.5
I had regular coffee=4
I can't rate my wife's food based on my taste, but she really enjoyed The Californian Omelette: Crispy Bacon, Avocado, and Monterey Jack Cheese $10.25
She also agreed that this place is worth a 30 minute, maybe 45 minute wait.
So, all in all, it was really good. Not the best, but really good.
Ladies, if your hubby, bf or whoever invites you to Mama's, let them know "They open at 8 am!!!!"
author: Loren L.

description:
Orange juice is super fresh, literally squeezed seconds before it was served. Staff is friendly, witty and funny. Be prepared to wait an hour and a half to two (2) hours on the weekend if you want to eat here. But it's worth it dude. Food is out of control good.

Make sure to get the Cranberry Orange French Toast, real Monte Cristo, Crab Benedict, and definitely a glass of orange juice. Iconic restaurant that is great to visit. Just get there as early as possible. Brunch times on a weekend will make for a 2 hour wait outside just to get in.
author: Heath W.

description: It's definitely a long wait so be prepared. Once you get in you order and pay at a window before sitting down. They don't accept credit or debit cards on the weekends. I ordered the Norwegian Benedict, which had smoked salmon and that was great. I also got the French toast sampler, which wasn't anything to write home about. Overall, I feel like there are better places with less of a wait.
author: Asia F.

description: Worth the 2 hour wait to eat their delicious monte cristo.
author: A L.

description:
Our friend came from out of town and she decided she wanted Mama's for brunch. Sounds good to me! 

The serving style is pretty cool - it's a counter for ordering (but with glass panes so you can see what they're making) and seating around a pretty cozy restaurant area. Great bloody marys and really good food but be aware of parking/wait. I had to head out and feed the meter just to make sure we didn't get a ticket. Otherwise, YUM! 

Had smoked salmon benedict...so good!
author: Jennifer J.

description: we came for breakfast again on our last visit to the city. Still great and worth the wait for a special treat. Delicious food and warm service. They don't ever make you feel rushed. Eggs Benedict and all the French toast are done superbly. The crumb cakes too!
author: Lisa P.

description: Great food and service! Despite the 45 minute wait, the food was absolutely worth it. The vegetarian omelette with goat cheese was huge portion that was very filling. The wait staff was extremely friendly and warm. Will visit again next time I'm in the area!
author: Lily S.

description:
Worth the 1.5 hour wait!

I had a special -- Dungeness Crab Benedict with Baby Spinach -- which was totally delicious. Although an expensive breakfast (~$30) it was pretty epic. Huge chunks of crab, a perfectly poached egg, and excellently cooked spinach leaves. The home fries were awesome, especially with a little ketchup. 

My mom ordered the Crab Omelette with Avocado, Tomato, and Havarti. My dad got a Crab Cake Benedict. Everyone left pleased. 

We also shared an order of Buttermilk pancakes. They were among the best I ever had - fairly small (which I liked). The syrup and raspberry jam were awesome accompaniments.

The service was good for what it was (bringing out water and meals, bussing tables quickly). Everyone working here seemed friendly and happy.

An unexpected bonus with the meal was my general feeling about myself afterward. Despite how delicious the food was and how much I stuffed myself full of it, it didn't leave me with the disgusting feeling I usually have after eating a ton of brunch food. Presumably, this was due to excellent use of kitchen techniques that relied less on butter and grease and more on fresh ingredients and attentive cooking.

Will definitely be back...ideally earlier in the day to avoid the ridiculous wait.
author: Greg K.

description:
Probably one of the best places to get breakfast in SF. Then why the 3 stars? because thats not saying much.  I have yet to try brenda's, but I would sya Mamams trails behind both Zazzie's and Dottie's and also Big Joes. I ordered pancakes with a side of bacon. The pancakes were about ten bucks more or less and were tiny! almost Silver Dollar hotcakes.  Their coffee is watery and the seating is kind of cramped.  

They don't really wait tables. Its strange. You wait in a line wrapped around the door because of hipster word of mouth, and then take your order at the register and then wait to be seated in a very crapped space with movies table bussers and patrons. 

When you are seated you just wait for your food to come. The place is about presentation I suppose morose than it is about food.  The surrounding neighborhood is filled with 60's headband wearing, bandana print leggings sporting, cowboy boots and flower dress rocking chicks with their thick black glasses wearing, tiny shirt, boxers exposed skinny jeans wearing boyfriends. They don't mind dropping more than average prices for mediocre food. The place is cute. And if you like putting on fake smiles and pretending to be pleased to impress people you are with then this is the place for you.
author: Vinny T.

description:
I always wondered about that ridiculously long line outside Mama's so I decided to get a to-go order to see what the hype was about.   the turnaround time was not too bad, around 10 - 15 minutes 

Monte cristo 
- be prepared for a super heavy breakfast!  I tried eating 1/2 of my sandwich and gave my coworker 1/4 and he could barely finish it himself.
- BUTTER, MAYO, EGGs  - there was so much of it that the inner sandwich was soggy / creamy
- overall it was a-ok ...but i would not have it again

Potatoes
- crispy, well seasoned, and moist!  excellent job for breakfast potatoes, unlike the usual frozen then deep fried type stuff

if the montee cristo was less soggy and they did not give me an expired package of brown ketchup i would be a little more happy.  maybe i'll give this place another try when i'm in the mood for a heavy meal
author: Tina A.

description: The food is outstanding!! You have to get there early to get in, but it is worth the wait! Fresh food, good service and reasonable prices... What else can you ask for? Give it a try... The locals know about Mama's
author: Karl M.

description: We were at Mama's on a Thursday morning during Spring break.   The food was unique and exceptional.  The Apple Pan Dore was incredible,  especially with a little raspberry jam.   We also loved the Farmer omelet and the orange cranberry French toast.   We got there at 8:05 and ordered and had been seated by 8:50.  Everyone at Mama's was friendly and we all wanted to go back the next day.
author: Arnie Q.

description:
Absolutely a must try when in sf. The line was long as expected , the patience tested and the challenge of getting to be seated seems to take forever , but ... Once the dungeoness crab cake Benedict and the montecristo was trotted in front of our table, forget it ! Transformed to a breakfast bliss like no other.
The gruyere cheese and the triangular bite size sandwich was like no other! This monte Cristo is a win.
For the crab cake , the actual crab meat was sweet and tasty and the flavor complemented with the potatoes that came with it .
After the meal , there was no feeling of fullness that's disgusting but light and satisfied.
Go and take The mama's challenge .. Should you wish to dare.. You won't regret it !
author: Nelce S.

description:
BEST BREAKFAST FOOD EVER!!! So i've been to Mama's several time, each time I am prepared to wait in line for at least an hour! But it is definitely worth the wait! I tried their sandwiches before, delicious! But definitely their breakfast food is way better! They have this french toast sampler, I love it! Usually its three flavor of the day, and its never a disappointment. The egg Benedict is delicious and savory. Just thinking about it makes my mouth watery! I had the omelette and it was pretty good but the french toast is where its at!

Mama's is a pretty cozy restaurant, great for breakfast and brunch, and no matter what time you go. Its going to be busy! Their servers are quite friendly and even if its busy they make sure you get the attention you need. Asking if you need refills or if you need condiments, they are the best! I would definitely go here if you have some time to wait for good food, but be warn you are going to have to wait and its not going to be a disappointment. Great place to go with friends, family , or someone special!
author: Amy T.

description: I tried Mama's at 2p on a Friday and still had to wait half an hour in line. I ordered the yogurt french toast with fresh fruit. However, the french toast was very dense and doughy. My server was understanding, said that the yogurt french toast was her least favorite dish, and let me exchange it for something else. She recommended the egg dishes so I tried the eggs benedict, but the hollandaise sauce was sour. I have never had sour hollandaise sauce before, wasn't sure if it was spoiled, but didn't want to send a second dish back. I think I should've tried the Monte Cristo, but am not sure I'd want to wait in line for Mama's again. I did find the Monte Cristo recipe online: http://www.foodnetwork.com/recipes/saras-secrets/monte-cristo-sandwich-recipe/index.html
author: Diana B.

description: I know why this place is popular with tourists and locals. The breakfast items are really good! Just be patient with waiting. We waited 20 minutes outside and 20 minutes inside the restaurant before ordering our food. The kitchen is extremely small with 3-4 guys making the food. My hubby got the crab benedict and loved it since there were chunks of fresh crab. This was an expensive dish for $20 which was a bit overpriced, but at least he liked it! I had the sampler trio of French toast with cranberry orange, walnut, and another type of bread. Love the homemade jam that was on the table. I used the jam as my syrup since it was so awesome! Cash only.
author: Jackie S.

description:
We will never, ever visit SF again without a visit to Mama's.  This is breakfast perfection.  

We visited with our two teens and arrived at about 715, 45 minutes before opeining.  Even then, we were second in line.  My two teens thought we were crazy to wait for breakfast, but they left as believers.

I ordered the crab cake omelette on a friend's recommendation.  Unfortunately, they don't make such a thing.  They did have a crab cake benedict.  After some negotiation, the lady taking orders conceded to make an crab cake omelette with havarti and avocado.  "Make sure you let me know how it is" she said.  

Well, let me say that this was thing of beauty.  The eggs perfectly cooked as always.  The crab cake just crunchy enough to add a new dynamic to the omelette.  Wow, just wow.  Was well worth the $27 price tag.  When I told the lady how good it was, she asked for my name and said it might show up on the menu, so if you order a "Jeff's Omelette", that's me!  (Aren't you proud of me, mom?!)

As for the rest of the meal, potatoes cooked perfectly with a nice crunch and the perfect amount of onion.  The remainder of our party reqported equally fabulous meals (though none might get their name on the menu.  Hah!

It's really a good thing we don't live closer or we'd be at the head of the line every day!
author: Jeff S.

description: best salmon I've ever had, monte cristo is the perfect combination of sweet and savory, crab cake eggs Benedict is amazing .... If you're going to wait 2 hours- get everything you're craving. It's totally worth the wait.
author: Mayra M.

description:
I am almost ashamed to admit that the wait was worth it, and everything that came with it - the sun scorching my face while I waited in line for over an hour, the 17 quarters I spent on the parking meter, the carbs I had to work off later that day. All of it. 

In fact, I took a vacation day from work the Tuesday after Labor Day thinking the wait would not be so bad mid-week. But I when I got there, the line was 30-deep. But I was there and I wasn't turning back now.

It was hard to choose but we went with:
- Monte Cristo: Ham and cheese sandwiched between french toast and grilled, so that the ham and cheese oozes out with every bite. Such a deliciously genius invention! I want to make babies with the Monte Cristo. I love it so much.
- French Toast Sampler: Walnut bread, banana bread, or cinnamon bread? In my usual gluttonous fashion, I could not decide one ONE so I opted for all three and got the sampler. I didn't even need to use syrup. The raspberries, strawberries and blueberries added the perfect amount of sweetness.
- Washington Square Mom-elette: A sausage, cheese and pepper omelette the size of Washington Square. I had two bites and surrendered. *raises white flag*

Their house breads are amazing. We tried carrot cake and blueberry sour cream bread and both were really moist and fluffy. I would come back for that alone.

I also must say that the service here is fantastic. Although you have a dedicated server, several staff members came by regularly to check on us, refill our iced teas and bring to-go boxes. And with a smile. 

So it is worth it? Yes. But bring your appetite and LOTS of quarters.
author: Mariela D.

description:
As a resident now living in one of the greatest city in the world, I've got to say San Francisco is definitely known to have some of the greatest eats,  has some passionate food lovers that will wait hours just to have a taste of heaven.

And last Sunday, I definitely became one of these crazy foodies who waited in line for 1 hour and 24 mins just to see what this hype is about. Thank God I wasn't hungover or starving, I would've thrown a fit if I had to wait in line for an hour for food, regretting the irresponsible decisions I made the night before. It was a gorgeous Indian summer day in early October, wearing shorts and tank top, what more can I ask for?

Finally, we made our way in this cozy little brunch place. 
Food:
Pancetta with red and yellow bell pepper egg benedict  - creamy hollandaise sauce with perfectly cooked runny yolk.  
Egg white only Californian omelette 
Chocolate cinnamon french toast with fresh fruits - a perfect way to finish this yummy brunch with some fluffy french toasts drizzled with maple syrup and fresh berries. 
Excellent service here, all the servers are super friendly!

Will I come back again? DEFINITELY! But I will most likely make smarter choices to come here right before 3pm closing time so I don't have to wait too long!
author: Mindy C.

description:
Pretty good. lol got their famous MonteCristo which after much argument they were willing to modify so instead of ham it would have turkey. Honestly, it was very heavy, over fried, but despite those issues, it was pretty good. A few things to note though:
1- The crazy lines are definitely not worth it.
2- They are so freaking busy and in a rush that service is not great and you cannot customize almost anything.
3- It's really cramped in there, so if you're going for relaxing brunch experience -not the place
author: Amir M.

description:
My first meal during this recent SF trip was a trip to Mama's. I have a rather list of SF bookmarks, and Mama's was the first to go. I was dreading a long line, but 1 hour from the time we started waiting in line to the time we started eating wasn't too bad. Plus it was a weekday. I don't think I could've handled anything longer.

Once inside, it was a well-oiled machine. After a long line outside, then there's another mini line inside, where you can watch the cooks crank out breakfast before paying at the register. After paying, then the waitress directs you where to sit.

My wife and I both had the specials -- I had the crab benedict while she had the crab omelet. Each of these dishes were a shade under $20, and along with a side of bacon, tax and tip, we're talking about a $50 breakfast for 2 here. We were given a table for 2 right by the door -- where minutes earlier I commented, I hope we don't get that table.

I didn't want to be gawked at by the people waiting in line, but it wasn't the case at all. Besides, I was too busy stuffing my face with crab to even notice. The crab benedict was good, and surprisingly not too heavy. The crab omelet was light and fluffy, and both dishes were stuffed with fresh crab meat. The side of bacon came with 5 crispy and thick pieces -- and nice salty contrast to everything else.

So was it worth the money and wait? It all depends. If you wait in a long line for something, you hope it's good in the end. The food at Mama's was good, but nothing earth shattering. Breakfast is breakfast. Mama's has everything down like a well oiled machine, and service was efficient and friendly. Solid 4 stars from me.
author: Dru C.

description:
went there with my family after 3 unsuccessful tentative; was always too busy, and finally at the 4th try we manage to enter. So the place is really small and narrow, but the atmosphere is really cozy.
We took some pancakes, omelettes and some cakes.
Overall is really good, the salmon omelette was a delish, the pancake maybe too thick for my liking and the chocolate too sweet. their homemade jam is the bomb, like seriously. 
Is it worth the line; well i would say that Mama's is not just a mere breakfast place, i mean doing 1h or queue in the morning is not usual; it's also a touristic place so yeah it worth the line, but im not sure i will come back, you can probably have the same worth breakfast in San Francisco without the wait.
author: Meryl J.

description:
We waited 3+ hours on memorial weekend. The most annoying thing is the lack of line etiquette from fellow patrons. Apparently having one person in your 6 person party wait while you galavant around SF is acceptable, as long as you arrive by the time they're at the front of the line.

The food was good, but not worth the wait at all. We ordered the monte cristo and Dungeness crab omelette. The raspberry preserves with the monte cristo made the sandwich. Fresh squeezed lemonade was refreshing. 

Dirty silverware didn't help the rating.

Bring cash if you don't want to pay a $1 surcharge or in case their debit machine goes down
author: Charlotte M.

description:
I was a little weary coming here considering most yelpers mentioned how long the wait was...2 hours!? #icant. But I decided to take a chance and I'm glad I did.  If you want to avoid the lines come around 2:30PM. I think we waited for around 20 minutes. 

Once inside it's super small but charming at the same time. I made the mistake of ordering an omelet when I KNEW I should have gotten the doggone french toast. (Forehead slap). 

Omelet is--sad to say--extremely average. I was over the moon for the perfectly cooked potatoes that came with it and the raspberry jam on my toast was amazing. (BTW--I owe me trying that jam to a super cool older guy who was standing in line before us. 

My boyfriend was the genius in our trip today. He ordered the cinnamon toast and I almost ate all of his! (Sorry baby!) 

The orange juice was fresh and epic. 

One thing I found odd was the owner appeared to be extremely brash and I found myself daydreaming about accidentally on purpose pouring water on him.

Another odd note was the bathroom. If peeling in an outhouse is your thing--you picked a GREAT spot. 

Tips summed up:
Come around 2:30PM
Use the bathroom before hand 
Stay away from the omelets 
Order the French toast 
Order the orange juice 
Try the raspberry jam by any means necessary.
author: Antoinette B.

description: Just went this morning and enjoyed the food people kept talking about. Everything is fresh and cooked on point. Of course the only bad part is having to arrive before 7:30 AM or else you'll wait in line but overall well worth the visit.
author: Jimmy M L.

description: Favoritr place to eat brunch! That says a lot since im not a breakfast person. My #1 is the monte cristo. I love the fact that you can see the chefs cooking your food because you know its fresh. I love that their side bread is from boudin and their homemade jelly is amazing! The hour wait is worth it.
author: Francina O.

description: The best time to go for brunch is around 2 pm on weekdays - that way you can avoid the long time in the line. The French Toast sampler was FABULOUS!!! The rest of the food was alright but not worth the line... So get the french toast! The staff was really friendly and chatty too.
author: Lisa L.

description: Is it worth the wait? Some may say. It's really hard for me to decide. I think I got a tan from waiting in line for 2 hours. The customer service was phenomal! From the cashier, bus boy, and waitress, we were treated so kindly and warmly. It felt like a Sunday family brunch. I ordered the Dungeness Crab benedict. They are very generous with the amount of crab in it! It was a delicious meal. Everyone in our party enjoyed their food. I wouldn't mind to come back but I'm making sure the line isn't so long.
author: Cheryl P.

description:
Most recently had a lunch date with my mom. The wait was exactly as I remembered. LONG! (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/MvAo0hj9FXOeNL5PwBZ0fQ?select=WiqSXrSFiPpYQX0pTbAVrA)

SERVICE: After you've waited in the line to get in, and waited again in the line to order, you wait again for seats to open up. The wait staff gets the job done. You want ketchup/tabasco, they get it. You get low on coffee, they fill it up. Not at ninja levels, but ey, it's a brunch place.

FOOD:
SMOKED SALMON BENEDICT -- I'm a fan of smoked salmon. I'm a fan of benedict. Put em together, not bad but there are better benedicts out there.. like their crab benedict. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/MvAo0hj9FXOeNL5PwBZ0fQ?select=-f6XgsPRBqP6FqiD6MjsDA)
DUNGENESS CRAB OMELETTE w/avocado, gruyere -- Delicious! I generally don't order omelettes, but when I saw them take a grip of crab... *drool* Not too cheesy. A little greezy. All delicious. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/MvAo0hj9FXOeNL5PwBZ0fQ?select=vjQ_GGxF16TqZy0sUMKpYw)

TIPS: 
-Come before 11 for a decent wait. Afterwards, expect at least an hour (weekdays) or a lot more (weekends). Don't come hungry/bored.
-Cash/Debit only. 
-Parking is a beast so drop off your buds so they can start the wait without you. From line to dine, you can be there over 2 hours. Park accordingly.

CONCLUSION: Come out for the delicious, home-made food. Stay for the sights -- very close to St. Paul's Cathedral & Coit Tower, Chinatown/North-Beach, Marina district, Lombard St.
author: Stanley L.

description: Probably useless to make an other comment (indeed it's good). However there is not enough to eat in the plates by comparison to the price.
author: Lonesome T.

description:
Overall: Amazing food, extremely fresh, perfect balance of variety and combination of dishes and cute atmosphere in busy little italian district. 

Food: 3 French toast plate with cran-orange, banana nut, and  another were a delicacy in every bite! 
Crab Omelette- so fresh and tasty one of my favorite dishes especially if you love fresh Crab. 

Recommend: By far one of the best breakfast places in SF, so YES if you don't mind the 20-45 min line for an Outstanding breakfast, worth any wait-time!
author: Nate M.

description:
I hate to be a nay-sayer, but for me, my experience was not worth the 2.5 hour long wait and I was honestly a little saddened, if not slightly disappointed. The Yelpers' reviews are what kept me patient, hopeful and eager, and once inside I felt giddy and excited like I had accomplished something, even if it was only standing in line for what felt like forever....

But the food was just okay- 1) Monte Cristo: yes, you gave me some tasty mouth tingles, but potatoes?! why you so burnt and puny??? 2) Dungeness Crab Benedict: I believed in you and told my bf to get the more expensive version of you because I thought it would be special! but I just did not really taste much of anything... 

Perhaps it was an off day, or a fluke, but with wait times the way they are, I just don't see myself coming back to give it another try.

*CASH OR DEBIT CARD ONLY.* Bring an umbrella to stand under if possible- the sun can be brutal when you're waiting. * Have a partner or two and take turns holding your spot in line- you can wander around Washington Square, or search for coffee or pastries in the surrounding cafes to tide you over while you wait. * Maybe play some Charade games with the people around you. * Or I guess if you're not a technological dinosaur like me, aren't bothered by screen glare, love neck cricks and ignoring your friends- you can play on your phone. * Or come super duper early. We came at 9:00am and they open at 8:00am if that gives you any idea how crazy it gets. 

Good Luck!
author: Allison C.

description:
As two people on a road trip, we wanted to try as many new places as we could for our meals.  We didn't expect the wait to be an hour in line in the hot sun, but did it anyway since we were on foot and there weren't any other good breakfast spots around.

We are very glad we waited because the breakfast turned out to be amazing.  My fiancee got the Shrimp Benedict that was loaded with avocado and shrimp, and lots of side potatoes.  I got the french toast sampler, complete with cinnamon, banana nut, and cranberry orange french toast, all home made breads.  It was amazing.  We were served quickly once getting inside and out the door in 30 minutes.  It was worth waiting that long and you don't have to stay around forever to appreciate this historic breakfast spot.
author: Andrew C.

description: Speechless. The food was incredible! Worth all the time we waited outside in line. Very fresh food made in front of your eyes
author: Mariana A.

description: Tried this place when I was visiting a friend in San Francisco. The wait was a bit too long, and the food did not live up to the hype. It's just another breakfast place, similar to most average diner in New York.
author: Rezaul K.

description:
We were visiting San Francisco and on a food tour when we first saw Mama's.  We noticed a huge line down the sidewalk for the smallish restaurant.  Our tour guide never made mention of it, but we looked it up when we got back to the hotel room.  What we found was that Mama's was touted as "the best breakfast in San Francisco."  Naturally, we had to go see what it was about...just not on the weekend.  

We went on a Tuesday morning, thankfully just before crowd that came in after us.  I was surprised that you order at a counter and then are seated, but I guess that keeps the line moving!  Thankfully, they have a nice dining room to make up for it.  The restaurant is decorated just like my grandma's kitchen was.  Every table has a different flowered plastic table cloth and there are tchotkes on the wall.  

I tried the Eggs Benedict with prosciutto and tomatoes.  And, yes, it was amazing.  I loved that the prosciutto was shredded instead of just one big slice.  It made it so much more flavorful, easier to chew, and cooked better that way.  The accompanying breakfast potatoes were delicious, too, and I love any place that automatically brings me hot sauce with my meal!  The service was fantastic and everyone from the greeter to the cashier to our server was extra friendly.  That's hard to do when you're crazy busy all day.  

On the way out, I noticed the specials that were posted by the door.  I wish I had seen them earlier because I didn't notice them at the counter when you order.  As delicious as my breakfast was, I might have tried one of the unique breakfast specials they had.  Oh well...there's always next trip.
author: Eric K.

description:
The awesome thing about funemployment (besides waking up late and not working) is we have the luxury of going to popular brunch places midweek to avoid the ridiculous lines!  We arrived at Mama's around 2:30pm and there was no line and plenty of open tables.  I'm sure to many who have been to Mama's at its peak hours, it must've look like a ghost town.  Being newbies to Mama's we were unsure of how it worked here, but we were promptly directed to the ordering counter by the friendly staff.  I ordered the Monte Cristo and the mister ordered the Kugelhopf French toast.  

Service was super friendly and the food arrived quickly.  I can see why so many folks love it here as Mama's offers some solid breakfast/brunch staples.  The food is pretty normal breakfast/brunch fare though--nothing to write home about.  I really enjoyed the monte cristo even though in one of the quarters, the cheese was not melted at all.  The roasted potatoes were alright.  The Mr.'s French toast was tasty, but again, nothing super special.  The portions were perfect, as we didn't leave overly full.  Overall, good food, but I would never wait in line for it.
author: Thi D.

description:
Worth the wait for this gem!
We enjoyed the crab omelet and northern Italian omelet.
The friendly staff took the time to explain the menu and highlight personal and popular favorites as well as the history of the place. 
Great experience!
author: Gabriel D.

description: If heaven served breakfast if would be catered by Mamas. This place is just perfection. We ordered Blackstone Benedict, Cinnamon And Chocolate French Toast, Mango and Strawberry Bellini and an Omelet. Everything was delicious, the service check up on us regularly and the food came promptly. We only waited 35 minutes on a Friday morning. You must try the jam! Ultimately, this is the best breakfast I've ever had
author: Connie D.

description:
If there were only two words one needed to know in the English vocabulary, "Monte Cristo" (or should I say French vocabulary?) is all that's necessary when venturing to Mama's. 

While they offer a wide selection of sumptuous fare, from their well renowned french toast to a host of delectable sandwiches, the Monte Cristo deliciously incorporates the best of both worlds. It consists of turkey breast, baked ham, havarti, and cheddar cheese packed between slices of bread then dipped in egg and grilled. When eaten with the homemade berry jam that's provided at each table, my taste buds are slapped with yummy goodness and my lips literally stretch in a wide grin of joy. In fact, other offerings at Mama's, namely the French Toast Sampler, have fallen short when compared to the wondrous Monte Cristo smothered in homemade jam. 

Although it goes without saying that a long wait can be expected regardless of when you come (weekdays included), don't let this keep you at bay. For residents and visitors alike, Mama's is something everybody should experience at least once. It's also wise to note that while debit cards are accepted (no credit cards), there is a service fee associated with it, so try to bring cash instead. 

Next on my hit list? Their Dungeness Crab Benedict! And I will surely be back to check it off. 4 stars!
author: Natasha H.

description: This place is to die for with super delish dishes and great service.  Problem is you may die before you get in the door and seated - it so popular that the line to get in can stretch down the street.  You would think they had the only stock of iPhone 6's in the Bay Area?  Anyway, when you get in your eyes start to roll with the sights of the super food and all kinds of people going GaGa over everything - me too!  My Monte Cristo was super and grilled, not fried.  You can have your French Toast made with any one of the fantastic Grommet Breads or from a variety of them - Rolling Back Your Eyes again!
author: Maria D.

description:
I can't believe I haven't written a review for Mama's yet! But oh man, this is my favorite place to get breakfast. The wait is really ridiculous, but it just makes the food taste even ten times better! No matter when you go during their open hours, you'll have to wait. My favorite thing to get here, well the only dish I've ever gotten here, is their Shrimp Benedict, which is their weekend special. It is sooo amazing!! All the ingredients just taste delicious together. If I wasn't enough of a fatty, I always ask for an extra side of hollandaise sauce to dip my potatoes in (genius, I know!). I've also tried their french toast whenever my friends get it, and I love that they top it with a ton of fresh berries. I think that's what makes everything taste so yummy, its the fresh ingredients!

One day when I'm a baller, I will definitely order their Crab Benedict, which sounds amazing as well. For now, I will stick to my usual order which never disappoints me. I love Mama's!
author: Marilyn W.

description:
Dungeness Crab Benedict. Enough said. 

Came here on a Friday afternoon with my boyfriend and luckily waited no more than 15 minutes. We ordered the infamous Dungeness Crab Benedict to share and two grapefruit mimosas. The Dungeness Crab Benedict was just shy of $20 (a bit pricey), but it was, I kid you not, really THAT good. The crab, poached egg and spinach were all cooked to "melt-in-your-mouth" perfection, and you can truly taste the freshness of the crab. Not to mention the cafe is just absolutely adorable.
author: Cathy C.

description:
Mama's is soo amazing!! Mama's is as good as it gets for breakfast and brunch in San Francisco!

I've been here 3 times and it has been consistently excellent. Each time we came here, we had to wait in an enormous 2-3 hour line. BUT! It's totally worth the wait!

I've tried the French toast sampler plate, Chocolate cinnamon french toast, Dungeness crab omelette, Northwest omelette (smoked salmon, capers, grilled leek, and creme fraiche), and the Californian omelette.

Every dish I've tried at Mama's was amazing and so so so delicious. The omelettes are extremely fluffy, the home fries are always crispy, and the toast is great. My favorite frech toast is the chocolate cinnamon french toast. The french toast is soft, very moist, and it is paired perfectly with the fresh berries and banana garnished over the dish. The sampler french toast plate is a good option if you want to try all the different french toast varieties Mama's offers, but personally, I like the cinnamon french toast the best.

The service is excellent. Everyone working at the restaurant is cheery and attentive.

The restaurant is very small which will explain why the wait/line to dine is always around 2-3 hours long. There is no waitlist, it is first come first serve, so make sure you plan ahead and arrive early! I would also suggest bringing something to do for the wait in line. My boyfriend always brings a book. : )
author: Monica T.

description: Always a line outside, if less than 40 minutes, then worth the wait. The French toast is so far the best in San Francisco, thick enough to hold the syrup, I had the monte cristo, if you don't eat with the homemade jam, then it is just delicious turkey sandwich, but the jam makes the sandwich to an amazing!
author: Sunny J.

description: I ordered the Monte Cristo, and I honestly didn't think it was anything superb or super special.  Even if it's made with Honeybaked ham, the crispy sweet texture that makes this ham delicious gets lost in the melted cheese.  The battered sandwich is lightly dusted with powdered sugar, which is nice, but the homemade raspberry jam is runny and too tangy for my taste.  The portion is also small for the price.  The wait for this place is way too long--it would be preferable if waiters came to your seats to take your order.  While I was waiting in line, it reminded me of being in front of a dance club that isn't crowded at all inside, but the promoters hold up the line to make it look like the club is the place to be.  Definitely won't be returning any time soon.
author: Monica O.

description:
Oooh boy...where to start.

Long story short: Mama's is NOT worth the wait.

We arrived at 8:10am, and found ourselves at the back of a really lengthy line. Arriving around opening time, we were doomed to wait 2hrs before entering the petit restaurant to order and get seated. For a restaurant to have an "auto-wait" of 2+ hrs (unless you arrive before the sun rises), the food better be worth it!!

The wait was so long that people in line were sending runners to grab coffee at nearby cafes for their group. A few taxis came by, carrying tourists who were asking the people in line how long the wait was or how long they've been waiting. After hearing "1.5hrs", they all got back in their cars/taxis and drove off. Smart decision...

Unfortunately, the food was all (MAJOR) hype, and definitely not worth wasting my time. Reaching the side of the restaurant, I noticed a news article that discussed top tourist destinations - and for SF, they had a long list of destinations to hit... and what's first on the list to start the day? Mama's! Yea... no wonder the hype has skyrocketed!

Upon entering the restaurant, I enjoyed peering into the kitchen, and seeing all the ingredients, breads, and food on the stove, as we waited in a tiny line to order our food. Then we waited to get seating. Waiting, waiting, waiting...

Now to talk food!

I went simple, not giving into hype, and ordered two poached eggs, bacon, potatoes, and toast. Pretty hardy, but not too much. I think they also water down their ketchup, seeing as I tipped that bottle over my potatoes, and that stuff just gushed out! The poached eggs were a bit overcooked, seeing as the yolk was near hard-boiled and gooey.

My girlfriend ordered the Monti Cristo. I have other friends who have spoken highly of the Monti Cristo, and it seems like my girlfriend somewhat enjoyed it. My opinion? Bland, and completely overrated! The sandwich is cut into quarters, before dropped in egg, and then cooked. I perceived this combination as a french toast sandwich, but they don't add cinnamon. It's just egg. Thus, everything seems really bland. I was also surprised they didn't provide maple syrup for the sandwich. Rather, it's served with more jelly... which is already in a canister on the table.

I don't see why the Monti Cristo is so loved, when it's so simple and underwhelming. Anyone could make it, as long as you have a sandwich and eggs. It's also a good think to make after a long night of drinking.

Oh well, after experiencing it once, I could say hands-down that it's NOT worth it! You could try this place out... but you could definitely go to other places, get the same (if not better) food, for a lot less wait-time.
author: Kevin J.

description: Worth the wait!! But get there early because this is one of the best breakfast joints you'll find. I got there about half an hour before opening and there was already about 20 people in line. I got the chocolate chip French toast, and it blew my mind. The food really stands on its own. Everything is fresh and made to order. This place is a must if you're visiting San Francisco.
author: Christopher T.

description: Honestly, it's not as good as what I had expected. It's so not worth it!!!! My friend and me waited for 2 hours and when we got in we had to line up for ordering. It took us about 15 mins. Moreover, when we got to order we could not get what we wanted coz they were not on the menu anymore. Plus, the cashier was kind of impolite with us. More importantly, we saw      flies hovering around the food..... Anyway, it's my personal experience and I have no idea there's been so many reviews. Basically, if you wanna have wonderful brunch, you must check out SWEET MAPLE (near Jp town ) It's so much better than Mama.
author: Jingyi X.

description: Spectacular. The Monte Cristo melts in your mouth. Definitely worth the 1 hour I waited (line, order, wait at table).
author: Mert S.

description:
Got poached eggs, french toast sampler, an omelet, coffee, and juice. The food is good. It's not holy wow this is the best freakin restaurant good, but it was good. I enjoyed it, the atmosphere is nice. The backdoor was open and the weather was nice out. My party and I had a nice time. And I live 2 blocks away so we did it smart and got there at 7:30am on a Thursday and were able to sit down at 8:05am or so.

That is the only way to do it. I repeat. ONLY WAY. If you think this place is worth over 30 minutes in line, you are straight up crazy. I don't know why there is always a line thats over an hour long. Park Tavern is caddy corner to this place and I prefer it to Mama's 9 out of 10 times. No wait, impeccable staff, amazing food, great cocktails.

But if you want the tourist trap, then wait in line. And don't let the line fool you. A line at 7:30am is different than a line at 8:00am and after because the entire restaurant is available before 8am (at which point they open and quickly fill all seats). So the only time a long line moves quickly is before 8:00am.

I'll close this review by saying that my 4 stars are based mostly on food, which I enjoyed.
author: Andrew K.

description: Gave three stars since I felt it was over priced for small portions. The food it self was good, but not phenomenal. I think it's  good for a quick stop of pastries (yum-o!) and peach bellini's.  People were nice, clean facilities, awful coffee (sorry ) all in all, you will walk out of there stuffed!
author: Jen C.

description:
2 words... MONTE CRISTO. *drool* sooo good!! esp w their homemade berry jam. BUT make sure to bring plenty of patience when coming around this part of town. 

less 1 star for the lack of parking in the area. less another star for the ridiculously long line during the entire time they're open. but add 1 star for liguria's bakery being directly across the street from mama's. grab a slab of your fav focaccia at liguria's, ask em to slice it up for you and munch on a few slices while u wait to be seated at mama's.
author: Grace V.

description: I've stood in line for Mama's three times but this was the first time I had made it all the way through the door and it was 100% worth the wait!! i got the Californian Omelette and it was STUFFED with avocado and bacon; they do not skimp on the add-ins whatsoever.  The potatoes were delicious and we also split a side of blueberry pancakes (YUM).  The bf got the Monte Cristo and he said he could eat that sandwich for the rest of his life and be the happiest person in the world.  I have to go back and get the French toast it looked SOOOO good.  Definitely WORTH the wait :)
author: Raina D.

description:
Went to Mamas with my family of four. The line was long and we got there 30 minutes before opening. The line never shortens once it opens either.

The food and service are amazing. Because of the long wait we were in a hurry or we would have missed our Alcatraz tour. We let our wonderful waitress know and she had our food, drinks everything out in 10 minutes. She was a miracle worker, we tipped her extra for doing an amazing job! 

The food was amazing as well, the kids had pancakes nd French toast both out of this world. My husband had eggs Benedict which was very good and I had an omelette that melted in my mouth .  

I would definitely recommend this if you have the time.
author: Tina G.

description: There's little to be said about Mama's that hasn't been already said. It really is as amazing, delicious, and quite the experience. We ordered the blueberry pancakes, dungeness crab benedict and mama's smoothie--everything was excellent and devoured in no time. Service was also great--everyone was really helpful and friendly. We came after 2pm and had no wait :)
author: Dani P.

description:
I think the hype of MAMAS got the best of me
I came here for my bday last year and as I expected I waited in line for about 70 minutes. 
When we finally got in we ordered first then was seated which I thought was a nice touch. That way you aren't waiting too long for the food to arrive. 
The food though wasn't memorable. I want to say I tried the benedict and the crab omelette. I think I enjoyed both, but quite honestly I don't remember. Due to the crazy wait I would rather eat brunch elsewhere. BUT Mama's IS a good place to at least try once!
author: Natasha I.

description:
We walked over to Mama's across multiple rolling hills, coming in hungry and slightly jet lagged. 
Mama's staff was a breath of fresh air. After waiting an hour to order and be seated, the staff smiled and chatted with their regulars, honestly inquired about our well being and graciously presented food to us. It felt like you were at an aunt's house. Yes, the wait is longer because they take the time to be so sweet, but the service is much more palatable.

And the food was fresh and hearty: french toast sampler, Nelson's Rancheros, fresh orange juice. The bread is fresh, spongy and topped with fresh fruit; the sampler was well paired with orange juice. 
Thank you Mama's!
author: Doreen L.

description:
The wait was one hour for a party of four. 2 omelets, 1 order of pancakes, an order of french toast, and the rancheros= $80.

The omelets were good. Not amazing. Wish there were more home potatoes I heard echoed through my crowd. The dollar pancakes were small and packed full of flavor. The rancheros could have used more egg? some avocado? it was missing something :( the french toast was good but it was not, i repeat no zazzie good. It was just ok. 

Just like the whole experience. It was just ok. Nothing amazaballs to stand in line for a hour plus but A-OK...
author: Michelle I.

description: I wish the food wasn't so incredibly delicious and tempting because I really would like to go back, but probably never will. The service was really, really disappointing. I felt like they were watching me the whole time, trying to flip my table the second I sat down. Also, don't even think about bringing kids. I've done it twice now and the servers totally patronized my kids and me. Also, no matter what day or time it is, you are guaranteed to wait outside for at least 45 minutes or more. That being said, the Monte Cristo is pretty amazing.
author: Ashley E.

description: Liked the system for dealing with the long lines - finally getting inside and seeing the food beautifully prepared. Family run was fun too. Food fun too
author: Steve C.

description:
If Mama's had a button it would say "I am worth waiting for"

Which, by the time (1 hour 25mins) I sat down and ate I felt like I had hunted, killed, and cooked the food I was consuming.



Monte Cristo : Amazing, so good. Hands down favorite. 

Blacklist Benedict : The bacon makes this dish. #2 favorite

Dungeness Crab Omelet : Good quality, didn't quite dig the flavor profile. Thought it was pretty good until the Monte Cristo BLEW IT AWAY.

Banana Pancakes : Best pancakes of my life. Nuff' said.

Chocolate Cinnamon French Toast : Sucked. Was so tough it bent the fork.


Orange juice was watery and grapefruit was good.

Come back for the Monte Cristo and Pancakes!!!!
author: ShenaniganHop S.

description:
This is a great brunch place. However, I don't know if I could wait 1+ hours every time.

IMPORTANT! If you do come here for brunch, bring sunglasses because you will guaranteed be standing in line facing the sun. Oh, wear sunscreen too :-) Gotta preserve that youth!!

Came here around 10am and waited about an hour (for a table for 2). My friend and I shared the french toast sampler and also the crab breakfast sandwich. Both were really good, we wanted a little savory and a little sweet. The crab breakfast sandwich was amazing... the bread was so soft and well worth it. However, the french toast was just meh. I've had better french toast elsewhere (Olea's and/or Universal Cafe). I wouldn't order this the next time I come around.

We did however, get one of the old fashion crumble cakes. THIS WAS SO GOOD. The other crumble cakes looked great too, so I would make a trip out here again just for these bad boys :)
author: Stephanie L.

description: Went on an "off" day and waited for about 30-40 minutes. The pastries, French toast bread, and other sweets look mouth watering when you walk in. Me and my friend ordered omelets which were massive and delicious. Side of the apple crumb cake and some coffee to boot. I could not of imagined that the food would be worth the wait but it certainly was. I wouldn't wait any longer than we did but I promise you you'll leave full and satisfied. Enjoy!
author: Gonzo T.

description: Ok, this was our first time having brunch here. Waited hour and a half in line outside, another 15 minutes inside only to find that there are flies all over the kitchen. The guys prepping the food don't wear gloves, and they do touch the food a lot. They gave us milk as 'creamer', when we asked for actual creamer, the lady just said 'No, no' and walked away. When I said that I don't like coffee with milk and asked for OJ, of course i was charged. No apologies or acknowledgement of the fact that they don't have creamer...There are so many places to eat around here, don't see a single reason to return here. The food is mediocre, service is at cheap chinese restaurant level, and it's not sanitary.
author: Irina T.

description:
Items selected:

Sampler French Toast - Banana Nut, Cinnamon Brioche, Cranberry Orange Walnut Covered with Bananas and Fresh Berries
Carrot Cake
Crumb Cake
Monte Cristo - Roasted Turkey Breast, Honey Baked Ham, Cheddar and Gruyere Cheese battered in Egg and grilled

The conference all but wrapped up and dinner not until 8:00pm a friend suggested a walk up to Coit Tower with the side agenda of potentially visiting Mama's, the 50 year old institution in North Beach where locals and tourists alike often wait hours to sample the fresh, made from scratch home cooking passed down from founder Mama Sanchez - the rumor was that around 2:00pm the breakfast/lunch crowd had dissipated...though that rumor turned out to be an eighty minute falsehood before we made our way through the line, placed our order, and sat awaiting our food.  A cute space whose long waits are a combination of its small size, attention to detail, and (appropriately) never rushing a customer even after their meal is finished it should really come as no surprise that once our selections did arrive everything was quite delicious and although certainly the sort of thing any home cook could probably make not exactly the sort of thing mom spends hours making every morning - particularly the multiple house made breads used to make the supple French Toast or superlative, thick Monte Cristo.  Obviously not the sort of place one would choose to eat every day given the crowds all-in-all Mama's is definitely an experience worth the effort...though next time I think I'd sooner show up at 7:30 to avoid the line and order a few more of the quick breads to snack on later in the day - particularly that crumb cake with its nearly inch thick streusel topping.
author: Michael U.

description:
Since going to Mama's a bit over a month ago, I've been routinely craving the Monte Cristo / Mama's Cristo. Like, on a daily basis. It was that good.

Obviously, be prepared to wait for such deliciousness. We got there at around 2:30pm (non-peak hours) and still had to wait 45 minutes to be seated. It is not for the faint of heart. Serious brunchers only. 

Also, if you're craving something sweet as well as something savory (like we were), just get the Monte Cristo or the Mama's Cristo. We ordered the Lemon French toast as well, but found the M. Cristo alone satisfied such a craving. My boyfriend's cinnamon french toast was hella good, though.
author: Alexander R.

description:
Three years in SF and finally decided to bite the bullet to try Mama's...

My roommate + company waited a whopping 2.5 hours (arriving at 10:30AM) and I, being the gentleman that I am, didn't leave the apartment until noon ;)

Regardless of what came next, nothing is and will ever be worth that kind of wait.

We went overboard due to the excessive wait time and tried the french toast sampler, stack of pancakes, Papa's fav omelette, count of monte cristo, and more.  I'm a strong believer of the fact that hunger is the most powerful seasoning, and yet, in the end, this was just another decent brunch spot with nothing to boast but its fame.

I encourage people to either come super early, on weekdays, or not at all. Try it before you're willing to commit 4 hours of your party's life to one meal.

P.S. The 3-star review is completely objective and dismisses the fact that the server spilled hot water over my arm in an attempt to reach across the table. If you want to serve tea to someone, please take the extra time to walk around the table. Thank you.
author: Nick W.

description: Best pancakes ever. They literally melt in your mouth!! Jelly is home made and very friendly staff. Long wait but it's worth it.
author: Kathy V.

description:
Some people wake up really early to go to the gym or to go to work. I wake up early and go straight to Mama's! 

For the Mama's newbies; you line up (90% of the time there's a line) outside, when you reach the door you're asked the # of your party, you're eventually let in to line up in another line for ordering. In this line you can study the menu and the specials. Fresh baked goodies, fresh shrimp, salmon, crab meat, veggies and part of the kitchen are displayed as well. You order with the cashier and from there you're advised where to sit. 

Mama's is bright and quaint, filled with a lot of regulars! The staff is really nice and welcoming. I don't know who "Mama" is but there is a nice gentleman, let's call him Papa, who goes around making sure everyone is fed and all is well... Very chatty with the regulars and the kiddies absolutely love him! 

But what I absolutely love is: 

Apple Pan Dore - The thinnest french toast ever, made from sliced sourdough topped with thinly sliced apples and smothered with a lemon butter sauce. Soo simple, light and delicious! 

Monte Cristo - A MUST... for breakfast or lunch! It's listed as a lunch item, but if you're there at 8am- all you gotta do is ask and they'll be happy to make it for you. I'm not a fan of ham, or any other fried Monte Cristo's at other establishments. But here, the ham, turkey, havarti and cheddar cheeses sandwiched between french toast and grilled, not fried, is perfection! 

Dungeness Crab Omelette - does this even need explanation? Fresh, huge crab chunks. Nuff' said! 

A homemade berry jam tops every table and is absolutely good with everything, from the toast to the Monte Cristo - every worker will come by and suggest you smother it on whatever you're eating. 

Mama's is quite refreshing and fulfilling... not your average greasy spoon, leaving you full and blah. But not your average healthy spot, leaving you hungry for more. Maybe it's just me, but I don't do good with light and fresh breakfast spots - but Mama's is the exception to that rule!
author: S Y.

description:
I AM NEVER EVER GOING to SF without stopping by Mama's ever again.

TIP: wake up early early and camp out at Mama's you will hit a line if you causally stroll in for breakfast. They also only take CASH! I arrived about 10:30am and I still had to wait about 30-45min for a seat. Was is worth the wait...YES! 

On top of the usual breakfast items they also have fresh seafood bases breakfast plates. Something like a Crab Benedict. Also a very ever so popular Monte Cristo with a side of fresh homemade jam. All the omelets sounded and looked delicious! Potatoes are home fries potatoes(seasoned deliciously).   

They also over a variety of baked goods a great snack to keep in your bag and eat while exploring the city. 

Prices can add up, but its worth it!!!
author: Jackie W.

description: Superb place for breakfast, fortunate to visit twice in the last 6 months. First time I was reticent to queue for over an hour but well worth it. Get there just before opening time to minimise queues and grab amazing sweet focaccia from Liguria Bakery across the road for a snack later..
author: Darren J.

description:
Don't leave this place without getting the Pan Dore. It's thin french toast soaked in a lemon butter sauce. You won't find that dish anywhere else and it's breathtaking.

The wait is ridiculous here. Clearly too many guidebooks have published the name Mama's. In a city that's obsessed with brunch - there are brunch places EVERYWHERE - there's no reason to wait for two hours here. Come on a weekday either right when they open or after 1:30.
author: Ellen C.

description: Not worth the wait unless you arrive at 7:30am on a weekend right before they open.  I had the egg white breakfast with the Italian sausage on the side and fresh fruit instead of potatoes.  The egg whites are naturally bland, so the cook adds spinach and what looks like canned mushrooms. My wife had the Washington Square omelet, (less tomatoes) which was excellent, but my eggs tasted as bland as they looked.  Seriously, it looked like reheated Army food.  The service is the only redeeming quality, which is above average to good.  The coffee was average.  The French toast looks very good, and you can request real maple syrup, instead of manufactured syrup.  Overall, go eat somewhere cheaper that doesn't take an hour for a table.
author: Will S.

description:
We got here at 11:40 am for brunch and lined up for a little more than an hour. just to see what all these buzz is about.

We got the crab omelette and the french toast sampler - the crab omelette was pretty big. It tastes good but I wouldn't say it's spectacular. I'm glad I tried it though cos crab omelette is not very common. The french toast sampler was okay also. Again, glad I tried it but not in love with it enough to line up an hour for it again.

The one extraordinary thing is the homemade jam. We had some toasts with butter and the homemade jam (which was made with some berries, I forgot which ones) - we could have it all day.
author: Gracie T.

description:
So I waited a little over 2 hours to try this place. It was like waiting in line for Space Mountain... My experience here was great overall, but that wait though... Why can't they just expand the restaurant? Haha, just kidding.

But I ordered the Monte Cristo and the Cinnamon Chocolate. Both were amazing. The  Monte Cristo with their homemade jam ... oh my goodness. Yum. The Monte Cristo is a sandwich btw, not a breakfast item. It's like a french toast, grilled cheese sandwich. SO good... And the Cinnamon Chocolate, it's as good as it looks. 

The service was great, the staff are friendly and nice. Especially the owner, he's super cool. 

I would come here again. But during the off hours like ... 3PM or something. I went at 11AM on a Saturday morning, so that was my bad call. Oh the things I do for food.
author: Chrisy Y.

description: So call me crazy, but I really don't understand why people wait hours in line for Mama's. Yes, it has good breakfast, but no breakfast is worth waiting that long for. The system is stressful; you order at the counter and then wait for a table to open up. Somehow the system works in that the tables usually open up as your food is ready. However, the food itself is just average. It's normal breakfast food that you can find elsewhere or make yourself. Pancakes, omelettes, french toast, yeah I get it. It's fine. My french toast was too sweet and the fruit was a bit soft. There are a bunch of other breakfast places in the area that won't make you wait two hours for some pancakes; I suggest doing that instead and enjoying the rest of your morning.
author: Regina L.

description: Loved this little place for breakfast! They've got the whole ordering thing down to a science and the food was spectacular! Highly recommend!!
author: Angi B.

description: Was this the longest line I've ever had to wait on for brunch? Yes. Would I do it again? Yes, and next time I'll bring a chair. Believe the hype! Check out their specials and make sure you order the fruit smoothie!!
author: Winnie L.

description:
I have a dear friend who I met through Yelp and we initially bonded over breakfast foods. French toast and the like. She once messaged me: "Do you dip or soak when you cook French toast?" It turns out we both dip. Over the past few years, we've traded some cooking tips and gone on some culinary Yelp adventures. 

When her birthday rolled around this year, there was only one place she wanted to go: Mama's. With over two thousand reviews on Yelp and a 4 star average, Mama's is *the* place to go for breakfast or brunch.

Now I'm not the type of girl who likes to wait in line for food. I just don't. I can think of so many other things I'd rather do than wait to be seated. But I'll do it for a friend in honor of her birthday. And we tried to minimize the wait by going on a weekday. There still was a surprisingly huge line (please note that pics in this review aren't mine, I just link to them from other fabulous Yelpers.) http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/mamas-san-francisco?select=bMs0gU72ZjeB1CXDt2_YMg#OawUK99pZ3IBleoLxk7nfQ  I found it shocking. And even more stunning was seeing some people wait with kids for over an hour. I can imagine doing that with a foodie adult friend, but never an impatient child (like me or my son). 

Anyway, birthdays are special, so we waited. And tag-teamed out of line a couple of times to investigate local bakeries and make a coffee run. There was plenty of time for that.

When we finally got inside, we decided to go nuts and order a lot of food, because we wouldn't likely return and put up with the wait ever again. So we'd try whatever we wanted on this one special visit.

We ordered (note photos are not mine):

* French Toast Sampler - House Baked Bread made with Cranberries, Fresh Orange Juice and Walnuts battered in Egg Whites, Chocolate Cinnamon French Toast, and Banana Bread French Toast http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/mamas-san-francisco?select=bMs0gU72ZjeB1CXDt2_YMg#qpaVLJLdxdVkhHrWoooTVA

* Pan Dore - Slices of Sourdough Baguette with Sautéed Apples in Lemon Butter Sauce http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/mamas-san-francisco?select=bMs0gU72ZjeB1CXDt2_YMg#v-qevWmOqGFBPzVaUXO2sA

* Blueberry Pancakes - Blueberries inside the fluffy pancakes and out http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/mamas-san-francisco?select=bMs0gU72ZjeB1CXDt2_YMg#hRjUmhJhxN4PaZDEg_jyxQ

* Vegetarian Eggs Benedict - Sautéed Mushrooms, Avocado, Baby Spinach and Grilled Tomato http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/mamas-san-francisco?select=bMs0gU72ZjeB1CXDt2_YMg#oo1oZHVRl93w_Mw-MyriRQ

* Chocolate Crumb Cake - Warmed up and very sweet http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/mamas-san-francisco?select=bMs0gU72ZjeB1CXDt2_YMg#vWOA05LUl46MXE91JchA5Q

* Fresh Orange Juice - Super fresh and sweet

It was a carb fest of gut-busting proportions. We had plenty leftover. While the food was 5 star worthy, I have to dock a star for the wait. Unless you're into that, it makes me think about the former USSR and those poor bastards who had to wait in line for things, and thank G-d I usually don't have to. Phew.

Our favorites were the Cranberry French Toast and Pan Dore (a unique dish), followed very closely by the Blueberry Pancakes. Their house-made jam was excellent as well. I wasn't crazy about the Eggs Benedict, but I liked the home fried potatoes that came with it.

To get to the bathroom, you have to walk through the kitchen. When we were there yesterday, the handle came off the faucet, so there was a definite plumbing issue to address. Be prepared for a wait and for cash only.

I thought the food was really delicious and excellent, but I wouldn't travel a distance and wait in a huge line for it. Unless I was doing so for a breakfast-loving friend.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
As far as breakfast goes this is the BESt in the city!

The wait only make you crave it more!

Me and my chick got here 20 mins before they opened Sunday.. Still about 40 people craving breakfast in line in front of us..

The restaurant only holds about 20 people.. So it still took us an hour 1/2 to eat.

When it's finally your turn to get inside... Don't get excited b/c you still have to wait in line in the restaurant.. I do like watching the 3 cooks go nuts.. Its a great view of the kitchen!

Great place, but bring entertainment for the line



Be sure to try the Jam... It's home made ;)
author: Andrew ß.

description:
Came here with a group of four, got there at 7:59 a.m. and the line was already pretty long. We had to wait another 45 minutes to get into the restaurant. Waiting in line to order gets you really excited because there are so many options and all of the pastries that you pass by in line makes you want to order more & more! So after you get into the restaurant, you have to order at the cashier and wait to get seated (should be relatively quick). I don't know what the procedure is if you want to order additional food. I loved everything that was on my plate, I ordered a shrimp omelette whereas my friends got benedict and other omelettes. Their jam was very tasty, and we couldn't resist ordering some carrot cake. Their decor is very homey, I enjoyed looking at their old-fashioned menus that were framed on the walls.

The only downfall to my experience was.. there are too many damn flies. They are so annoying! Flying near our food every other minute, I had an arm workout trying to swat them away! Not a pleasant experience. Maybe it was where I was sitting? (Next to the kitchen) It really bothered me though and it almost makes me not want to come back.
author: Kawai N.

description: DO not wait in line for this!  The food was just average. Presentation was beautiful but that does not justify the wait.
author: Kayla P.

description:
Mama's was the first place where my husband and I had breakfast here in San Francisco. We queued up for one hour and twenty minutes  but it was worth it.
The food was delicious. We shared: French toast Swedish cinnamon, blueberry pancakes and North Beach Mama's Benedicts.
Maybe too much but we made it!!
The service was really good, very friendly and kind.
author: Elena V.

description: This place is one of my favorite places for brunch in SF. I had the Monte Cristo and I can't wait to go back. Take your pick, everything is delicious.
author: Tessa C.

description:
My favorite part of the dining experience was standing in line inside the restaurant, watching the cooks prep/prepare the food and being separated from the array of goods by a mere piece of glass.I came here on a Wednesday afternoon and the wait was negligible. I ordered 2 dishes: 

Pan Dore - (2/5) french toast drenched in lemon butter. I didn't like the sour/oily combo that was a little bitter and it soaked the already thin slices of french bread to the point that they were soggy/rubbery. The bread was too thin to have a fluffy consistency and the egg mixture overwhelmed it. It tasted of fried egg basically and I regretted choosing this french toast even though it sounded so unique!

Monte Cristo - (3/5)  I loved the presentation, how the meat & cheese were encased inside the batter and it was divided into 4 neat triangles. While the bread was pretty good, the cheese I had was not melted enough and tasted like Kraft cheese, which I really hate. The breast and ham were thin deli slices that they gave too little of, at least relative to the thickness of the sandwich bread. In short, what was on the inside left something to be desired. My two friends took two of the  4 triangles eagerly since it looked really good, but they were left unimpressed as well. 

I tried a bit of my friends' french toast sampler. The presentation was stunning like most dishes here. The fruits were a nice touch, but I usually don't pay restaurants for fresh fruit. I go to the farmer's market for those. The french toasts themselves were underwhelming. I think the best one was the banana bread, but banana bread is hard to mess up.

I think their savory items are better overall from past experiences of ordering benedicts and everything involving eggs. 

I'm going get on the bandwagon and say that I would come here again if the line is short, simply because  Mama's is usually in such high demand and I buy into the hype and recognize a rare opportunity.  The service is always efficient at least, and it is an inviting, cozy spot to eat with warm, bistro colors. Besides the ambience, the food I ordered was sub-par and it is quite expensive, esp. for a cash-only place.
author: Alice L.

description:
So my husband and I were the suckers who waited an hour and half in the freezing cold rain on a Saturday morning for Mama's...and BOY was it worth it! The inside was so homey and inviting on a cold day.

When we finally got seated I got the smoked salmon eggs Benedict and the hubby got the french toast sampler. To this day, that is still the best smoked salmon Benedict I've had and I want to go back and have it again...just maybe not on a Saturday ;) I wouldn't say the cappuccino was very good, but the hubby really enjoyed his mocha! Yes, we will be back!
author: Emily S.

description: Definitely worth the wait!!! We stood in line at least 90 minutes for a table for two. Would gladly do it again :)
author: Albany G.

description: We had to wait over an hour to get in and ordered the food. They sold out dishes without telling and cancel our order but they made it up. Won't come back again. It's a place for tourists.
author: Ann R.

description:
