They were well cooked, although the biscuit kept falling apart amongst all the sauce/egg yolk. I prefer my biscuits a little toastier, and crisper. Steph Y ordered a crab omelette and it had really big crab chunks + a good amount of avocado. 

SO... I'm glad I tried it. If it weren't for the wait, I'd probably go back more frequently...but Curly's is nearby, and usually has less of a wait. Way more practical.
author: aileen c.

description:
I used to live in North Beach and could not find a better breakfast place in the neighborhood.  In fact, I have not found another place like this in any other city that I have lived - and I've tried.  Omelettes are fantastic (my favorite is the Californian - love the avocado, bacon, monterey jack cheese), french toast is superb, the display counter with breakfast pastries that you are forced to line up against before you place your order is Disneyland magical, and the vibe is like sitting down in mama's kitchen for a brilliant home-cooked meal.  This is breakfast at its finest, even with the wait.

And yes, it is worth the wait (unless you are hungry, and then you might be gnawing your fingers off before getting in on a weekend, particularly - try Tuesday - Thursday mornings for a relaxed atmosphere), and yes - if you live or visit SF, it is obligatory to make it inside at least once.  Chances are you won't forget it and make excuses to make it back as often as you can, as I do now traveling to SF on business...
author: Todd S.

description:
The wife and I were in town for a long weekend in SF over the 4th of July weekend.  Mama's had been recommended in a book at our hotel, so we hopped onto Yelp to check the reviews.  All of them seemed to point towards a delicious breakfast, but a lengthy wait.  Now, my wife and I are not the "waiting" types.  I really haven't been that many places that are worth a significant wait.

Mama's was worth the wait.  

We arrived much later than we inteded, as many reviews pointed out that lining up at 730am for an 8am opening would be appropriate.  With a late night out, we had a hard time getting out of bed and thus ended up at Mama's closer to 8:45am.  The line was already down the block, half of it shaded, the front half of the line (right before you step inside) right in the sun.  

We waited nearly an hour outside, before stepping in doors to the "inside line" which was much shorter but allowed you time to see the chefs in action and some of their fresh baked goods.  The smell was amazing, and we loved watching the chefs cooking up their delicious treats.  We must have changed our minds about what to order 10 times while waiting inside.  We spent maybe 30 minutes inside waiting to order, and then waiting for a table to open up.

Mama's is a small restaurant (you could call it cozy if you're nice, "cramped" if you're upset).  It is nice and well maintained - and the staff was very friendly while we were there.  I can't imagine how hard it would be to be happy at all times when they are SO busy, but they did a good job of seeming that way.

We settled in on our orders - myself, I ordered the Washington Square Omlette (sausage, veggies, cheese) and my wife ordered the french toast sampler.  We also ordered a stack of buttermilk pancakes to share.  Yes, too much food for us...but really, we're on vacation, and we wanted to try it all.

The omlette was delicious - made especially so by the fantastic spicy italian sausage contained within.  It was perfectly cooked and perfectly seasoned.  My favorite part of the entire meal.  

My wife's french toast sampler came with 3 different types of french toast - each delectable in their own right.  Very different.  We liked the banana bread french toast the best.  The pancakes as well were light, fluffy and delicious.  

Don't forget to try the jam they have on the tables.  It's made fresh there and I can't remember the name - but it was great on toast, great on pancakes and great on french toast.  

Service was quick and efficient (it would have to be to keep this place moving and seeing as many patrons as they do), and it was a decent value for the price.  Portions are good sized, but not outrageous.  

So for us, the wait was worth it.  We would definitely return, although we'd probably try to get there earlier.
author: Chris B.

description:
I DON'T WAIT in lines. Hence the reason why I have not been to Mama's until today. I thought maybe a week day would be good to try Mama's, maybe there would be no line. WRONG. 
The wait was probably only 45 minutes which I guess is good for this place but I was starving. It just got worse when we were inside in line having to stare and salivate as the cooks prepared the food and all the wonderful looking breads and cakes that were displayed. I was almost ready to pass out by the time we sat down.
I had the pancakes and fruit. Delish! The best pancakes I have ever had....they were as light and fluffy as the air. And I actually finished the whole plate of them. This means that they were really that good. The OJ was freshly squeezed and refreshing. 
Service was prompt.
I will def be back again, even if that means a wait.....
author: Kelley D.

description: I got there at 8:15am on a Saturday and waited for about an hour outside before I was seated. It was well worth it, however I wouldn't go if I was starving since the wait seemd to get longer and longer as the morning went on. We had a bellini and peach coffee cake to start... so good! The peach coffee wasn't overly sweet and the bellini was refreshing. Our omeletts were just how we ordered them as well (we can get picky) so that was a big plus. Small but comfy place to treat yourself to breakfast if you get up early :)
author: Jackeline A.

description:
We went here for Sunday Brunch but the brunch turned into lunch as we had to wait so long in the line. Usually I would refuse to wait that long but everything was in favor that day. Perfect company, perfect weather, I was not that hungry when I got there, and most importantly, I had picked the place after reading the yelp reviews. 
After we got in we had to wait in line to order and wait again to be seated. I do not know how long we waited in line - I just lost track of time. 
This place is small but cozy. I ordered mamas children's favorite omelette which came with potatoes and sourdough bread. My friends ordered fruit bowl, white eggscrambled florentine, and pancakes with berries. The food was good, but the prices are a bit on the high side for the portion size. 
I am sure there are other similar breakfast places that have good food, better pricing and no wait -- that's what I prefer.
author: Krupali T.

description: This is one place I don't mind waiting an hour in line. I have the crab eggs benedict (about $21) , and they never disappoint; huge chunks of fresh crab in there! The only reason I did not give it 5 stars is that the last time we went, my husband got pieces of raw bacon in his omelet that made him sick :( Other than that this place is delicious. Also recommend the chocolate french toast!!
author: Debbie J.

description:
I know, Mama's in North Beach.  Its a popular breakfast spot.  Most folks know about it since its sitting on the corner of one of the most famous SF neighborhoods.  But yesterday Mama's kind of saved my life. So I must pay tribute here.

I had one of those sf "wednesday blow outs."  And I was sh-sh-sh-shaking on Thursday morning.  So I hopped in my car with my royal ground double cappuccino and went up to coit tower to calm my spirits. It was a beautiful sunny morning in North Beach and this was helping me get through this surreal moment of edgy morning bliss.....

After walking around in circles up on Coit Tower, I drove back down the hill to washington park.  Yes, Mama's was open.  I parked my car and went into St. Peter and Paul church to ask for some salvation.  It was a  brief but peaceful interlude.  Then I hustled back up to the corner.

I swung the little half door of Mama's open and walked inside.  Not much of a line at 8:15am.  The only thought I could muster at this moment was "french toast."  But wait, I can still read and the specials board conveniently had blackstone eggs benny written out in front of me.

"I'll take the number one special." I said.  Then I turned and grabbed the corner table by the door.  A little kid who was waiting for his dad sat down next to me in a chair.  I looked at him and he smiled at me while swinging his feet back in forth.  Oh god, he can tell?  Does he know what a mess I was last night.  I smiled back and said hello to the kid and opened my sf guardian....laughing to myself.

Then suddenly the blackstone eggs benny appeared on my table.  "I'm, umm dehydrated," I told the sweet waitress from Portland....  She got the hint and kept filling my water glass.  Another moment of clarity hit me.  This eggs benny is really a life source.  Totally fresh hollandaise sauce, fresh bacon, and home fries.....ah the sweetness of this warm dish was  filling and reinvigorating.  Thank you Mama's.  Thank you North Beach.  Thank you San Francisco.
author: Georgio N.

description:
This place opens at 8am and we arrived at 8:20 and there was already a line.  The wait was about an hour from the time we got in line to the time we ordered.  Given this place it pretty small I understand why the wait is so long.

I got the eggs florentine and it was delightful.  The eggs were poached to perfection.  Once you stick your fork in the egg the yolk comes oozing out mixing with the hollandaise.  How the egg is prepared can really make or break a dish for me.  I don't know what they put in their hollandaise  sauce, but it different than the norm and different in a good way!

My bf got the northern italian omelette which  has prosciutto, basil, tomato, cheese and avocado as an extra and it was delicious.  No tabasco, salt or pepper necessary.  The eggs were very light and fluffy which is something I'm not used to with omelettes.  There was a shell in the eggs, but I can look pass that since it tasted so good.  The dish also comes with a baguette and potatoes.  The baguette was good, but I was not a fan of the potatoes. 

This place takes cash only so make sure you have cash on you before getting in line.  You don't want to wait in the long line and when it comes time to order be told its cash only, so be prepared.
author: Constance J.

description:
Was it worth the wait? Yes. Will I go again, not if I have to wait in a line that's longer than 20 minutes. Like every other review, we went Sunday morning, waited for an hour and a half and had great food.

I spoke to the waiter about ordering take out and he said that's an option during the week but not on weekends. I'd definitely do that.
author: Eliz M.

description: Great food and service, well worth the30 min wait in the rain.  Huevos rancheros one of the best, eggs Benedict to die for..thx Mama...
author: Taylor A.

description:
Mamas cafe it was a cute place , I heard a lot  about the menu so I went to check it out and this is what I found there.

  My husband drove around looking for a parking spot and note to any one going there that does not live in city, there is never a parking in that area !  Well a  hr n 1/2  later he parked and yes I was still waiting in line to his surprise , I didn't like how long the wait was ! 

   Well the man who meets you at the door needs a chill pill for sure not a nice person . We were rushed in by the door man only to find we were rushed into another line and standing almost over people sitting down to eat cause there's no room to breathe .

   I felt very uncomfortable there because there's no real time to see what they have to offer you. If you didn't see the menu outside from your way in your out of luck . The people behind you in line are hungry as hell too so their rushing to hurry up.

  The seating situation is very close knit and its very loud in there almost like everyone's  yelling at each other. So if your looking for a relaxing breakfast NOT IT ! 

  The waiters there were very nice I'll give it that and the food was good and pretty looking. Ya but  there's more then one place in this world that does good and pretty looking food . That you don't have to wait that stinking long to finely eat at ! Not going there again .
author: Dollybell R.

description:
Mama's is a decent brunch.  Calling it great would be vastly over-estimating it, while calling it bad would be slander.  I can in no way call anything they make the best, but I do appreciate that there is a great deal of individuality and effort put into each dish.

On a good day, I would call it the 5th or 6th best brunch in SF, based solely on food quality.  When you factor in the cost (at least 10% higher than everyone except Dottie's, which is the best) and the wait (by far, the longest in the city, averaging around 90 minutes), there is no reason to ever go there, when given options.

However, if you do go to Mama's, get the french toast.  It's the best thing on the menu.  Portions are small-ish, but flavorful.  If you're hungry, get something else while you wait in line or you're going to need to eat afterward.

As a last word, it's good, not great by any means.  So if you want to go somewhere famous, eat at Mama's.  I won't tell you never to eat there, but if you want to eat somewhere that you'll love, eat at Dottie's, Pork Store Cafe, or Stacks' (in that order).
author: Ben N.

description: Okay wait a gosh darn minute here. I may be from the south AND the mid west but in trying this food (after the well known hour wait) I was surprised that I didn't quiver in my boots after the first bite. It was just a nice, regular breakfast. I wish I could say I would try it again but I won't because of the wait and that it's only worth about a 10 minute wait to be seated. i am confused as to why this is so popular. Have you all tried the Local Cafe in Oakland? Great breakfast.
author: Lilah A.

description: I had the BEST PANCAKES OF MY LIFE here!!!! They were so delicious.  I found the reviews here on Yelp for the place interesting and decided to try it out.  As my home-base is Hayes Valley, it took a bit of effort to get over to the place but it was well worth it.  I had to stand in line for about 10-15 mins and met some really nice tourists.  The service was great and there is a really nice breakfast menu.  I had the Buttermilk Banana Pancakes with seasonal berries (raspberries, blueberries, and strawberries) on top and 1 scrambled egg.  The eggs were very fluffy and the pancakes were unbelievable.  I will definitely advise anyone to go.
author: Portia S.

description:
My breakfast had a hair in it.

I know what you're thinking: WAIT A MINUTE!? DIDN'T YOU GIVE THIS PLACE 5 STARS???!

Yes. For 3 very important reasons:

1. When I got my food it was tasty and delicious. I got the French toast (or Swedish toast or some kind of toast) topped with fruit and with fresh squeezed orange juice. (Did I mention that home-made jam included with every meal.) I was careful... watching out for hairs in every bite. Their food has great presentation. Their baked goods are freshed baked, fresh, and very good.

2. Three different people came by to apologize about the hair in my food including the chef. Which is amazing considering the next point....

3. ... the food was cheap. Seriously. You will probably pay just as much at an IHOP or a Denny's and it won't look as nice, taste as good, or be as fresh.

So, children.... to summarize:
GOOD PRESENTATION + GREAT TASTE + EXCELLENT CUSTOMER SERVICE + LOW PRICE = 5 STARS

I've been to 5 star restaurants that are less apologetic about the disgusting things they try to serve me.... and its unrealistic to expect all of your chefs & food handlers to be completely bald... so I overlooked the hair thing.

One warning though... I went on a weekday early in the morning. Supposedly the lines are so long sometimes people turn to cannibalism or die of old age before being seated. You've been warned!
author: J B.

description: I am amazed on how this place really meets the expectations. We got there around 7:45 am on Thursday and there was already a big line. We waited and about 8:20 we wee inside and ready to orders the the breakfast menu has four different items: Benedicts, omelettes, French toast and pancakes. Since it was my first time we order the French toast sampler and of those I like them all.
author: Gerson D.

description:
What no one really tells you about this place is that the wait is 1 - 2 hours. Yes, hours. For eggs and toast.

Is it worth it? I've gone a couple of times and each time I had to wait. The food is very fresh because there is such  high turnover. Also, there is no take out. 

I recommend the French toast with comes with lots of berries. If you get eggs and toast, you'll be happy because they are perfectly cooked. Not too brown. Not too raw. The chef is a big guy who handles all the eggs. He wears a top chef hat and you can tell he's in his groove when he juggles 5 egg orders. Why do I know this? Because there is really no table service. You stand in a line that runs along the kitchen and order at the check out. This gives a perfect view of their tiny kitchen.

By the way, they make their own jam. However, it lacks pectin so it's very slimy at best. I hope their chef buys pectin to thicken it up.

There are a lot of brunch options in the city. This place is probably the most popular, since there is a line around the block at 7:30 in the morning. If you want a more leisurely brunch, I suggest you visit West Portal area.
author: Andie C.

description:
The only reason anyone could ever consider, think, wonder or even question the idea of giving Mama's less than 5 stars would be the line.  And seriously guys.... seriously?  Get over it.  Yeah, there's a line.  Why? Cause the food is beamed directly down from heaven into your open and extremely undeserving mouth.

Ok, so back to Mama's.  Yes, I'll admit it.  The line is long.  It takes awhile.  On the weekends (my only opportunity) I'd go there expecting an hour wait, and hey if you're surprised with only 45 mins then good for you.  Once you get in the door, you might think your wait is over, but no.  There's another line.  Sorry, there I go on the line again. 

Ah the food.  I wish I understood what they did to the food here to make it so damn amazing, but I fear it's a mystery lost in the swirling mists of time.  Seriously though, how can they possibly make EGGS taste so good?  It makes no sense.  I cook eggs.  My mom cooks eggs... YOU cook eggs.... it's like they sprinkle crack in every tasty bite.  And the french toast?  forget about it!  it's created from pure joy, grilled and sandwiched with some sort of fruity goodness which accents it to perfection.  I reccomend going with a friend and sharign a few things.

Not to go on, but i seriously seriously love this place.  I'm almost GLAD the line is so long so I only go every couple of months.   Perfection, Deliciousness and Extacy, all under one roof.  

I don't want to over do it though, so don't set your expectations too high ;)

All in all, heaven on earth; especially if you're as passionate about breakfast as I am.
author: Joseph F.

description: it was a long while ago since i was last at this place for breakfast.  I never really like egg benedict but i actually like it from Mama's.  I also like the cranberry bread, it was so delicious!  But the wait was really long, over an hour in a cold hungry morning!
author: Angela K.

description:
Brunch on a Friday afternoon.  1:30PM.  The wait is about 20-25 minutes.  

People-watching out on the street corner.  Young blonde kid with a backpack stops to teach the elderly Asian lady cross-guard a secret handshake.  People napping on the grass of Washington Square.  Space out a little in the warm sun.  This is the life.

Waitress calls us in.  Inside, Yousuf and I stand in line to order.  It's cozy.  Menu looks good, and I can't decide - got too many options!  Game time decision - and I order the Swedish Cinnamon French Toast (7.25) with fresh berries in season (+2.00) on top.  Turned out to be quite good!  Fruit was definitely fresh, really sweet and loaded on top.  French toast is yums.  Though, I did end up recommending Olea in Nob Hill to Yousuf if he ever wanted some reeeal good french toast - probably the best I've ever had.  Mama's comes in close behind nonetheless.  The waitress was nice, attentive.  I'll probably be back.
author: Christine Y.

description: One of the best breakfasts I've ever had. My boyfriend and I had orders of 2 eggs benedict and a Pan Dore. Which I adored! I can't wait to go back and have another satisfying breakfast.
author: Jamaree C.

description:
During our visit to San Francisco we stopped at Mama's expecting a delightful Sunday brunch only to find 67 other people with the same idea!  Opting to leave and return on Tuesday, we finally found a more modest 30 minute wait and one of the most worthy breakfasts of late. 

The french toast, prepared with 3 different house baked breads, arrived smothered in fresh berries and bananas was amazing.  My partner had the "Californian" omelet with avocado, jack cheese, and crispy bacon.  Delicious.  The side order of bacon was good, but the hot spicy sausage was much better with a good balance of heat and flavor.  

Mamas is a must with any visit to San Fran, just go early.
author: MarcAnthony C.

description:
Mama's mama's mama's..this place is fabulous. Yes b*tches, the line is long. It's SF, get used to long lines for good places. Or don't, and miss out on this place, but either way please stop whining about it. 

The food is spectacular. While there is nothing all that original about the menu, what makes it a great dining experience is that you can taste the freshness in the food. 

Now..the wait, here's a little secret, and I'll mention this for my Dottie's review as well but it applies to all busy brunch places - if you want to miss the line, go there a half an hour before the place closes, not before it opens because there'll still be a line beforehand. Yes, you won't be going at your 'brunch hour' if you do this but the primary purpose should be to try the food, not at what hour does that happens. I've gone at this time before and, trust me, it's worth it.
author: Shreya C.

description: you're going to be standing in line for about 30-40 mins, but it's worth it ! Best brunch so far :)
author: Florencia I.

description:
I'm a hypocrite.
 
Monday through Friday, I'll willingly skip breakfast for that extra 45 minutes of sleep, but come the weekend, I will scratch and claw my way to a good brunch if necessary.  And with places like Mama's serving up such heavenly mid morning meals, you can't really blame me.
 
Expect to see a huge line here, but trust me when I say this place is most definitely worth the wait.  The menu is expansive and chock full of tasty items, but we settled for the household favorites.
 
The Dungeness crab eggs benedict was solid, featuring perfectly poached eggs perched atop a generously portioned bed of fresh, savory shellfish.  Also stellar was the Monte Cristo, a jumbo turkey and cheese sandwich dipped in egg and lightly grilled to hearty perfection.  And each of the three different selections of the French toast sampler was cooked in such a delectably sweet batter that I felt strangely compelled to stand up and spontaneously break into a riveting gospel chorus with every subsequent bite.
 
But it was Mama's homemade jam that brought the entire meal together.  I kicked things off with a small dollop of the spread, but what started out as a mere sampling quickly devolved into a barbaric scene, with me rabidly scarfing down half of table's jar before our food had even arrived.
 
It was this savage behavior that set the tone for the entire meal.  Interspersed between mouthfuls of delicious food were primitive grunts of delight and fanatical rants praising the meal in a flurry of expletives and adulation.  We were loud, obnoxious, and maybe even a bit overzealous with our jam consumption, but you'd be remiss to say food that good warranted anything less.  Sorry, Mama's, but you brought this upon yourself.
author: Daryl W.

description:
The Best Breakfast/Brunch no doubt about it!!!!

I found out about this place from Yelp and also from a friend who just ate here last month.  We had to wait alittle over an hour, so grab your coffee and wait in line outside this cute little place.

My 2 friends and I split a large fruit bowl (which is not very large), Cinnamon French toast with fresh berries (you get 3 slices), Ham and cheese omelette.  It was just enough and we left full and extremely happy.

The service is wonderful, you order at the counter and then they seat you.  Our drinks and fruit bowl came out right as we sat down and the food came 15 minutes later it was perfect.  Its a MUST do when in SF and its right across from Washington Square park.  I love this place and I believe its cash only.
author: Danielle H.

description:
we got here at 8am on a sunny and warm saturday morning.  the line was already long!  our wait was about 50 minutes but with the weather being so nice i didn't mind too much.  we found parking right down the street.  luckily the meter doesn't start until 9am so we go an hour free.  

i think the wait is worth it. they still had a line when we left at 10am but people come in and out in pretty much groups so you're guaranteed to get seated within an hour i would say depending on how large your party is.  i wouldn't recommend coming with too many people here. the people are really nice!  we never once felt rushed to leave.  

they don't take check or credit but will run your card as a debt.  just bring cash!  it's faster

here's what we got:

northern italian omelet: Pancetta (Italian Cured Bacon), Mushroom, Fresh Basil, Tomato, and Garlic Jack Cheese 

washington square omelet: Italian Sausage, Tomato, Bell Pepper, and Hot Pepper Jack Cheese

the italian one came with a nice kick of flavor.  the washington was good too.  the sausage really stood out.  i liked that the omelets didn't taste too heavy and greasy

french toast sampler: yummy.  the french toast also didn't taste too heavy and sweet.  the sampler had the banana walnut, cranberry orange walnut, and a cinnamon bread in it!  they use their own baked goods for the french toast.  

chocolate crumb cake:  they warmed it up and we had a yummy treat before we started our breakfast.
author: huong n.

description:
We walked by on a Sunday morning, the line outside was literally halfway down the block.  We figured that it must be really good but luckily for us, we had already eaten breakfast.  

Tuesday morning, we were wondering where to go for breakfast, my boyfriend remembered Mama's and off we went.  It was 8:30am and there was a line, at least it was short.  

It was definitely worth the wait!  

I ordered the French Toast Sampler, which was different breads in French Toast style and tons of berries.  My boyfriend had the Eggs Benedict.  I sampled some of it and it was really good.  

I am glad we tried this place out and I am pretty sure that if we go to San Francisco again, we'd definitely go there again.
author: Rose P.

description: omg! amazing breakfast!!! be prepared to wait, but its soooo worth it!! order their French toast!! its amazing..!!! any of their egg benedicts are awesome... Monte Cristo is definitely a must try also!! make sure you get there early!!!!!!
author: Tracy G.

description: Mama's you cook better than my own mother. Any chance you guys are willing to adopt me? Went here with the girlfriend and wow is the only word in my vocabulary that describe this place. The food was simply amazing. As a huge Brunch fan, this is my number place to go to. The only downside to this amazing establishment is the fact that's everyone knows about it. The line is always such a pain to get through that you'd wish they offer you something to eat while you wait. I swear I lost a few pounds just waiting to get in, but boy oh boy, was it worth the wait... Word of advice, come early.
author: Michael N.

description:
Tried it for the first time with two friends, Sydnie T. and Alison L. I think they liked it more than me. I guess it's part of the North Beach experience, coming here for an all-American breakfast? Well, yeah, I'm not really a breakfast person...I got a BLT. Hey, I would've gotten the more expensive club but they don't serve those on weekends!

Weekends...ugh...long-ass line. One hour wait. Well, it wasn't even breakfast by the time we got seated. Maybe that's due to our tendency to oversleep in general, but oh well.

Experience just wasn't great for me. I'm used to my $4 breakfastes in the Sunet, perhaps $5 if it's a burger and fries, and I'd be in and out in 30 min flat.
author: Kris Q.

description:
We waited in line for an hour and a half.  Was it worth it?  Sure.  It's been a while since we were there, so I don't remember what we ordered, but I do remember that it was good.  Not incredibly mind-blowing, but good.  The atmosphere is down-home cozy, the coffee was great, and the service was really friendly.

We'll be back.  Next time we'll get there earlier, and go home with homemade pastries or pie or banana bread, etc.
author: Joshua B.

description:
HoLY MoLY! This place is fantabulous! Everyone raves about Mama's french toast and for good reason.  Whoever thought of using banana nut bread for french toast is a genius! If you're going for first time, don't narrow your options, try the French Toast Sampler (it comes with 3 different varieties) AND the Monte Cristo (you won't be disappointed). 

My bf and I came here on a Saturday afternoon around 1pm, found street metered parking 1/2 block away and was seated in 25 minutes.  Of course the food took a little longer, but luckily we had a snack beforehand to tame our appetite because we knew the wait would be awhile.  But even with our snack we devoured everything in sight.  

I wonder if they serve brunch all day because I'm craving a Monte Cristo now!

In line, we met a family from France who saw Mama's in their guidebook.  How neat huh? If you haven't tried this place yet, you're missing out!
author: Shirley W.

description:
I live on the East coast and I would fly to Mama's and wait in line on sunday morning to eat their amazing fluffy pancakes.  Luckily, the most recent time we visited SF, there was no line yet on sunday morning.  we got there at 7:30 and were 2nd in line! by 7:45, there was a huge line behind us.  In addition to the pancakes, I ordered the dungeness crab benedict - which were amazing but they could have added a bit more crab for $21.  The coffee was fresh and delicious.  We also ordered the carrot cake with cream cheese frosting to go.  At mamas, pancakes are #1 (although I'd like to try the french toast next time) and the carrot cake is a close second.  Best carrot cake I've ever had.  You can see real shredded carrots, and the cake itself was so moist and the frosting was the perfect touch - not too sweet either.  We chatted with the baker on his out to go home for the day - he was very proud of his work and I can see why. He does good things at Mamas.

They only accept cash.
author: tina y.

description:
Besides the 2 hour wait (and in my case, in the rain), brunch at Mama's is just delightfully splendid. Wonderful little traditional breakfast shop that truly embodies what San Francisco is all about. It has the old school SF feel with the architecture and the comfort of a traditional diner.

The food is quite good, got the Monte Cristo which is an amazing culmination of flavors when you add the homemade jam. I think in the end I ate more jam than sandwich but both are great. Prices and portions are reasonable. 

You order and pay at the counter, service is diner-like. Not a whole lot of seating so make sure you get there early or super late. The line is quite ridiculous, might need to make like Black Friday and camp out the night before.
author: Ed L.

description:
I had no intention on going here on my recent vacation to San Fran, but after passing it 4 times and seeing a line out the door, i figured I would have to try it. 

The wait sucks, I got there at 7:30AM (30 minutes before opening) and wasn't seated until about 9AM. This is my only negative comment though.

The food looked amazing, everything was super fresh. Everything ran efficiently, and the environment was so warming. So on to the food. I had the crab benedict, and it was pretty good. The crab was insanely fresh, but i felt it just needed a bit more flavor overall. Still I highly recommend it. My girlfriend had the french toast sampler, which was also pretty good, but a bit overwhelming(the sweetness). I've had better, but this is definitely among the best. 

The freshness alone makes the food amazing, everything was bakes fresh (blueberry muffin was INCREDIBLE). Don't get a mimosa, for 8 bucks, it should come in a bigger glass.
author: Terrence C.

description: I think this was the best pancake I've ever had! I don't even like pancakes. Well worth the wait. During the week, the line seems to start filling up around 7:15am so you might want to get there before that. I don't even know what else to say about this place, everything is really good, but the basics are rrrrreallly good. I would wait on line again just for the pancakes and maybe a side of eggs. This is a must for any visitors or locals wanting some good breakfast.
author: Meshach R.

description: My favorite breakfast and brunch place in San Francisco. Even though every time we have to wait in the long line for an hour or more, the food has been always great and we feel it's worth the waiting. The service is good most of the time. They only take cash or debit card. As San Francisco long time local residents, we still like to go there often. Most of time, you can see tourists from all over the world, ling up there. We tried most of the items on their menu, and everything is delicious! Absolutely recommend this restaurant !
author: Dyan R.

description: I have been wanting to check Mama's out for the longest time. Now that I live a few blocks from here its easy to roll out of bed and get here early. We got in line around 8:15 and there was already about a 40 minute wait. Apparently you should get here before they open at 8 to be seated immediately.Totally worth the wait. If you are starving you can grab a croissant from a nearby bakery or foccacia from across the street. I ordered a special - french toast made with egg whites and applesauce. HANG ON. Egg whites?!!? Since I have an egg yolk allergy this made my week. Thank you Mama's for the first french toast I've eaten in years. The service was good for how busy they were. As we left, people in line thanked us for leaving :)
author: Sara P.

description:
This place is amazing! It's pretty tiny, which calls for a wait time of about 2 hrs! We went on a Saturday at 10am and sat down to eat noon. While we only actually spent about 30 mins in the restaurant it was well worth it.

I had the french toast flight - 3 slices (1 of the regular french toast, cranberry and banana bread). This was accompanied by chicken sausage and a small glass of OJ. The food was fantastic...I can't wait to try more items from the menu.

I wouldn't try going with groups larger than 4, as the place is very small. The bathroom is in the back, past the kitchen, in what appears to be a makeshift add-on.

You pay before you eat and they move you through the line as effectively as possible. I suggest you try this place out at least once! Definitely worth the wait!
author: Regine N.

description:
Waited in line for around 40min...service was okay. They seemed kind of like they just wanted the day to end. It took too long for them to refill my water. (The third time was better, second time we called our order in and picked up to go. 

I got the monte cristo sandwich and decided to be fat and get a side of poached egg too. Tried the sandwich by itself first, it's okay. Added the jam, yummmm. Then put my poached egg on top of a slice and pierced it and ate a piece with everything. OMGGGGGGG it was awesome. It was heaven and I enjoyed eating every last piece of it. I didn't finish the home fries though. Those were only okay...

Second time, got the french toast sampler. meh, it was normal, nothing spectacular.

Third time, northern Italian m'omelette with only egg whites. Good, egg whites cooked well, but it was pretty salty....and VERY VERY VERY OILY. It was soaking in a TON of oil. That totally defeated the purpose of getting an egg white only omelette.

It can take a while to be seated after ordering food...and while you're waiting there for a set, you're kind of in everyone's way. It's a very small (but cute!) place with some highlights, but not all the food is above average.
author: Victoria L.

description:
Heidi has hit a milestone!  #50 and I couldn't think of a better place to review than Mama's.

Mama's I love you in the sun, the rain, the fog and on a hung over Sunday morning when if I don't eat in like 20 minutes --- we will have a moment on the sidewalk.  But still I wait - I would wait 2 hours for your delish breakfasts offerings.  Mama's I heart you with all of my San Francisco heart.

Mama's is a staple in North Beach and in San Francisco for that matter.  And for me the place of much laughter and fun and wonderful memories that keep growing.  The food keeps me coming back again and again and again.  The smells, the laughter and the coziness is wonderful. Anything and yes I mean anything you choose is so yummy you will think of it the next morning and say I want me some more of that!

I love the French Toast and the Eggs Benedict.  It does in fact taste just like Mama used to make.  Check this out Yelpers - and enjoy!!
author: Heidi S.

description:
Worth the wait!  My favorites include: any type of eggs benedict, monte cristo, and chocolate cinnamon french toast.  There is also really good homemade jam on each table.  The service is great, and I also like that you can watch the cooks prepare food as you wait in the line inside.

Try coming on a weekday so you don't have to wait for hours!
author: Jean O.

description:
Pretty tasty! Checked it out on a late Weds morning. Busy but not craaaazy busy. Like a 15 min wait in line get a seat right away busy.

So actually that doesn't really sounds busy now does it?

Anyway - we were given tasty muffins in the line and the food came really fast after we were seated. OJ tasted fresh, eggs were poached to perfection. 

My dude had a french toast - the swiss? I don' remember, love the varieties. What is strange is that they let him order it with fruit...c'mon clearly you confused him with too many questions. Why would he want a cantaloupe ontop of his french toast? He wanted the berries!!!!
author: Allegra F.

description: Good food, perfect for breakfast with a date. The food can be a bit pricey and the wait is a real deterrent.
author: Brooke G.

description:
I went here with friends who drove in from San Jose - it was nice to have a "special" spot to go to, and with all the warnings about the wait, we were prepared.  

Worth the wait on a usual basis, no!  on a special occasion, HELL YES!  a great breakfast experience and the more the merrier the more to taste :)
author: Sarah X.

description:
The main reason I"m only giving this place 3 stars is because I guess I didn't order from the breakfast items since that's what they're known for. I ordered the hamburger, which comes on some other kind of skinny sandwich bread. It was alright I suppose. 

My friends and I went in the afternoon on a Fri and there was a long line outside that goes into the restaurant. I'm not quite sure how long we have been waiting because I had fainted outside in line for some reason or another which is another story, which was about a 10-15 minute ordeal. Before that we were already waiting for about another 15 minutes. Guess next time I'll try the breakfast :P
author: Annissa H.

description:
Average. Touristy. Over-priced.

Que malo!  I was really looking forward to a great experience, and even brought a book to prepare for the wait (2 hours). 

I was befuddled that Mama's was order-at-the-counter, but I suppose it did give me opportunity to gaze longingly at the delectable pastries in the window.  The ollalieberry ring was too pretty to pass up - and the buttery, flaky, goodness didn't disappoint.

Unfortunately, the omelette and pan dore left too much to be desired.  

I'm ok with a 2 hour wait for life-changing food experiences, but throwing together watery dungeness crab (not even Jumbo lump), avocado, and Brie (more rind than cheese), is not recipe for success in my belly.

The pan dore, as unique as it sounds, is nothing but a hot mess.  The sour dough slices are akin to chewy, tasteless plastic dipped in egg and suffocated in a lemon butter sauce that would have been better paired with salmon.  The warm sliced apples were commendable. 

The conclusion to Mama's in Washington Square, is a 2 hour wait, a delicious pastry, a disappointing omelette, an inedible french toast, and a decent orange juice for $40.   

Know Before You Go:
1. Be ambitious - wake up at 7, get there before 8
2. Grab a pastry
3. Go to Ella's (in Pac Heights)
author: Jane L.

description: Amazing place for breakfast (including breakfast for lunch), though the line to get in can be brutal.  Best bets are any of the french toast (except the chocolate one, oddly enough), the monte cristo, anything with dungeoness crab, or anything with Italian sausage.  Their carrot cake is also amazing.
author: Scott E.

description: Totally NOT WORTH THE WAIT.  There are a ton of breakfast places in San Francisco (The Butler and The Chef, Just For You, even Creperie........) that put out an equally tasty breakfast. Today had friends in from Illinois that desperately wanted to eat here. So I went along, as I did the last time with visitors from Ohio. I'm from Chicago originally, but what is the deal with people from the Great Lakes region needing to wait in line for french toast? Took two hours and fifteen minutes to sit at a table. Never again.
author: alistair g.

description:
We waited nearly two hours to get into this place for breakfast on a Sunday morning. It was worth it.

Everyone's breakfast was completely delicious. However, mine was the best. Banana infused pancakes with a request to also infuse walnuts into the pancakes. Perfect. I swear, it felt like the pancakes exploded in your mouth with flavor. 

For being such a happening place, the service was so so good. I couldn't believe how many times we were talked to (well, once we actually got inside the restaurant). That just added a whole extra special feel to the place. Maybe it's because they know we've all been waiting forever for this food, we better be treated nicely.
author: Richard J.

description:
So I have only been here once and frankly I just don't get all the hype. After waiting in two ridiculous lines for god knows how long, I pretty much lost my appetite and just wanted to sit. The whole lay out of this place kills me. It is like let's see how pissed of we can make you before we feed you. 
I had some shrimp Benedict and the hollandaise sauce did not mix well with the fresh shrimp. I love a good breakfast spot but this place is just OK.
author: Kathleen E.

description:
After waiting in the outside line for close to an hour, there is an additional 15-20 minute line inside prior to placing an order.  The good thing about the indoor line is you can watch the cooks do their magic and you have an excellent view of all the breads, pastries, fruits etc... You also have some time to review the menu (albeit it is difficult to see the chalkboards).

We had a french toast variety and a salmon special, 2 coffees, an OJ and a Mimosa (champagne/orange juice $7.00 fair price but the taste was bitter and it was served almost at room temp) plus 3 to go pastries. The presentation and the flavor of the meals were very appealing and good.   Service is fair (I think they are just too busy and overwhelmed) and you feel a bit rushed while dining (likely because of the huge line).  Coffee is blah...shame shame.  Overall price is a bit high.  Our total cost for two including the three pastries was about $70 (with tip).

The place is tiny. I have mixed feelings about the ambiance due to size and how busy the place is.  There is only one restroom that is very tiny, outside in back and down some narrow stairs.  They need to lease adjacent space or maybe make an arrangement with the city to put some picnic tables in the park across the street and then take to go orders from folks in line outside who don't necessarily care about going or sitting inside. 

In short most will enjoy the food and dining experience.   However, the wait is ridiculous.  Is the food worth the wait....for my wife and I, no.  However, some folks will likely argue it is.  The overall value is a judgment call. For us, it is too long a wait and too pricey for what we got.  We enjoyed it but feel we lost too much time considering our short trip visiting the wonderful city of San Francisco.
author: C R.

description:
While the food here was okay, I was turned off overall from this little restaurant by several factors: (1) a particular staff waiter/bus boy and waitress who were extremely rude and had very bad customer service, (2) inadequate seating arrangements with long waits well over the time of being admitted into the restaurant, (3) another long wait for food to be received after ordering (while parties who ordered after us were getting their food before us), (4) our waitress suddenly was always at our table when we were near finishing up our meal to ensure what kind of tip was given, and (5) no apology was ever mentioned by any staff member though they know the tension that ensued. 

My family and I went here open minded to see what the craze was all about since there are always longs lines down Stockton, upon passing this little restaurant. This place is really recommended for parties of 2, if you want seating right away. I understand that because of the small size of this restaurant crowding is unavoidable but a system of ushering your guests to wait outside or near the back would have been a nice suggestion rather than the rude barking of demands to "clear the aisle." It is like the staff was unequipped with handling large crowds, though that is how is has always been there.

The packaged experience was horrible and I plan to never again set foot in this restaurant. I now fully regret paying a gratuity of 15% for a meal that was accompanied by exceptionally awful service just because I felt the pressure of staff eyes and hovering. There is a sign posted upon exiting the restaurant which states "come in as guests, leave as friends;" I find this to be quite insulting after the experience my family and I have come to have.
author: Valerie R.

description:
It's true what they say, FRENCH TOAST SAMPLER all the way! I never order french toast, but based on the yelper raving about it, how could I not? It was heavenly!

I ordered an egg dish and while it was pretty good, I wouldn't come back here just for eggs, there are better places around the city for that (like I'll take Brenda's over Mama's any day)

Aaaaaannd, the wait sucks major butt.45+ minutes plus. So don't come here if you are ravenously hungry, you may go ballistic over the wait.
author: Pauline T.

description: If you hate waiting in line... this is not for you... BUT it is SOoOOooOOOooO worth it!! Monte Cristo is the best thing ever created!! The Blueberry sour cream bread mmmmm OH SO GOOD! Everything is fresh and yummy... I suggest you go on a weekDAY, maybe on a day you "feel sick" :)
author: Jennifer S.

description: This place beautifies San Francisco. Any of these dishes ( Monte Cristo, Smoked Salmon and Lox, Smoked Salmon Benedict) will guarantee you to cry with tears of joy as you eat. This place is super homey and comfortable. Best time to go would be after 2pm or else the wait will be super long :/
author: Carrie T.

description: Finally tried Mama's after years of being on my bucket list & only waited 10 min on a Wed late morning!  Truly lived up to the reviews!  Had the Crab Benedict w/ home potatoes & one of the best I've had.  The Swedish French toast w/ fresh berries was delish too!  Will be back again. Love my city!
author: Monica B.

description: This review is for the french toast.  Went here after a red eye flight, and ordered the french toast sampler.  The french toast was made with different pound cake slices - one cranberry, and I can't remember the rest.  It was a nice variation on the meal.  Also came with fresh jams.  Cute place, good breakfast.  I wouldn't wait in line though if I ever went back.  I'm sure there are tons of other great breakfast joints in the area that are just as good.
author: Tai M.

description:
I love breakfast food. It is my favorite meal of the day. If I could eat breakfast all the time, I would. I love it all, eggs, toast, french toast, waffles, pancakes, bacon, sausage, all of it. 

I was introduced to mama's last year by a friend's co-worker who graciously waited in line for us to have breakfast. So my first experience was nearly perfect. I didn't have to wait long, I ordered and we got a great corner booth. We enjoyed mimosas, an omelette to share and french toast. It was great. I felt like I had been missing out on the best breakfast place in san francisco, I mean, where had it been all my life?

I have been there only one other time and if I didn't live so far from mama's I would probably go all the time. I think about going all the time. I crave their french toast and wish they were open all day. Can't wait till I can go again.
author: Jennifer T.

description:
I MISS MAMA"S ALREADY!! I went to mama's for sunday brunch last week and i keep thinking of the french toast that they made. 

I waited in line for around 35 mins and i was so desperate for the food while waiting coz i could see through the windows of what people were having. It was sunny and located in a peaceful corner of Washington Square, so i was quite patient during waiting. And u have to line up when u entere the restaurant again to order for your food, a bit odd but it's fun too coz u get to see how the chefs cook your food. 

The ambience of the restaurant is very faminnie, very sweet & cute, with lots of love hearts decorations, along side with colourful and delicious food, mama's has definitely woke me up from sleepy sunday morning! I had french toasts with summer berries and a smoothie! it was awesome! Also the staff was very friendly and efficient, i had a great time there and i highly recommend others to go if you ever get a chance to hit San Francisco, good experience!
author: Sandy K.

description: Touristy place, don't make the same mistake I made and wait for hours at this place, food is worse than hotel breakfast restaurant, nothing is worth to wait such a long time and my "dungeness crab omelet" was so fishy I couldn't even finish it
author: Anna N.

description:
Not too much of a fan.

Went there on Friday at around 10, waited for 1.5 hours. The bf ordered the omelet which was average, nothing spectacular. I ordered their famous Monte Cristo and I found it to be disappointing. The sandwiches came barely warm.....I hate it when restaurants serve their food cold. 

As a matter of fact, I didn't write this review until I tried Monte Cristo in another restaurant. It might be unfair to Mama's if I criticized their sandwiches when I had it for the first time. Now that I have tried an excellent Monte Cristo in another restaurant, I can say the one in Mamas is overrated.

The food is ok. I just don't think it worth the wait.
author: Ris L.

description:
Three of us came to this sunny little restaurant on a Friday afternoon for a late brunch.  The wait was minimal (about 20 min).  The food was really good overall.  And ambience and service were excellent.  We left satisfied and happy.  We all agreed we must come again! 

It was tough deciding what to order, as the menu was full of goodies.  We ended up going with a Monte Cristo, the Dungeness Crab Benedict, and the Northern Italian Omelette.  We dined family style and shared everything.

The MONTE CRISTO was a thing of beauty.  Four golden wedges of turkey/ham/cheese sandwiches egged and grilled into perfect, perfect French toast.  Lightly dusted with powdered sugar and accompanied by a small ramekin of homemade boysenberry sauce.  Oh my goodness, savory and sweet, warm and light, this dish answered every one of my needs!  As I took my first bite, my mind began to hum.  :)

The DUNGENESS CRAB BENEDICT was also quite good.  The poached eggs especially were done really well.  The egg whites were so tender, but still completely cooked.  And though I'm not a big fan of crab usually, I enjoyed the meat here, which was fresh and tasty.  The Hollandaise was also nice and mustardy.  I'm glad they didn't drench the whole dish in it.  The English muffins at the bottom, though, were soggy and a little sad.

The NORTHERN ITALIAN OMELETTE was a let down for me, but my two dining partners really enjoyed it.  I found the egg overcooked, with both the texture and the flavor reminding me of a rubber ball.  Very strange.  The filling was also lackluster and rather generic.  I didn't taste any basil or pancetta.  Maybe it was late in the day and some ingredients ran out.  But again, the people sitting to my left and right thought it was good.  

The grilled red potatoes that came with each of the dishes were so-so.  My sister makes the ultimate oven roasted version with cilantro/garlic pesto and peanut butter(!), so perhaps I'm overly critical here.

The housemade berry jam, which is really more of a sauce in texture, is very good and also pretty for the eye.  It's magenta, a little tart and not too sweet.  A drop of it goes well with everything.  

Service was excellent all around.  The wait staff, the bussers were across the board very efficient and courteous.  The owner was also very personable.  All are truly praiseworthy.  The vibe at Mama's is full of goodwill and welcome.  This is a happy place. 

Overall 4.5 Stars!
author: Allegra I.

description:
I was sooo excited that I finally got to try Mama's!  My friends who live in SF always talk about Mama's but every time we tried to go, the line was way too long.  I took advantage of the fact that I was in SF on a rainy Friday and went to Mama's, hoping for a shorter line during a weekday.  Luckily, the line was indeed shorter, but we still had to wait about 45 minutes to be seated.  As everyone has already stated, there are literally three different lines - one outside, one to place your order and one to wait to be seated. 

As usual, I couldn't decide what I wanted, so I ordered both the two eggs with Italian sausage and the chocolate cinammon french toast topped with berries.  Both were delicious!  I was especially fond of the breakfast potatoes and the french toast.  Three of my friends ordered the famous Monte Cristo - two of them thought it was too cheesy; the other friend really liked it.  The orange juice at Mama's is also worth mentioning as it is freshly squeezed and surprisingly delicious. 

All in all, I had a very nice experience at Mama's - yummy food and good service - but the wait is a bit excessive.
author: Karen L.

description: Best Breakfast in SF. I just wish the place was bigger so that there wasn't always an hour plus wait to eat. Wait staff here often seem to be a little grumpy... I probably would be too if I had to work in such a small place with a non-stop line of people cramming to get in from opening to close.
author: Scott S.

description:
The perpetual question everyone asked at Mama's this past weekend was, "Is it worth it?" The answer is a resounding "No." 

My boyfriend and I had read that if you don't get to Mama's by 8 AM on the weekends, it's an hour wait - no problem!  Both of us were OK sleeping in and arriving at 10:05 AM. 

TWO AND A HALF HOURS later, we were finally seated. We were only in the city for a day and a half, and I really wish I had the 3.5 hours back that we spent in line and eating here. 

The French Toast Sampler looked amazing, but was not nearly as tasty as we'd hoped. The Monte Cristo sandwich was good, however, and the homemade jam is very good. 

If you are planning to eat here, I'd suggest going on a weekday. However, a better use of time (and money) would be to go across the street and buy a huge slab of jalapeno and cheese focaccia bread from Liguria Bakery for $5 (they sell out though, so get there before noon).
author: Kristen A.

description:
This place is everything that everyone described it to be. 
Of course there was a line, but thankfully it moved relatively quickly and their system of ordering the food before you sit down seemed efficient. After waiting outside, you wait in line inside and take your order and stand there till a table is ready. It's definitely small and a tad cramped in there but worth it. 
The food was delicious of course. I had the pancakes with fresh fruit. the pancakes were thick and fluffy and the fruit was all perfectly ripe. I also had the orange juice. and it was obviously fresh squeezed. It wasn't that cold which was surprising but totally worked. 
As long as you come with expectations of waiting and good food, you will not be disappointed : )
author: Kathryn G.

description:
My husband and I were visiting San Fran for a few nights and several friends had recommended Mama's to us.  So we braved the line and arrived on a Saturday morning at 9 am.  Boy was it long!!  We ended up waiting a total of an hour and 15 minutes (this includes the line outside AND inside).

I ordered the Dungeness Crab Benedict and my husband had the French Toast Sampler.  Both were very good and their homemade jam went perfectly with the french toast.  There were huge pieces of crab meat which I appreciated.  For $18.50 though, I thought that was a little steep.  Both of our meals along with one orange juice came out to $38.  Their portions are large so we were both stuffed when we left.  Our waitress along with the entire staff was very friendly.

Overall great food but wouldn't wait in line for over an hour for it again.  Being from the Washington DC area, my husband and I are used to restaurants with elaborate brunches and breakfast items like Mama's.  I guess in San Fran a place like this is more rare.  So if you're going to visit Mama's, make sure you go early!
author: Hyun Y.

description:
is to much to ask for half stars?!?!

not 3 stars and not quite 4 either.

kinda like a ride at disneyland where you get through the door and think FINALLY!!! only to find yourself in ANOTHER line, to which you get through and you think WELL ITS ABOUT TIME!!! ONLY to find yourself in ANOTHER LINE?! 

well, welcome to MAMAS!!   you wait to get inside, then once your in you wait to order your food, then you wait for a table to open up, and with all that waiting you think your food should get to when you do. but it doesn't. to their credit, its SUPER TINY in there and they got that front kitchen running smooth as oil.

i got the crab omelet with avocado and brie. MEH, all that avo was covering up the crab goodness. however the french toast sampler?!!?! YUM!! quick tip from the server to put some of the jam on top!!! LOVING IT!! 

so was it worth an hour and a half wait?! ummmmm, no. would i wait an hour for it?! possibly!! but anything less than 40 minutes would have me saying YES!! LETS GO TO MAMAS!!! anything more than would require serious consideration. 

btw, the only thing that made this trip worth EVERY MINUTE OF STANDING IN LINE.... CARLOS SANTANA. in fact i heard he frequents this place quite often. even though we didn't say hi (even though he was a table away from us) it was just as exciting to sit that close to a legend!!!
author: Christine L.

description:
Hmmm, yeah, I think most of what can be said has been said already. But why not say it again? 

I've been to Mama's twice. The first time I went on a weekend and braved the line. The second time, I showed up on a weekday ten minutes before they opened and walked out stuffed before 9AM. Definitely worth it to do the latter; not so sure about the former. 

I've tried both the chocolate french toast with fruit and the pan dore. I definitely recommend the pan dore, because I've never had anything like it elsewhere and it's damn good on its own merit. And get a baked good too because--well, why not??
author: Robyn M.

description:
The line was f-in' long, but my God, the FOOD...

I had the French Toast sampler, and sis-in-love and I split an egg white scramble and also ate on my brother's pancakes.  Everything was delicious, top notch, but the best part of the meal?  HOMEMADE JAM ON THE TABLE.  I could have drank this stuff, it was so good.
author: Jo S.

description:
French Toast Sampler was incredible. Topped with fresh berries and made to perfection. The orange juice is also very fresh and I recommend it. I also recommend the chicken apple sausage and whatever sweet baked good they have there!

A very cozy place, just like mama's house and had a southern feel. I was also very impressed by the service, given the crowd...and this was on Tuesday morning.

The trick with this spot is the wait. It has become extremely popular and an hour wait is standard.
 
They also ONLY accept cash, which had me running across the street to the post office to buy some stamps, JUST TO GET CASH BACK!

Overall, loved it and can't wait to be back in SF.
author: Pedro S.

description: The wait is too long. Too long!  If you have the patience to wait in line, the service is good.  The crepes, omelet, benedict, everything is good!  Don't bother with their coffee.  It will be a disappointment after you stuff yourself with delicious food.
author: Byron L.

description: Best breakfast I have had in SF. There...I said it. Expect a line to get into this joint, but the french toast is delicious and so are all the omeletttes. Service has been great the 2 times I have been there.
author: Mo A.

description:
If you're an impatient person like me, it's best to come during the week, when the lines are more managable.


I went with a friend on a tuesday and because I arrived late, didn't have to wait.  He however, had to wait a good ten minutes in line.

My advice: arrange with more punctual friends to meet there at a set time and then arrive 15 or 20 minutes later.  That way, you get to waltz in and eat.

As for the food, mama mia, it is pretty darn good I have to admit. I had the Monte Cristo and it was WOW.

If I get the chance, I'm going back.  Yum
author: Julia Y.

description:
Definition of dedication: waking up at 7AM on a Sunday post our own apartment party to finally try out Mama's. 

Living in North Beach means several things: great bars, nice park, and "OMG have you eaten at Mama's?"

After months, roommate and I decided it is finally time to brave the line and check out what the big deal is. 

There we were with several friends, all fresh with hangovers like drunken daisies sipping on coffee (chai tea for me!) waiting in line at 7:30AM sharp. We told ourselves to lower our expectations just so this is not the greatest let down. 

30 minutes later, we get into the restaurant to get into ANOTHER line to order. Granted, it probably made things easier. And they did have a nice display of fresh fruit and fresh ingredients- including chefs preparing an amazing french toast sampler drizzled with maple syrup and chocolate sauce topped with fresh berries (ended up being roommate's order). 

I got a lump crab benedict. It was very delicious, much better than restaurants with crab cake benedict- remove the sogginess factor. Underneath poached eggs on top of bed of sauteed spinach and english muffin, the crab meat was salty and fresh. Yum!

But now the big question is- was it worth the wait? 

Absolutely. Not. Not until they take reservations or have a bar for me to sit down/wait at anyway. Bar is key for popular dining.

Glad I've been, might one day crazy that delicious benedict again, but for now I think I'm going to be alright dining at Rex's with less wait and save the $10 for a tall glass of bloody mary. 

Zapped leftover omelette still delicious for a grey Monday lunch, though.
author: Fiona S.

description:
Friday morning about 10am, there was a line of about 20 people along the side of the restaurant which is normal.   I've dined here many times in the past and it's not worth the hour plus wait anymore but is absolutely worth the 15 minute wait for a  phone order.  I ordered two monte cristo sandwiches and 15 minutes later I was across the street at Washington Park enjoying them with my friend.

A couple noticed I had ordered to go after picking up the food and they followed suit by doing the same thing.  While we were on the bench eating, they praised me on how smart I was in doing so which was definitely a compliment because any other day I'll tell others, if I'm dumb today, I'll be dumb tomorrow....

I don't think you can order to go on the weekends.
author: Jona C.

description:
This food here is absolutely deserving of 5 stars.  But the wait time is just absurd, hence the 4 stars.  Came here last Sunday (rainy sunday) hoping the rain would fend off some patrons.  Waited probably 30 or so minutes outside, then 15 inside for 45 min total wait.  We got inside right before the downpour began, so we were able to actually eat here.  Had we arrived 15 minutes later, there is no way we would have waited in that rain.  So that was that.

For food, I had a florentine scramble, and a 'side' of the french toast sampler.  I wanted bacon, and the florentine had that.  I wanted sweet, and the sampler had that.  So I got both.  The french toast sampler was awesome, with fresh fruit and 3 different varieties of dessert bread tastefully prepared for my ravenous appetite.  As for the scramble, that thing was gone before I even realized it.  Got it with the sourdough, and the cheese, bacon, spinach and potatoes that accompanied it all were also dominated.  I didn't feel too pushed by other patrons, even with this weather.  I may have been too into the matter at hand though.  Service was good, drinks were good, I just wish this place didn't have such a long wait otherwise I would have quite a few more afternoons filled with food coma induced napping.
author: William B.

description:
this place was our first stop in san fran after having drove 6 1/2 hrs from OC. we got there around 8am, tired and starving. not to mention it was sprinkling out and the line had already wrapped around the building. but i wasn't about to skip out on the place that so many friends raved about. so we stood shivering in the cold , waited and waited. befriended a nice elderly couple and chatted away for almost an hour. finally got in. waited again by the cashier for another 15 min. 

ordered the crab dungeness crab omelet and 2 fresh squeezed orange juice cups. pretty pricey i must say. the total came out to be 30 dollars. OH EM GEE. i have never spent that much on breakfast, ever. i was even more surprised when our drinks arrived, the cups were half the size of my hand, literally, for 3 dollars each. the bf found it amusing that we spent that much on orange juice when he has a big orange tree at home which i never touch.. sighs..

the omelet, however, was very good. egg, crab and avocado definitely blended nicely together. we enjoyed it a lot.

overall i would say it was worth the experience. the restaurant, even though small, was cozy and had a homely feel to it. the workers were nice, the customers were nice. not too crazy about the price, but i would come here again the next time i visit SF, and try their french toast.
author: Anh L.

description:
I'm convinced that the cooks on the weekend are different than the ones on the weekdays.  Everything seems to taste better when I come here on the weekend.  But then of course, there's the weekend line to deal with, that I usually manage to avoid by arriving at 7:45am or 2:30pm.  

Here's what I learned on my last visit this Sunday when I arrived at 11am:

Expected wait times:

First green awning - 5 to 30 minutes

White wall - 30 minutes to 1 hour

2nd green awning - 1 hour to 1.5 hours

Blue awning - 1.5 hours to 2 hours

Anything past the blue awning - It's good.  But it's not that good.  Eat elsewhere.  Come back another day.
author: LaSha G.

description: Had to go back for seconds! Lovely breakfast and brunch spot. I absolutely hate the line outside this shop, it is not healthy and it easily lasts at least an hour to an hour and a half ( i really am urging management to take some action to finally remove this issue)  but once you are finally seated with a plate in front of you, you  remember why you came. The food is just wonderful!
author: Kemi T.

description: Amazeballs! Best fresh crabmeant omelette ever.  Worth the wait!
author: Maryellen P.

description: After reading the reviews about the long wait I was skeptical.  We went on a weekday and got there about 10 minutes before they opened.  There was a line but not too bad.  We were seated with food within an hour.  The service was friendly and everything was good.  I had the cinnamon french toast with fresh berries.  The berries were ripe and fresh and the french toast was pretty good.  The homemade jam was delicious.  Overall I went hear because it was highly recommended, I probably wouldn't wait in line again though.  It was good but I wasn't blown away.
author: Daisy T.

description: Hate the long line -- but love the baked goods and the eggs benedict. It's a cute little breakfast spot. I only come here when I have a friend visiting from out of town.
author: Shivani S.

description:
be prepared to wait and stand in line for a very long time.  even though we came here towards the end of brunch, we had to wait.  i can't imagine waiting in the blistering cold during primetime.  because everyone always talks about mama's, i had to give this place a try.  

they have a lot of specials that include dungeness crab and lobster, i would definitely give those a try unless you're not a fan of seafood.

eats:

shrimp and avocado benedict: i love benedicts and i loved this play on this benedict.  the shrimp was so so but i really liked the avocado with this benedict.

nelson's rancheros: this was so so meaning i've had better huevos rancheros.  i'd definitely try another dish when you're here.

french toast: they let you order smaller portions of french toast.  the chocolate banana french toast was delicious as well as the banana nut which was topped with an abundance of bananas.

tips: come here early or late or bring a book to read or better yet good company who will keep you highly entertained in line.
author: Carli F.

description: I'd heard so much about this place that I knew I had to stop by during my visit to SF. My friend and I waited 1.5 hours in line at 1 PM to have brunch. I guess by this point, it's pointless of me to call it brunch. After we ordered, we had to wait an additional 15 minutes to be seated. Surprisingly, our food arrived relatively quickly (compared to how long we had waited). I got the Vegetarian Eggs Benedict and my friend got the Monte Cristo with the Assorted French Toast Plate. Needless to say, I've had better. I must say, though, considering how busy this place is, our waitress was extremely friendly.
author: Janice C.

description: Mike at the grill was very helpful in picking what to have Sunday morning. Everything was great and well worth the wait (arrived 20 minutes before opening and was 20th in line, 50 people behind me when the doors opened - cabs all over the place)! My new fav breakfast place in Washington Square.
author: Mr C.

description: Overall, brunch was pretty good. Egg dishes were average, but baked goods and pancakes were delicious. Would go back again, but not sure the LONG line (about 2hours) was worth it for me.
author: Kim S.

description: Hands down the BEST meal I had in San Francisco.  Waited in line for two hours which were well worth it!  While waiting in line, one of the servers came out with some homemade scones and breads, what an amazing little teaser!  The french toast sampler was out of this world, with each different type of bread better than the next.  The fresh fruit on top was delicious.  The homemade strawberry jam and apricot scones were to die for and the coffee was great!  The service was wonderful!  What a great little place!!
author: Jenna W.

description:
1. OMG the Line Outside is long
2. OMG the Line isn't moving
3. OMG the Line is a trickle
4. OMG the Line CONTINUES inside!
5. OMG you Order & PAY while standing in Line inside
6. OMG there's no priority for seating even after you pay in Line.
7. Sure, the food was good. 
8. Not worth it.
9. Not that kid friendly, see 1-8
author: AxeMe A.

description:
11/19/09
a friend and I went to Mama's for brunch. We both had eggs bene, I had the vegetable one, she had the florentine. both excellent. great place, breakfast all day, but they have lunch food too. definitely a must go to in North Beach, though not Italian! I didn't get coffee, but wish I did, it smelled fantastic. cash only, and you have to wait to order in line, pay, then wait for a table to sit at. there is a tiny tiny bathroom outside in the back. I had seen a huge line here the day before, but this time it wasn't so bad. we got right in and things went pretty quick! Wish I could've eaten there again, I wanted to try so many other things!!!
author: Liza M.

description:
I knew what I was getting into. And I hoped it was worth the wait, and in the end, I was really satisfied and left feeling a little more complete, but I keep wondering why I put myself through the torture. We got in line around 11:30 and the line was pretty long, but the mistake was coming hungry. The minutes dragged on and I could smell the food coming through the open windows which churned my stomach even more. And then when I got to the windows I saw all the people eating the beautiful plates of food I was smelling, and then even after stepping foot inside I spent a good chunk of time watching the chefs cooking while waiting to order and be seated. Everything was good and the jam was delicious and worked REALLY well with the monte cristo and I usually stay away from any type of jam. The four thick evenly battered and grilled pieces of sandwich was the perfect texture with the right ratio of meats to cheese. My favorite from the French toast sampler HANDS DOWN was the orange cranberry walnut bread; the others didn't stand out too much, but still thick and fluffy nonetheless.

Staff was friendly and attentive among the chaos inside and the tiny diner felt like a local establishment you'd visit in a small town, even though there were too many things going on. Overall, the food was delicious but I'm not sure if that was because my stomach was eating away at itself by the time I took my first bite or if it really was that standout. Maybe that's the key to their system: get you super hungry so you think the food tastes better, and since you're hungry, you eat fast so seats get freed up faster? Worth a try in my book, but definitely not a place you'd be a regular at, unless you're a masochist that wants to sacrifice at least an hour each visit.
author: Stephanie T.

description: This place is amazing!!!! Had to stand in line for ore than an hour in the rain but well worth it, must try: Monte Carlos
author: Amanda N.

description:
this place is OK - i think it's over hyped.   

i would not go there again and wait for 1 hour to get in.   there are literally 2 lines...  one line on the outside...  you'd think... "oh, this is manageable, there's a line everywhere else so I'm just going to wait... ".    EEK, WRONG!   once they let you in, there's another line to place your order and be seated.   HA!

i had the french toast sampler and salmon egg benedict.   i'd have to say the food was just so-so.   if you like truly great french toasts, go to Beretta in the Mission.   the french toasts at mama's, you can find at other diners, i'm sure.   my salmon egg benedict was also just ok... a little on the salty side.

the coffee...  there's a cup on your table and they come around and pour once in a while.   the taste was not memorable, no clue what beans or roast they used.   

for superior food, i'd recommend Just For You in Potrero Hill.   there's a wait in the weekend but not as atrocious.   and the service there is way faster than at Mama's.
author: Kelly M.

description:
90 minutes wait for a overcooked poached egg and over lemony hollandaise sauce! Totally NOT worth it.  

For $40, my bf and I had an freshly squeezed orange juice (definitely spiked with sugar!!!), a crab omelet (not very tasty), and the horrible egg benedict I described above.   The best part of the meal?  The roasted potatoes.  

I have no idea why this place is so popular!  I can make better egg benedict that they do!  I came here and lined up because of the hype.  However..... never again!  Tons of other better place.  I know you won't believe me (because I thought it is still worth it after reading all the other negative reviews)...so.... line up once and you can be the judge.
author: F C.

description:
Mama's serves one of the best breakfasts in San Francisco.  I have known about their long wait outside the place.  So we thought we would get there late at 2PM on a Sunday after everybody else.  The wait then was still 1/2 hour - ah patience my friend.

We ordered the Kugelhuph and the Northern Italian omelette.  The Kugelhuph is one of their french toast selections that has golden raisins, cinnamon, dates and sliced almonds.  Golly, this thing was awesome!  It was recommended to try their ollaliberry jam with the french toast, as it is better than having maple syrup.  Yes, they are right on this too.  The Northern Italian omelette had pancetta, mushroom, fresh basil, tomato and garlic jack cheese.  Love the size of the omelette (very big) - its served with grilled red potatoes and my choice of toast (sourdough baguette).  This is excellent too!  

I have been told that this place has been here for 56 years.  With Mama's, good things come to those that wait!  Remember to practice your patience while in line.
author: Janet H.

description: Start by saying, "over rated". Not worth the long wait in line and tiny servings. They have the breakfast market cornered, big reason they are so busy because there are no other breakfast places in close proximity. Prices are on par with the area. Wouldn't waste 2.5 hours for again.
author: Aaron F.

description:
Good lord, what more can one add to a place that already has 714 reviews?!  Eh, what's another, right?  

My buddy and I thought we'd be shrewd and get there 10 minutes early before they opened to avoid a line on an early Saturday morning.  Fat chance.  There was already a rather long line formed by the time we arrived. 

The food is very solid here.  Tasty, ample quantity but expensive for breakfast food.  I mean some of the specials were $20.  For breakfast?!  With the kind of crowd this place garners, you'd think they could keep some of the prices down a bit.  

The biggest perk about this place is that you might be fortunate enough to meet cool people while waiting in that awful line that barely moves.
