We met two very cool women, Dana and Heidi, who were gracious enough to share a table with us (in order to get seated quicker) and then offered to drive us (two perfect strangers) to our next destination.  How freakin cool is that?  I'm beginning to like this city more and more.

Mama's gets a mixed review from me.  Good food but the prices, long lines and the fact they don't accept credit cards are big minuses.  Pshaw!
author: Jim D.

description: Is it amazing because I'm so hungry after waiting to eat for an hour or because it's really the best breakfast spot in north Beach? Hunger clouds my judgement, but I can tell you that their pancetta eggs Benedict and French toast platter keeps me coming back time and time again--even with a year-round hour wait at all times. Skip the omelets, which are far less good than the Benedict's and sweet options.
author: Sam S.

description:
I'm a regular at Mama's for the following:
1. The jam available on every table... will take whatever you ordered to a whole new level of AMAZING.
2. Pan Dore (never tasted french toast this good, the lemon butter sauce kicks butt).
3. Crumb cake ( not something people usually order but I looove it)
4. Dollar-sized pancakes with raspberries and blueberries (perfect for a satiating meal)
5. North Beacher M'Omellette (the potatoes on the side are so-so).

My one complaint: some servers leave the tip from the previous person on the table and not-so-discreetly grab it when you sit down. I don't need a reminder to tip, thanks very much! ;-)
author: Virginia S.

description: It's eggs, pancakes, french toast and bacon. What's there to rave about? All in all it satisified my breakfast cravings.
author: K T Y.

description:
Yes, breakfast is simple and I keep it simple when I go to Mama's.

Somehow they turn an omelet, potatoes and sourdough bread into art. Amazing, amazing stuff. With a side of bacon and fresh OJ and I am in heaven.

Not a big french toast fan, but with chocolate and fresh fruit, it is amazing.

Yeah the line sucks, just go during the week or have someone stand in line for you.
author: Howie F.

description:
BLUEBERRY MUFFIN BREAD
Best thing I had here... so tasty.  

OMELET
Was expecting it to be spectacular.  Far from it.  It was good, but not "an hour wait" good.  Too greasy.

EGGS BENEDICT
With all the great baking going on up in here... you put it on the standard English Muffin?  Common now.

MONTE CRISTO SANDWICH
Tiny.  Adorable.  Exactly what it's not supposed to be.  Should be chock full of ham, cheese, and fat as a stuffed pig.  Not here.  Hardly any meat and cheese at all.  And hardly any sandwich for that matter... 3 little wedges.  And hey... where is the dame syrup!?!?!

STAFF
Nice people.

PARKING
Nightmare.

OVERALL
I can see how this might have been a top breakfast place at some point... it still has the air... but I have had much, much, better for far less to-do.  Oh, and for f sake... if you have this volume of business, take credit cards.  Really.
author: Dan M.

description:
Amazingly there wasn't  a line the other morning, so I figured it was one of those rare moments to  enjoy.  

The food is definitely pleasant and enjoyable.  It reminds me of an upscale breakfast at an upscale hotel, only this is at a quaint little corner joint. 

All in all, it's great...not sure if I would ever wait in line more than 15 minutes, but if you wander by and don't see a line...well, why not enjoy ?
author: Charlie B.

description:
Well, well what can I say....breakfast has never been better. I am truly more of a breakfast at noon kind of a girl, so a place like Mama's is perf. for me, serving b-fast until the late afternoon. 

Everyone's heard of the place, seen the line, and wondered what the big D is. Well, I am here to tell you. After you wait in the line outside, you wait in a shorter line on the inside. The menu on the outside window is helpful so you can get a head start on what you would like to order. Once you're in, you're golden. The smell of french toast and pancake batter is tantalizing. Your eyes will gloss over as you see bowls lined up on the counter brimming with fresh fruit. The kitchen/counter is busy and makes you realize how fresh everything really is. 

The menu has tons of variations of french toast entrees, omelets, scrambles, pancakes, and lunch choices (salads, quiche, sandwiches, etc.) I had an egg-white veggie scramble with fresh fruit on the side (so good and healthy to boot). The P-Cakes w/ fresh berries were also amazing (one order can easily be shared). You pay when you order so sit down, enjoy an excellent  breakfast, and leave your tip at the table. 

FYI: go with the fresh OJ (or a Mimosa). The bloodymary was not the greatest.
author: Theresa T.

description: I went for brunch. WOW.  I've heard this place is the best in San Francisco. It lived up and beyond its reputation.  I ordered the pancakes with chocolate toppings = heaven.  I also split a veggie omelete, which is better than most omelets I've had.  The really long line only lives up to Mama's reputation, that it's the best in SF.  You must go, if you visit!
author: Ashley G.

description: worth the wait. yes theres a line. yes it takes about 45 mins or more but its the same when you go to an olive garden or cheesecake factory so you can do it for this spot ! eggs benedict with mushrooms was to die for. fresh lemonade was great. i will give it 4 stars only bc there weren't free refills so i felt like i had to really sip on that lemonade... also the bathroom is a little weird to get there you gotta go through the kitchen area and some stairs outside... but OTHER then that i loved it !!
author: rza S.

description: We went in with high expectations but the wait was not worth it. Pancakes were okay (1 out of 3 was good), bread was hard, Hollandaise sauce was not very good. Only the jelly and service were great.
author: Abhishek K.

description: Great brunch spot.  Expect to wait at least 30 minutes, at most ~2 hours.  It's worth the wait, though.  I recommend going on a weekday or at least *not* a holiday weekend to minimize the wait.  Note that they don't accept credit cards; cash and debit cards only.
author: Jason T.

description:
Monte Cristo is the best you will ever have. We also got the Crab Benedict and french toast, which were very good as well. The homemade jam was also quite tasty. 

On the weekends you will be faced with a pretty long wait. We got there at 8:30 and waited about an hour- but it was worth it for sure. By the time we sat down, the wait probably was around 2 hours. 

Everything was very good. However, if I had it to do all over again- considering the price comparison of all menu items.....i would have just gotten like 5 Monte Cristos. Definitely eat breakfast or brunch here if you get the chance- the hype is real.
author: Jesse A.

description:
It's not that good. They have a douchebag  working there who comes across as mentally challenged and who barely speaks English barking orders that you wait outside to create the illusion that it's a hot spot. It's freakin French toast people. Overpriced for that matter. Obnoxious pretentious a-holes...

Oh and the clientele...

"oh I love mama's...it's like San Fran...so cosmopolitan."

GO HOME TRANSPLANTS - you f-ed up our city for us locals enough already.

Nothing is worth waiting 2 hours in line for... I'd rather go to IHOP...which by the way is just down the street
author: Phil L.

description:
The first time I ate at Mama's, I was in love....with the food and my then-boyfriend.

The second time I ate at Mama's, I was disappointed....with the food and the model thin pretty boy I was then kinda sorta considering dating. 

Based on my experiences, I learned a couple of things.

First, the wait at Mama's on weekend is long. Very long. So you must go there with someone whose company you truly enjoy, so much so that the SF chilly wind wouldn't bother you. Otherwise, you would inevitably raise your expectations for the food to compensate for the pain, which is not really fair (especially if you intend to yelp afterwards).

Second, Mama's has some interesting dishes you would not want to miss. Their serving portion is generous. Unless you are going there in a large group, and especially if you are going there with just one another person besides yourself, make sure that your companion LOVES to eat and LOVES to eat a lot.  

The first time I tried Mama's, the wait didn't bother me. Love was in the air. We shared Dugeness crab benedict, day's special omelet, and the combination french toast. Needless to say, the 6'3" 230+ lbs then-boyfriend and 5'3" *cough* I cleaned up the plates, smiling, laughing, and savoring each bite. The french toast was made of three different kinds of sweet bread, which gave each slice different texture and varying degree of sweetness. It's fun sharing it with someone and discuss which one's your favorite and why. With the homemade jam, this was the best french toast I'd ever tasted. The Dungeness crab benedict was made of fresh and authentic ingredients, where each ingredient retained its original flavor yet worked together beautifully. This was truly a 5+ star experience. 

The second time I went there, the wind seemed colder. The wait seemed much longer. Once inside, I ordered the divine french toast to boost my mood along with some kind of eggs benedict, and the pretty boy ordered  the Dungeness crab benedict. After a long wait, the food was served, and I was disappointed. The poached eggs were over-cooked. The model-thin pretty boy didn't seem to enjoy eating too much and just poked his eggs and took a few bites of crab. The french toast was still good but went cold and hard barely touched. The food was still good, but the magic was gone.  I felt like this was a 3 star experience.

Next time, I'll go there on a weekday alone, just so that I can write an objective review.
author: Nana N.

description: San Francisco institution. Favorite of locals and tourist alike. One of the best brunch places in the city. Portions are generous and delicious. Cash only. Be prepared to wait especially on weekends.
author: Les W.

description: Long wait, Very over priced. On top of all of this the food was not very good. Had the crab benedict and was so looking forward to a great breakfast but when it arrived and I took my first bite the crab tasted old and did not leave a  pleasant taste in my mouth.
author: Michael W.

description:
The food really is AMAZING here. But like a lot of other reviewers, I waited close to 2 hours in line!

 I remember one saturday I was searching yelp for the best brunch in the city and mama's most definitely seemed to hold that title. I also read how everyone was waiting hours in line for brunch on saturdays and sundays but I thought to myself, "Oh Meagan, you know how people exaggerate!"

So the next day (sunday), my boyfriend and I jogged on over to mama's and saw the line. We got there early to try and beat it, 8am or so, early for a Sunday. The line didn't look too bad, but we had no idea how little tables they had. So we waited almost 2 hours, made new friends in line, and finally got to try the DELICIOUS food!

I ordered the french toast sampler (I think) and my boyfriend ordered the Eggs Benedict. Both were very good.

Like many other reviewers have mentioned, the food is most definitely 5 stars, but I would only go again if it was during the week when the line was (hopefully) a bit shorter!
author: Meagan R.

description:
I must admit, their french toast with fresh berries is pretty damn good.  When Cecile R. suggested this place as our meeting spot on a Friday morning, I scanned the reviews and confirmed the date, time and place.  I kept moving the time a bit later with each reply, and she kept dropping hints that there might be a wait. In my mind, I thought "On a Friday morning? Can't be! People should be at work."

Well, during my 4-day trip to San Francisco, the sun was shining and the weather was sweet. Birds were chirping, everyone was gay and apparently also wanted to eat at Mama's.  I arrived just 10 minutes prior to our designated meeting time of 9:30. Cecile was already waiting in line to order inside; not lines outside just yet.  

We both ordered the french toast with fresh berries, a side of bacon and scrambled eggs. We were seated immediately.  Once our food arrived, I looked at the front entrance to find that the bottom half of the dutch front door was closed and there were faces eagerly peering in.  Wow, Cecile was right.  These locals mean business when it comes to Mama's!!!

Our server was VERY attentive and each time he brisked by he would move the container of jam closer to our plates and say, "Try the jam with the french toast."  Great suggestion! The homemade jam matched perfectly with the french toast.  

I love you Mama!
author: Liza S.

description: First of all, it's SO worth the wait in line...second, the carrot cake is like whipped heaven and third....umm it's just plain really good!! Thanks Mama, we will DEFINITELY be back for more!
author: S L.

description:
Great breakfast, I really liked the potatoes and the Hollandaise sauce on the Egg Benny.

Wait can be REALLY long so be prepared to wait because the place is TINY.  Parking can be rough too so be prepared.

FRESH OJ was great also.

The Monte Cristo was awesome, not greasy like I thought it might turn out but just perfect.  They use really great ham also.
author: Shawn A.

description:
I'm a healthy eater, so I try and avoid brunch items that involve a lot of greasy animal parts. Sadly, this limits my selection to tofu scrambles and egg white scrambles and, when I'm not feeling adventurous, scrambles. 

It gets boring.

And places tend to charge more for them because some component of the slaw happens to be "organic." There's supposedly also a price premium for ordering a dish that involves a lot of advanced culinary techniques like stirring clockwise and stirring counterclockwise. 

Thankfully, Mama's offers a great menu of healthy items (yes, even a scramble, but it's surprisingly hearty) and charges less for it. And though they only accept cash and the wait can be long, you accept it because the reciprocated dining experience is pleasant. 

The last time I went, we were seated by the door. It was a little weird at first, doing things while the people in line stared and salivated... but then I realized that's pretty much how my life goes every day, so I ignored them and brought my focus back on my scramble.
author: Keane L.

description: The line here was so long and my friends and I stood in line for an hour before we were seated, but it was totally worth it! Since we waited so long in line, we ended up eating sooo much food. By the end of the meal, I was unable to fully stand up. My belly was weighing me down. I tried both the French Toast sampler (swedish cinnamon, banana nut, and orange cranberry french toasts) and the Northern Italian M'Omelette: Pancetta (Italian Cured Bacon), Mushroom, Fresh Basil, Tomato, and Garlic Jack Cheese. They were sooooo good! One of the best omelettes ever...the ingredients went together really well. The Garlic Jack Cheese was the bomb. The pancetta was slightly too salty for me but overall it was still delicious. French toast sampler was also really good...i ate it with the copious fruit that came with the dish as well as their homemade jam instead of syrup. Don't like my french toast being too soggy or too sweet. I heard that their syrup isn't unbearably sweet tho and tasted healthy ^_^ Out of the 3 different french toasts, I liked the orange cranberry one the best, then the swedish cinnamon. The banana nut one basically tasted just like banana bread (less like a french toast). My friend who ordered the monte cristo was also very impressed! See a picture that was taken!
author: Liwei Y.

description: Great food, amazing service. Everything here is made from scratch, the banana nut bread french toast was out of this world and the eggs benedict were perfect. It'd be nicer if they have more space and took credit cards (cash only, or $1 additional charge for using a debit card).
author: Don W.

description:
This is a good quality breakfast restaurant. They do make a good breakfast. The servers are nice. The price is fair. 

The wait is probably not worth it. Although, the wait isn't really their fault, so can't knock them for that. Well, I guess technically, it is their fault for attracting customers, but the negative side effects of having to wait 2.5 hours to sit down, isn't their fault (which I would do only for the experiment, and to make my lady happy). There is most definitely some external factor at play that is not the actual quality/value ratio of the breakfast that makes people wait that long, when there are so many other options. Perhaps the war stories, perhaps the nice weather, not sure, but people really like waiting their.
author: doug d.

description: One word--OVERRATED. Being a local, and living in the neighborhood, I see the line that goes out Mama's doors everyday. I always say that I feel bad for the people/tourists in line because they wait 45min to 1 hour and 30 min for just an--- average meal. Im not saying that the food is bad, its just not worth waiting for. There are much better things to do with your time while visiting an amazing city like San Francisco.
author: Samantha R.

description:
love, LOVE Mama's to death!

The only bad thing I can say about this place would be the lack of parking (depending on when you arrive) and the crazy wait, especially during their busy hours (close to breakfast time).

It's one of those order and pay places so it's great for friends but maybe not so much for dates.

The waitresses and staff are always friendly and welcoming which is another reason why I love this place.  It's cute and small, perfect for good conversations and great food.

For all you newbies, when in doubt, order the Monte Cristo.  It's breast of turkey, baked ham, cheddar and havarti cheese bread-dipped in egg & grilled, served with Mama's special homemade jam.  I am SO not a jam person but Mama's has made a convert out of me.  Trust me on this one.

I've also tried countless other items but by far, the Monte Cristo is the one most worth boasting about.
author: Lisa W.

description:
Absolutely delicious but not worth a two-hour out-the-door wait. Maybe a half hour wait, at most, after which you'll still be hungry and ready to ravish the food, rather than left numb from hunger after a two-hour wait... I've experienced both! 

Parking is not too bad, even during peak times. I've never had to circle for more than ten minutes. Usually there is meter around the area or you can walk a few blocks further and park at two-hour parking. Just remember when you parked because you pretty much will have to move the car right after you order because you waited for two-hours! Have I emphasized the two-hour wait enough...?? It's ridiculous but it's even more ridiculous how many people would wait that, only to finish their grub in less than fifteen minutes... 

The place is tiny!! The service is hit or miss. The servers are usually friendly but the cashier can be downright rude with attitude! Might've been his off day... 

Everything looks delicious there but I only come for the Monte Cristo. A Monte Cristo, dipped in egg and fried like french toast, with a side of delicious berry jam! My company also enjoy their Eggs Benedict and french toast. 

Come during "down"-er time, early morning on a weekday and order the Monte Cristo!!
author: Cynthia W.

description:
I wanted to hate this place so badly.  I live 3 blocks away from this restaurant and always said to myself that I would never wait 1/2 hour to 45 minutes for breakfast.  Always called the people waiting in lines "idiots" for waiting in line for food.  A friend stayed over one nite and we decided to go check it out.  This day I was the idiot. 

Waited in line outside.................went inside..............waited in line inside.   It was awesome.  Service was great.  Food was great. Ambiance was cozy. 

Sorta like waiting in line at an amusement park where you know it's going to be well worth the wait.
author: jason g.

description: I had a Monte Cristo for the first time ever. It was sooo good. All others will be very hard to compare.
author: Chris V.

description:
There are three things that suck about Mama's: 
* they aren't open on Mondays, so I can't indulge my momolette hankering on that day 
* they do not accept credit cards, which means someone else is almost always paying because I am not known to carry cash 
* the 1-1 1/2 hour wait on the weekends 

But, the good outweighs the bad: 
* fantastic views of one of San Francisco's funnest & most historic neighborhoods 
* fast service; you order and pay at the register (while being able to watch them prepare other customers' food) and then you wait for a table to open up 
* prices are on par with every other good breakfast place 
* my two favorite momolettes are "the californian" (bacon, avocado & jack cheese) or "SOB south of the border" (black beans, salsa, sour cream.) 
* their freshly squeezed OJ is sweet & pulpy, just the way I like it & their mimosas are strong, again, just the way I like it. 
* my Mama's buddy & i always split a different french toast every time we go, but the Pan Dore & the Chocolate Cinnamon with fresh berries are the most decadent. 

They've got a patron for life in me (only just not on Mondays when they're not open & not during the weekend breakfast rush; I don't like to have to wait too long for my french toast eating experience to begin.)
author: Fancypants X.

description: Legendary wait. If you have an hour and a half to kill then wait in line. The wait makes the food taste better. You're probably starving to death and then there's the windows. This goes both ways. You're staring into the windows watching everyone enjoy their food, making you even more hungry. After you're finally seated, you relish the limelight as everyone standing outside catches glances of your omelette and french toast sampler. Soak in the deliciousness and pretend you're enjoying it more than you should be. Sweet revenge.
author: Jake J.

description:
Damn this place is gooooood! While visiting San Fran a few weeks ago - and after a high recommendation from my friend, we tested out Mama's. On a Wednesday morning, we arrived at Mama's with high expectations.

For you newbies, you stand in line to order - cash only. When a table opens up, you are directed by the cashier to the table. It's actually a pretty efficient process.

What did we order? I ordered the prosciutto eggs benedict. (I'm savoring over that dish as I type now.) If you're a fan of eggs benedict, they have several to choose from. My sis ordered the chocolate french toast with berries. The food came fast and had amazing flavor.

The service was 5 stars! At a place that turns tables faster than you can blink, our waitress was attentive, patient, and just so nice. 

Love it.
author: Sharon W.

description: WORTH THE WAIT!!! Also it is less of a wait if you go towards the later part of the morning and on a weekday, but nonetheless it is worth it!  I suggest sharing and starting off with the Monte Cristo! The french toast is pretty good! My friend had the Washington Square Omelette  Breakfast I believe and loved it! Anytime you are in San Fran this little gem is a must visit spot for sure!!!
author: Mimi A.

description:
I miss my MAMA!!! 

i waited in line for like 45 min and i was mad hungry.  my friends told me to check this place out because they said it's really good.  I'm a big breakfast person so I decided to check it out for once.  Once i walked into the place, they had so many choices for you to pick to eat.  I can't remember what i ordered.  I think it was scrambled florentine.  All I can remember the food was really good.  The prices were decent.  

You know how mamas do...no one can beat mama's cooking!
author: Henry K.

description:
So I did it... 

I waited in line 1.5 hours to get breakfast. Yes, it's true and was worth every 5,400 seconds. The wait was treacherous! Let me tell you, nothing like waiting outside in a line looking through the window drooling at patrons eating dungeonous crab and melted brie omelets. To add insult to injury... they all looked happy and I was miserably hungry. Misery loves company, let me tell you! 

Once you actually get inside this breakfast establishment the line still continues until the register (where you place your order). Inside, this is where you will see the artists at work. They are speedily making french toast with chocolate and mounds of fruit atop, or lumping crab and spinach inside a juicy omelet. A nice service touch is that the waitresses will come by offering free dark chocolate brownies to those still waiting in line. Niceeeee! 

It was my turn, and I dropped $30 for this crustacean shmorgesborg. This included a ginormous egg white omelet filled with crab, swiss cheese, spinach, and avocado. Accompanying this beauty was also potatoes and toast. Last but not least a bloody marry to wash it down. Not just any marry touches these lips... but Mama's marry with mama's famous mix looked capable of doing the job. I always get them extra spicy with a side of horseradish. It was good shit! Nothing had to be added at the table. All fresh ingredients with a nice brazilian soccer team kick. Would I go back... yes!  thanks nancy t. for showing me the light.

p.s. this place is tiny and the bathroom is basically an outhouse behind the kitchen.
author: Rhett S.

description:
Mama! Mama I'm coming hoooome.

There are two categories of hyped up places: Those that are somehow popular for reasons other than the quality of the establishment, and those that are pretty good, but are so talked about that nothing could live up to the expectations. Mama's is definitely the latter.

At 12:30 on a Thursday there were a couple of people ahead of us (and the whole order first and then sit thing is strange, but efficient I imagine). On a weekend morn I'm sure I'd probably go to the store and cook at home before standing in line for an hour or more, but it WAS really good and deserving of praise. Around 1, everyone went back to work and we were able to enjoy our meals in relative peace. 

Like every other well-known good breakfast place, better to hit it off hours.
author: Jon L.

description:
deserving of 5 stars admittedly...but there were two things that accounted for the lack of the 5th...wait time of an hour and feeling rushed towards the end of the meal. 

food was excellent! I suggest visiting on the weekend to get a taste of the crab Benedict. Service was good with the exception of towards the end when I was asked three times if I was through...even though there was still food on the plate and I gave no indication of. eh...not too much of a biggie but when u were waiting for an hour plus beforehand....

side note:  bring the hard "chedda"...skrilla...they do NOT accept CC's...c'mon now mama's...you're in a prime location of san francisco with a line of people who willingly wait for an hour or more to partake in stuffing their faces with your grub...UPGRADE! take our money please...but hows about making it a little easier on us...=)

overall...GREAT place for brunch....
author: Ed W.

description: We got there an hour and a half before it opened to be the first people inside and it was worth it. The monte cristo and their homemade jam are to-die-for and it's been on my mind for nearly a month after now. Unfortunately, they only sell their jam during the holidays though...
author: Heidi C.

description:
Food was solid breakfast standards. My California omelette was loaded with bacon and avocado....my favorite. I love places that pack it in. Nice touch with the potatoes.

Mimosa was one of the best I've ever had. Perfect blend of oj and champagne. 

Minus a star for the ridiculous line, but honestly, if you can't hack it by waiting for 45 minutes, then you don't deserve the food.

Also, one of the waitresses looks like Melrose from Top Model. My hungover friend couldn't stop ogling her. 

I apologize for the shortness of this. I may still be drunk.
author: Devon S.

description:
Might be the busiest breakfast place Ive ever seen. Loooong line when we got there and I had to be convinced it was worth it. It was.
I ordered  the crab omelet  and was blown away. Lots of Fresh crab cooked just right. A little pricey for breakfast, line was way long. I do not think I would eat here every day, but man it was pretty good.
author: jd a.

description:
Just do it...at least once.  Get in that long line for weekend brunch.  The food is worth trying...at least once (or figure out the off-peak times to go).  Even on a cold, drizzly Saturday morning, the line to get into the restaurant was 1 hour then another 15 minutes to order and be seated.  3 of my girlfriends and I wanted all breakfast foods and shared the Dungeness crab benedict special, Monte Cristo sandwich, Apple Pan Dore, an omelette, coffee cake, and a side of bacon.  Yes, we finished it all. 

Everything was excellent, but the standouts were the Apple Pan Dore (french toast with apples and lemony buttery sauce) , meaty not too greasy bacon, coffee cake, and the Monte Cristo (turkey, egg and cheese sandwich dipped French toast-style and grilled and served w/ jam).  I'd pass on the crab benedict the next time since the Hollandaise sauce masks the taste of the fresh crab anyway.  Everything else was under $10 and I could go back every day of the week to try more of their French toasts.   

I've totally been craving the Monte Cristo but it seems easy to make at home.  Ooooh, I found Mama's recipe which was featured on Food Network.  I'll definitely add bacon to it when I make it. 
http://www.foodnetwork.com/food/recipes/recipe/0,,FOOD_9936_23807,00.html
author: Mimi L.

description: Mama's is SOOOOOO good!  We went on a Friday and arrived at 8:30 am.  Mama's opens at 8am.  There was already a line outside.  We were seated at 9am.  Its a small little cafe so they cannot accommodate large groups.  I had the Dungeness Crab Benedict which was amazingly good, I substituted fruit instead of the breakfast potatoes which is not offered but they will accommodate if you ask. They do not skimp on the crab.  My husband had the Northern Italian Omelet which was also very good.   When we left the waiting line had doubled.  Its is a little pricey but we found it worth it.  I would recommend getting there when they open and also going on the week days instead of weekends.   The staff were very friendly and the place is clean.  Glad we experienced Mama's while we were visiting San Fran.
author: Christine T.

description:
Mama's is definitely very good but NOT as good as Dottie's True Blue Cafe (see review). Because I tried Dottie's first, I was not as wowed by Mama's as I might have otherwise been. Even though Mama's is right in my North Beach neighborhood, I would still choose Dottie's... 

BUT... Mama's is in a great location overlooking Washington Square Park. The restaurant is super cute with a little French 1/2 door at the entrance and cute, colorful tables inside. You can probably expect to wait in line about 30 minutes during the week and an hour on the weekend... so bring good friends so that you can chat in line (and then steal their food once you order!). You order in front of the kitchen which is cooking up tempting deliciousness. Both times I've come, I've ordered egg dishes and been a little bit disappointed. My friend tried the crab omelet and it was delicious but EXPENSIVE (about $16?!). I've heard that the sweets with fresh fruit are really good and will probably need to try them next time... Mama's also serves up mimosas, bloody mary's, okay coffee, etc so you can pick your morning poison. I'd recommend checking out Mama's but knowing that it's, at best, only the second-best...
author: Meghan P.

description:
"Let's go to Mama's!"

It's 7:40am on a Saturday morning. For some reason, the first image that pops into my head when I wake up is the line that usually weaves out the doors at Mama's on Washington Square.  That is exactly the same image that I see as we pull up to Mama's. This is despite the restaurant still has 10 minutes till it opens. Who cares?!! I want Mama to cook for me. This is NOT mediocre food. It's good. It's wow...ooh...it's now!

THE STAFF - friendly as their fresh squeezed orange juice.

THE WAIT - Who cares? Grab a cup of Joe, a newspaper, some nuts (food or friends), and your set to loiter in Q.  

THE COFFEE - Sucks! But, who cares again? Not all coffee is like Blue Bottle.

SOME OF MY FAVORITE DISHES: (DRUM ROLL)

Apple Pan Dore - If you feel like something sweet and not in the mood for pancakes and you like anything apple. This is your dish. Yum. This is even a good dish to share for dessert. Dessert for breakfast? HELL YEAH!

Swedish Cinnamon French Toast - Delish-shee-o-sis! (so good, it gets a new word to describe it!)

M'Omelette - Tested and approved the California, S.O.B., and the Farmers omelette. 

SERVING SIZES - Like OMG Huge!

But, lets not stop there...Mama's has weekend specials. Usually local food items are involved like crab, avocados, tomatos, etc. Their pancakes are yummy and their pastries are filling. I want to bring Mama home!
author: Liz K.

description:
Where my ABBA at?

Ive been waiting since I dont know when
So I made up my mind, it must come to an end
Sunday brunch? will I ever learn? 
Mid-week wait is way more under control
There's a hunger within my soul
Past baked goods and the register rings
One momlette please, with everything, o-o-o-oh

Mama's meal, here we go again
My my, how can I resist you? 
Mama's meal, prosciutto benedict again? 
Warm coffee cakes, oh how much Ive missed you
Yes, Ive been brokenhearted
Waiting till the crowd has parted
Why, why does everyone know? 
Mama's meal, midweek its a go,
My my, I could never let you go.
author: Brad C.

description:
Ok, so there was all this hype surrounding this place. It's supposedly THE brunch place in San Francisco because people wait what seems to be eons for tables, as it felt that we did this morning. Granted, we were a party of 5, and in this tiny little restaurant, fitting 5 of us definitely seemed to be a bit of a chore. 

We stood in line outside the restaurant, then stood in line inside the restaurant to order our food from the slightly surly lady behind the counter. Then we went back outside the restaurant to wait for our table again. All in all a strange way of going about things. 

But, I must admit, when we did get the table, it was very much to our liking. Large and round, which is always a good and social way to seat a party of 5. But the food was rather dull, I must admit. The omelette and home fries were, well, not what I'd stand in line for, and the coffee was HORRIBLE. But, on the other hand, the bacon was nice and crisp, and I usually mainly gauge a brunch place on how they do their bacon. In this area, they are on the right track. And the gal serving our coffee kept it coming with a smile.

But for this Potrero/Mission gal, I probably won't be making the long trek back to this little part of Stockton St. any time soon.
author: Rachel F.

description:
Damn good "home-style" grubbery here....small tables and long lines makes this place hard to gather a decent crowd for a grub session. I had their sausage omelet which was delicious and shared it with the pancake sampler. Key is using their special homemade blueberry sauce!
Crab Benedict ahhhhnold is also good and was highly recommended to us. Expect a line wait of about 30-60min during prime time.....

Enjoy!
author: Mike F.

description:
I've eaten here only once with some friends who insisted that this was THE place to get breakfast/brunch.  I waited in line with them for probably over an hour and a half.

The place is very cozy.  The food is definitely better than your standard Denny's or IHOP.  The only problem, and it's not really a problem for them I guess, is that I grew up in a small town where you had mom n pop places to get breakfast/brunch because we had no large chains.  So I'm used to quality breakfast/brunch without the hour and a half wait.  I could actually drive back to my hometown in an hour and a half and eat at one of those places, plus the food would be much cheaper.

I would never wait in line here again, but that isn't saying anything negative about the quality of their food or the service.
author: Luis M.

description:
Oh my god, oh my god, look at that!  Whats that? Oh my god!  That looks so good!  That smells so good!  Oh my god.

That was the conversation we had in line waiting to get sat at Mamas.  Everything looked so good!  Everything sounded so good!  When we finally got sat it was well worth the wait.  We did have to wait 45 minutes to get sat.  It is cash only.  But every bite i took of my fresh dungeness crab omlette with avocado and sourcream, was well worth the wait!
author: Lauren F.

description:
I usually don't review places that have over 250 reviews already, but I live a half block away from Mama's and I can see Mama's from my living room.  I feel compelled to share something about Mama's:

I have no earthly idea how this place came to be regarded as the be-all / end-all of brunch eateries in northern San Francisco.  It is a totally decent place that I will stop into when it's easy to do so.  It IS NOT worth a 20 minute wait, outside, in the rain. 

I don't know how else to say it...the two reviews I can see right now talk about a 45 minute wait and a 35 minute wait...damn.
author: Thomas K.

description: There is an extremely long wait.  You wait outside in a line to get inside.  Once inside, you enter into another line to order.  After you order, you wait to get seated.  There is one small bathroom in the back.  The monte carlo is overrated and extremely sweet.  The eggs benedict tasted better.
author: Tea T.

description:
The only thing my hood lacks is a great breakfast place, I think I've tried them all and they're a bismal.  IHOP was the best, but I hate Fisherman's Wharf.  On my first morning in San Francisco in nearly a month, I have no food in the fridge and I'm in desperate need of a filling breakfast to jumpstart the day.  Since it was a weekday and I was weighing the options at 7:30 in the morning, Mama's came to mind.  Surely, all the frat boys and sorority girls that I see waiting in line on the weekends would be just rolling out of bed or enroute to the FIDI.  I was wrong, arrived a bit after 8 and there was already a line.  Not a big deal as I figured it was now or never.  I was surprised that it was all tourists in line so Mama's must be prominent in tourist publications.

When you finally get inside, you think that you've reached salvation, but nope you're tortured even more by shuffling single file past the assorted coffee cakes that are spilling over with crumble and baskets of fresh fruit and seafood.  Although I'm leary of trying fruit that is sitting next to salmon.  I would think the odors of the fish would corrupt the essence of the fruit.  I played tribute to my own Mama and ordered what she would have ordered, the North Beach omelette.  

The only good thing about the setup is that the food usually arrives within minutes of getting seated at a table.  The food was close to perfection.  Omelette was stuffed with veggies and cheese, but I thought the roasted potatoes were a bit on the bland side.  Decor was more impressive than I thought it would be.  I was expecting mismatched dive in desperate need of an overhaul, but I got a bright cheery Provencal atmosphere which this Francophile appreciates.

I'm not a big fan of lines so the only time that I would be likely to return is on a weekday, when I play hookie from work.
author: Amy Z.

description:
The nice things about being unemployed for a month include: (1) reading the entire internet each day, (2) not having to interact with crowds, (3) lighting fast internet speeds, and (4) being able to go to Mama's and only have to wait 45 minutes to be seated.

Wait, did I just get excited about only having to wait 45 minutes?  Damn right I did.  I'd never actually been here because of the lines, but I went on a weekday and was amazed that it met the hype.  The omelettes were huge and the baked goods were fantastic.  

But I can't give a place where you line up for food five stars.  Can't do it.
author: Geoff K.

description:
I am not a big fan of breakfast but my friend took me there for my birthday.   We had to wait for an hour to get in but it was excellent. 

Monte Cristo was die for.  

Server told me they open at 8:00am but line starts from 7:30am.  Crazy, huh?
author: M M.

description: The food was good. no complaints, but the wait for it isn't worth it at all. I only suggest coming here if you have a lot of time to burn.
author: Peter C.

description: I like it's chocolate french toast so much, test really good and I think its the best choice for breakfast!!!!
author: Sharon-Xiaoying H.

description:
Went here for a breakfast bday thing...OMG the food was really good!  Im glad my friend found this on Yelp!  We came here before they opened so parking was no problem and there was no line, yet.  

We didnt know how it worked but here it goes...so basically you stand in line, and the line goes inside also.  The place is small, homey, and quaint.  We thought it would be like a resturant setting but it wasn't.  So you order your food and get seated because its brought out to you.  What we didn't know was that my friend was running late so we couldn't save a seat for her.  So luckily the line wasn't long and I went out and waited with her...

So if you're going with a group of ppl, make sure they are all there....

DROOLLL im craving some breakfast dishes right now!
author: dawn b.

description: minus one star for the wait. Other than that, I love Mama's. One of the yummiest places to eat brunch at. And they make the food look so presentable and pretty. Clean restaurant, awesome people working there. TIP: come here early if you're trying to eat on the weekends......extremely long lines. But if you're pretty patient , i guess it wouldn't be a problem.
author: Colette P.

description:
3 words...... worth the wait!!!

Like everyone else, I waited 2 hours outside and 30 minutes inside the restaurant. I love the place! It's small and quaint. The interior of the restaurant reminded me of a grandma's kitchen. 

The food served here is unique. Its not your average breakfast restaurant. The food has its own personal touch and you realize your getting your moneys worth. 

I ordered the Lox and Bagel platter and it was amazing!! My gosh, whoever thought of this dish is a true genius. Much appreciation to the chef.
 My boyfriend ordered the regular Eggs Florentine  and I love how they perfectly mix the spinach and mushrooms with the egg. We also wanted to try the Swedish Cinnamon French Toast and there definitely were no regrets. The fruits were fresh. Even the jam was homemade which totally won me over. 

Overall I would visit Mama's the next time I am in town. Worth the wait, but it would be nice if they can expand their lot space.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
runner arrives, stands behind me, with both plates held up high:

R:  french toast?
E:  *points to the woman*
W:  thank u!
R:  ... and ur pancakes, sir...
E:  =O
R:  ah haaaa, gotcha!

mmm washington omelette, sooooo good...  8D
author: Ethan L.

description:
It is super delicious, the wait wasn't as bad as imagine either. We waited about 30 minutes including the order line located inside the restaurant. It is very cozy and there are plenty of 2 hours parking or meters. We of course tried the Toast Sampler, and they were all very good and yes the Monte Cristo (sandwich)  is two thumbs up!!! Next time I really want to try the weekend special tho, but I am sure the wait will be a lot longer! 

Great place for brunch. I love the fresh OJ!
author: Sandy L.

description:
i love breakfast!!!

the wait was long but we thought it was worth it. we kept ourselves entertained by people and dog watching.  

the bf had the smoked salmon eggs benedict and i had the french toast sampler.

i enjoyed his more than my own plate...but the french toast was really good...i guess i wanted to eat everything.

will be going back really soon...actually tomorrow for my bf's bday. YAY.
author: nancy b.

description: We got to this restaurant 10 minuted before it opened and there was already a line! The line was well worth it though. You order your meal at the counter after walking through the line while watching everyone prep and cook the food, really cool. The decor is really unique and homey and the staff is super friendly and helpful. I ordered the banana pancakes which were okay, but my mom ordered the egg whites, perfectly crispy, the bacon, thick and juicy not like the cheap stuff, and the best crumb coffee cake ever. The coffee was great as was the company. We met three couples each from different cities and all very nice.
author: Caitlin Z.

description:
Mamas is definitely my favorite breakfast spot in SF. Its totally worth the wait to get in ... take a cup of coffee with you! Once you get inside the smells of fresh cooking engulf you, you get to watch the chefs cooking all that scrummy food. Mouth watering you place you order ( mamas eggs benedict is my fav). you get shown to your seat and are served quickly and by really friendly staff ! 
You often get to see some lovely fitties whilst standing in the queue ... especially if you are havign a late breakie on a Saturday morning ... tee hee !
author: Amy W.

description:
Long lines and with good reason...Mama's is more than worth the ridiculously long wait.

Be prepared for tough street parking and long lines, amazing omelets, unparalleled coffee cakes, sweet service, and the biggest post-breakfast food coma you have ever had in your life. Needless to say this is my favorite breakfast joint in San Francisco but I only have time to go to Mama's on weekends when I have the time to spare. FYI - CASH ONLY!
author: Kathy E.

description: Waited in line for an hour but so worth it! Shared a crumb cake with my friends, it basically melts in your mouth! Got the French toast sampler and it was amazing! Definitely would go back and wait in line again!
author: Aubrey M.

description:
As previously stated a 100 times before, the line for mama' s is ridiculous. I have never been able to make it over mid-week due to the fact that I have a job!

Is Mama's worth waiting in line among crowds of tourists and their fanny packs? Yes.. that is if you have 2 hours (total) to spare for breakfast.

Hands down the best brunch (and friendlist staff) in San Francisco. I need to make a return trip soon.
author: Sarah W.

description:
I've always stayed away from Mama's long lines, but as part of my f(unemployment), I finally left my apartment to walk to the other side of the park and try the french toast.  Since it was a Wednesday there was only one couple ahead of me in line so the wait was short and soon my order was taken, a seat was cleared, and my order was in front of me.  Now I'm not a french toast kind of girl, but one bite of the chocolate french toast and I was hooked.  Loved it so much I convinced a couple of friends to go with me again  so I could try the Monte Cristo...pure heaven.  I may have to go one more time before I leave on vacation.

Service here is amazing, both times everyone was super friendly and not in a fake overbearing way, but you can actually have a conversation with the servers and you know they are being genuine.  

One of the few places that is absolutely worth all the hype!
author: T V.

description: The Dungeness crab omelette was well worth the lengthy wait... and the $20 it cost.
author: Andrew J.

description:
Yeah Mama's is good, we all know that.

Yeah, there's usually a long wait in line, know that too.

So what's the use in another review.  Good question.  Mine will be an opinion just like the other 600+ reviews on this joint.

On a weekday morning, almost afternoon, my wait in line was about 15min.

Not too shabby considering the other reviews mention 1 - 2 hour plus waits.  I don't know why.  This place has great food, and I like the homemade jam at every table over the brioche french toast in particular.

But waiting 2 hours?  Not so much.  Like I said great food, and even great service, but if your wait is more than an hour, I wouldn't recommend.  Only because its breakfast, and when the anticipation of food is before you, who needs a wait?
author: Patrick K.

description:
I would give it 5 but they don't listen when you tell them how hard you want your eggs poached - but then hardly anyone ever does.  Okay, I give them 4.39 stars.

Def some of the best breakfast food in town but don't come here hungry, you will be waiting outside for a while. Prolly a looong while. 

Think you can beat the line by going for a weekend brunch at a ridiculously early time? You can't.  

Think you can beat the line by going on a weekday between breakfast and lunch? You can't.

Think I'm exaggerating with those two extra os? I'm not. 
Smart diners bring a snack to tide them over while they are waiting - seriously last week I saw a woman in line who had brought a ziploc baggies with apple slices to munch on while she waited to get into the restaurant.  I was all 'why didn't I think of that?!' 

Still, they do wonderful breakfast food and you shouldn't let the wait discourage you.
author: lisa g.

description:
Want to sell  your soul for wealth, power, fame and beauty but Satan just won't materialize to do the deal? Here's second best... go to Mama's and trade your youth for a piece of toast. 

At Moma's you will spend 60 to 90 minutes waiting on the sidewalk if it's  a weekend, 45 minutes on a weekday.   Hit it wrong, as I just did on a beautiful Saturday in late July, and your wait could be closer to two hours.  No exaggeration.

Two hours lined up on on the sidewalk. Nearly the entire lifespan of a Mayfly, boarder line long term relationship for some people. I was a teenager when I arrived and by the time I got to the counter I was ready for the senior discount. I should have left my watch at home and brought a calendar. 

Once you are inside food comes out quickly, portions are generous and most items are well done. Seats are comfortable and noise level wasn't a problem. But there is nothing so magical about any item on the menu to justify the wait.
author: Bill S.

description:
I mean it's breakfast. How hard is it to F- up breakfast?? 
Right but Mama's isn't about not  F- ing breakfast up, it's about perfecting it.
Damn Mama's is so good. 
Granted I'm a big fan of table side service, especially when it's for the first meal of the day I not loving the wait in line to place your order biz going on here. 
But because Mama's breakfast fulfills all my brunching needs, for you Mama, I'll get off my hungover butt and stand in your line to order one of your fabulous breakie choices. 

Big portions, reasonable prices, and a picturesque location.

But being that I despise weekend crowds, I recommend only stopping by on off days. That is unless your down with the wait or live close by to the poppin breakfast joint. Otherwise, Mama's is best left to special weekend morning occasions.
author: Kat R.

description:
waiting

waiting

waiting

waiting

one hour later.......

we finally got in

dungenous crab omelete - delicious

cinnamon sugar french toast with fruit - decent

crab eggs benedict - HORRIBLE!!!!!!!!!!

extra free smoothie - very nice, and tasty......

I won't ever go back...... the hype and heat ruined it for me.... 

btw the check was almost a hundred dollars!! for brunch no thank you...
author: Nina M.

description: Mama's is bangin! Hands down one of my favorite little spots in the bay, If you dont have time then this place doesnt have a table for you. The average sidewalk wait is at least an hour plus, but it is so worth it. The omelettes here literally slap the fork out of your hand and actually tell you whos boss, the Chocolate Cinnamon French Toast with seasonal Berries and Bananas lets you know the Captain on the cover of your Captain Crunch has been feeding you garbage for years & there pastry selection makes hostess treats look like a booger, straight up. They also serve bottled beer which is quite refreshing after that long wait, but once your in the door and im standing in line in front of you, leave me alone, decisions decisions...
author: Keith D.

description: Totally overrated! Waited almost 2 hours in line only to receive a plate full of disappointment. I ordered the crab omelet that was 27$. There was very little crab for the price of the dish and the egg itself was very plain and not seasoned well. The potatoes were okay but nothing special. The coffee was room temperature, yuck! My daughter ordered the classic eggs Benedict. She has had eggs Benedict in other restaurants and loved it but here it was disgusting. The whites of the poached eggs had a snot consistency and were very unappealing. My daughter barely eat any of the plate and when she expressed her distaste towards the underdone eggs the waitress acted surprised but seemed to not care. They only take cash and give no receipts so you have no proof that you ordered anything. The waiters leave the previous customer's tip on the table to inform you that you should leave a tip also...which they don't  deserved because they provide little to no service. The only thing that we did enjoy was their fresh squeezed orange juice.  Overall, the wait is not worth the food that we ordered. This restaurant is too hyped up for what is actually served.
author: Natalia V.

description:
Is it worth waiting in line for over an hour outside just to wait another thirty minutes inside? You better believe it!!!! This has got to be THE best breakfast I have ever had the fortune of tasting! Every one of their breakfast options is basically amazing! The coffee is sooo good, the juices are freshly squeezed, and everything just tastes so homemade! 

The only thing that prevents this place from utter perfection is their waiting system. I know most popular restaurants in San Francisco have long waits, but the difference with this place is you actually have to wait in line. I say it would be much better if one could just write down their name on a list, and then simply relax and wait in Washington square. That is the only recommendation I have, but other than that this place is a must go!!!
author: Luis O.

description:
My 84 year old dad came up on the train today for brunch and I suggested Mama's. Initially I was loathe to make him stand in line for 40 minutes. But he was totally unfazed as were people 2 yards behind us. I couldn't believe how nonplussed they were to do something like this for breakfast, which I consider the most disagreeable meal of the day. I think I have trouble digesting eggs, I hate sugary maple syrup and jam, coffee at that hour makes me feel strung out but homicidal and I'd just rather be in bed sleeping. But there we were. My back started aching after 25 minutes, but my dad stood there rigid like an old marine waiting for marching orders.

When we finally got inside the staff were incredibly nice. The system for getting people up to the menu and the ordering place then to your table is very organized and painless. And even though you've already ordered and paid, the table service is very attentive and friendly, and they offer you coffee the entire time, never making you feel rushed. There is no turn'em and burn'em feeling here once you're inside, at all. That would have killed it for me having waited as long as we did.

The first thing we saw was the beautiful display of quickbreads and crumbles, We couldn't resist piece of the regular crumble - it was buttery and amazing, quite sugary but splitting one prevented it from being overpowering. From the many excellent-sounding choices on the menu, I got the florentine scramble and my dad got the northern italian omelette. We were both very happy. I was very impressed with how fresh and non-sandy the spinach was, and as promised the scramble contained bacon which was plentiful and of excellent quality. 

The french toast made from banana nut bread really tempted me, as did the banana walnut french toast and the brioche french toast. There's lots more to try here, and I'll come back when I have time to wait in that line and when I have enthused companions. 

I can honestly say even though I don't generally appreciate breakfast and brunch that this was exceptional.
author: Roxmarie M.

description:
4.5 stars

Mama oh Mama how I love you! From your heart attack egg's benedict to your fluffy buttermilk pancakes with fresh fruit ... I LOVE YOU! Everything I had was delicious! 

We came here early Friday morning around 8:30 am. We only waited for 10 mins outside and inside.  We order our breakfast in the front and wait for a table to clear up to be seated. Food came out in 15 mins and it was unbelievable.  Make sure to try their homemade jam with the pancakes. By the end of the meal ... the jar only had a quarter of the jam left ...(Opps!) 

When we left Mama's, the line was loooooooooooong ... thank goodness we came early. Try to come around 8 when they open to avoid the crazy line.
author: Miki M.

description: The wait was a draw back but it was sunny and pleasant out.  The breakfast was outstanding but pricey.  The atmospere was great.  I'd do it again, if I have the time.
author: Richard S.

description:
715AM: the sexy lady wakes me up and is like its time to go to Mama's!!!! I grumble, whine, scratch my ass, and pretend that I went back to sleep while I try to sleep.

730AM:  the sexy lady  is like WAKE UP NOW WERE GOING TO MAMA'S!!!! (I almost sh*t in my pants)

745AM: I'm dressed well, showered, brushed my teeth, washed my face yada yada and out the door.

8AM: turn onto stockton and start bitching about how theres never no spaces to park in north beach.  Cuss at all the north beach residents, DPT, SF, people that are fortunate to live near mama's while the sexy lady emotionally supports me.  

810AM: car is parked on the other side of a hill from mama's.  I'm out of breath and cuss under my breath some more as I see a 20 person line in front of mama's.  

815AM: Bored shes reading anthony bourdain's book, im reading my haruki murakami book.  

9AM: We get let inside to suffer through a smaller yet more torturous line because we get to watch as people eat our favorite breakfast in SF.    We watch as chefs prepare a hollandaise sauce thats drizzled over perfectly poached eggs.  Potatoes get grilled to a crunchy brown with bits of onion.  pancake batter is poured like silk water and the instant the batter hits the hot griddle an explosion of memories of sunday morning breakfasts with your family  emanates from your olfactory nerves to through your mind as you breathe through ur nose.  

915AM:  The sexy lady wants crab benedict, I have the california omelete although the washington square wants to be devoured by me also, but so does half the other items on the menu.  We can't resist getting pancakes since their berries are incredibly sweet and theres a sweet surprise waiting for first timers at Mama's that sits at every table so humbly it often gets forgotten.  

930AM: We're finally seated, I sip my hot cocoa like a little school girl and she sips her coffee ready to do business.   I stare at the humble Mama's jam, in its little plastic container with its little spoon.  Little do people know this is what makes mama's so unique.  Their homemade jam.  Its not overly sweet, and its made with tons of berries.  I love berries, and I love mama's jam.

945AM:  Our breakfast arrives, our table is crowded because of our order of blueberry pancakes but we can finish it.  The freshness in every ingredient for both our benedicts and omelete are immediately noticeable.  Its simple american breakfast fare but everything is cooked well and cooked with really good ingredients.  Even the strawberry that garnishes the pancakes is as sweet as the maple syrup.  But F the Fing syrup I take spoonfuls of it with the pancake bits into my mouth, oh Mama's you could be billionaires if  you charged for the option to have this blessing on my table.  Oh but please don't because I'd have to give up so many luxuries in my life for that jam.   

1030AM:  The sexy lady has a smirk on her face like she just had some incredible sex.   I'm satiated beyond any other happiness this world could offer.  I'm contemplating just sleeping or defecating for the rest of the day.  We stroll off in glee.  

Don't even contemplate going to dottie's if you can make it out to north beach!!!!!!!!!
author: Tomo S.

description:
I had been wanting to try this place for quite some time and I finally got around to it this week. 

I chose the Chocolate Cinnamon French Toast and it was absolutely delicious. Then again, I had been waiting in line for over an hour and a half, so maybe anything would have tasted great. 

The service here is alright, although the waitresses I observed didn't seem to care for their job too much. 

There is always a line at this place, especially on the weekends. I recommend eating at this place at least once, if only to satisfy your curiosity. However, I don't think it's worth all the hype and the long lines.
author: F K.

description:
So I was just at Mama's last week and I miss it already. My friend lives a few blocks away so I try to eat there every morning when I'm in the City... you know? Get the day started right.

There's usually a line (okay - ALWAYS a line) and it amazes me that when people come up with their Zagat guide books and see all of us waiting patiently outside they ask, "Is this place really that good?"

My reply is, "I flew up from L.A. just for this."

But as tourists do, they get impatient and wander off to enjoy McDonald's or something else.

There really isn't more I can say about this place that hasn't been said already. This place is the best.

It's all about the jam - Olallieberry jam - for which I am now on a search in L.A. to get.

Everything here is divine. The staff is super friendly (and even remember me from time to time).

Go.
Wait in line.
Wait your turn.
Order your food.
Eat the best breakfast ever.
Go home and cry.
Deal with it.
author: Gator L.

description: Great food! The best French toast I have ever had. Delicious fresh fruit and wonderful service. The only problem is the line to get in. Definitely worth the wait though. Definitely be there waiting when they open up at 8 because the line just gets longer as the day goes on.
author: Brittany C.

description: Not as good as I expected it to be. I ordered their special of the day, the french toast trio and a mocha. The mocha was so sweet I couldn't drink it. The french toast trio, ditto. I could only eat one piece of the toast. The other pieces were way to sugary for me. It was okay, but not "wow", which is what you would expect. I'll stick to other, not so popular places with better food.
author: Danielle L.

description: Came here last Sunday during the Italian fest. Get ready to wait a while in a pretty long line. Well worth it though. Great breakfast options, ordered crab and avocado omlette, smoked salmon benedict and french toast (everything was shared between myself, my mom and grandmother). Everything was great and the place is really cute. The last star is for the spiked lemonade, taste like no alcohol is in it and got me pretty buzzed for having ate so much food.
author: Candice B.

description:
We got there last Friday a.m. about 10 and waited an hour, but it was so worth it.  This is my FAVORITE place in SF.  Even my boyfriend who was totally annoyed that we were going to wait an hour for breakfast, said it was incredible.  He said that it was the best crumb cake he'd ever eaten!  It was to die for!  Even their OJ is killer.

Otherwise, we had an italian omlette, scrambled eggs, bacon, the basics really.  It was all fantastic!
author: Kim D.

description: Great breakfast and brunch menu. Delicious food but seriously not worth the ridiculously long wait (50min+ on weekends).
author: Cam N.

description:
Heard great rave reviews about this place from my boyfriend and his good friend so he decided to take me to this place for breakfast. :)

I ordered the chocolate cinnamon French toast with seasoned berries and bananas. It was great with the sauce that is on the table(Ollieberry?). The French toast was really good and I really enjoyed that the orange juice was fresh squeezed :) My boyfriend had pancakes with fresh berries.

The place is quite small for the amount of traffic it gets but the food is delicious and the people that work there are really nice and courteous(always checking to make sure we were doing fine throughout our meal).

I would love to visit again and love that there are regulars that come to this place :)next time I will need to try the Monte
Cristo everybody is raving about :)
author: Kathleen L.

description:
I wish this place were owned by my Mama because I'd be sitting down at the breakfast table every morning! Although, I do have my waste line to consider so it may be a blessing that we're not related. 

I take a lot of time scoping out different breakfast joints all over the city and this is by far my favorite spot to date. I ordered the banana pancakes and was so impressed with JUST the presentation that I had to take a picture - four pancakes stacked on top of each other, topped with bananas and a side of fresh, colorful berries. It was a masterpiece. I inhaled them.

Obviously you're all aware of the long waits and the small tables by now. The wait can be avoided if you make it early enough and the small tables, well, don't go with a party of 10. It's that simple.
author: Julia N.

description: I really wanted to like this place but the line time was completely ridiculous.  We had a group of 5  gals who braved the cold on what we thought would be an acceptable wait time for a Friday morning.  What a surprise when we ended up waiting almost an hour and a half in the cold.  We got there at 10:30 only to be served right at noon.  By that time we were famished. The food is ok, yes the place is charming and staff courteous and friendly but even after that a meal at Mama's just could not validate the long wait.  If it was Sunday brunch (or even Saturday) on a summer's day it still woudn't be worth it....don't get me wrong - I will wait in line for unique, special and worthwhile food....Mama's just didn't offer it.
author: Lea G.

description: Do I need to post a picture so you can see for yourself?! The food is amazing and it's still family owned. Great food, great atmosphere. There is typically a line outside, but it's worth it!!!
author: Kaley F.

description:
Seriously? 4 and 5 stars all the way? Give me a break.

Overpriced, overrated, overly-crowed. Enough said.
author: Wes Z.

description:
Yesterday I showed up, prepared for a one or two hour wait.  Lo and behold, it being Tuesday morning at around noon, I was able to waltz right in and order.  Take off work to go on a weekday so you don't have to wait!  The chicken sandwich was delectable, the servers were affable, and the country kitchen décor made me feel right at home.

I could not help but come back for more the next day.

French toast sampler = great.  An even better choice than the grilled chicken sandwich.  The best of three French toasts was the cranberry walnut.
author: Lee S.

description:
Great brunch/breakfast place if you don't mind the wait and the crowds.

Came here on a Thursday morning around 10am and was greeted by a 20 minute wait outside in the cold.  Mama's is a fairly small restaurant with about a dozen tables but you order before you're seated so that speeds up the turnover A LOT.  You'll find a typical breakfast menu here with a variety of pancakes, eggs, french toast and pastries.  Everything was very fresh and prices seemed aligned with most other breakfast places- about $8-10 a plate.  A group of us sampled:

French Toast Sampler- the orange cranberry was decent- though a tad too flavorful for me, the cinnamon was sooo good- like eating a cinnamon bun but less gooey, and the chocolate was good as well.

Shrimp and avecado eggs benedict- the avecados were sooo good and creamy and fresh.  i expected the shrimp to be tasty but it was just boiled and bland for my taste, but they loaded my plate with lots of shrimp.

California Egg White Omlet- great healthy option, but nothing out of the ordinary.  it's hard to mess us breakfast foods like this, though i must say everything was really good and fresh.

Monte Cristo- I always try to stay away from monte cristos in general cause you just feel horrible afterwards, but this one was a much healthier option, not greasy at all.  very very good.  every one at my table loved this dish.  

Overall great place with decent prices.  Parking was a tad hard but not impossible.  service was great.  bathroom was weird..an outhouse pretty much.  we sat in the back so we didn't feel cramped by other tables or people pre-ordering but i'm sure tables in the front felt differently.
author: Minners N.

description:
This place is delicious and worth the wait, you will totally love it, no kidding. make sure you bring a magazine or game to kill time while waiting. I totally recommend the french toast sampler. 
Customer service is awesome and the place is very cozy.
author: Juan L.

description:
Simply put, the best monte cristo sandwich EVER!  I've had their pancakes and french toasts, but I like the monte way too much to give it up for anything else at Mama's. 

The wait is brutally wrong, so either go way early or well after lunch time around 2. Either way, well worth a try!
author: Stephen C.

description:
Don't go there. Really.
Think about it. The line is always long. It's hectic. And once you have tasted their food, their coffee, their delicious mimosas, you will be hooked. 
Seriously. I'm warning you, once you breakfast there, you will never be the same again.
But if you insist, here are some tips:

So the lines are long, you say. Well, that's easy to fix. Mama's closes are 3pm. So have breakfast really late. Get there at 2:30 and 85% of the time there will be no line. Or, just go on the weekday. 

Hectic, you say? Again, weekdays are better. Sometimes there are actual empty tables. Yup. Sometimes, there's actually empty tables. No noise, just pleasantry's.

Now, about that yummy food. Well, we'll just leave that to the professionals.
author: Carla P.

description:
Noticed an ad about this place in one of those hotel magazines when we were on vacation in San Francisco and so glad I did.  The best breakfast I've ever had.  I had the French Toast Sampler and my husband ordered the Northern Italian Omelettet.  Sides of bacon and sausage completed our delicious meal.
A word of caution, be prepared to wait in line for a long time depending on time of day.  We waited about 90 minutes, but it was definitely worth it.  A small place inside, so it's not the destination for a large group.   Would I visit again?  Absolutely!
author: Paula H.

description:
I love this place!!  It is a homey little place, not the trendy, gentrified eatery you become accustomed to in SF.  You wait on line outside for anywhere from 15 minutes to over an hour, then place your order at the front counter.  Oh, the choices, they are aplenty.  I once made the mistake of bringing some out of town guests here during Passover---they had to drool over the freshly made breads and pastries, but couldn't actually eat them!  Fortunately, they were able to enjoy a non-bread-containing meal.  Everything I have had here is fabulous!

Things you should know:  cash-only, parking can be a b*tch, the bathroom is a couple of steps above a port-o-pottie (looks-wise, but it is clean), the food is to die for.
author: Danielle B.

description:
I've probably already written this, but brunch is my favorite meal.  It implies sleeping in and, upon waking, consuming two meals' worth of food; that is truly brilliant, a stroke of utter, syrupy genius.

My bf, cousin, and brother waited for maybe 45 minutes on a Sunday; yes, we knew it was going to be like this, it was almost one and there was still a line (though not that bad).  When we did get it in, everyone but my bf (the only non-first-timer) gasped at the spread of food in front of the kitchen, which is visible when you walk in, only plexiglass between you and loaves of cinnamon bread; bowls of fresh berries; the cooks busily prepping gorgeous plates of food for readied customer-mouths and bellies just like ours.  There was a huge pile of Dungeness crab I wanted to climb into and eat from the inside out.  (Next time, I swear...next time. They currently have a crab/eggs benedict special for $19.95, but it just wasn't in the budget.)

The four of us ordered the following: the Washington Square, the Californian, Mama's Children's Special (those were all omelettes); the Cinnamon French Toast.  We all shared a side of bacon and an order of the silver dollar pancakes, which we tried with their homemade jam at the recommendation of our very nice waitress.  Let me tell you, we cleaned those plates, down to the orange slice garnish.
author: M. H.

description: Simply 'outstanding' ! I had the dungeness crab benedict - the best ever. Friends had the the 'low fat' french toast & the french toast sampler. All superb! Warm, cozy interior inviting you to hang out on a rainy Sunday, but you realize that you may be faced with an hungry and angry mob as you leave. Lines are looooong and now I understand why.
author: Gregg M.

description:
Unbelievable... and not in a good way.  I had family visiting from out of town and I wanted to take them somewhere extra yummy, so I opted to brave the line at Mama's.  I am going to keep this brief, because relaying the whole story just makes my blood boil.
Bad food.  Period.  Out of 6 meals ordered, only 2 were good.  To top it off, there was MOLD on the French Toast.  Seriously?  Mold?  Really?
Horrible customer service.  We presented the moldy bread to the host and he foolishly stood there, looked embarrassed, and then . . .did NOTHING.  Again, seriously?  
I will never return to this joint, and I will do my best to deter others.
author: Lacy T.

description: Be prepared to wait, but the food is delicious.  Everything is so fresh and prepared quickly.  You have to wait outside until there is room for you inside, so dress for the weather.  We got there a few minutes before opening and it ended up being about 9 before ate...not too bad and the line outside was twice as long when we left.  Would recommend, but get there early!
author: Kathleen M.

description:
Excellent food--had the blueberry pancakes and eggs Benedict with Dungeness crab. Both were outstanding.

The only reason that this doesn't get 5 stars is because of the ridiculous wait times (over an hour!) and the fact that it doesn't take credit cards.
author: Jonathan L.

description:
The first time I went here and I saw a celebrity! hehehe I've always wanted to try this place after hearing several people talk about how good it is and the loads of really good yelp reviews it had.  The guy and I drove by Mama's on Sunday but the line was ridonkulously long, so we decided to try it some other day.  We were back on tuesday and there was no line whatsoever! (YAY) The menu had so much stuff, I didn't know what to order.  After a couple of minutes I decided to get the Washington Square omelette and he got the Northern Italian.  I liked my omelette but I liked his much better!! Next time I wanna try the fruity stuff!  I was practically drooling looking at the food from the tables next to us.  

One thing i didnt like (eeek!) about Mama's was that I ended up smelling like kitchen the rest of the day.  It was really bad, I didn't even have to sniff my clothes and I could smell it -- much worse than korean bbq restaurants. lol
author: JUDY L.

description:
Lisa and I got there at a bit past 8 am in the morning on Sunday and there was *still* a line. Granted it was fairly short (about 15 minutes), but still!

The food though was fantastic. I mean fantastic, stupendous, atounding, wonderful, amazing and really really good. My french toast was wonderful and Lisa's eggs were perfectly cooked. 

I really wish they had a sign up listing all the little coffee cake, bread and muffin items they had available (they seem to have six or seven) since they all look so good, but I have no idea what any of them are.

Worth the wait at 8 am. Would it be worth an hour long wait? Hmmm. Possibly. :)
author: Jordan M.

description:
Fittingly enough, I came to Mama's on Mother's Day (but sadly, without my  own mommy).  Instead, a few friends and I ventured here because I was told that it was about  time that I had the Mama's experience.  I was a little doubtful - after all, I've already had tons of great brunch experiences.

We waited in line for almost over an hour, and I was told over and over again that brunch nirvana was just ahead.  So, I patiently waited and prepared myself.

Maybe it was a combination of the anticipation, the wait, and the hunger - but Mama's really was a great brunch experience.  We ordered the banana bread french toast that was sweet and came with fresh bananas sliced on top.  When it was drenched in syrup, it was the best companion to the rest of our savory meals.  

One friend had the monte cristo (definitely order it if you have never tried it), others ordered the omelettes and I had the salmon eggs benedict, which was by far one of the best eggs benedict I've had.

It really seems like you can't go wrong with ordering almost anything off the menu.  But be prepared - the rest of your day might end up turning into warding off an impending food coma.
author: Shay F.

description:
We all know by now (either by reading or experiencing) the horrendous weekend wait at Mama's. By now it is silly to reiterate. I will say however that for anyone reading this who is having trouble visualizing just how long "the line" will be, picture this: 

an adorable, quant little daisy of a restuarant with, say, about 12 tables with contented diners licking the maple syrup off their chins and smiling with delight at their lovely waitress as about 50 cranky, hungry, hungover and anxious people wait their turn to be delighted. 

In all honesty, I went their on Sunday and the line not only went out the door, but it streched up the street for about 20 feet. No joke.  I STRONGLY recommend going on a week day. There is almost NO line and the waitresses are even friendlier. Yum!
author: Becca A.

description:
I'm a picky breakfast person. I think the eggs should be a certain way, toast should be buttered right, french toast should be nice and eggy, etc.

Okay, yes, there is a wait. It was about 45 minutes, but I read the Chronicle while I waited, and talked. Went by fast. Oh, and read the menu in the window.

So, I got Mama's Children's Favorite - or something like that - that was an omelette and got a slice of raspberry coffee cake. The omelette was done perfect - I get it well done - and the coffee cake was a great way to start the breakfast. The french toast looked great, and I will have to try that next time I am there.
