My only caveat is that it seems better suited to smaller parties. If you try to bring the whole family that's in from out of town, you will probably wait longer. Oh, and people, get a clue - if it is a busy place, eat and leave, don't dilly-dally. Blech, it's about turning over tables.
author: Jeremy P.

description: The Monte Cristo sandwich is to die for. The jam that they have is also amazing. There is quite a wait, usually at least an hour, but it goes by quickly. I wasn't too impressed with their hot chocolate the second time around, but the first time I went, they put cinnamon and chocolate syrup on the whipped cream, and it was awesome. The staff here is friendly and attentive, but they don't hound you which is great! Come if you're not immediately starving and willing to wait for a great meal!
author: Yesenia C.

description:
The line is long. Really, really long. And I was really, really hungry. Like ready to keel over and pass out from low blood glucose hungry. But I stood in the damn line. And boy, was it worth it. I had the eggs benedict with pancetta and my friend had the eggs benedict florentine, and we did a swap. So I tried both, and they were both sooooo good. I had some apple crumble thing that was off the hook too. And the orange juice is sooooooooooo good. Freshly squeezed!

I lived in Berkeley for 4 years and never knew of this place 'til my visit back to the Bay Area last weekend. Oh, that makes me wanna weep. I'll just have to move back after I finish grad school down in LA. =)

However, the potatoes I had were undercooked. Maybe it was b/c the line was so long and they didn't have time to cook it long enough? Not a good excuse, huh? But either way, I don't think that deserves a whole star deduction. Everything else was so freaking good. YUM!
author: Victoria H.

description:
I went here for the first time today after having an all out raging night in the city. We were just looking for somewhere to catch something to eat and this one had good reviews. Now here are a few good points that I thought were noteworthy:

1. On a Saturday morning, be prepared to wait at least 1-2hours to get seated and get your food and no they don't take reservations

2. It's TOTALLY WORTH IT!!! I had the Cinnamon French Toast with fresh berries and the homemade jam with a little syrup... yes; HOMEMADE JAM! 

3. The homemeade jam is delicious! 

4. Orange juice Fabulous

5. Service was on point. Everyone was really nice and very quick to get you what you needed. 

6. You order and pay before you get seated so when you're done you just up and leave. With that in mind, don't get excited when you get your foot in the door because there's still another line to order and pay :) Worry not, it's worth it.

I will absolutely be back here. On a weekday, on the weekend I don't even care. They also have an array of muffins and breads that looked sooo good. They're certainly on my list for next time. I love Mama's. Oh ya, we were also a group of 6 and we had a nice cozy table in a corner.
author: Jenelle A.

description:
I am not a morning person, so understandably it's safe to say that I am not too much of a breakfast fan either, but if I ever happen to change my ways I will run into the comforting arms of Mama's. 

My food experiences at Mama's never fail and I love a sure thing. And being the creature of habit that I am, I always get in no specific rotation: their tasty Swedish French toast w/seasonal berries, any of their omelets(if I'm feeling adventurous), or their sometimes on the specials board chorizo scramble and always, always w/a side of bacon. So this is why people wake up for breakfast! Cozy little spot, busy but friendly servers ("try the jam"), but beware of the line for this place it's hit or miss just like their coffee and if Yelp had half stars for the coffee alone would've put them at a 3.5 okay maybe 3.75, you don't want to talk bad about Mama now.
author: Cecile Q.

description:
Not much else to say other than it's one of the best breakfast's we've ever had. Location was awesome. Crab and cheese omelette fantastic as well as the swedish swirl french toast. 

Line is long and you may question waiting 30-45 min but do it - it's more than worth it. While we were there the chef brought out a pastry with their homemade jelly inside - warm and delicious.
author: Reagan H.

description:
Disclaimer: I'm a fan of "Stuff white people like", so if the site offends you I suggest you don't read the rest of the review and that you get a sense of humor. 

Mama's is the Mecca of breakfast places. If you are white and love breakfast places (redundant) you have go here once in your life. How can it be worthy of an hour plus wait? 

I was determined to find out. With my white friends (hey, I like to be as authentic as possible), I waited in line for an hour. They have an odd service system that makes tipping difficult. We had to stand in line and order with the cashier. The couple behind us were seated and had table service. 

I had read so much about the eggs Benedict so I had to try that. I really wanted the crab version but at $18 it was too steep for my recession budget. I settled on the shrimp version. Anyone can toast an English muffin, poach some eggs but it takes talent to me a good hollandaise. Mama's version was good, light, but not lemony enough for my taste. 

I'd heard the mythic tales from my white friends about the hour long lines for french toast. Pain perdu is just stale bread that the French reuse. Mama's famous french toast was a bit of a let down. I was expecting something closer to a soft bread soaked in milk and eggs resulting in a custard texture. Unfortunately, it appears that they simply dip the slices of bread in egg. True, they use banana bread for the french toast but it is just banana bread dipped in eggs then fried. Doesn't sound too appetizing does it? I'd rather just have the banana bread. I have to admit the presentation with all the fruit is lovely but I care more about how it tastes. 

So I can check Mama's off my bucket list. When do I receive my honorary white status card in the mail?
author: Monica L.

description: THE BEST CRUMBCAKE ON THE PLANET! And there are four choices -chocolate cake, vanilla cake, and different versions of choc and no-choc toppings. The cake is actually bakery-quality cake, and they don't skimp on the big-chunky crumby topping. This is pro-level baking. No after-thought here. I had the eggs benedict - the hollandaise was so light and dijon-y - absolutely perfect. Yes, cash only - good to know before you go. Also, try to hit it on a weekday. No lines. Very pleasant service.
author: Carolyn F.

description:
There's nothing else I can say that all 35345346 reviews haven't said.  But for my own personal memory of the place...

I'd give the food 4 stars but the service is excellent and our server was very attentive (but not bugaboo attentive) and he was funny.  Kept the coffee cup full.  

Yeah the line was pretty long (~30min) on a Thursday but it was fun to experience the waiting and the anticipation of seeing what all the fuss was about with this place.  But we started with some coffee cake then got our dishes of the Monte Cristo and Northern Italian omelet....no need to describe it because I'm sure there are 3453543 descriptions of each item on the menu from all the reviews.
author: Raymond L.

description:
We wait one hour to get a seat.  We ordered the french toast sampler.

The ingredients used are all very fresh.  The breads, berries and the banana on the french toast are worth 5 stars.  But the three french toast were disappointing.  While they look very good with the colorful berries, syrup and the powdered sugar, they lack one thing that make them french toast,  They are lightly coated with scrambled eggs and fried.  Under the thin layer of fried scrambled eggs, the breads are just .... plain breads.  While the breads are very good bread, they cannot be called french toast.  The french toast I know are soaked thoroughly with a milk-egg mixture before pan fried.  The soaked bread would cook to become bread pudding-like custard.

I would rate the french toast 3 stars only, credit given to the 5-star ingredients.  If I include the one hour wait for this overrated dish, I would give it only 2 stars.
author: Robert W.

description:
Was a good little SF tourist and was reading my Where magazine in my guest room. Voted best brunch/breakfast in the city.... And even more cool that my lovely friend Paige suggested it before I even said anything about the article. I love when the touristy places are really where locals hang out too.  Prepare to wait and take in all that is North Beach.

We hit at primetime brunch time.....about Noon on Sunday. Waited about 45 minutes. Yes, we got snacks of coffee/tea across the street just to tied us over. 

We had the Californian and Farmers omelette, as well as the smoked salmon benedict. It is home fries, not hashbrowns but they were great. I guess I wanted more of a carbtastic meal, as I wish we
 got more home fries.  A great lingonberry? jam on the table. Accommodating staff that was eager to refill coffee & water. A delicious way to end the weekend in SF.
author: Lisa V.

description:
NEWSFLASH: Waiting in line for 2 hours does not make food taste better. 

(But when Mama cooks, she puts a little love in each batch...)
author: Katelin H.

description:
Seemed like a pretty touristy spot to start with, who else has the time to wait over an hour for breakfast, but I would not even wish this place on  the most annoying of tourists. I would also hope that if I traveled to another city a Yelper would warn me of an overrated place like this.

Have heard great things about this place and after 3 years decided to try it out. I ordered the monte christo which was decent as well as a corned beef benedict. They were out of corned beef, would have been nice to know before waiting in the half hour first line, but I was already committed so I got the shrimp benedict instead as did my buddy.

I have never had such fishy tasting or dry shrimp in my life, were literally the consistency of overcooked Idaho spuds, very obvious they just through some old frozen shrimp into a pot and put them in. The eggs were good but the holandaise sauce was very sour and almost tasted rotten as well, the flavor may have come from the rotten shrimp.

Long story short I refused to eat mine and stuck with my monte christo, my buddy ate his and is now extremely sick. If waiting an hour for mediocre food and food born illness is your idea of  time and money well spent then this is the place for you.

There are plenty of great breakfast eateries in this city, there is nothing special about this place that warrants the wait, glad I tried it, won't be going back.
author: Erich G.

description:
I heard from a few people that this place was really good, so I decided to try it.  I told myself that I didn't want to wait longer than half an hour in line, so when we got there, the people said he was about a 30 minute wait.  Well, it wasn't...it was more like an hour and half wait and I only waited that long because I didn't want to leave because I had already waited in line for so long.

We were really hungry by the time we got our food...but our appetite didn't help the fact that the eggs benedict wasn't that good.  The hollandaise sauce makes any benedict dish, and it was too sour for my taste.  My friends had eggs benedict also, but different versions.  They weren't crazy about theirs either.  

Since I had decided when we got inside that I would never eat there again because of the wait, we decided to splurge and also order the chocolate cinnamon french toast.  I am so glad I did because I would've walked away from that place completely disappointed.  The french toast was thick and cooked just right.  They drizzled it with just enough chocolate sauce and piled berries on top.  It was delicious!

Bottom line: I've had better breakfast that I didn't have to wait so long for.
author: Cookie N.

description:
"Okay.  So Mama makes you wait but patience is a virtue (at least that's what my Mama always said).  Is it really so bad to be standing on a picturesque street corner in a trendy SF neigborhood (try any streer corner in Darfur for some true perspective on your good fortune, have pics if vicarious living is your thing).

And that moment...when you get the call to enter...it brought me back to my days as a young buck when I finally got the green light to make a mad dash for 'second base'.  A glorious moment indeed...the anticipation...the fumbling....well, you know the rest.  

The food.   Everyhting was lovingly prepared, just like Mama used to do it.  Pancakes were fluffy and fruit was fresh.  Omelettes were as omelettes should be, folded perfectly and stuffed with all sorts of artery-clogging goodness.  Brought me back to by days as a young back when I finally got to sink my teeth into...well, you know the rest.  
Definintely worth a try...the restaurant that is...actually not just the restaurant.

Oh...and the pay first policy is always nice so at the end you just get up and walk out.  Brought me back to my days as a young buck trolling the red light district in Amsterdam...well, you know the rest."
author: Joseph S.

description:
Found this place on Yelp when I was in search of a yummy breakfast place last week...

I showed up super early on a Tuesday and totally thought there wasn't going to be a line...wrong. I guess there's a line everyday..all day. But of course there would be because they have some of the best dishes! 

While waiting for my breakfast, the BF and I had the blueberry sourcream coffee cake and I can't even describe how it tasted without triggering my cravings again...Sooo moist and warm, and mmm yumm. 

We didn't get any of the special pancakes/french toasts (we should have) but that's why we'll come back and try them. The BF got the shrimp eggs benedict and that was super tasty. I had the florentine omelette and it was okay, just the average omelet so nothing special about that. I think i just ordered the wrong thing, because everything else I tasted was great. 

Will totally come back and try the other coffee cakes and french toasts! :)

Go Mama's
author: Joy A.

description: This was our first time in SF, we would go by the ratings on yelp to help us choose our restaurants. Mama's had some seriously good ratings, so we made it a point to stick it out with our two kids on line for 1.5 hrs. The result was .... What a let down! After all the good reviews I thought I would have something out of this world, but in reality, I wasn't impressed in the least bit. After paying double for our whole "heavenly" experience, we were so much more satisfied with Mo's grill down the block for way better food for half the price. No line, no wait, good service and great breakfast. Mama's is just way too hyped up. Don't fall for the trap!
author: Angela R.

description:
Okay.  I skipped out on the first attempt over a month ago when this place was first introduced to me.  Gary went instead.  Said good things.  I think.  Hmm... makes me wonder now that I may have missed something.

Well... when I went yesterday (granted it was a Saturday), but Seriously!, a 2 hour wait for an egg dish.  I think not.

Who developed the obscured way of being seated at this place? You go from one very long line (time) to another long line where you wait to place your order and then wait for a table... a lot of waiting and truly you begin to weigh the options (other great restaurants, since this city is filled with them, weighed against hunger turning on you and making you nauseous for waiting too long).

This eatery reminds me of a nightmare where you are never able to get out of the nightmare, due to the long wait in the line to get out of the...

I think you get the point.

Was the Crab Omelette worth the $20?  No.  My choice still stands with Stacks (in Hayes Valley), where the Crab Frittata wins hands down, and if my memory serves me correctly, over half the price less than Mama's.

My large freshly WARM?? OJ.  Nice...

I think the only decent thing was the bloody mary and that really didn't contain vodka... 

It was the friends we were with that made waiting here tolerable.  However, I believe they should consider changing the name from Mama's to Nana's, 'cause by the time you are finally seated, Mama has aged and is now a grandmotherly Nana.

Sorry, will not go back.
author: Benjamin B.

description:
Three stars. 

-1 Star for the hour long wait and it just being pretty good. 
-1 Star for dry toast and coffee that was blah.

The food was good, the atmosphere was nice, but it was just not worth the exceptionally long wait. 

I had to come into the City (I'm an East-Bayer, really) so I Yelped for a place to Brunch and I found this place. The line was long so I figured it must not suck.

It did not suck. However, it was not the best brunch I ever had (that was at Pamela's in Pittsburgh, PA, in case you were wondering -- Corn Beef Hash Omelet. Mmmmmm) and it should have been, with the amount of hype this place has on Yelp and the really long line. But it was just "mostly good." 

In reality, if I hadn't had to wait an hour to get in, I would have given it four stars. 

But the toast was still dry.
author: Monica G.

description:
Went here this past weekend.  I wouldn't say the food is to die for, but it's good.

We had nothing to do, so we waited a good 45 minutes in line (got there around 1ish) chit-chatted, hung out, and then got in to order.  The food took a long time to come, but I guess I didn't mind so much because I wasn't STARVING hungry..

I ordered the classic eggs benedict and the bf ordered the Nelson's Racheros.  Basically what that is, is poached eggs in salsa with black beans and tortillas.  Pretty good.  My dish was prepared very well, but it was your pretty standard eggs benedict.

Overall it was good, but I'm not craving it.
author: Kimberly F.

description:
This is without question the best breakfast I've ever had.

I live in Miami and I miss this place to an almost painful degree.
The food was the freshest and best tastingI've ever had.
I hope this place remains this good forever.
If I had money to throw, I'd be flying to SFO to be eating there at least once a week.

The line? it's well worth it my friends.
author: Diego M.

description:
Location:  Far from where I am
Hours: Earlier than I'd like to be awake
Wait: 45 mins - 1.5 hours
Payment: Cash Only

Worth it?  Abso-freakin-lutely.
author: Yeeman N.

description: If you love breakfast food, then this place is the place to go! The homemade jam is amazing!!! I always get an omelette and some sort of bread just for the jelly! The only reason I am giving it 3 stars is the RIDICULOUS wait, if you're like me you are starving (hungover) by the time you get there and then about to die by the time you are at the front of the line. As you wait in line, there will be passerby's that scream "overrated" at you which just makes you even more angry! BUT, I must say...it is worth going at least once!
author: Tiffany T.

description: most famous brunch place in the city, 1-2hr wait but totally worth it every once in a while
author: Niket B.

description: As always, the food never fails! Came here with my parents on Wednesday right before it was about to close so around 2:15ish. First time I went with no line! The place is so cute and makes you feel right at home. Service was awesome. Our waitress was a tall blonde lady I think her name was Kate or Kim? She always checked up on us and was super nice.  Ordered the french toast sampler. Superb! All the fruit was ripe and sweet. Mango smoothie was just OK for its price. But next time I gotta try the dessert, it looked so yummy :) I love Mama's!
author: Rachel M.

description: 4 stars is very fair for this spot. their monte cristo is best i ever had. everything else aint bad. line is always a deterrent
author: Charlie C.

description:
Wait in line patiently.

Order both items:
Dungeness crab omelette and Swedish cinnamon french toast w/fruit.

Smile at your server for reminding you about the hybrid, homemade jam.

Find a spot at the park to take a nap.
author: Nich T.

description: I have to admit, when I saw the long line waiting to get in, I thought to myself "I'm not waiting over an hour for no freakin' scrambled eggs". But, I was with friends and we waited approximately one hour to get in. Granted, the food is great...but does it justify waiting over an hour in line? NO, it does not. They herd you in like cattle, sit you down in a cramped table; and you better hurry up, eat, and get out. it was an experience, but I can easily find other places that are equally as great without the one to two hours of waiting.
author: James L.

description: best overall breakfast place i've been to ever. I've had fluffier omelletes. but tastier? no. they've really got their flavors perfected here. their benedicts are wonderful, too. but what i am going to get from now on at mama's is the monte christo. GOOD LORD! it is deep fried cheesey meaty sweet goodness. it was my first monte cristo but i have a feeling none will ever live up to mama's version. despite the long line and the frenzy inside (it's an eager happy frenzy though) it's worth all the trouble.
author: Tin-Tin E.

description:
There's only one word to describe this place: divine.

I love breakfast food, especially great breakfast food and Mama's has it. They offer so many great options that I often find myself torn between a savory dish and a sweet dish. I've found their Monte Cristo sandwich quite satisfying and am dreaming of having one right now. I highly recommend it with their very tasty, very addictive olallieberry jam.
author: April B.

description:
Do I even need to add another glowing review to the collection 366 that came before me?  Yes, yes I do...

Mainly because I've been singing Mama's praises to various friends, only to hear "But there's always a line.  I don't want to wait."  Well people, grab a coffee and a trashy magazine, buck up and hold out for the 45 minutes to an hour it takes to get your foot in the door, because it's worth it.  Really damn worth it.  Shrimp, tomato and avocado eggs benedict.  Enough said.

Then go pass out in a food coma in Washington Square, next to the random homeless guy with a backpack and trekking poles who likes to stick his tongue out at strangers.  He won't steal your wallet (most of the time).
author: Sarah J.

description:
Mama's is a delicious tiny breakfast shack!!!!! So good! The best thing to order is the French toast sampler!!!! BOMB sugary, syrupy goodness!!! The line was out the door n once u get in u have to wait in another line to order... N once a table for ur party is ready... U r seated!!! Strange way... But it rolls smoothly!!!... N I gave this place a 4 because I ordered the Monte cristo n it had MAYO!!! yuck... So it kind of killed my breakfast... So if u HATE MAYO like I do... Make sure u say no...

BTW... the eggs benedict looked sooooo good!!!!!
author: Leslie S.

description: Currently my favorite breakfast place! I am not a big fan of french toast as that is what they are known for... But when I come here, I always get the crab egg benedict! The hollendaise is perfect and I love real crab meat! Also outstanding service, which it should be since it is a fairly small restaurant with a huge line formed everyday! If you don't want to wait, just get it to-go, or go after 12:30-1:00pm, but that does beat the purpose of getting breakfast. Oh well, when food is this good, you can have it whatever time you want.
author: Charles L.

description:
The wait has been thoroughly described in all of these reviews, so I'm going to focus on what the wait may or may not be worth:  The Food.

I ordered the classic eggs benedict after hemming & hawing over the potential of a prosciutto & tomato benedict (mmmmmmmfff -- I love me some prosciutto, but is it really a breakfast food?).  

I was directed toward a table immediately in front of the kitchen, and to my delight, I watched as Mama's two plump chefs expertly whisked eggs, flipped pancakes, and buttered generous portions of sourdough toast.  (I love me some open kitchen action, too).  

When my plate arrived, the benedict was piping hot and smothered in a rich, salty hollandaise that--dare I say it?--was a tad too vinegar-heavy for my morning palate.  But the thick, smoky Canadian bacon, the fresh & bright green sprinkling of parsley, and the plump, buttered english muffin all more than made up for the vinegar misstep.  (Seriously--do they make their own english muffins?  I've never encountered one that's nearly 3/4-of-an-inch thick.)

Overall, the dish was nearly perfect.  Next time, however, I'm taking the pancake plunge--my neighbor's plate of flapjacks was brimming with bright, fresh berries, the sight of which convinced me a second trip should be worth the wait.
author: Ann M.

description:
I live in L.A. but whenever I am anywhere near S.F. I make sure I fit a visit or two to MAMA'S.  Even though you stand in line to order your food (like Carl's JR,but not) and they give you a number to put on your table instead of complete full service I just love it here.  The server does ask you what drinks you want....just not for food.  The people are super friendly and sometimes they even offer you a decent size piece of one of their extra yummy baked goods since they know you have possibly been waiting 30 minutes to an hour just to get to where you order.  

I love their moist and fluffy buttermilk pancakes served with fresh fruit.
Their omelets  and coffee are pretty good too. Everyone I have brought and all the people eating around us always seem really happy with their food.

If you have time to wait I would definitely recommend breakfast at MAMA'S!
author: jodi h.

description:
i was visiting sf so no biggie i waited about an hour to get in. i was curious to the recommended sunday brunch. living in philly, it's a place easily comparable to a place like sabrina's....from the outside. once you step in, the sweet smells of breads, pastries and other fine brunchy foods take over. you walk up to the counter, order then pay. it was pretty pricey so my taste bud's hopes were high. the crab omlet was huge and filled with lots of real crab. my boyfriend wolfed it down. i'd tried it and tasty wasn't the word. my french toast were thick and fluffy, topped with the freshest fruit. 
a small establishment but packed with flavor. a must do for all visitors looking for a great start to their day.
author: crystal e.

description:
[15:00] "fiance": i totally had a hankering for Zaftigs earlier :-)
[15:00] "fiance": although i think discovering Mama's was huge in filling that void
[15:01] me: yeah
[15:01] me: Has there been a day we haven't talked about Mama's since we've gone there?
[15:02] "fiance": no
[15:02] "fiance": i don't think so
[15:03] me: I'm going to yelp our IM conversation, is that okay?
[15:04] "fiance": sure
author: Alex D.

description: Oh my gosh!! So yummy!!! We visited San Fran for the first time and knew that we couldn't leave without eating here. We got in line at 7:20am and I'm really glad we did. The line filled up so fast!! We were the first of three couples to order and be seated. It's definitely tight in the restaurant but worth it. I ordered the cinnamon Swedish French toast with a side of bacon and it-was-to-die-for. My husband ordered the egg Benny and his was amazing as well. Oj was crazy and the coffee was perfect. Get there early or wait. They are very organized and efficient.
author: Keli G.

description:
Mama's is amazing, and I guess if you're a tourist its worth the wait but, the line most of the time just sucks. The food is delicious but; no food is worth an hour or two in line. 

That being said, if you do get in the monte cristo is probably one of the best things here. Its kind of expensive, especially for juices and basic drinks. parking in this area is also horrendous. they need to expand!
author: Samantha J.

description: We got there about 8:15 am and waited 30 minutes- but worth the wait.  We got Hot Chocolate, coffee, french toast, and the washington sq omelette.  Everything was really good- definitely lived up to the hype.  The restaurant is well-organized- they really have their shit together.  We had to ask for coffee refills once, but our waitress got it right away.  The Monte Cristo looked so damn good...I had order envy when I saw other people getting that...and the benedicts.  Everything just looks so good.
author: Amy B.

description:
Excellent!!  Great place for breakfast. Get there early. They open at 8 am, but people start lining up at 7 am. We got there at 7:30 and got a seat. In the first wave. 
Wonderful French toast and pancakes.  Look forward to the place on every visit.
author: Steven S.

description: This is one of my favorite brunch places in SF.  If you go on a weekend, be prepared to wait in line.  It's completely worth it!  Go there when it first opens.  The coffee cake is still warm and so delicous.  Love the french toast too.  Really can't go wrong with anything on the menu.
author: Shelly W.

description:
We've had many failed attempts here, simply walked away when we saw the line. But today, we decided to brave the cold and attempted and boy were we lucky, there were only 6 others in line and we were inside the warm environment of Mama's within 10 mins. 

We had the chocolate coffee cake, apple turnover cake with hot chocolate to start with and shortly came our Banana Nut French Toast Covered with bananas and eggs florentine. Everything was fresh, tasty and just wonderful.
The servers were all very friendly and as I was eating the the french toast, the server pointed out to us to use the jam which will be a much better choice and he was right on! We sure wish the line is a lot shorter so we can come back more often...
author: Yan M.

description:
Ok, get over it. The line is a given if you're gonna try to go to Mama's during peak hours. Either deal with the wait, or go after one o'clock on a weekday.

Very, very well done food and a surprisingly large menu for the quality of the dishes. Like others have mentioned, the Monte Cristo is amazing and the Benedicts are stellar (the poached eggs are almost always cooked perfectly), with the Crab Florentine as a stand out among them. House made jam at every table, good coffee, fresh juice and a wide assortment of scrumptious pastries add a lot to this cozy spot on Washington Square. 

It's really too bad the tourists know about this place because it does get get quite crowded, but with very good reason. Best breakfast in the city in my opinion and easy to see why Mama's has been around for so long.
author: Halli P.

description: I heard about this place from a friends coworker and it was also in my hotel guide book. Of course I also checked it out on Yelp. Everyone sure was right!! Definitely one of the best breakfasts I've had. I was considering ordering the Salmon scramble but everyone on yelp raved about the Monte Cristo so I changed my mind. I am SO glad I did. I would have been very sad if I never tried it. People can tell you how good it is but you'll never believe it til you experience it for yourself. So go try it! Bf got the dungeoness crab omelette, it was good but wasn't great. Even less so since my monte cristo was only half the price! I will definitely crave it when I go back to New York. The pancakes were good too, very fluffy with crispy edges, I love that. Would definitely recommend this place to anyone. Go early! We went on Sunday, got there 30 minutes before 8 when it opens and there was already a line.
author: Mary H.

description: Mamas is simply orgasmic. The freshest ingredients, mouth watering goodness, words simply cannot describe. Every time I looked at the menu there was something else I wanted to try. I have found my new breakfast spot in sf.... It is a small place and waiting is part of the excitement.  Had the special dungeness crab omelet with havarti cheese avocado and tomatoes.. It was wonderful....my friend had the banana bread French toast , home made banana bread lightly battered , fresh fruit I was glad he let me have a bite otherwise I would've ordered one myself... The best breakfast I have had in a long time.
author: Jorge J.

description:
Mama's is a little place near Coit Tower.  You can't miss it since there is a line that branches out from the corner.  "There's a line?" you ask?  First and foremost, it's not a ridiculous line.  Secondly, be prepared to wait for an hour or so before being able to be seated.  The owners are aware of this line and offer water and samples to those who are waiting in line.  A menu is placed on one of the windows so that you have a chance to decide on what you want so that when they take your order, the process is streamlined.

Once you make it inside, it is packed, the hosts/hostesses, servers are really busy.  This does not take away from the hospitality that they give to all patrons.  They are courteous and friendly and they make sure that your order is to what you have specified.

We were seated and since we had a large party, it took a bit to get the food out.  Some restaurants bring the food over once it's ready; here, they bring all of it out so there's no waiting.  Our party ordered quite a bit ranging from the French Toast Sampler, to multiple types of "M'omelettes" where some contained dungeness crab and salmon, while others with traditional ingredients.

If there's one M'omelette you have to try, it's the Florence M'omelette. Not only is it an omelette with crispy bacon inside, it contained some greens and cheese that tied the flavors together effortlessly.  I paired a beer with our brunch, but the reason why I paired a beer wasn't because I liked beer.  Mama's is the first place I've been to (that I know of) that serves Anchor Steam Beer (Yay San Francisco!).  I couldn't pass up that offer.

The overall experience was great even though there was a wait in line.  Plan accordingly because parking is a little difficult.  Public transportation is best and if you walked, even better.
author: Nicklaus B.

description:
I come to San Francisco about twice a year from Orange County. I only come to eat and Mama's is one of two places that I must go to. I've introduced several friends to this place and they all loved it! OMG! I love their food! I get so pissed off at the "tourists" that complain when they are in line. Hell, if it wasn't so damn good there wouldn't be a line. And if you want a quick breakfast go to IHOP. 

I really shouldn't be recommending this place so much then the line will get even longer!
I'm coming up that way again in 4 weeks! I'm counting the days!
author: Stephanie E.

description: Have been going to Mama's since 04. Same fanfare and queue. Great Dungeness Crab Benedict though the omelettes are decent but not special.
author: Adam X.

description:
Places like these should not be rated by stars (what more can you wish for than good food and friendly service?). I'd rather rate places like these by how many minutes I'm willing to wait for a table.
I give this joint a 45m rating.
author: Timmy T.

description:
Yum! Yum! Yum!  Okay, so it's a given that you'll be waiting in line to get into Mama's...that aside, once you're seated, you're golden.  

It was a weekday when I went for the very first time, so luckily, we were able to step right inside and wait in a mini line...and gawk at all of the sweet cakes & breads and fresh fruits on display.  It was fun and completely distracting to watch chefs at work, preparing such dishes as French toast and eggs benedict with a creamy hollandaise sauce.  I kept changing my mind about what to order...bouncing back and forth between a savory omelette to sweet stack of pancakes.  So, what did I do?? I combined the savory and the sweet and asked for a Monte Cristo sandwich.  SCORE!!   It was perfectly awesome...served up with homemade blackberry jam that I just couldn't get enough of.

I'll definitely be making more return visits there!  It was cozy and very quaint.  The food was top-notch, and the service once we were seated, was extremely attentive, refilling my iced tea on several occasions.
author: Evelyn K.

description:
The best things in life come to those who wait.  

But boy!  That's a long wait!  So in the meantime - grab a coffee and a scone at Cafe Roma's first, a Sunday paper, and hopefully a good conversationalist by your side and you're set!
author: Yelper A.

description:
I have been here 3 times in the 2 year life in San Francisco. I refuse, and repeat REFUSE, to wait in a line for food regardless of how delicious it is. Sure I sound snobby when I say this but the fact of the matter is that when I do have time to sit down and eat breakfast at a fine establishment like this... I don't want to wait in fear of starving to death.

Mom and Dad come into town to spoil me rotten. Next morning STARVING we go to Mamas. Line is present and restaurant opened 30 mins earlier. Not bad actually, we decide to stay.

GOOD LORD only 20 mins later and half a newspaper we are seating  with the all time cutest waitress ever. She was all over us with coffee refills and smiles.... my mom was feeling a little ill from hunger pains and I think out waitress literally leaped over the counter to get her some crackers to nibble on. 

Worth the wait if your hunger can stand it. I recommend hitting it early and mid-week. Leave to the tourists on the weekends.
author: Nancy B.

description:
I don't know if I'm missing something, or people like Mama's because they're starved by the time they get a seat, or I just had bad luck the day I visited...but, I don't get what the big deal is about this place. I ordered a stack of pancakes with berries and  I have to say that I have had better...

Oh well, I'll give this place another chance the next time I'm in SF...
author: Taz M.

description: I'm from OC... hands down... best breakfast I've ever had at noon. Got there at 10:30AM... waited 2hr & 30min in the rain... but it was all worth it!
author: Tiffany W.

description:
I'm not an American breakfast type of gal. Give me a bowl of pho or fried rice over pancakes and bacon any day. So when friends suggested that we have breakfast at Mama's and then told me it'd be an HOUR wait before we'd be seated, I was indignant and ready to march to Chinatown to pick up some take-out dim sum. After much persuasion- and because I was craving fresh squeezed orange juice- Mama's prevailed and I waited dutifully in line along with the rest of the herd to see what all of the hype was about. 

I'll admit- the breakfast is pretty good here. Although I ordered the dullest thing on the menu (2 eggs over-medium with Canadian bacon), my breakfast companions were more adventurous and their fluffy omelettes and pancakes covered in fresh fruit made my plate look like green eggs and ham. Who knew Canadian bacon wasn't really bacon but ham instead? I was horribly tricked . . .why are the Canadians always trying to differentiate themselves from Americans?  

The orange juice and home-made jam did make up for my ham surprise however. I did notice that I was the only person in the entire restaurant who picked white over wheat toast, which I found a little funny. I mean, you're already gorging a heaping plate of 3 eggs, bacon and pancakes smothered in maple sauce. How much more damage are a few pieces of white bread going to cause?

Anyways, I left Mama's satisfied- it did exceed my somewhat mediocre expectations. I still would pick a bowl of pho over it, however, the fried rice may have been beat.
author: Alice P.

description: Anyone who write's a bad review for this place because of the wait is a nut! Go eat some grass!! This is worth the wait time and time again.  Staff was smiling, food was awesome and it was slammed! (As it is every time!)
author: Maggie F.

description:
The food is great! The service is friendly!  Why don't I go there every weekend?  Well, it's really the seating system that they use. You wait and wait and wait on line outside, then you get inside and you're still in line!  Once you order at the counter, you might have to wait some more to get a table.  By the time you're seated, the food comes about a minute later. Even if you're a slow eater, you only spend a few minutes at your table.  I can appreciate that this helps more people per hour to enjoy Mama's yummy food, but it doesn't have the lazy Sunday morning brunch vibe that I am after.  I would almost say that this is the place to go for a quickie brunch, except that you could wait an hour in line before getting the quickie part!  I much prefer a meal where I can warm my seat up before I'm done.  

I'll take the Dottie's wait any day. At least I'm sitting at a table with a hot cuppa coffee while I wait for the kitchen to be ready for me.  There's something so charming about inefficiency on a Sunday morning.
author: Jess S.

description:
After reading raving reviews from fellow yelpers, I had to make Mama's a stop on our girls day of fun.

My friend and I wanted to get to Mama's early Saturday, as I am well awared of the line. However, life happened, and we arrived at the restaurant around 9:30am. Saw the dreaded line, but I was not about to walk away.

I kid you not, the wait was 60 minutes! Once we got into the doors, we still had to wait for a table -- this restaurant is definitely not for the impatient. I ordered the french toast and the friend ordered the Dungeness crab omelette. We both got the recommended coffee with our - by this time, 10:30 - brunch.

Finally got seated at 10:45. Food did come quickly and oh man was it good! I don't like maple syrup much, so the homemade jam was a great touch. I tried a bite of the crab omelette, and determined to go back next time and get one for myself.

Now I have to fingure out when the line is shortest :)
author: Lois W.

description:
It's taken some practice but I've finally gotten the visit to Mama's down: 

LOGISTICS: 
Coming from the south bay, I grab a hungry friend or two and drive to the city for a breakfast I almost never refuse. This in itself takes some planning as friends grow hungry during an hour's drive. Make sure to drop them off at the door to start waiting in line while you drive around for a parking spot...good luck. 

WHAT TO ORDER: 
Eggs Florentine! 2 poached eggs covered with spinach, mushrooms and hollandaise sauce. I've ordered eggs Florentine at a handful of other breakfast restaurants and this is the only one that includes mushrooms. writing about it makes my mouth water! also, be sure to order the pancakes topped with fresh fruit to balance your sweet and savory cravings :) 

If I have to admit it, there are definitely 'wrong' orders here. their omelets, seafood dishes and french toast are "OK". I would not wish these dishes on any first timer. 

WHY IT'S AS GOOD AS IT GETS: 
You can't beat Mama's charm. Like I said in another review, I like my breakfast with a little charm...it brightens my day! Upon my last visit to Mama's not only did I score an awesome parking spot but I enjoyed pleasant conversation with some tourists from Austin.
author: Sarah Z.

description:
Quite possibly the best breakfast joint in San Francisco.

Now that is a bold statement, considering that there are tons of breakfast joints per square foot in this town.  However, this place is one of my favorite spots to grab brunch.  If it wasn't for the weekend wait, I'd probably set up a be a permanent fixture.  I always felt there wasn't enough of that "greasy spoon" flavor at many of the SF joints; but this place offers a delicious middle-ground between healthy and rich flavors: reminds me of some New England diners I've been to.

I love the Eggs Benedict, and they have tons of other variations: from Crab, to Shrimp & Avocado, to Salmon Benedict.  I love the Salmon Benedict too.  The Benedicts have a deliciously rich, yet lighter, Hollandaise Sauce.  I love the Eggs Florentine as well (can you tell I love Hollandaise), and the Lox Bagel Platter.  I love their Omelettes too; I suggest the Washington Square or the one with Panchetta in it.

A delicious, and more health-conscious, diner that reminds me of New England spots.
author: Satoru Y.

description:
Yay for coming here on a Tuesday!  There was still a wait but it wasn't bad at all.  We had the crab omelet with avocado, french toast with berries and chocolate, and three types of crumb cake.  Booyah.

I'd be hard-pressed to say that the french toast was anything special.  I prefer La Note in Berkeley, and several places in NYC.  Mama's french toast lacked the nice fat slabs of bread that gives you the gooey inside texture.  The omelet, however, was fantastic.  How good can eggs be?  Mama's good.  The crumb cakes were delicious too, all three of them.  I liked the apple and cream cheese (I think this was the flavor) the best!
author: Deborah H.

description:
Cash only must be mentioned first in case you read no further.  
It is worth your while to pay another banks atm fees in order to get some :)
After spending 4 days in San Francisco on my first visit ever to the city I can say this was my favorite restaurant out of many we tried, including Dottie's Blue Moon.  That one was good, but this is simply the BEST.  Possibly the best breakfast I've had anywhere.   Once you have eaten at Mama's everything else will pale in comparison.  The pancakes where heavenly as well as the omelet and fresh squeezed orange juice.  The service was excellent too.  Everyone was so friendly and nice.  I won't wait in line for any restaurant so we planned ahead and got there early, around 8am on a Friday morning.  We waited about 10 minutes.  You go through a line, order and pay then get seated.  You have full service once you are seated.    I would go back to San Francsico (from TX) just to eat at Mama's.  :)
author: Jennifer C.

description:
Perfectly decent breakfasty food.  If the line wasn't over an hour, it would probably get 4 stars.  

But seriously people, what are you guys waiting in line for?  Its not that nice inside, and the food isn't spectacular.  Don't people in North Beach have anything better to do in the morning?

I say take the walk of shame and head someplace else the morning after.
author: Steve S.

description:
This visit to the greater SF area is the 7th time I've been here but my first time at Mama's. Still somewhat jet-lagged and wandering around the north beach/chinatown area I was starting to go a little negative mentally and be like when the hells are we getting to this place and is it going to be worth it.

Operating on one of my long held principles that hunger is the best sauce everything was really good. The savory vs. sweet argument continues to rage. I got the florentine scramble and my partner in dining crime got some hamburger thing that was served on a baguette-not being a red meat consumer myself I didn't try it but it looked tempting. We got a blueberry cake thing so the meal was the delightful alternating of sweet and savory.

the debit card machine was not working but fear not we had cash. (this was told to us after we ordered which was really the only service faux pas of our visit)

The lemonade was tasty and refreshing.

The trip back to the lavatory is an interesting odyssey.

Next time the pancakes or one of the lunchier items!

Re: The wait-we went at 2pm so there was none YAY!
author: Eve S.

description:
My friend and I were staying in San Francisco and we searched for good breakfast places and this popped up. With over 600 reviews we thought the line should be worth it... ok, the line was ridiculous. It took 45 minutes to get through the door and then once in, there was another line where you order the food. Once you order the food you finally get to sit down. So was the line worth it? The consensus was no, BUT the food was good. We would just go on a weekday when it's not so busy instead of a Sunday morning.

I had the crab omelet with spinach and it was extremely, melt in your mouth good. There were lots of crab, they didn't skimp on anything. My friend's french toast would have been just okay, but the homemade jam made it really good.
author: Mariver C.

description:
all right, so this is the deal,
this is an awesome place for brunch,
be ready to take a nap after you eat here.

things ordered :
OJ, smokes salmon benedict, and french toast sampler (banana walnut berries and cinnamom flavored)


no need to use flowery language to sell this place,
just go and try it out, and tell me how it was 

I brought cash this time. last time when I stood in line and reached the door, I realised I had no cash. had to walk back empty stomach :(
author: Utsav M.

description: Wait an hour in line...be satisfied the rest of the afternoon.  You must try the homemade jam.
author: Annie C.

description:
Waited about an hour for my group of six (arrived at 11 AM, made it in by 12:10). 

The food was hearty and pretty delicious. The staff is friendly and efficient and the food comes quickly once you order. Also, the OJ was fresh-squeezed! Probably not the best breakfast I've ever had, but solid and tasty. 

I'd go again, but maybe earlier to skip the line.
author: Madeline N.

description:
Two hours wait for a SANDWICH?!!

This was my first brunch as a San Franciscan (is that the right term?) and let me tell you- without a drop of alcohol, this was WELL worth the wait. After four years of champagne-clouded Sunday brunches, I felt it only appropriate to celebrate my first SF brunch with one of the most well-known brunch places in the city- Mama's. 
I know some people think it is ridiculous to wait so long for a seemingly over-hyped place but I think it depends on what you order.
If I'd waited two hours plus for the omelette or french toast, I probably would have cried, packed my bags and moved my butt back to Clinton Street Bakery in NYC but if you're one of the few that did their research and GOT THE MONTE CRISTO sandwich then you probably gave tis place five shiny white stars just like I have done. You were probably also one of the lucky people who had a sandwich change their life.
That's right. CHANGE THEIR LIFE.
Four triangles of perfectly fluffy outsides harboring creamy havarti/cheddar and turkey insides and accompanied by fresh jam- this perfect little confection is worth every second of waiting.

We also ordered the crab omelette- which was filled to the brim with sweet, hearty chunks of dungeness crab meat and the yogurt/egg white french toast with fresh berries. Both very tasty and well-prepared but the reality of it was, they were both merely just two great back up singers to a truly talented Beyonce of a Monte Cristo.

Last few things: 
-Bring Cash or a Debit Card. 
-Make sure you aren't here with a first date (it's going to be a long wait, what if your date is a dud?)
-Wear Comfortable Shoes (you'll be standing a long time.)
-Bring your appetite (you'll want to eat everything after you're finally seated.)

Bon Appetit!
author: Lianne Z.

description:
Hm...  Against better logic, I stayed up past 3 and wound up waking to a world of lethargy and reluctance.  Fortunately, I know this beautiful way to meander through such a feeling: breakfast.

Went to Mama's with my boy Luc, and contrary to the popular vote here, half the restaurant was free and empty.  Apparently, this is an order at the counter dig, and so we did with the scrutiny one such as I usually applies to a menu upon first evaluation.  I wound up with the Washington Square Omelette and a glass of OJ.

Sat down, BSed for a few minutes.  OJ and water arrived.  Nice waitress.  OJ tasted like sugar-water with mild orange flavor.  0 points.  The water was clear, and full of ice.  I suspected no foul play.

10 minutes later, food arrived.  Mine was pretty decent, although I wasn't really digging the ingredients (that, of course way my fault, and I rightly beat myself later with a knotted rope, like the albino guy in the Dan Brown novel).  The carrot cake I ordered alongside was really, ah.. fluffed up.  Taste wasn't quite as good as the Sweet Things carrot cake, from Tiburon, but it was pretty decent.  Anyway, food... Eh..  3.5.

Paid, left.  Had enjoyed a quaint little view of the Square, some morning relaxation, and probably irritated everyone around us with our loud-mouthed comments (read: my associate's loud-mouthed comments).

All told: Able Service, Good Food, Average Price.  If you dig breakfast, hit it up.  If you hate breakfast - aside from the necessary mental evaluations - move on.  Parking in North Beach often isn't worth it.
author: Philippe N.

description:
I waited an hour --- in the rain --- to get into Mama's on a late Sunday morning. It was worth it. It's one of those rare eateries that exceeds all the hype.

There's a reason why Mama's food score on Zagat is consistently up there with the likes of Slanted Door and Delfina. Superb.
author: The Other Jeff A.

description: Wow...just wow!  Worth the wait!  Had the fresh crab Benedict and Monte cristo. Will be back to try lunch.
author: Mathew F.

description:
Thank you yelp.com for leading me to the best breakfast I've ever had. After reading all the reviews for this place I decided that this place was worth waking up at 7am on a Saturday morning for. We got there 15 min before opening and there was already a line outside. Crazy! For breakfast!? Don't people in SF sleep?! 

After waiting in line for 30 minutes, we were seated and hungry. Everything on the menu looked really good. My wife settled for a dungeness crab/ spinach egg benedict w/t side of potatoes and I went for the swedish cinnamon french toast w/t berries and a cup of fresh oj. The egg was poached perfectly and the benedict/hollandaise sauce was surprisingly lighter than expected and after trying the french toast I feel like I now know what a french toast is supposed to taste like. 

Come here early, wait in line... and be satisfied. 

*side note* i enjoyed this place better than dottie blue. It felt "homey". The food was better too.
author: Victor H.

description: A week in SF amd this was our best meal, hands down. We went on a Wednesday morning - arriving before they opened. It was a short wait but the line grows fast. The shrimp benedict was divine. Service is quick and friendly, even if the place is a little cramped. So, forget that this is probably in every guide book or you have to wait forever...just go and have an amazing breakfast.
author: mary b.

description:
Ups: EXCELLENT food. wow.. Seriously, everything I tried was GREAT and everything I saw looked delicious. It is a very cute romantic place. Fun to watch the cook's preparing the meals while you are in line to pay.

Downs: price is not that great. I am a big fan of cheap food, but it is worth every penny. THE WAITING SUCKS. there is always a giant line outside. Be ready to wait a long time outside...
author: Fabiana H.

description:
My wife and I wanted to try out Dottie's, but the line was a 2 hour wait.  We skipped Dottie's and headed out to Mama's.  Mama's also had a line outside, but it was much shorter than Dottie's.  We were seated in 16 minutes.  Not bad at all.  The food was GREAT and as well as the service from the waiters.

My wife and I both had Mama's French Toast Sampler, Chicken Habanero Sausage, Chicken Apple Sausage, Carrot Cake, and a Coffee Crumb Cake.

Mama's French Toast Sampler -  Consisted of 3 French Toast.  A Banana Nut, Cranberry Orange Walnut, and Swedish Cinnamon.  All topped with fresh berries (blueberries and strawberries) and bananas.  If I knew the portion was very large, I wouldn't have ordered the carrot cake and the coffee cake.  I did try their delicious homemade berry jam.  This sampler is a keeper!

Chicken Habanero Sausage & Chicken Apple Sausage - This was delicious.  Both tasted exactly like Aidell's brand.

Carrot Cake & Coffee Crumb Cake - PERFECT! 

Mama's is a small place.  The seating is a little cramped.  When the waiters walk by, I would have to lean forward because I felt like I was in the way. 

My overall experience at Mama's is a 4 star experience.
author: Wenzel A.

description:
This place became intrinsically wrong with its popularity.
Since everybody knows that brunch is so good here, the line in the street extends well around the corner and people are ready to catch sun burns waiting for so long. You might even end up making new friends in line and spend more time with them than your actual ones. Then you finally enter the restaurant portion of the waiting line and watch people eating until you realize that it's your time to order, and you have to order before getting seated.  Oh, and it's cash only.

Basically it's like standing up, waiting until your brain becomes lethargic. I mean, there is so much i can laugh and talk about with my friends around noon on a mid-Saturday with a hangover and WITHOUT food in my stomach but after 2 hours, it becomes work. 

Let me describe this place.
First:
Wait-wait-wait-wait-wait-wait-wait-wait-wait-wait-wait-wait-wait-wait-wait-wait-wait-wait-wait-wait-wait-wait-wait-wait-wait-wait-wait-wait-wait-wait-wait-wait-wait-wait-wait-wait-wait-wait-wait-wait-wait-wait-wait-wait-wait-wait-wait-wait-wait-wait-wait-wait-wait-wait-wait-wait.

All the sudden:
Oh-oh-action-action! No time to think, get moving! people are waiting!  Ahhhhhhhh!

Then of course you love your little chair and think: hum, this chair is comfy!  Ahhhh, the food is yummy.  But i kinda wanna eat more or something else... now that i have my chair i'm gonna take my time... no, that wouldn't be fair to everybody else back in the LINE.

Fuck this.
author: Damien J.

description:
Simply: Came here with Picky expecting empty stomach to be filled and satisfied.  I  was not disappointed.  Had to wake up extra early to get in line and was one of the fortunate few that got seats in the first round after  they opened.  Had the florentine benedict and hot chocolate.  The food has a homey feel and I was definitely full when I came to the last bite.  Overall, an excellent first experience and I look forward to trying the other items on the menu.... the omelettes looked tasty... and so did the french toast .... and the pancakes too... i think it's going to be more than one return visit  =)

The only down side may be needing to find street parking but if you are there before the restaurant opens, the chances of parking is slightly better.

Picky: THIS IS ABSOLUTELY MY FAVORITE PLACE TO EAT BREAKFAST.  Quite possibly in all of california. THE END.   

Note: If you can still eat after a meal at mama's you must go across the street to pick up some foccaccia@ http://www.yelp.com/biz/liguria-bakery-san-francisco
author: Simply Pick y.

description: I'll keep it short. Overrated, not worth the wait, especially if you live in SF.
author: amit s.

description: Great Food and well worth the wait in line! A breakfast must when visiting SFO.
author: D.W. D.

description: I hate brunch but I would come back for brunch here. The turkey sandwich so good it melts in my mouth ;) (monte cristo)
author: James V.

description: GO BEFORE 10:30. I waited the longest ever yesterday at Mama's: 1 hour 40 minutes. The five of us were cursing ourselves "should we leave? stay? leave?" Of course we stayed! GO BEFORE 10:30. Those darned cakes and rolls to order before you get your meal are worth the wait by their own standards- try the amazingly frosted carrot cake or squishy blueberry cake! Everytime I go to Mama's, I order something new and everytime I take my first bite... I forget how long I waited outside. Yesterday was the Apple Pan Dore and it was I-N-S-A-N-E. And the manager always thanks everyone for waiting once they make it inside. GO BEFORE 10:30. For service and food that good, the wait is definitely always worth it. Once you've sat, the service is very attentive yet almost invisible. I just wish they'd consider new real estate :-) GO BEFORE 10:30.
author: Meredith R.

description: The food was good but it was not worth an hour and a half wait in the sun.  Plan to get hungry and need to use the restroom while you're waiting.   Something you might want to do one time.
author: Jeff D.

description:
Meh...I have experienced better. A lot better. For a lot less money, a lot less time and for much tastier brunch. Not to mention the ladies the man and I had to stand in line with for an hour and a half...eesh. Go back to the dive bar on Fillmore from whence you came evil wenches and don't ruin my appetite. I digress. 

Food: crab benedict was ok. They definitely don't skimp on the crab, but it didn't taste fresh. The sauce was pretty bland and the eggs were overly poached. Potatoes were nothing special. French toast sampler was a bit better, but not really anything special. I don't really consider french toasting cranberry orange bread that revolutionary. Coffee included milk but not half and half. OJ was freshed squeeze (hence, two stars). Total cost for two people: $40 without tip. 

In a long-winded conclusion - Mama's appears to have been invaded by well-intentioned tourist and evil gaggles of girls who use the same bottle to bleach their hair. A person in search of a good, reasonably-priced brunch should look elsewhere.
author: Caitlin C.

description:
So, I have tried to eat at Mama's a few times on the weekend. The first time I went, it was around 9:30. I thought this was pretty early, I was wrong! This past week, I was dog sitting and my friends pup was up at the crack of dawn. I got back from walking the pooches and it was about 7:15. I did the hole "are you sleeping?" to my boyfriend and got the "I was!" So, long story short, I arrived at Mama's by 8:00.
To my surprise there was already a line. This time we grinned and bared it and all I can say is wow! I had the low fat french toast and it was amazing. I can't believe it was low fat. B-friend had one of the huge omelet's and it was also very good. 
I now know that this place is worth the wait! If you find yourself up earlier than you would like to be on a Sat morning, I say head to Mama's!!
author: Lisa A.

description:
I spent my 20 minutes in line deciding between french toast and monte cristo.......a huge dilemma when you are sooo hungry!  I chose french toast, which was really great, but spent the entire day wondering if the monte was better.  No worries, this place is at the top of my list next time in am in SF.  

Really, really great food.  OK interior (but small) and great service!
author: jennifer j.

description:
Hokay. So this is THE spot for brunch. There really is no bad dish on the menu, and the highlights are plentiful. For breakfast, french toast is a great option. The blueberry coffee cake is rich, but in a good way. It's sweet and definitely a sinful experience. 

For lunch, the slim joe can't be beat. They grind up the meat and cook it like a steak sandwich on a tasty baguette. It's awesome when served with a salad or potatoes. And finally my favorite - the Monte Cristo sandwich. The bread is dipped in egg and three slices surround two layers of ham and cheese, then the whole mess is dipped in egg and grilled like french toast and served with powdered sugar and a homemade jam.

Amazing food.

Add in fresh squeezed OJ (or a mimosa), coffee, and some sourdough toast, and you've got yourself a great way to begin the day.

How do you avoid the line? Invite a friend, ask him/her to get there early, then tell them you're running late. Awful to say, but in all honesty, the only way to circumvent what can be an hour and 20 minute wait on weekends.
author: Aaron F.

description:
Alright, I agree with everyone else about the food.  REALLY good.  Service is great too.  LOVE the atmosphere too, really quaint and bed and breakfast like.

STILL, we waited the predicted hour and a half from the standing in line to the paying at the cash register, to the finally sitting at our table and getting our food.  While the food was very, very tasty, I still think a better system would be nice.  Like being able to write your name on a wait list like most other brunch spots in SF.  I just went to Brenda's last weekend and though we had to wait 45 mins there, we put our name on the wait list, went to Peet's and came back in time.  

Aside from the wait, everything else was awesome.  If you can handle 90 minutes to eat, then def. give Mama's a try.
author: Swetha G.

description:
I know Yelp will be paid to slide this review out of sight, but here goes.

Mama's is to breakfast what House of Nanking is to Chinese food. Over hyped and mostly for the tourists.

This place's wait system is insane. First you stand outside for an hour. Then you get in and stand in line to order at the counter. Then, after you order you wait AGAIN, usually standing over someone else's table while they eat and try to ignore you. Then, after an average of 10-15 minutes you are seated. Yes, you wait twice to be seated.

And the food is just meh. I was here twice and everything with an egg in it is pretty bland and uninteresting. The eggs florentine, spinach scramble, and huevos rancheros were all lacking and needed salt. The potatoes are also not particularly interesting.

The only this I've had that was above average was the french toast, which is made from some unbelievably good banana, cranberry, or cinnamon bread. Good enough to be eaten without syrup. But probably not worth the wait.
author: Mark F.

description:
For a year I was oh so lucky to work across the street from Mama's. I would call in my order and half an hour later just run down and get it. Even with this weekday benefit, I STILL came down on the occasional weekend and stood in the crazy line because the food was that good. 

Many a day, the black beans and a slice of bread made my happy healthy lunch. For breakfast the eggs are beyond divine.

Definitely grab a coffee from teh cafe a couple blocks down before taking your place in the infamous line.
author: Lise L.

description:
The wait is no fun, but I would say the food and overall dining experience make it worth it.  The cashier was extremely friendly and even let me substitute a few things without charging me extra. =) Our server was attentive and our drinks were constantly being refilled without ever having to ask. 

Both the fresh squeezed oj and aj were impressive. I tried the eggs florentine (great if you love veggies) and the dungeness crab benedict (nice twist on a benedict, but I personally like ham better) Mama's has a variety of french toast options to choose from. They serve pretty much serve everything, but your typical french toast. I tried the apple pan dore which is comprised of crispy baguette slices and warm apples in a light butter-lemon sauce. Not too shabby I would say.
author: Irene B.

description:
Dungeness crab eggs benedict was delish.  They used a nice portion of crab (big pieces) and the eggs were done perfectly.  Honey had the farmer's omelette and the quality of goat cheese was creaaaaaamy!  As a side we got the chocolate cinnamon french toast.  Soo yummy, I got chocolate on my sleeve. 

The wait is well,  looooooong, but the weather was pretty, so not too too bad.  

FYI, there's a wait outside and a line inside too.  Once inside though, you can watch the food prep and see the pastries and other baked goods.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
Ugh. 600 reviews. I am just reviewing this for the sake of my own personal eating diary so I remind myself not to come here ever again.

Don't get me wrong, I am willing to wait forever if it is something good, but I just don't see what the hype is with Mamas.

Personally, I think it is more of a tourist trap more than anything.  They really do have a great marketing strategy here- they make you stand in line so you see all the food while waiting outside. Once inside, they parade you next to the food line so you can salivate and over order since you eat with your eyes.

I tried the open faced omelet with smoke salmon, capers, and sour cream drizzle. It was descent but nothing spectacular.

My friend had the prosciutto brie omelet which was quite heavy and rich for breakfast.

I felt that 75% of this place was filled with tourists which personally signifies a red flag to me. 

Don't believe the hype, Mama's is good if there is no wait, but the price and the wait just doesn't justify it as being one of the "greatest breakfast places" around.

Oh, BTW, cash only or debit card for $1 more. bleh. I can't even get my air miles.
author: Joel Y.

description: This place was good, but I don't see what the big hype is all about. My boyfriend and I waited 45 min in that ridiculous line for breakfast. Maybe I was more irritated because I was hungover and starving like hell. I ordered the smoked salmon benedict and my boyfriend had the monte cristo. We also shared the different french toasts (I forgot what it was called) and I just thought the food was A-OK. The service is great, but honestly the food was just ok to me. I might be biast since I was extremely hungover....
author: Jennifer T.

description:
Definitely a MUST for both tourists and locals.  Although, the wait can be excruciating long and the noise level extremely high in the cramped space, it is WELL worth it.  Get there early (they open promptly at 8:00 AM) because THERE WILL BE A LINE!

The food is California fresh and the coffee is classic...mmmmm....to die for Americano.

My favorite the veggie "m'omelette".  If you have a sweet tooth and a penchant for apples, like myself, try the Apple Pan Dore.
author: Hiromi N.

description: When we saw the reviews and photos on yelp, eating here was our first stop when visiting SF.  Seeing the long line outside ( the inside only seats about 20  people) I thought, this is going to be a great spot.  They let people inside and you stand in an order line, and you pay,  Cash or debit ( 1.00 CHARGE )  and everything LOOKED delicious.. but they do say, looks can be deceiving, and boy were they.   I ordered the Northern omelet and it was OK, and the potatoes that I was most excited about, was the most disappointing.  It was blackened and burnt.  I almost felt it wasn't a good day for the Chef.  I was really disappointed with this place and want to give a another shot, but given the long way... I would have to consider another place.
author: Justine R.

description:
We saw this place on the Foodnetwork and decide to try it out on our vacation this year. 

As you pull up, as anywhere in San Fran, you can imagine the parking situation, if you can find one at all. Across the park on the south-side there is a parking garage which is fine, since the limit by the meter is 45 min, which can easily be spent waiting in line to get a seat at Mama's. 

When you finally get in, you order at the counter. Large selection of breakfast stuff to order from, some that may surprise you. I was daring and ordered the crab omelet. Wasn't too bad, but after a while the crabbiness was a little overpowering, but I'm not a seafood person myself. It was done very well, and worth the try. 

My wife ordered some veggie omelet and she said it was awesome. We ended up sitting by the door. This made it either really stuffy inside since it is very cozy, or really cold when they opened the door to let in another guest. 

Overall, the experience was nice. Expect to wait sometime for a seat, but definitely a place to come when in town.
author: Robert D.

description:
5 stars for their Benedict's (those fatty time bombs ARE the bomb) ... incredible french toast.. fluffy pancakes... fresh fruit.

But 2 stars for the line.
author: Nenette Y.

description:
You already have the masses swooning over you, so I'll just leave it at this:  Mama, if you were a real person and not just the name of the freaking best breakfast place I've ever been to, and if you were single, and if I swung that way...I'd marry you...and I'd put out...just so that I could have you cook your french toast or your apple strudel-esque coffee cake or your North Beach omelette for me every single day.  

Be prepared to wait in line, they only take cash, it's small...yada, yada, yada...you've already read it all...
author: Susan L.

description:
This is one of the best brunches in town. Everything here is yummy. They step everything up an indulgence level for full (calorie) taste delight. For example, instead of just banana bread they make banana bread french toast. 

Their monte cristos are so good, they will make you cry. 

The only drawback is that since everyone loves it, the line/wait can be very long so you should try to go on the early side. Also, they only take cash.
author: lindsey l.

description:
Okay. So I've heard nothing but high praises about this joint, and as much as I don't want to give in to the generalized opinion of Mama's.. I REALLY LIKE IT!

It could be because...
1. I live only 4 blocks away! Too bad there's always a line or else I'll be here every morning!
2. The best eggs benedict I've ever had in my LIFE.. The flavors were well balanced and serving sizes were perfect.. I ATE EVERYTHING!.... like a beast. 
3. Cozy small diner brighten up with while paints and the neat home style fixtures!
4. BEST CUSTOMER SERVICE in the area! The waitresses were extremely attentive! you glass of either DELICIOUS coffee will never be half full...
5.Olallieberry!!!! yess.. Olallieberry Jam is the best with their french toast!!
6. and the list goes on!

IF YOU LIVE IN THE BAY AREA or IF YOU'RE VISTING YOU NEED TO TRY THIS PLACE!! 

next friday: MIMOSA'S for my 21st BIRTHDAY!!
author: Alex C.

description: This place is awesome. My friend took me here for my 24th birthday and though there was a line, it was well worth the wait. The way you order is a tad unconventional with going up to a counter and all but who cares when you get great food. the place is cute and the staff is nice. I will for sure come back
author: edward k.

description: Soooo good! I am happy to report that the reviews are not wildly exaggerated. We ate here on a Wednesday morning, arrived at about 9 AM, so the line concern was a non-issue. We waited for about 10 minutes to get in. Once in, we were ushered to the counter to place our order, then we were shown to our table. I have an omelet - Mama's Children's Favorite - which was filled with sauteed mushrooms, green onions, tomatoes and jack cheese. I also had a bloody mary which was the best I have had in quite a while! It was so good and spicy! My friend got Eggs Benedict and a side of sausage, which he also liked a great deal. He said the sausage was really good. The service was super efficient and I thought the prices were really good. I would def come back here. I am not sure I'd wait in line for an hour for breakfast here, as I am sure there a lot of other places I haven't discovered yet in the area, but I would make it a point of trying to eat here again.
author: Tammy S.

description:
French Toast is really the only thing special about this place.   The wait outside was a bit overrated for this place.  I got the dungeness Crab omelet ($18) - and it was Good but not great.  They were skimpy with the ingredients - avocado and brie.  The potatoes were like the ones you would get at any diner.  

My boyfriend got poached eggs with beans and salsa ...and it was also OK.  The french toast sampler was well worth it.
author: Niki D.

description:
Yeah!!! Best brunch place ever! The line is suboptimal but  worth the wait and it is fun to observe the awkward morning after prebrunch chit chat while you stand around getting hungrier. 
The staff is friendly, not bitchy or haggard from doing the morning grind and both brkfst and lunch dishes are tasty.
author: Roxane S.

description:
When I heard about Mama's and how people will wait in line for an hour plus just to get some breakfast, I knew I had to try it. I dragged my fiance out of bed at 730am so we could get ready and head over to Mama's one Friday morning, to try the apparent best breakfast food in the city. We were not disappointed! 

We got there at about 8:30, and were inside by about 9. The interior decorations were adorable... it felt so cozy inside! I had the french toast sampler, and let me tell you, the cranberry-orange and banana-nut french toasts were unbelievable! I did not use one spec of syrup on them for fear of ruining their taste. My fiance had some kind of omelet, which was also amazing. We ate the jam on his toast, and it really is incredible, like everyone says. My fiance is even willing to go back, and he does not usually like breakfast food (I know, I know, I'm marrying him in spite of that).

This was byfar the best breakfast I have had. Even though there is a huge line out the door, we didn't feel pressured to eat quickly and get out--although we did eat pretty quickly. I say it's worth the line outside and I can't wait to go back. 

A couple words to the wise... Be careful going on a weekday, because when we went we were serenaded by construction workers using a jackhammer RIGHT across the street from Mama's. Also, it is very common for one person to stand in line and hold the spot for any number of people (we saw one person hold the spot for about 8 others). It didn't bother me in the slightest, but it could be an annoyance so just FYI, it happens... a lot.
author: Bridgette A.

description:
I Love Mama's, the line is worth the wait. The service is great and OMG the food is delicious. We had the eggs Florentine along with the medallion pancakes. 

Obviously if there is a line to get in it's because Mama's is a special place!
author: G A.

description: If you are in San Francisco, you have to vist.  I HIGHLY recommend the scrambled eggs and crab.  There's a wonderful selection, I kind of made this one up.
author: Stryceelyn J.

description:
SO not worth the hour long wait. Had friends in town so I thought this would be a good place to try out. Not my greatest idea. 

The food is ok, but they don't take credit or debit cards (which is a major pet peeve of mine). I would have given three stars based on the food alone, but my expectations were so high based on all that I had heard about Mama's amazing breakfast food that two stars were deducted for the dissapointment factor alone.
author: Hope A.

description: Good food but I'm not sure if it's worth the wait.  Luckily for me I had friends wait in line first because I'm definitely not the type to wait no matter how good the food is.  Customer service is pretty good and the food is fresh.  Parking is definitely hard to find around there.
author: Jen L.

description:
Alright, so everyone's talked this place to death with superlatives in the papers, the 'net, and via word of mouth.  I was so sick of hearing how great this place was that I drove all the way up to San Francisco to check it out.

Well, really, we were there for other reasons, but the former makes it all the more dramatic, no?

Despite driving in turtle traffic for 45 minutes to arrive there, we managed to snag a decent place in line for nary a 30 minute wait on a Sunday morning.  The queue itself is filled with tourists like ourselves and locals, which in itself is a great sign.  While there are a few line casualties, everyone waits, and we were soon to find out why.

The menu is a decision-making catastrophe.  The omelets are enticing and the traditional french toast and pancakes are anything but normal.  The high-quality ingredients and the simplicity of the recipe combinations could make any breakfast attendant schizophrenic.  After way too many back-and-forths, we decided on the kugelpuph and a pancetta omelet.
