While the dungeness crab benedict looked tantalizing, I figured I'd stick to the beaten path for our first time around.

This place is worth the hype.

My omelet was cooked to perfection and the ingredients did not overpower one another.  The kugelpuph was a delicately eggy brioche that melted on first bite.  It was made all the better by the super-fresh berry garnish and syrup.  What's more is that the carrot cake we ordered had to have been the best and most unique I've ever tasted and I like to think I've had my fair share.

In the end, this restaurant is most definitely in my top 3 breakfast spots of all time.  Any time I'm in the City again, I'm going here.
author: Mark N.

description:
Who knew there was this small hidden restaurant hidden on the corner of Washington Square Park? I didn't. I've been to this area several times, and not once did I ever see that green awning to this little tiny place.

Fortunately, we didn't have to wait in the long line, but our friend did. According to him and his friends, it was an hour wait. We just walked right in to meet them.

I ordered the Vince's chicken sandwich, without even noticing the breakfast menu. Stupid. Always look at everything near the register because they do have a list of other foods there. 

Anyway, the chicken sandwich was small, but I will have to say it was pretty damn good. The thing that I think i regret was when i saw everyone else i was have their breakfast/brunch delivered to them! They looked so good. i tried the Crab something omlette with brie, and oh wow...that was delish. Proportions for the breakfast seem more than enough, while my sandwich was just right.

This review is probably not helpful, but if you like hanging out in North Beach near the park, and are willing to wait in the line to sit for food, then go! It's a great little spot and I wouldn't mind going back there to try the breakfast foods =)
author: J D.

description:
This is my favorite brunch in the city. I've reviewed it before, but I went again, so I feel the need to sing its praises again.  I drag visitors there and force pancakes upon them whenever possible.  I will *gasp* leave the mission and brave the hungovers and the tourists in North Beach and that "save yourself for brunch" hunger for some sweet Mama's love... that's right.  It's that good!

I've said this in another review... but it's all about what you order.  Most good restaurants have several good menu items, but if you miss out on that one signature thing you just don't get hooked.

I am writing this because I was there yesterday and I saw people NOT EATING PANCAKES.  

True, they have the best benedict I have ever eaten... but the pancakes... oh the pancakes... I think they're made with crack.  Please please please, do me a favor and get an order for the table... with the berries.  And use the homemade jam.  Please.
author: Linda L.

description:
Came with my sisters today for some breakfast.  We got here at 10 and the wait was about an hour.  If you want to avoid that come at around 11:30.  I had the Washington Square with tomato, spicy jack cheese and and italian sausage.  My sisters were attacking my omelette.  Meanwhile my sister had the scrambled Florentine with spinach, bacon, onions and cheese, which was somewhat similar to what my other sister had .. the Farmers with leeks, bacon, goat cheese, and spinach.  The Florentine looks like a much smaller portion than the omelettes, but it was tastier than the Farmers, only because I do not like leeks of goat cheese. 

NOTE: This place does not take credit cards.
author: Jen P.

description: Best eggs benedict with prosciutto and tomato.
author: Mindy S.

description: The food is great, i must admit. However, it's very odd how you have to wait in line on the street while looking in the window and staring at people eating. Plus once you sit down you're the ones being stared at and you can feel like you're being rushed, but that won't stop me from coming again.
author: Devon M.

description: We love this place.  It's one of the best places to go for a weekend breakfast.  If you are waiting in line, bring the Sunday paper and hang out.  it really is worth the wait.
author: Lori L.

description:
One of the best breakfast/brunch spots in the city.  First tried Mama's almost a year ago and every time I eaten there since the same has held true: 

1)  They make the best fresh baked coffee cakes ever - hands down
2)  The service is friendly and efficient
3)  Plan on 30 minutes minimum to get a table - but believe me it's well worth it.

If your ideal breakfast includes fluffy omelettes/eggs, perfectly cooked sausage/bacon, a side of home fries, and maybe a short stack buttermilk pancakes - then this is your spot. 

I think I would eat breakfast here at least three times a week if I had no job, time was never of the essence, and I didn't mind a 44" waistline by the end of the year (oh, did I forget to mention - NOT health food).  Until that day, the occasional brunch every few weeks will have to do.

Enjoy!
author: Drew W.

description:
You know how on Entourage, Johnny Drama makes breakfast for the gang every morning, and they love it, well I imagined that this place can kick Drama's ass (a la Chuck Lidell) any day of the week. If Denny's is the Toyota of breakfast foods (solid and affordable), this place is like the Bentlys of breakfast. 

The food is on the pricey side for a breakfast meal, but trust me, you get more than your moneys worth. And once the owner suggested that I try their homemade linginberry jam, and omg, it was like a flavor explosion in my mouth. Not too sweet, and not too smart, it was amazing. You will not be disappointed when you come here.

2 negative aspects are that its friggin tiny as hell, like can literally only seat 20 ppl at a time, max, making the wait absurdly long. Coming early is an absolute must.
author: Robert L.

description:
The best, heartiest, most consistently great tasting American breakfast food in the city.  I heart Mama's. 

What you will find at Mama's:
- Happy servers.
- Hearty center-cut bacon done right.
- Fluffy pancakes.
- Great jam.
- CRAB BENEDICT
- My favorite omelettes (Washington Square has mighty tasty sausage, whilst the Northern Italian harbors equally good pancetta) 
-  A long line ( although if you can drag yourself out of bed at 830AM, then you will be quickly seated and fed )

What you will not find at Mama's:
- Fancy international breakfast dishes with obscure ingredients and hard-to-pronounce names.  If you want that, go to Ella's.
- My friends Serena and Angela who must have lost their taste buds in some tragic hot cocoa accident

One final note:
I almost didn't write this review, because if I encourage more people go to Mama's, then I'll have to wait longer in line.  But i ultimately figured what's one more rave review on top of the hundreds already on here.
author: Bradley T.

description:
So I was that guy--standing in the huge line for brunch on Saturday morning at 10am. Were we waiting for iPhones? Free methadone? WalMart to open the day after thanksgiving? No. Eggs and toast.

The system is structured very poorly. You wait outside. You wait inside. You wait at your table. (unless you're a group of 2...) This was quite painful. Eating breakfast at noon is painful on its own.

Once I had food in front of me, it was great. I would argue most anything would taste great after waiting two hours--but that seems to be the name of the game here.

I couldn't discern if they had any specialties--the menu seemed pretty standard, but the basics were done really well. 

So overall, If i could skip the line somehow, I'd be happy to go back.
I guess my main qualm is with the concept of waiting two hours for breakfast without there being anything discernibly inventive or exquisite at the end of the tunnel.
author: Eli A.

description:
On our third attempt, we succeeded and got in to have breakfast at Mama's with no waiting in line. You see, the lines are horrendous on the weekends and I'm not willing to wait more than two hours for food, but was obsessed with trying the place. 

The key is to get there at 7:30 a.m. and stake yourself in front right when it opens at 8. To our surprise, there was a small line that had already formed at 7:30. 

I have to say, I don't really get what all the hype is about. I mean, I know it's a SF institution and all, but why is the line snaked around the block with throngs of people patiently waiting for nothing extraordinary? 
 
The bread selection was fabulous and the French toast sampler was definitely tasty, but my smoked salmon eggs benedict had a hard yolk, which is a pet peeve of mine. Proper benedicts are meant to have a runny yolk and a place like Mama's that turns out thousands a week should know how to get it right. So I did what I am not fully comfortable doing, and sent it back. The waitress was very apologetic and accommodating, which made me feel better. 

Will I brave the lines again or show up at 7:30 on a Saturday morning again? Probably not. I came, I conquered the line and I'm ok with not going back.
author: Lee H.

description: Long cue to get in. Mmm, Food is yummy. Nicest breakfast/brunch in the area.
author: Àngel B.

description:
don't come here if you are super hungry unless you are ok w/ waiting an hour.  otherwise, come well ahead of when you THINK you will be hungry.  even on a wet dreary sunday, we waited about an hour before we got inside, and it was another 20 min or so after we got in, ordered, and got seated.  however, the food is pretty good.

4 of us split the dungeness crab omelet w/ avocado and brie, the dungeness crab benedict w/ spinach, the italian omelet w/ pancetta, and the french toast sampler.  it was a lot of food, but we managed to finish all of it.  the portions are pretty hefty, and the omelets come w/ baguette.  be sure to try the jam on the table w/ your toast.  yum.
author: Helen T.

description:
While I don't think I'd wait over 30 mins to eat here, it IS pretty delicious. When you wake up on the weekends, starving (and possibly hungover), who has the patience to stand, peering in through the windows at everyone else's yummy plates of food? 

Not me. 

However, if you do wait, it's a tasty breakfast. I had a fantastic benedict here (although I am not a purist and generally don't get hollandaise - blasphemy, I know, but sometimes restaurant hollandaise scares me). The sweet breakfast items looked equally awesome but I'm more of a savory gal in the AM. 

I'm looking forward to going back and trying some more nummy brunch dishes...
author: Alli J.

description:
ok this place has great brunch!!  I agree with everyone else - i had M'Omelette (washington square) - it was great - large, tasty...a little pricy for its money coz eggs r not worth much...but it was good overall

i also had a special of the day, mango smoothie...i think it was either 6.95 or 5.95...not worth it.  it tasted like mango but mostly ice...so definitely not worth the money.  plus this super icey drink really didn't go well with greasy food like omelette.

I wish i could give 5 star for the food and 2 star for the waiting...but i guess i'm giving 2 star here coz I won't go back.  Its definitely not worth the 3-hour waiting for me. our group got there around 11am ish and didn't get food in front of us until at least 2pm.  waiting outside was long and difficult, under the sun, with no seats, water and hungry.  then once we got inside, there was another long waiting line for us to be seated.  therefore it was not worth it for me.

i don't know what they can do...maybe take reservations but the restaurant staff seemed to think the waiting was their thing and we should just cope with it.  therefore i'm not going back...unfortunately...sad but true
author: XYZ Q.

description:
Bad News: You have to wait in line for an hour to eat. 

Good News: Best Breakfast on the planet.

Strawberry Pancakes, Greek Omelettes, Monte Cristo. Hot holy mother of God and everything sacred.
author: Danny D.

description:
My former boss recommended this place, so for the longest time I wanted to go but never found the time. My wife and I got married in San Francisco, so i figured the morning after the wedding would be a perfect day to go.

The lines are super long(especially during the weekend) but if you you in a group and buy yourself a coffee to wait in line, believe me, time will fly. There is so much to pick!! when I got there I couldn't decide.

My wife and I were seated and greeted very nicely. The people there are friendly and the food is amazing....delicious, fresh, and delicious. 

So if you wanna enjoy an awesome breakfast nook with awesome food, this is the spot however, it is rather pricey.
author: Jonathan C.

description: Probably my favorite breakfast in SF.  Although everything is decent enough, the main attraction is the Monte Cristo.  A unique version unlike any I've had elsewhere.  Who would've thought sugar and blackberry jam would go so well with ham, turkey and mayo?  It does though.  The French toast sampler ain't to shabby but you can get that anywhere. A nice little place in a picturesque hood.  Walk here if it's feasible.  Prepare for a 1-1.5 hr wait.
author: Chewbaka D.

description:
the line gets pretty long but worth the wait.

you have to order in line then find a seat. 

best breakfast place in the city.
author: Carol Y.

description:
ABSOLUTELY WORTH THE WAIT! I came up here for Christmas weekend with my girlfriend and her family. She found mamas through yelp and the rest is history. We waited an hour and a half for one of the best breakfast I've ever had. Pancakes were delicious and covered with blueberries, rasberries, and strawberries. Word of advice, lose the syrup and use their homemade jam. Unbelievably good.

Had some of my girlfriends Swedish French toast which was very good and also great with the jam. The shrimp Benedict was very delicious.

If you want to take home a jar of jam, you have to call it in a week in advance.

This will definitely be my favorite SF spot for years to come!

Go there and wait for an out of this world breakfast!-
author: Jordan G.

description:
This place is awwwwesome! I've been here a handful of times and every time it's because my college friends come to visit.  The wait can be rather long, but with good company, it goes by somewhat quickly. 

I came here yesterday with friends and lucky for me, I am always late and happened to get there right when they were at the front of the line.  Yay me! This is what we got:

French Toast Sampler
I didn't personally get to try this, but it looked delicious, chock full of fresh fruits with 4 different types of bread. 

Monte Cristo x 2
This was simply amazing. I must say when my friend said she was going to order it...I was a bit hesitant of how it would taste, but my god! I was WOW! It's soo good. It's a ham and cheese sandwich dipped in what I believe to be French toast batter, so it was a perfect balance of sweet and salty. There were 4 wedges, but they were simply amazing. I sampled 1 wedge from my friend, but I was raving about it all day.

Northern Italian Omelette
The omelette was really good. It was stuffed with mushrooms, Italian bacon (I forget the name of it), bell peppers, tomatoes, and just a bunch of stuff.  It was really good.

The staff is very attentive and service is good. You order your food, get your table, eat, leave your tip, and leave as a satisfied individual for the rest of the day.  The food comes out very picturesque. Definitely worth a try. Maybe go on a weekday when the wait is not as long. :P
author: Dolores L.

description:
Heavenly.

Seriously. I hope that a breakfast eatery as special as Mama's is on every street corner in heaven- right next to a Costco hot dog stand. I'm a simple girl :o)

The breakfast at Mama's is worth the oftentimes 1-hour+ wait. If you're fortunate enough to have yourself an easy breezy Sunday with no planned agenda in view, visit Mama's and allot yourself 2 hours for the entire experience. Chat with friends whilst waiting in line outside, bring a newspaper, answer work emails- whatever you want cuz you're GONNA wait. There is NO escaping it (unless you arrive at 2pm, then it's a slightly more decent wait time of 30-45mins). 

Mama's makes their  omelettes with only uber-fresh ingredients. I ordered the California omelette, and let me just say that they spared no expense. Oodles of avocado slices piled in just as it should be. 

Their french toasts are the fluffiest on earth. Their pancakes equally divine.. On my second visit to Mama's, I ordered the chocolate-drizzled french toast loaded with blueberries, raspberries, and strawberries. As the plate was set in front of me, for a moment I felt like a princess. Like the entire masterful concoction was made just for me. Sigh~* The experience was nothing short of utopian. People say that babies are gifts from heaven, but I secretly would have no objection if someone were to add brunch to that list of miracles.

Can't wait to go back for more. Mmm...
author: Elaine T.

description:
My favorite item here is the Northern Italian omelette.  The taste of the pancetta is really brought out in the eggs.  The omelette's super flavorful and loaded with ingredients, I couldn't stop eating it off of my SO's plate.  I've also tried the famed Monte Cristo here.  It's yummy and the homemade jam is delicious, but I find it a bit too greasy and filling for my late morning appetite.

I love the little cottage-like decor inside.  The service is great too, particularly, by a server named Betty T. :)  However, it just pains me to have to wait for food when I'm already hungry.  Coming to Mama's requires a plan, which consists of finding a treasured parking spot in North Beach, getting a spot in line, waiting in the sometimes cold weather for that warm "hello" that allows you to enter the restaurant, ordering your food, and hungrily waiting for the food to arrive.  And frankly, when I'm hungry and wanting to break my fast, I don't want to go through all of that.  But if someone were to ask me for a breakfast recommendation in the city, Mama's would be at the top of my list.
author: Diane L.

description:
Best breakfast I've had so far! The line is a bit of a wait, but its well worth it. I had the omelet with pancetta, jack cheese, and mushrooms with a toasted sourdough bagette. 

Only down sides are the long wait, and that it's CASH only. Otherwise, a great place to head for breakfast if you're not in a rush.
author: Christina K.

description:
I really can't find myself giving more than 2 stars to Mama's.  The last time I went, my bf found a big shard of PLASTIC in his omelette.  We told the server, and he didn't even seem sorry.  We didn't get comped or get a free juice or coffee - NOTHING.  They just took the plate back, and I'm betting they just took the shard out before promptly returning to my bf the same exact plate.

The food here is nothing to write home about, so I'll write my two-star review on Yelp.  It's a very basic breakfast/brunch/lunch place that attracts a huge crowd solely because it's an institution in SF.  You'll almost certainly have to wait in a long line.  I have waited for as long as an hour and a half to eat here.  I don't see what the fuss is about.  I've had the "Momelette" which is a basic omelette, among other bland omelettes on the menu.  I've also had the pancakes which are also not spectacular.  Same goes for the French toast.  If I'm going to be waiting over half an hour to eat, it's got to be amazing.

I was not and am not amazed by Mama's.  Save yourself the time and go to Mo's Grill instead.

If you choose to disregard my advice and do end up going here, be aware that once you actually get inside the restaurant after your hour-plus wait, you have to continue to stand in line until you reach the cashier.  Then you finally get to place your order, find a table, and then have your food brought to you.  It's really inefficient.
author: Kira K.

description:
love, LOVE this place! one of the best breakfast place in SF. it is worth lining up for. i usually come here early so i don't have to wait in line for that long. it's worth waking up early to get breakfast here. 

their egg benedict is soo goood, its cooked perfectly and the hollandaise sauce taste fresh, they serve freshly baked pastry, the fruits are fresh, orange juice is freshly squeezed, what can get better than that. food is flavorful, portion is a bit large, so make sure your hungry when you eat here. the food will fill you up, you'll probably won't be eating until dinner.

i like how you have to order your food first before you get a seat, which i think makes it faster to serve the food, and service here is good. this place is my fave spot for breakfast, worth the wait in the line! make sure to go early, at least 30 mns before they open or an hr early before they open if you don't wanna wait in line.
author: Toni Rose M.

description:
The food is good, don't get me wrong, but it's not worth the wait. Seriously, how long do you want to stand in line for eggs and bacon?  If you say over an hour, then sure, go for it. But you can get equal quality food in the area without the lines. You have to wait 3 different times before getting seated. The first time while outside, the second while inside to order, and the third wait is for a table after ordering. 

We had the Northwest omelet (lox) and eggs florentine. Both were decent. If you like bloody mary's, then they have a pretty good mary. The ruby red mimosa is tasty as well. Overall, either come here very early or very late to avoid the crowd if you don't want to wait.
author: Jun W.

description:
Monte Cristo with homemade jam. That's all you need to order. The jam was so good, I could eat it by itself...

Tip: Get in line on the weekends around 2:15 p.m. The line is totally shorter and you won't have to wait for an hour+.
author: Adrienne C.

description:
30 min standing outside in line + 15 min standing inside in line + decent but not great food = disappointing.

Chocolate french toast (3.75 stars) - looked incredible covered with berries, bananas, and drizzled chocolate. Tasted good like a dessert and breakfast mixed in one but not incredible.

Rancheros poached eggs over beans and salsa (2 stars) - perhaps my fault for ordering this one given all the other awesome sounding omlettes and scrambles. But I was in a Mexican mood and this sounded interesting. What I got was 2 ordinary poached eggs on top of a bed of ordinary black beans and a sparse amount of lame salsa. The home fries were good though.

Bottom line: Cute place, but not worthy of the 4.5 stars on Yelp and not worth the incredibly long wait. If I didn't have to wait long, I'd come back for another try.
author: Jim C.

description:
Little over an hour wait but the food was mostly meh.

Dungeness Crab Benedict wasn't so flavorful and the potatoes that came with the dish were not as crispy as I would have liked.

The gf got the Salmon Benedict which was decent at most. She felt the poached eggs werent that great.

Better off trying Zazie over at Carl and Cole....
author: song c.

description: MIND BLOWING VEGETARIAN EGGS BENEDICT. Well worth the wait!
author: Rozelle D.

description:
big line. no shade in big line. HANGOVER. ouch. 

great food!  quick, friendly service.  BIG portions. Share.
Crab omlet is riiiiiiiiich and filled to the brim with fresh cracked crab. Only one shell piece.
Orange Juice is amazing. 

Hangover cured!  

Yay Mama!
author: Jenni D.

description:
Part of me wants to give this place 3 stars, because I truly think it's overrated.  Then again, that's just mean, and not neccessary.  It's very cute, and yes, you'd better be ready to stand around, because it will be a while.  The food is 4-stars, and the service is 4 stars.  Very solid food, interesting mixes of flavors, and the coffee cup never goes empty.  Also, it's cash only, so keep that in mind.  However, is an hour long wait really worth this?  It's a little steep for breakfast, so again, is it worth it?  I had omlette, which, had excellent fillings, but the eggs were a little too firm, and it wasn't really fluffy.  That to me would make it a 5 star omlette.  Also, it looses points for it's bathroom, which I think may actually be a health hazzard to anyone nursing a hangover.  

I admit, their coffee cake was excellent, and their preserves were excellent too.  Imagine that you're making killer blueberry muffins at home.  Now, imagine that you have to run out of the house for an emergency, so you pull them out of the oven with about 1/3 of your time before they're done, hoping that it will continue to cook...and they don't. What you have is a gooey, blueberry madness, which is soo tasty!  That's their coffee cake. I'm still partial to Hobee's, but I'm a south bay girl at heart.
author: Erin O.

description:
This is the best place in SF for Breakfast.
Bad things... parking, the long wait, it's only open for breakfast and closed on Monday (I think.).
But seriously... I've never had a better breakfast in CA. I love this place. When you go to meet your friends there... take turns waiting on line. One time you get there 1/2 an hour early.. next time they do...
It works out. It's worth it.
author: Theresa N.

description:
It took me a looooong while to make my way over to Mama's.  I spent eighteen months believing that the line around the block was all tourist-generated hype, but I was gravely mistaken.  It took a good friend who was in town this weekend to change my view for good, and I am REALLY glad I came around.

If you don't want to be disappointed, you must order the Monte Cristo, which is OUT OF THIS WORLD.  Quite possibly the one thing I'll keep coming back for again and again.  Mama's, you freakin' got me!
author: Andrea U.

description:
Oh my! 
Talk about a unbelievable breakfast experience. I thought it was kind of weird to wait in line order then be seated but it worked out fine plus paying for you meal in advance was cool too. 

Mama's has a nice cozy bed and breakfast feel to the place with great natural lighting. 

Let me tell you about the breakfast me and friend had. Light Buttermilk pancakes were the best and very filling. I had a side of scrambled and eggs and potatoes but I couldn't even get into them because the pancakes took up all the room in my tummy but that did not stop me from tasting everything on the table. I like my eggs cook hard with a slight golden tint to with with spinach(yummy) and you can't go wrong with country friend potatoes. 

My friend had the egg white omelette's with a chicken sausage and it was nice and spicy; cooked to perfection. Although we did add some extra hot sauce.  Oh I almost forget the home made jam that like a boysenberry or something but it was tasty on pancakes and toast .  

This place is great for one of those late Friday or Saturday nights with breakfast in the morning kind of things.  I can't say if Mama's will cure a hang over but you will walk away maybe stumble away full and satisfied.
author: Karim R.

description:
Here's a haiku I wrote about Mama's:

Look at that long line
Food must be good is it so
No it's not don't go
author: Luke F.

description:
After reading about the forever long lines on  the weekends, I came here on a quiet Thurs morning for breakfast. I must say, these yelpers know good breakfast!My omelette was stuffed with sausages, tomatoes, cheese, spinach. Mama sure don't scant on the ingredients! Breakfast for 2 was about $40.. which was kinda on the pricey side... compared to your usual IHOP or DENNY'S. But after trying this place out, you can definitely see why and it's worth every penny.WILL BE BACK!!! 
P.S MUST TRY DOLLAR PANCAKES!!!!!!
author: Lisa M.

description: Everyone should try Mama's at least once- even though we were questioning why we should wait in line for nearly an hour (on a weekday, no less) I was so satisfied with the pancakes that I ordered.  We also split the French toast sampler, and coming from someone who is not a big fan, I thought their banana-nut and cinnamon French toast was amazing.  Both the pancakes and French toast were so light and great energizers for the rest of our day.  I suggest going to Mama's in the afternoon, around noon, to grab a late breakfast or lunch to avoid the crowds, but Mama's is by far the best breakfast you can find in the city!
author: Shannon W.

description:
You know, I was hungry when I arrived in San Francisco last Friday.  I asked the lobby man in the hotel where I could find a fabulous breakfast.  He told me of a place he goes to all the time, but since he just walks and never looks or thinks, he couldn't remember the name of the place, I've done it myself so am not surprised.  So he went online and said "oh wait, there's Mama's on Washington Square.  It's a San Fran hot spot and staple of a place, you oughta try there."   He told me if I go, he wanted a critique since he said he lives literally around the block from the place but hasn't ever considered it because he said he hates lines.

Done deal I thought, if it's a place that continually has a line out the door, that's gotta be a good thing.

Walked the [several blocks] walk the next morning at 9.  Found the place by the vision of the line out the door.  I stood there until I was asked in, then waited another several minutes to be seated all in all, 49 minutes.

The menu is daunting because I have a love for Eggs Benedict but then saw everything else and thought oh oh.  I settled on the EB and was brought a delicious meal.  I hate to admit, this small woman ate every delectable bite.

The place is adorable, cheery, welcoming and inviting.  I'd gladly go again and again and will.

To the lobby man at the hotel, I told him a huge thumbs up and also told him to bow to the line, it's well worth it [just one time].  :)

A+
author: Gian G.

description:
It was a nice day out so we decided to take the trolley which is a block out from Mama's. It was a nice way to roll out for breakfast. 

We arrived with a party of 4 at around 9am on a Thursday. This must be a good thing as we hit it perfectly and walked right in to order and take a seat. We had no waiting time at all.The place is warm and cozy but the food is amazingly delicious. From the french toast sampler which went in the middle with fresh fruit for 4 of us to share. The benedict with prociutto, omelettes were very good and ther service was excellent.  

We will be back to SF during Christmas and will be at Mamas for breakfast !!
author: Keola U.

description:
Definitely a solid and very yummy breakfast spot in the city but the wait is ridiculous (worse than Dotties!) and Im not totally sure it's worth it. Even when Im there at an early hour, there is still a wait... Just because it's a good "Mom & Pop" place doesn't mean it's automatically worth a wait. 

That said, I really do like it. Breakfasts are always hot, filling and it is pretty unique. Their monte christo is absolutely excellent.

I do think it's just a tiny, tiny bit overrated and definitely don't attempt this if you're ready to die of hunger! You may die waiting!
author: Anita B.

description:
Yes, the line is insanely long, but have you ever seen a brunch place worth its salt (or maple syrup, as it were) that didn't have a throng of hungry people orderly standing outside?  And besides, you are in one of the prettiest spots in SF, a few feet away from a pretty park (if you're really stressed about the wait, go do tai-chi with the seniors on the lawn) and all those crazy streets @ 45-degree angles that you only find here.  

I had some insanely good cranberry french toast--I'm a cranberry phene, so I couldn't get enough of that sweettart combo...it's been a while since I visited, so I don't remember what else I had, but I do remember my visit being a great start to a lovely Sunday afternoon.
author: Chris R.

description:
Mmmmm Mmmmmm Mmmmm!

The only way to describe a little slice of heaven on a sunny San Francisco morning. I've been to this cozy little joint a few times now and have been sweetly surprised and satisfied both times. 

The food is delish! - from the rich signature crab and avocado filled omelets and benedicts, their scrumptious french toast selections, to the  savory salads...Everything I have ordered, and tasted from the plates of my friends, have been better than great. Oh, and that coffee cake - oh man, is that fine! Get a piece to go, and make it a sweet snack later. 

The absolute worst part of this delightful place is the wait. Don't plan to go on a Saturday or Sunday unless you are in the mood to wait a good hour+. ( And don't think if you go at 2pm that you'll miss the brunch crowds, everyone else is thinking the same thing...)
author: Erin M.

description:
Hands-down the best breakfast in the city. I'm tempted to say the best breakfast place ever but out of fear of being presumptious, I'll just keep it at that. I used to live a block away and didn't even end up trying Mama's until I moved away because the long lines used to scare me away.  I'm here to tell you that it is well worth the wait. I haven't had any of the sandwiches so I can't vouch for those but try any of the omlettes, pancakes, french toast...basically anything on the breakfast menu and your tummy will thank you and so will your tastebuds. 

I took my sister here when she was visiting from out-of-town and after all the hype and the nearly 45 minute wait she said, "it was just as good as i imagined." how often does that happen?  

Can't say enough good things about Mama's!
author: Esther J.

description:
Who would've thought Dungeness Crab in an omellete would be so good?  The combination of the crab and brie really did the trick! 

I had my heart set on trying the Salmon Benedict, too! I guess that will have to wait till next time! 

The Lemon-Blueberry French Toast was really good, also! It was better than the French Toast Sampler that we tried last time. 

Always a treat!
author: Becka T.

description:
The line is long. The brunch is great. The homemade jam is delicious. 

If you do not want to wait in a line for an hour, then show up early - 8am early. If sleeping in is a priority for you, the be prepared to wait for quite some time. Mama's is really small, so please don't take a big group of people, there are only two tables that accommodate more than 4 people. 

Once you cross Mama's threshold, you will witness the wonderful open kitchen. You eyes will widen as you see plate fulls of fresh salmon, shrimp, and crab. The corners of your mouth will turn up in an involuntary smile as you see the heaping bowls of fresh raspberries, strawberries, blueberries, and melon. Finally the intoxicating aroma of freshly baked, still warm from the oven coffee cakes will knock you on your butt. Then suddenly you realize it is your turn to order, and despite the fact you have been waiting in line for over an hour - you have no idea what you want to order. You thought you wanted eggs, but now you see all the coffee cake and you feel conflicted. The endless list of french toast was appealing, but you just saw one of the short order cooks put an entire fist full of crab in one of the scrambles. 

Bottom line, you cannot order wrong here. All the items are prepared with care and made with fresh ingredients. The pancakes are impossibly fluffy, the french toast melts in your mouth (the half stick of butter might have something to do with that), and the eggs are filled with delicious fresh goodies. Make sure to use the homemade jam in your toast, and do your entire party a favor and order a couple pieces of coffee cake for the entire table to share - no one will complain after they taste it. Well worth the wait on special occasions and deservedly a SF institution.
author: Dana H.

description:
first time here and it was only a 20 minute wait. score! its definitely a good idea to check this place out for brunch on a weekday if you can. i totally understand the hype for this little joint. there's no sign up sheet you just take a spot in line and wait patiently.

they had a bunch of specials...a lot of them involving dungeness crab. holla!! i was all over the dungeness crab benedict...i messed that ish up! =) it was soooooo good. the crab was perfectly flavored and had a hint of lemon to it. they also piled it on. exactly what i expect if i'm paying $20 for breakfast. i also like that they don't fill half of the plate with potatoes, just enough to satisfy your appetite. my friend and i also shared the french toast sampler...that was definitely the way to go because we got to try a little of everything. totally legit. get it.

service was great. how they know where you're sitting to bring you your food is beyond me but it works. i'll be back!
author: Linda N.

description: The food was ok, the bloody mary awful and the line on a weekday at 11am : an hour! This place is better than your average brunch jount, but nothing special enough to justify the wait. Its a tourist trap and I git trapped :(
author: Sandra S.

description:
I looove Mama's. First went here with a friend when I was visiting the bay. I had the French toast platter that I thought was good, but nothing special. My friend had smoked salmon egg benedict, and I just fell in love at the first bite. The yolk and the sauce melted in my mouth, it's heavenly gooooood.

Second time I went with my boyfriend. He ordered monte cristo, its super yummy too. I had, yes, egg benedict (I cant get enough!) Well just one thing, their portion is HUGE, so it's better to share. Cause you might get sick of your food if you try to nom it all by yourself. 

And also, the line can be overwhelming, but it's worth the wait!
author: Sendy K.

description:
Probably the BEST breakfast joint in S.F.!  I have been there about 4 times now, and I've never been disappointed!  They're pancakes are light, fluffy, and yummy!  (and I don't even like pancakes!)  Their Crab Benedict, which has generous portions of real crab, is excellent!  (not on the regular menu, but part of their specials)  They also bake fresh carrot cake, coffee crumb cake,  and muffins- tasty!  A few tips:

-Go early, otherwise you may have to wait 45 min to 1 hour
-Bring cash as they don't take cc
-Portions are on the generous side so if you are not super hungry, you may want to split

Happy eating!
author: Kristine Y.

description:
Absolutely fantastic!!!!

This place has all the character of a great  city eatery.  Ridiculous line to get in, no-frills streamlined ordering system (a la Soup Nazi in Seinfeld) but fantastic eats.

I ordered the Crab Omelet with avocado and brie.  Perfect choice, considering we arrived at 11:15 but by the time we were able to order, it was nearly 1 o'clock in the afternoon.  Next time I'll try the Monte Cristo I think, which looked very tempting...

This isn't a place you go for the impeccable service, or atmosphere.  It's a cute place, in a fun location with great food.  That's it.
author: Myles K.

description:
If you haven't noticed by now, I can be a *bit* of a BRAT sometimes.  I'm generally a cranky person and if I am annoyed you will probably see a little of what my Mom likes to call "The BEAR".  It's where I get so annoyed that I practically growl/bite the head off of anyone that happens to be the subject of my wrath.

A few things that will ensure the appearance of The BEAR: waiting in line, getting up early, not enough sleep, and no coffee.  So, I guess it wasn't a great idea for my friend to introduce me to Mama's one fine morning this weekend when ALL of these elements were in place.

So yeah, while I glowered and growled my way in line at the butt-crack of dawn, I am pleased to report that I have found The ANTI-BEAR:  Mama's.

As soon as I got my soy latte, and took a bite of the most scrumptious, fluffy pancakes known to man--The Bear was tamed.  And OMG, to whomever invented the Monte Cristo--bless you.  I had some of my friend's and it was PERFECTION.  It was everything good about breakfast wrapped up in one glorious, mega-calorie package.  

FEW things in life and in San Francisco are worth the wait--Mama's is one of them.
author: MakeUp M.

description:
I tried this place out on a Tuesday, and although the line wasn't ridiculously long (I'd say about 20 people in front of us), it still took 30 minutes to get a table.   What made it worse was that when you finally set foot in the building, you had to wait in a second line to order food and be seated.  That was torture, seeing all the yummy food being prepared in front of you while your mouth drools and your tummy growls.

I went with the Monte Cristo sandwich and it was a savory, salty, cheesy, and yet slightly sweet amalgam of flavor.  It came with a side of homemade jam that was pretty tasty to dunk the sandwich in.  =)

I tried a small piece of Apple Crumb cake that they had warmed up before bringing out to the table and that was delicious as well.

I also had a small sampling of the Northern Italian "Mom'lette" that my mom ordered and it was fantastic.  Pancetta, mushroom, fresh basil, tomato and garlic jack cheese.  I would definitely try an omlette the next time I go there.

But dammit, the wait...that's what would make me think twice about going back soon.  In the time it takes me to drive to SF, find parking, stand in line, order, eat, and leave, I could have gone to Nini's in Burlingame which is 5 minutes from my house, had food that is just as good, returned home and gotten a 1 hour post-brunch nap in.

Keep in mind I went on Tuesday, which I figured would be an "off day". I can't imagine what the wait must be like on a Saturday or Sunday.
author: Wade Y.

description:
Yes it's a great breakfast in one of my favorite neighborhoods, but at this point I'm over the whole wait-in-line-for-an-hour thing.  I love breakfast and I love Mama's, but I don't love the tourists who don't know how it's done.  You wait outside, then you wait inside, then you order, then you pay, then you sit down, then they bring you breakfast, then you eat.  There.  Not too hard right?
Love the pancakes and french toast and all of the breads/pastries--absolutely delicious.  Worth it to go, especially if you've never been or if you want a special treat.  But for a relaxing Sunday breakfast I have other city favorites that don't require quite the effort.
author: M. C.

description:
Chicago Yelper here...I know good brunch when I see it, and I saw it at Mama's this morning.

I was introduced to Mama's by a local, and, yes, the line is worth it. The service and the food was great! I had the cinnamon french toast and he had the Slim Joe sandwich. Both were served hot, with his having these amazing grilled potatoes. We shared a slice of carrot cake and a slice of the sour cream cake (yes, everyone shares extra plates here).

So do yourself a favor and stand in line. It moves pretty quickly, and you will be happy you did. And GO WITH A BIG APPETITE!
author: Mary d.

description:
Note: I can't actually understand why everyone is complaining about the line - you all are aware it will have one, and if you don't want to wait, don't. There's a reason for the line. And no one forces anyone to stay and wait. Silly people...

As my neighborhood brunch place, I am never let down. Of course the line is out of control- but what do you expect when the food is so damned tasty and pretty?! My friends and I like to consider line-time as time to chat, catch up, and enjoy soaking up some Sunday morning rays. 

My favorite when it's a special is the Crab Benedict- it's just fantastic! I order it on their Sourdough baguette rather than an English muffin as I'm partial to a baguette-- and I get the sauce on the side. Neither of these specifications annoy them and both are plated up with a smile-- and I enjoy that. As Sally says "I just like it the way I like it." I appreciate that they're willing to serve it to-order for a loyal customer (and I'm sure for a newbie as well).

Delish! Worth the wait- know you're going to wait if it's not a week day and grab coffee somewhere in NB to enjoy in line.
author: Diane S.

description:
This place is my favorite big time for breakfast. You'll find the best Montecristo sandwich and eggs Benedict in the City.
If you live in San Francisco try to go on week days cause weekends the line is too much.
Cyrus is the best!
author: Sergio D.

description:
Stopped here for breakfast after reading all of the rave reviews. The food was good but I don't think it's worth more than about a 30 minute wait. Another item to consider is if you have a car, parking can be tricky and you need to be ready to feed the metter while you wait. I think we waitied outside about 20 minutes or so.The outside then inside line is pretty slick,like waiting in line at an amusement park, just when you think you've made it there's another line. The service was good, friendly and fast. We did have the rare opportunity of seeing a kitchen fire, I considered it  a floor show. So they had to shut down the stove and we waited a while. In an effort to get food to customers I don't think they cooked the potatoes fully but otherwise the food was good. I had the mini-pancakes and they were delicious. 
Since there are so many restaurants in SF I doubt we'd eat here again simply because there are so many more out here.
author: Tony H.

description:
Is this place worth the wait? Probly...

I come here every once in awhile to get an eggs benny or some french toast. It's small, so chances are you will wait over an hour before getting seated unless you're in the first or second wave of people in line. I take visitors here and they always approve. 

All the food is great. Everything on the menu is tasty and doesnt taste like anything else on the menu. All their breakfast breads/cakes behind the glass are definitely good too. The OJ is delicious and tastes freshly squeezed. It's a bit pricey so you might as well upgrade to a mimosa. 

The people are always really friendly. It's clean and charming and consistent. They could easily charge a dollar or two more and people would still come. 

A quick warning though, their bathroom is through the kitchen and in the back...kinda outhouse-ish. It's really small, I imagine tall or wide people will have trouble sitting...that is if they need to sit...maybe to drop a duece or something.

Enjoy!
author: JeF m.

description: I am not a morning person but Mama's is the type of restaurant that makes me wake up. I also don't like waiting in line but waiting for a huge avocado and bacon ommelette with a toasted baguette with homemade jam is worth it. Everything is fresh and made from scratch. They're juice is also freshly squeezed and they have the best apple juice ever!!! Whenever you're in the bay area and want good breakfast, Mama's is the place to check out.
author: Evelyn V.

description:
BEST ! 

I got Washington Square Omlette ..GREAT! spicy.

Home made jam.

Try if you have 3 hr. that  morning.(wait 1.5hr. at curb,0.5 hr. for food

and 1 hr.for eat&talk)...come back for sure.
author: nilav R.

description:
It's all about their croque monsieur! served "French toast style" cute plating and some warm compote for dipping! 

With 300 plus reviews already penned I don't think I can do further justice with my amiable word-smiting but the casual atmosphere, fresh ingredient bar (where you can watch the cook prepare), and quirky staff ensure that Mama's deserves every star!

Also they have "Money Trees" on the table where you should leave your tip nested in the branches....I guess money really does grow on trees ;-)
author: Christopher S.

description:
I don't really think that this place needs another review talking about how awesome the food is.  With over 300 reviews and growing, if you aren't convinced that the food is awesome then you should perhaps keep eating at Denny's.  That said, if you want to eat here on a weekend then you will have to wait...and wait...and wait some more, unless you go really early.  

Advice, bring cash cause that's the only way you are going to be able to pay.
author: Katie O.

description:
It pains me to write this review, because every other time I've gone to Mama's I've left happy and would have given them five stars. I usually LOVE this place. This time I left grumpy and unsatisfied.

The food deserves five stars, but you know what? It's just not worth the wait. I've always gone on a weekend before, and I expected long lines because most of the great brunch places in San Francisco have long lines on the weekends. But on a Thursday?? We waited longer than we have ever had to wait before, more than an hour and a half from the time we got in line to the time we were finally served. When the food finally came, there were too few berries on the pancakes, too few potatoes with the eggs, and half of the potatoes were crunchy because they were either way overcooked or still nearly raw. Even if it had been perfect, by that time my blood sugar was too low for me to care.

We realized that the reason Mama's is busy even on weekdays is NOT because it's so much better than any other place, but because it's in all the stupid tourist books, so all the stupid tourists who want to be near Coit Tower, Fisherman's Wharf, etc. clog up the lines. I think we were the only locals there.
author: Jen R.

description:
I came here about 6 years ago with Lisa and loved it a lot.  So when I was visiting this weekend, I luckily found this place again and it was amazing despite the long (_x_) wait.

If I ever move here, I am coming here every weekend for brunch!!!!
author: Ernie K.

description:
worth the almost 2 hour wait. yes. 

just alone. for some of that fresh peach jam. *Drool* i wish i could have stowed a container in my purse.. but can't do that to mama. 

anything you order will be good. our group of 8 ordered a variety of what they had to offer. and we all approved.

wait staff. so accommodating and pleasant. 

side note: check out the insanely tiny bathroom in the back. felt like it was created by the amish.
author: lilmissalice d.

description: I went to Mama's in Washington Square last month with my friends. The restaurant's American country atmosphere was cute both inside and outside. We had to wait for over 30 minutes because it is very popular and there is a long wait outside and long line inside to get seated everyday. At first we we're tired for waiting, but the waiters and waitresses were very kind and friendly, which quickly relieved our stress. The restaurant serves American-style breakfast and brunch: salad, sandwiches, omelettes, eggs benedict, pancakes, French toast, and so on. There were many different menus, so we took a long time to decide. We orderd eggs benedict, an omelette, French toast, and shared them. They were all delicious and the seasoning was just right, especially the French toast's topping of fruit, which was not too sweet, so I liked it the best. We had a fun time. I would like to go there again and try another kind of omelette, French toast, pancakes, and so on. I recommend that you should go there with a few friends with enough time because there are only about 10 tables, so you have to wait and can't stay longer.
author: Ryo R.

description:
Best breakfast in SF. Whatever you want, it is here...french toast, pancakes, omelettes, and much much more. 

Don't worry about the line. It moves quickly. Worth the wait, 

PS Try the French toast sampler.
author: Steve P.

description:
(Only not a 5 cause of the line)

We knew where we were headed.  We had been told by at least 10 people we had to go there and if we didn't get there early we'd be waiting in line.  The second part we screwed up.  After we were able to regain our equilibrium, walk and shake off the head fog from the previous night we headed towards

MAMA'S ON WASHINGTON SQUARE

Mama's is a motherly feel inspired too small bakery and restaurant.  I say too small cause on a Friday around 11:30am when people should be working, this isn't LA where people don't work, we were standing behind about 30 people outside of Mama's.  We were told it's like this everyday and weekends are even worse.  Mama's line is like nothing I've ever seen (Pink's in LA is the closest).  While most restauants have a waiting list or people just hanging artound outside, at Mama's the line starts inside the restaruant at the register and travels up the block elementary school style, one person behind the other.  The employees regulate how many people come inside at a time and if you leave the line you're screwed, you've lost your place.  Standing there you wonder if Mama's is worth it?  Well you should see the food first.

Our party of three ordered Prosciutto and Tomatoes Benedict, the Vegetarian Benedict and a special, the French Toast Sampler. 

The Prosciutto and Tomatoes Benedict was very tasty, a mix of salty flavor from the prosciutto, creamy hollandaise sauce which was a little bitter or sour, which is a nice original touch.

The Vegetarian Benedict was just as tasty.  If you read me often you know from my burger eating that I'm as carnivor as they get, but this vegetarian dish packed the power of a carnivore's punch, full of flavor.

Then came the sugar and like Jesse James' obsession with sexy tatted-up pinup models my obsession is with sugar.  I like Jesse's obsession just as much, but they don't have "Those" kinda girls at Mama's.  Not only did I order the French Toast Sampler but I ordered two slices of Cinnamon Sour Cream Walnut bread.  Today I was all about the carbs and the sugar.  The French Toast Sampler was fantastic, two of the three.  What was cool about their french toast was they make it with their sweet breads and cakes. (The basket of breads photo is what they use to make the french toast) One piece was banana nut topped with fresh bananas, swedish cinnamon topped with berries and another was cranberry orange walnut, which I could have done without (just my personal taste).  The banana nut and the swedish cinnamon was soo sweet and tasty I didn't even need syrup which is like Jesse James and Tiger Woods not needing sluts.

By the end of my french toast rampage I was stuffed.  I had also eaten the last bites of both of the Benedicts.  I stand to see good food go to waste, especially not after waiting 40 minutes in line.  But we were still left with the Cinnamon Sour Cream Walnut bread.  My friend and my cousin were waving the white flag.  BITCHES!  But I still had the motivation and will to at least try these heavenly sweet pieces of decadence.  I dove in and it was everyting every coffee cake in every coffee shop around the world tries to be.  It was sweet but not too sweet, spiced but not too much cinnamon, and soo moist I thought it was attracted to me.  (This is me chuckling.)

I didn't try the Chocolate Drizzle Crumb or any of the other spectacular baked items they bake fresh daily, but they all looked amazing and if the line wasn't forever we probably would have gone back to try them. 

While Mamas is a great meal, a fantastic breakfast
and was worth waiting in 40 minutes in line in the hot sun for, it wasn't good enough to do it again.  Nothing against Mama's but I don't really know any meals I'd wait 40 minutes for.  I totally go to Mama's again if I was back in SF but not if I had to wait in line.  No line means I'm there, otherwise SF offers too much good food to be standing in a line.  That 40 mintues we lost could have been 40 minutes of drinking, eating or finding tatted-up pinup models that we missed out on.

-LAFoodGod
author: John S.

description:
Love
LOve
LOVe
LOVE the eggs benedict and french toast. Tried the omelette before but it's pretty basic. Monte cristo is good too but what makes me come back to mama's everytime is because my memory of the hollondaise sauce on top of the eggs benedict is so strong. I take 1 star off because the waiting time is just crazy and the staff hurry you all the time that I can't really enjoy my breakfast. Good for breakfast and small party. More than 4 people? Don't go to mama's
author: Cliff T.

description: Best breakfast/brunch hands down in San Francisco.
author: Christopher D.

description:
Yes, the line is long. Yes, it gets disorganized and there's no real place to wait for a table. However, if you're grumbling tummy can take it, it's worth the wait. There's a reason for it's almost 500 reviews! Situated on a sunny corner of Washington Square, the place has got charm. Tables by little curtained windows make for a cozy morning meal. And the food is great. Pastries are yum... I like their coffee cake. And they've got great egg dishes too. They pretty much have anything you want. 

However, if it ever came to the 2 top breakfast spots battling it out- Mama's and Dottie's- Dottie would totally whoop Mama's ass. Although Mama'd put up a good fight.
author: Nina H.

description:
Dear lord, I'm the 501st person to review this place.  I've been here on other occasions, but this will be my first review of it on Yelp.  I really, truly love coming here for brunch.  I live in San Jose, but whenever I'm in San Francisco around the brunching hour, I try my best to make it over to Mama's for a bit of brunch heaven.  The delicious food totally makes up for having to wait in line for so long.  I've waited close to two hours before, but I've always felt that Mama's brunch is worth my while.

This past Sunday, my bf and I tried out the Scrambled Florentine (an omelette with bacon, onions, mushroom, and spinach) and the French Toast Sampler (an assortment of French toast flavors), and they were both delicious.  My bf hates waiting, but I got him to admit that our one-hour wait was worth it.  :-)

Give this place a try if you're in the area.  You won't regret it!
author: Diana C.

description:
Not much else I can say that the 750 other reviewers haven't, so I will recommend my favorite: the Monte Cristo.  It is a very elusive item that I can't seem to find at other brunch places.  Mama's was my first introduction to it and can be considered to some one of the few reasons I come back (the other reasons being great service and the cute restaurant).

It'll probably add 5 pounds to your ass in that one sitting, but it's worth every single calorie.
author: L Y.

description: Somehow I lucked out and didn't have to wait. The food was good. Coffee was nothing spectacular. The breads and muffins looked tasty. There is only one tiny bathroom and its outside of the restaurant. You have to walk through the kitchen and out the back door to get to it. So while waiting in line, you are standing either in the kitchen or at the entranceway of the kitchen..either way you are in the way of the servers. I wasn't a fan of that but I'm sure I will be back.
author: Danielle P.

description:
Absolutely the best breakfast I've had EVER!!!! And there are a LOT of places in San Diego (where I'm from) known for local breakfast joints. 
I had the cinnamon french toast with FRESH mixed berries - sweet, but not too sweet. My husband had the eggs benedict, amazing with the sourdough english muffin, gave it a distinct tang to it.  My daughter mowed her scrambled eggs, and my son couldn't even finish his pancakes they were so huge (and really fluffy).  The wait staff was great and helpful in storing our stroller. They came out and gave us samples while we were waiting in line.  I would move to SF just to be a regular here!!!!
author: Aimee M.

description:
LOOOOONG Wait on weekends.  

However:

The Monte Cristo with chocolate coffee crumble as a side more than makes up for the wait.  

And hey, if you're really hungry and you know you're gonna wait for a while, go across the street and pick up some foccacia.  That place is good too. 

If you aren't like me and can't eat a gross amount of food, well you can participate in the tai-chi marathon that will be going on in the square.  Make sure you have a friend to hold your place in line.
author: Kenneth K.

description:
I've lived in SF for umpteen years, and have never been to Mama's.  I always hear all the hullabaloo about how AMAZING they are, etc., etc., etc.  However, I didn't live in North Beach and didn't want to deal with the line.

Now I live in North Beach and after we woke up at 7:30 last Saturday, we decided to head down.  Still a line.  Still didn't get our food until 8:45.  But it was good.  Inventive, their baskets of breads looked a*mazing.  So I had the french toast trio.  Nice.  Very good.  

Servers were also super sweet, never had to give anyone the mad eye to top off my coffee.

So now I can say I've been.  Will I ever go back?  It's one of those places where I don't want to deal with the wait, so I'm glad I got my one time there, as I'll be looking for another neighborhood haunt in the new hood.
author: Karen C.

description: Amazing breakfast.  We went on a weekday.  Didn't have to wait in line, but it was still quite crowded.  Washington Square momlette was incredible, as was shrimp egg benedict.  Have to come back the next time we are in town.
author: Liver B.

description:
There's a reason there are always lines of people waiting to get in to eat here. Fresh, homemade breakfast foods, with lunch options too. I sometimes go with my boyfriend and split a Monte Cristo. It's pretty great there.

Plus, I live down the street and I see people in there cleaning almost every night- like hard core cleaning. It's SO nice to know that a restaurant is squeaky clean.
author: Christina S.

description:
Great place for breakfast/brunch.  When I go here on the weekend, the line is out the door.  Getting inside can take a long time.  Although excruciatingly long, it's worth the wait if there's only 7 people or less in front of you in line.  Today I was fortunate enough to come on a slow weekday morning, and walked right in.  I had the California Omelette.  It has jack cheese, very crispy (tasty) bacon, and avocado.  I enjoyed every bite.  I was tempted to get the special crab, avocado, and sour cream omelette.  I also almost ordered the proscuitto and tomato benedict.  I resisted the temptation this time, but will have to indulge on my next visit.

I liked my mimosa.  Very good.  Heavier on the champagne - just the way I like it.
author: Angie C.

description:
4.5 Stars because of the loooooong wait

Food - Absolutely amazing even though it's simple! Everything just has the perfect touch of salt, blend of flavors, or combinations of exactly what I want for breakfast! I must say their french toast is a bit too sweet if you are getting just that. The french toast sample was like eating a plate of desserts, however, the orange cranberry one was quite tasty. I usually get an omelette with egg whites - children's is my favorite. The potatoes are good and the toast with their house jam are excellent accompaniments. Tiniest cup of OJ but you can't beat the taste of freshness!

Service/Decor: Cute, small mom & pop type homey feel restaurant. Service was excellent. The only thing I hate about going here is the loooong wait (about an hour) on the weekends and then once you get inside, you wait a while longer to order the food.

If you are patient, then you'll be fine. Otherwise you'll be starving and start questioning if it's really worth the wait. Oh yeah, and they take debit card & cash only!
author: Linda C.

description: Bring a pre breakfast coffee and pastry for the line and it's worth it. Showed up at 8:30am and waited 2 hours in line and 30 mins to order/get our food. Great staff, atmosphere and food. The Monte Cristo and fresh squeezed orange (grapefruit) juice screwdrivers are theeeee best. The bacon was cooked well too, for those of you who are as picky as I am about good bacon.
author: Ann C.

description:
we got there on a saturday morning at 8:30, and we ended up waiting for an hour and a half outside, and another 20 for our food to come out. the restaurant is really small and cramped, and there's a clear glass separating you and the chefs so you can watch them at work.

okay it still gets 5 stars because it's TOTALLY worth it. food was delicious.
author: Becky K.

description: Waited 2 hours on a Sunday morning but it was definitely worth it!! Recommend the monte cristo which was to die for!! Cute lil place that serves up great food!!
author: Steph N.

description: The wait is always fairly long but its so worth it. Im not big on breakfast but this place is just amazing.
author: Alyssa V.

description:
This place is amazing! Their omlettes can't be beat (try the California). I love how you just order your food and take a seat. It takes the guess work out of everything. 

I will definitely be back!
author: Marissa g.

description: Overrated. I heard this place served the best breakfast in San Francisco... but I can't say I was entirely impressed. Makes a decent breakfast, but don't know if it's worth the 1-2 hour long wait. I ordered the the dungeness crab omelette and the french toast sampler. The dungeness crab omelette was nothing special, though the french toast was pretty good.
author: Sophia B.

description:
This is my favorite sweet breakfast place in the city. Their french toasts are awesome thanks to the variety of breads you can choose from. Everything is really fresh and they are willing to make things healthy if you want: egg whites or no butter

The only thing that keeps it from getting a 5 is the long line in the extremely high priced OJ

I like the savory choices at Ellas better
author: Keith R.

description:
Soooo, after venturing and enduring the always-and-forever line, I have had three very interesting experiences at Mama's, and have come away feeling calm, full, and eventually, very satisfied. 

My girlfriend-slash-breakfast and brunch connoisseur and I have decided there is an A-team and B-team that rotate in the buttercup wonderland. If you get the A-team, your eggs benny has a hollandaise that is perfectly balanced, your omelettes are perfectly light and filled with flavorful ingredients, and your salmon and crab are light and fresh. Simply put, all elements come together to make you realize that the 90 minute wait wasn't only worth it, but that you've had one of the most deliciously simple breakfast meals of your life.

If you unfortunately are greeted with the B-team, however, things may look the same on the surface, but all of the sudden the wait you endured doesn't seem as  much of a payoff. The hollandaise has separated slightly, and the food lacks overall freshness and delicacy. 

From what we can tell, the A-team works the weekend crowd. Obviously expect to wait, and when you do, be prepared to have an incredibly beautifully executed meal done with care and consideration.
author: Libby T.

description:
This place is adorable, from the dutch doors to the buttercup yellow paint on the walls. The line is long, but get over it. The food is good.

I aspire to rave about the breakfast items as other Mama's fans have, but today I can only attest to the amazing simplicity of the caesar salad. Yes, I ordered a salad when every other sane person around me feasted on french toast and pancakes. 

It was the dressing that did it...I'm guessing oil, parmesan, seasoning and garlic. Simple but very flavorful. No egg or anchovy. Probably one of the best caesars I've had anywhere.
author: Karen B.

description:
This has to be one of the more overrated yelp spots that  I have ever been to. I mean the 4.5 stars is impressive for any place. It got to the point where I started to think the food must be downright magical. Don't get me wrong,it was good breakfast food, but it wasnt quite what I thought. I got the hyped Monte Cristo and my friend got an omelette. The food was fresh and both were good and well made. Why only 2 stars then?! 

Well 1st of all, the wait. I went on a tuesday and I waited for a freakin hour!!!! I mean its breakfast food, hard to really truly screw it up. They do use fresh ingredients, which I give mad respect for, and which definitely puts it above the Stacks and Dennys of the world. However, after waiting 40 minutes to get a table, it took another 20 minutes to actually get served. Its a small place and they cant handle that many customers at once, so why the ridiculous wait after you sit down?! Is any breakfast really worth that wait??

Also, the red potatoes were completely undercooked. Like I said, good  breakfast, but VASTLY overrated.
author: Tommy Y.

description:
I'm a big breakfast guy, and this place is one of the best places. Had the shrimp avocado havarti cheese omlette. It was cooked perfect, fresh ingredients. The home fries were perfect, with a good crispy bite to them. The chocolate crumb cake was delicious too. The service was also very attentive and nice.

As everyone else has said, the wait is very long, so be prepared for at least an hour weight on busy days. But if you got time to kill, and craving a good breakfast, defintely a must go place.
author: Eddy N.

description:
So I have to admit I'm slightly disappointed.  I've heard so many good things about this place and it just didn't live up to my expectations unfortunately.  I came here with my friend Jeff who moved to Seattle a few days later.  Jeff loves eating so I thought this would be a good place for our final SF meal together.

I knew to expect a long wait.  We arrived at 10:15 on a Friday morning and a long line had already started.  We arrive to the front door and end of ordering line about 45 minutes later.  Probably sat at like 10:55 and got our food around 11:15 or so.  So all in all waited an hour for food.

I ordered the french toast with the apples and lemon sauce stuff.  There was an advertisement on the window for it winning an award so I thought it would be a good choice.  Jeff got a salmon scramble thingie.  We both got mimosas and coffee.  Jeff got toast with his meal so he got to try the olallieberry jam.  

My meal was ok.  It was french toast made with a bagutte cut long-ways.  The french toast was really eggy which I like.  It takes a bite out of the sweetness.  And this is just that--VERY sweet.  It has this lemony sauce in the place of syrup and sauteed apples on top of that.  It was just a little too sweet for me.  

I ordered a chicken apple sausage on the side and it was amazing.  You could tell they cooked it in the same pan they cook the bacon and other fatty yummy stuff because it was pretty greasy.  Which was nice because it definitely gave me a nice break from the sweet french toast.

I tried a bit of Jeff's scramble and it was pretty tasty.  Nothing spectacular but very good and had fresh salmon.  He also got a side of pancakes and they were probably the best thing either of us ordered.  Light, fluffy, perfect combination of salty and sweet.  Pretty much why I love breakfast in one wonderful bite.

Also, Mama's should be commended for the olallieberry jam.  Its soooo fantastic.  My mom took my sister and I and some of our childhood friends olallieberry picking every summer north of Half Moon Bay and it brought me back.  So tasty!

All in all, I think I had WAY TOO HIGH expectations of Mama's, maybe I ordered the wrong thing.  I don't know.  

Either way, I like both Chloe's and Ella's much better.  Sorry!
author: Angela S.

description:
the hour long wait was worth it. 

the monte cristo is delicious; it has the perfect combination of sweet and salty.

the home fries were the best i ever had

my tomato and proscuitto benedict wasn't too salty or plain.

the smoke salmon omelet is open faced, but i was a little bit disappointed that the smoked salmon was cooked.  it still had the flavor, but i would've preferred it to be raw.
author: Jenn C.

description: It irritates me everytime i see a long line for this place. it's standard brunch fare with ill reflecting prices and that line is just not worth it!
author: Jean K.

description: Worth.The.Wait. I didn't even want to wait in line to see the Sistine Chapel while visiting the Vatican, but I'll wait for Mama's, it's just that good. Without fail I stop here whilst visiting SF.
author: Hugo C.

description: I came here the week after thanksgiving, and the food was delicious. I ordered the monte cristo and man was it one of the best breakfast items i have ever ordered in my life especially with the homemade jam they offer. which is wayyyyyy better than using syrup. trust me. As for my girlfriend she ordered the eggs benedict, which i have never been a big fan of but i must say that when i took a bite of hers i actually would have been pleased to have ordered one for myself with no complaints. Service was great and as for the line yeah there was one, it took about 45mins to get in but when your with friends/family time fly's right?!!! :-) Go to MAMA'S and enjoy.
author: Mike W.

description: This place is always crowded it usually about a 45min wait, but the food is worth it I like the french toast the best thing you could call your order in and come on down pick it up and enjoy the good food at your home our any ware you want
author: barbara v.

description: I'm not a huge fan of standing in line for anything, mostly because I hate standing, and I really hate lines. But, Mama's will always be the exception if every visit is like this one. Crab meat, eggs, tomatoes and gruyere on fresh brioche!? Yeah, that's truth brother.
author: Dave N.

description:
Delicious. Absolutely delicious.

I got the cinnamon french toast with fruit-- definitely go for the fruit. Syrup was average, the french toast was fluffy and amazing, and -- as other yelpers have said-- the jam (ollalieberry?) was YUMMY! Plated well, served nicely, tasted great and was too much food for me. 5 stars!

He got the eggs benedict... I'll give it four stars. I'm not a connoisseur, but the hollondaise sauce was unusual-- it had a tangy, vinaigrette-like taste, with a bit of a spicy kick. It was very good, just not expected... which is also good. ;)

We got here around 8:10 on a Friday workday morning and the place was almost full, with a line out the door. By the time a few people had gotten seated by 8:20, we were waiting inside. By 8:40, we had placed our order (you pre-order before you take your seats, for efficiency) and gotten a table. We got our food around 9. Not SO bad, people!
author: Samantha B.

description: I discovered this place two years ago during one of my trips to SF. Now, every time I visit the city Mama's is a must. The line is long and it sometimes gets me irritated, especially when I'm hungry, but it's definitely worth to wait! It's there that I had the most delicious blueberry coffee cake. Moist, yummy goodness with a cup of soy latte is a great way to start. I am an omelette at a breakfast joint kind of person, and theirs are very good. We usually order different things with my boyfriend and then pick our favs. At Mama's we fight over what's the best. A wonderful destination for foodies! FYI - cash only!
author: Karolina W.

description:
If you are in the mood for a breakfast to put all other breakfasts to shame, come here!  Thanks to the fellow yelpers I knew to come in hand with a cup of coffee to keep me going while waiting in line for a table.  I went with the french toast (lower fat version, it was a daily special) and it was soooo tasty, smothered in fresh fruit and powdered sugar.  If you are on any kind of a diet, it is tough to eat at Mama's - but not impossible.  They had this Eggs Benedict special with avocado and shrimp.  I didn't order it but one of my friends did and it was AMAZING, closest thing to heaven as far as I could tell.

So why 4 stars instead of 5?  This place is always crowded but it is hard to have a leisurely breakfast with your friends when you know there is a ton of people waiting outside (in the SF cold, fog and wind) so you feel obligated to eat and run.
author: Katie P.

description:
Had the banana-nut french toast and the pancetta/basil/tomato/forgotwhatofcheese omelet....  Toast was okay but the omelet was goood.... like finger-likin' goood...  praise the god's there's pancetta in this world...

Worth the wait?  I dunno... I could've made that breakfast....... 50/50 toss up..
author: Alex K.

description:
**UPDATE**
Hmmm...I wonder if they read my Yelp review?  Mama's now has a French Toast Trio where you can get try out the Cranberry-Orange, Banana Nut, & Swedish french toasts.  YUM!

If you're a chocoholic, the Chocolate Cinnamon French Toast is pretty tasty along with the hot chocolate.  :)

*ORIGINAL*

What can I say that hasn't already been said before?

The hubby & I came here one Sunday morning after many weeks of noticing how long the lines were at any given hour.  We lined up a good 1/2 hour before Mama's open to ensure we would be able to eat right when they opened.  Bring a newspaper/book to read while standing in line.

Their french toasts (my husband got the Cranberry-Orange french toast & I got the Swedish cinnamon french toast) are so good & should be eaten with their homemade jam rather than syrup.  The jam is so good my husband wanted to smuggle a jar home with us!

The only thing that would make this place better is if they offered a french toast sampler--one of each type of french toast they offer.  I mean, how is a girl supposed to decide otherwise?
author: Jenny M.

description:
There is not much to say about this place except that it is absol effing fabulous .... and the line to get in blows ... but hands down best breakfast in the city.

The 'monte cristo' is delightful and you must order it ... so good in fact that I once gave part of mine to some Brit that was sitting next to me randomly cause I wanted her to experience its tasty goodness.

Go here but go early. Wait is usually 45 min plus. Bring the paper and some friends to kill time.
author: Allen X.

description:
Nestled conspicuously on the corner of Washington Square, this quaint, bright country kitchen serves the most fantastic french toasts and omelets.  The french toast is light and fluffy, which allows for the overload of fresh berries, powdered sugar, and if you elect, warm chocolate to dissolve wonderfully in your mouth.  After my first bite, I just smiled.  

I really enjoy the Northern Italian omelet, which has this nice smoky flavor.  They make their eggs soooo perfectly.  The side of fried potatoes you get is crispy on the outside, and soft and warm on the inside, once you break the skin.

Though you often have to wait 45 minutes (or more) for a seat, especially for large groups, the wait is undoubtedly worth it.
author: Elaine Z.

description: I love this place. This is my favorite breakfast spot in SF. I would recommend that you go on a weekday. We went on a Monday and we waited for 30-40 mins. It was well worth the wait. The Dungeness crab Benedict was phenomenal. The bearnaise sauce melts in your mouth & the crab was amazing. My friend ordered the Monte Cristo and it was so tasty. Customers fall in line like a fancy cafeteria style, the fish bowl kitchen looks like you are staring at Dean and Deluca's market and watching the chef's.  Then after customers order you get seated in a cute home style kitchen atmosphere. Its a lovely breakfast spot if you are patient and have someone entertaining while you wait for a delicious breakfast/brunch.
author: Ellen H.

description:
I have always been too scared of the weekend lines, so after being recently laid off I thought I could come here on a weekday and not have to wait. Wrong. Still had to wait, but maybe not as long as I would on a weekend. 
I ordered the Children's Favorite Omelette and an iced latte. The server brought out my latte and said "I have a decaf latte" and ran off, while I started freaking out because I needed to feed my addiction!
