description: This place is so busy during the weekend.  Expect to wait at least an hour in line.  The omelets are really tasty as are the mimosa.  The sweet breads are also really good.  Everything is maybe five dollars more than it should be, but it's in a really great location and it's a nice place to have a nice, slow breakfast (once you're finally seated)
author: Linh N.

description: I have eaten here a couple of times in the past and the food was up there with some of my favorite breakfast spots in the Bay Area like Los Gatos Cafe and Bill's Cafe in Willow Glen.  It gets crowded on weekends and that is usually when I go.  I am not a sun person and of course one day I went the line was going down the block and the heat was killing me.  All in all I would probably wait in that line again to enjoy the food there over and over again even if the sun was out.  Just be ready to deal with cranky hungry people in line complaining about the wait.
author: David F.

description: If standing in longish lines upsets you, then pick another joint, son. The food here is everything solid SF breakfast fare should be: plentiful, cooked to perfection and fresh as HELL. Hi, my name is Ortho, and I Am Impatient, but Mama's is worth the wait.
author: Ortho S.

description:
Do NOT waste your time!  The food is akin to the cheapest diner mush you've ever tasted, AND posted in minuscule font on a faded white-board lets you know the crucial fact that they only accept cash for payment - and at $18.50 a plate, that's ridiculous.  
I waited in line for 90 minutes: no place to sit, standing on a concrete sidewalk with a 30 degree pitch, aching feet and bored out of my mind (not much commerce in the area) only to be served a very lackluster spinach Florentine scramble:  a ton of salt couldn't provoke any flavor from the spinach, with undercooked bacon slices, and potatoes that had no taste with depressing, lard-smeared toast.   It was disgusting!
The dimwitted staff is excruciatingly slow and there are only 12 tables in the place!  When you get to the door, you may think you are close to eating but no..... you still have another 20-30 minutes inside waiting on line to order!  No menu, you must crane around all the heads and bodies to read what they serve.  
I saw NO handicap access to this place.  If you are diabetic - forget it!  If you are hypoglycemic, like myself, this experience is close to a death wish.  
While in line, you will get your picture taken by a dozen tourists, all fascinated with the line of (poor saps?) eager to eat at this greasy spoon.  Maybe you will be lucky, like me and get to listen to a gaggle of girls behind us squeal with inane shrieks as they loudly discussed - in my ear - their social 'lives'.  
It was pure hell.  And I put that lightly.
For those that crave to 'be someone' as they wait in line at a snobby club, for the moment the doorman permits you entry, only to be overcharged for weak drinks and wonder when the fun is going to happen, then go ahead and waste your time in beautiful San Francisco waiting in line to eat here.  You won't be the only one, I promise.
author: Sandra B.

description: Went here for breakfast while visiting San Francisco. The line yes, was very long. We waited outside in line for over an hour and when you get in, you order at a counter. Service was pretty fast. I never though I'd pay 20 bucks for breakfast, but the dungeness crab omelette with leeks and jack cheese was really good. Made my mouth water. I ate half and shared the other half. I also got to try their light and fluffy pancakes which were excellent. I think the line was definitely worth the wait. If I visit San Fran again, I would love to go again!
author: Brey R.

description: I've been going here for over 10 years. The best breakfast spot in SF. I bring all of my out of town guests here. Go on a weekday. Less of a crowd.
author: Johanna W.

description:
My world traveling friend introduced me to this place years ago, and nestled in Washington Square with lines outside of the door, I probably would have 1)never found it or 2)bothered to wait in previously mentioned lines.

Let me say that my friend loves breakfast-I, not so much, but I do LOVE eggs benedict and this place is AMAZING!!!!  I've been there a handful of times and they never have disappointed me.  The line moves much quicker than you think it will, despite the fact that there are only a few tables inside (and no outside seating), but browing the daily specials menu detailing some delicious items is a great way to pass the time.  They are cash only (I believe) and have a pretty extensive menu selections of scrambles, omelettes, french toasts, seafood fare, etc, and this is just the breakfast menu!
author: Lisa G.

description:
Even though there are already 1000+ reviews, let me just give my two cents. 
Someone once told me Mama's is "the best brunch in the city." Another person told me they sometimes make trips into the city from Oakland just to get Mama's pastries. Still other people tell me they have waited over an hour to eat here. 
Ok - so I was convinced I had to try this place. My friend and I stumbled upon this place after I aimlessly walked through Chinatown and into North Beach. It was a Tuesday morning, and there was no line, so we decided to give it a shot.

We got the monte cristo, brioche french toast, and the cinnamon sour cream cake. Was it all delicious? Yes. Was it the best brunch ever? Probably not. Would I cross the bay bridge just to bring a few slices of coffee cake back with me? Never...

Lets put this all back into perspective. I think Mama's IS REALLY good, but I think I overhyped myself because of the 1000+ reviews on yelp. 

Our food was all VERY well-prepared, but what really did it for me was the homemade jam! The omelettes also looked good, and it seemed like that what a lot of other people got. 

I would come here again as long as I didn't have to wait over 20-30 minutes. I don't think it'd be worth a 1 hr. + wait. I would say the morning breads and pastries are probably not all that worth it either. Our small sour cream cinnamon cake was $3.95. It was good, but not THAT good.
author: A. F.

description: Okay, so this place is good. but its not worth the hype in my honest opinion. my vote is more of a 3.5 than a 3. but its not worth a four. The best thing here is there french toast. I like spreading their home made jam on it. Other than that, everything else is pretty average in terms of brunch options. I feel like you can get the same thing at other brunch houses in the area.
author: Minerva l.

description:
It's awesome! 

I've only been there once but you only need to go one time and you will fall in love with this place!

The only thing that I'm not 100% happy with is the long line you have to wait in to get into the place.
author: Matthew C.

description: Been here a couple times since its in the neighborhood. The worse times to come here is in the morning! People, if you think lining up here at the break of dawn til - 10, be prepared to wait wait wait! I usually come here after 12 cause there is hardly ever a line, but don't come too late cus this place does close at 3! I've gotten the prosciutto, tomato, eggs benedict at least twice and I am always tempted to get it again & again cus its so tasty! The omelets are good too, but nothing out the ordinary. I've had a bite of their shrimp omelete... eh, not a big fan, but everything else like the french toast and hashbrowns etc are really good. Service is good, they are always busy, but at the same time are able to give u a good amount of attention. It is a little pricey, but what do you expect when so many people love this place? Also, they take debit & cash only!
author: Jackie M.

description: I love the food.  The lines are almost as bad as they are for a KOGI truck
author: Dgs S.

description: In from Jersey on business and I came across this joint on yelp and stopped in on a Thursday (thankfully there are people just like me who like to help others w/reviews).  Typically there's a wait to get in as the place is always hopping.  We sat down quickly and the food and service were the best.  It blows to live 2,400 miles away from this place...I love breakfast dammit!
author: KB C.

description: It's good - not great, and not worth standing in line for three hours.
author: Larry B.

description: Mama's is a must stop for breakfast while in San Francisco.  The line was outside the door, but the restaurant staff are very efficient and therefore our wait was not long.  Our drinks were a peach/apple bellini and a bloody mary and both of them were delicious.  The fruit is really fresh and super juicy.  When our meals came out they looked like a picture from a magazine.  My husband ordered pan dore and I ordered an omelet with cheese and tomato.  Both of us enjoyed our breakfast very much and we will definitely return when we are in San Francisco again!
author: Brittne E.

description: Not sure I can say much more about Mama's which has not already been said in so many Yelps. We hiked over to Mama's after getting many local recommendations as well as the many positive Yelps.   Yes, the locale is nice near the park.  Yes the restaurant is small and only seats maybe 25-30. Yes, there can be a long wait as the line is queued outside the main door and inside as well to place your order.  Yes, this is their way of ensuring the seated diners are not crowded and waiters can actually deliver the food.  During each visit we had a combo of dishes ranging from the French Toast Sampler to the Dungeness Crab Sandwich.  Yes, the food is very good.  Yes, the breads are awesome.  Yes, the photos posted are accurate.  Yes, they do not take credit cards - cash or debit with a surcharge.  Yes, we were lucky as we managed to eat here twice - but only by arriving very early, well before opening.  Yes,  Mama's is a nice family owned / run business which has excellent staff with a great memory for people.  Yes, our waiter remembered us from earlier in the week. Yes, I would I wait in line to eat a Mama's - I did.  Would I arrive during peak times and wait two+ hours?  ... Probably not, as my time in the city is limited.  Eating at Mama's is an experience and tradeoff in time - which you must decide.  And finally, yes while you are there, if you have not taken the short hike up to the Coit Tower after breakfast, you should but check the opening times first.  Cheers.
author: G M.

description:
I don't know about this one.  Friends raved about it, and so I was all too happy to try it.  Line wasn't too bad -- it moved rather quickly (you order and pay before sitting down, so it's like a literal squat and gobble -- not really a place to linger).  The line was my biggest concern, so all's good on that front.  

So, while waiting, I was debating between the croque monsieur and the farmer's omelette.  I opted for the omelette, which turned out to be a huge disappointment.  The omelette was rubbery and the flavors were disappointing.  My friends scored the french toast, which, although a somewhat smaller portion than a hearty girl such as myself typically goes for, looked quite tempting.  Having said that, however, I will confess that I am INFAMOUS for having serious plate envy.  I'm not proud of it, but there you have it.  

So, all that to say, I was not at all impressed with the omelette, and the potatoes were so-so (a little seasoning wouldn't have hurt), but the jam was divine.  I think it was just a case of bad ordering.  Next time I go back I'm trying the french toast AND the croque monsieur, dammit.  Then I'll reassess.
author: Samantha R.

description:
Have to wait for a while to get a seat but you should go! 
Great breakfast, branch restaurant. Their benedicts are awesome.
author: hugh k.

description:
Mama's is divine! This adorable spot at the corner of Washington Square Park is so warm and cozy, just like mama's! And can anyone say no to chocolate cinnamon fruit french toast? or better yet, dungeness crab omelette? --SO good. This is another place I always like to take out of towners for a good meal. 

Although the food is well worth the wait, sometimes you just don't have time to devote to brunch at Mama's. There are no reservations, and on saturday mornings, the wait can easily take 45min-1 hr, so I recommend bringing an 'appetizer' to tide you over. Oh, and don't even try to wait in line and have your friends come 'join your table.' I've seen the owner kindly ask someone to leave for doing just that. 

Also, CASH ONLY.
author: Caroline S.

description:
After reading reviews about this restaurant on yelp, I knew I had to try it. So, on a trip up to San Francisco with my friends, I stopped into Mama's. 

Luckily, when I arrived around 1 pm, the line was short and the wait was only 15 minutes. I noticed all the wonderful desserts they had lined up as I waited to order. We were seated quite quickly after we entered the establishment. 

Their French toast and pancakes were really good, but what I think makes this restaurant worth 5 stars is their Monte Cristo. Their Monte Cristo is soooooo gooood and is definitely what you should try the first time you come here. This is what sets them apart from other breakfast joints. 

Despite the distance and the wait, I definitely will be returning to this restaurant the next time I'm in San Francisco!
author: michelle n.

description: The line here is Ridiculous...it seriously goes around the block but I figured Hmmm if the line is sooo long the food must be amazing!!! Well it WASN'T this place is super Overrated the food is average and their set up is just awkward. We went to another breakfast place down the street right in front of the park and their food was delicious (wish I remembered their name, Bummer) If you're in the area DON'T waste your time. It's NOT worth it.
author: Perla H.

description: This has been bookmarked on my list for so long that I finally had to suck it up and come here and wait for brunch.  I knew the wait would be long, but a 45 minute wait starting at 1:45pm was almost too much for me.  The food was terrific - the eggs benedict was my favorite, followed by the monte cristo, and then the french toast.  Very cute inside, and at least the wait is in front of the picturesque park.  Not sure I will return to brave the line again, though.
author: Melinda C.

description: We have only had breakfast.  To me eggs are always just eggs.  Having said that the eggs benedict are incredible. The baked goods melt in your mouth and are worth the 1-2 hour wait in line. The crumb cake is wonderful.  Reasonable prices.
author: Dick G.

description: We were in San Fran for 5 days and passed Mama's and the Q a few times, not into waiting 30-120mins for a table... so we went back at abt 2ish....so 15mins in the Q ....10mins to ordered and 5 mins to be seated. The staff are so happy, kind and helpful, Mama's has a very welcoming, cozy and relaxing feel to it. The food is stunning, fresh and delicious, I'd highly recommend the Monte Cristo. Enjoy
author: Audrey C.

description: The best blast brunch place in San Fran. Def beat Dottie's cafe hands down. Can't go wrong with monte cristo!!!! To die for. There is always a line. Trick is to go somewhere between 2:00 and 2:30pm. Line is like 30 mins. If you go earlier, be ready to wait 1 to 2 hrs. Restroom is really small but clean. Brace yourself. Wish this place existed in Philly. At least, just the monte cristo!!
author: Robyn K.

description: A MUST when you visit San Francisco.  Go as early as you can, the line grows fast!  Worth the wait!
author: Sharon D.

description: This place is awesome.  The wait is tolerable on a nice day...which it was both times I've come here...plus it gives you plenty of time to deliberate which breakfast you want to indulge in.  I had the eggs benedict this time- so yummy!  My parents both got omlets and my brother got something he really liked...maybe a scramble of sorts.  Anyway, it was delish.
author: Kirun M.

description: Fresh delicious breakfasts! Don't go hungry though, you'll be waiting in line on the weekends, so take a coffee and little snack for the wait. (Get some foccaccia first from Liguria Bakery across the street.) I like to go early on weekdays, its SO good!
author: karla m.

description: My bf & I waited in line for 45 mins and everyone in line were tourists. I felt the wait was not worth it. We discovered people can order take out by going thru the back door and ordering at the cashier and I would have preferred enjoying my breakfast in the beautiful park across the street, instead of having the crowd watch hungrily at our plates. We ordered the smokehouse benedict and the monte cristo. Both were mediocre. We also ordered an old fashion crumble and a jar of jam to go since a good friend highly recommended it. The crumble was delicious-  fluffy and not too heavy! The jam we tried in the restaurant was quite tasty - not too sweet and very fragrant but the jar we brought home didn't compare - it was very blend. All-in-all, it didn't knock my socks off.
author: J C.

description: Been there two times in the last two weeks.  It is well worth the wait......so don't talk yourself out of it.  Just do it!  This past weekend I had the pancakes with blueberries and bananas on top.  Fabulous.....but PHENOMENAL if you use the berry jam in addition to a little of the maple syrup.  Get ready for a nice walk after breakfast.....cause you will surely need it!!!
author: Jeremy S.

description: Took my fiance there for a nice breakfast and after waiting in the rain, yes we waited....we were blessed with a seat and proceeded to eat some of the best pancakes and eggs benedicts you could imagine. The interior is really cute but can be busy. Be prepared to wait and wait and wait. It's worth it though!
author: Erik U.

description: This was my pick for brunch club a few weeks ago. Food pretty much gets a 10. The french toast sampler was delightful, four different kinds of bread made into french toast, with a bunch of different fresh fruit and some yummy butter and special jam. GF got the monte cristo which was fabulous. Might order that next time. The wait however....It is insane. Seriously, took about an hour and 45 min to get a table, and the system is kind of interesting. You wait in a line, and you are still in a line when you order, then they seat you. The food does come in a timely manner, which is nice.  I had read the reviews, so I knew the wait could be crazy, but when it is actually happening and your tummy is growling, it is hard to imagine that anything could be worth that wait, especially when there are so many choices out there.
author: Natalie D.

description: Love Mama's breakfast! I would give them 10 stars if I could. Food is delicious and fresh and they have large selection. Last time I ordered crab omelet with tomatoes, Havarti cheese and avocado, it was delicious and it had lots of crab meet. The place is not chip, so I go there on special occasions like my birthdays to start the day right :) They also have a big line and it might take about 20 min to get inside but after you order, food arrive very quickly.
author: Olga Y.

description:
No Credit Card.

Good food, service. but 45 min wait for arriving at 9am Sunday morning...I will only come and wait with a good friend! When we came out around 11am, the line looks really crazy. 

The portion is very good. We were soo stuffed.
author: Amy C.

description: We had the Slim Jim burger ($8.00) with the home fries - extra crisp!  They were served on a baguette and the full burger trimming of cheesy sauteed onions.  It was as Yelpland say Delish!  Yes, we had the "famous wait in line" but it was only for 17 minutes!!  Service was excellent as well as the refills on my iced tea (4 times!!!!)  We spied other people's meals and swore we'll be back for their brunch.  My niece from San Diego bought 6 of their cake desserts to take away and one more cake to eat before we had our Slim Jims.  A beautiful feast indeed.
author: Marian G.

description: went here a few weeks back. the food was good but im pretty sure no food is worth waiting in line for that long... we waited 1.5 which seems to be the average time. i had the Monte Cristo which is good but i wish they did not put powdered sugar on it... the bread was super fulffy which was cool. my guy had an "mom"let and it was good but not blow your mind good. the potatoes are really good tho. the staff is nice enough. its a super busy place and very small you don't really have too much interaction with your server you order at the counter usually but we got lucky and ordered at our table the food comes pretty fast and is hot so that's a plus! try it if you don't mind a wait, but don't complain about the wait or if the servers are grumpy, they are working at a crazy place that is always packed and very small... cut them a break!
author: Elise B.

description: definately best brunch ever, excpet the super long waiting time. I love the orange juice, it is so fresh.
author: Carol X.

description:
My favorite breakfast place!!! 

Must orders:
Monte Cristo - French toast with meat and cheese, pan fried and paired with homemade boysenberry jam. 
Slim Joe - wonderful sandwich burger.
author: Diana T.

description:
This was my second favorite place we visited on our recent trip to San Francisco.  We got here early afternoon, around 12 or 1, and there was a line outside of about 10 people or so.  We waited in line for probably 25-30 minutes before getting to the counter, but it wasn't all bad since they had the menu put up on the window so you can decide what you want while you wait.  Once you get up to the front of the line at the cash register, you order, pay and then they seat you.  Beware, while you're in line inside the restaurant, you'll be tempted by the breads and pastries they have on display.  I couldn't resist getting a piece of coffee cake with chocolate drizzled over the top.  Very good!  It's a somewhat small place, so seating is kind of limited, but our party of 8 managed to get 2 tables next to each other.  

They have a good menu of breakfast items (a lot of eggs/ omelets, French toast and pancakes) plus a variety of sandwiches and salads that are served between 11 and 3 (they close at 3pm).  I couldn't decide whether to get the Washington Square omelet (Italian sausage, tomatoes, bell peppers and jack cheese) or the French toast sampler (one of the specials, which included three different types of French toast with some fruit topping).  One of my friends was having the same dilemma, so we decided to get both and split them.  Genius idea, huh?  Both the French toast and the omelet were great!  Mama's makes a homemade berry jam that tastes fantastic on the French toast!  The omelet, very good too.  The Italian sausage in the omelet was awesome and I couldn't get enough.  I don't know what it was, maybe the spices, but it was really great.  A couple of my friends ordered the crab omelet and the crab eggs benedict, both of which were fantastic too.  One of the others also had the burger on a sourdough baguette, which I didn't try but which looked really good.  

The service was good, no issues, and the prices were reasonable ($5-$10 for most dishes).  Overall, a great meal and I'd definitely come back here on a future visit to SF.
author: Kevin F.

description: Omg! A line! Yes, you wait in line...because it's small inside! The food is really good. I popped my Monte cristo cherry there and haven't had a decent one since. The Benedicts are also very good with perfectly made hollindaise. Don't let others reviews of the line keep you from going. We sat next to Annie Lennox one time, and if it's good enough for Annie Lennox, it's good enough for me!
author: Jeremy D.

description: Like many of the other reviewers, this place is ok but not worth the 2 hr wait. We came here for Sunday brunch and both had eggs benedict.  My boyfriend had the prosciutto & tomato benedict, and I had the smoked salmon benedict.  Both eggs were over-poached and not runny at all. The home fries were really good and crispy.  Overall, it's ok but I wouldn't be back if it's a 2 hr wait.
author: Mon L.

description:
* * * NOT WORTH THE WAIT * * *

My friend really wanted to go to this place because she heard it had some good brunch.  She warned me saying that it would probably be about an hour wait.  I've passed by a few times and have seen a really long line.  We were in line for close to an hour and a half.  We finally get inside and wait in another line to order our food.  As we were ordering our food one of the waitress rudely pushed my friend.  As there is any place to stand because this place is so small.  We order our food and have to wait, once again, to be seated.  We waited for another 30 minutes to get our food, once we were seated.  All three of us agreed that the food was OK and couldn't understand what the hype was all about.  We got there at 12:15 and didn't leave until about 4.  We wasted a total of 4 hours for just OK food.  They should change the name of this place to WAITING, as that is all you are doing.  Oh yeah and the bathroom is the size of the closet heading into the kitchen.  The kitchen is one of the only places to wait to use the restroom.  You'll get yelled at if you stand there though.
author: Juan L.

description:
I can't help but be prejudiced by the fact that we waited over an hour and a half to eat.  It was a Saturday, and we got in line at 11am, put 2 hours' worth of money in our street meter - and it still wasn't enough time for us to sit down and eat.  

Mama's is a small restaurant - and as you wait in line (as I did outside for an hour) you get to read the various awards they have won over the years, including one I've never seen before - an award from the California Egg Commissioner for creative egg recipes or something of the like.  So we waited in line - and true to form - it was half an hour and suffered not moving up in line but by maybe a couple of spaces when one of us considered leaving.  But we were determined because, as we saw it, we were already invested in this by half an hours' worth of our time - and dammit - we didn't want to be the suckers leaving the line after we had already been here that long.  But that was where we went wrong...

After an hour waiting in line, we finally got to go inside.  First of all, bring cash because that's all they take here.  We ordered within 10 minutes - at the counter.  Because here, they take your order at the counter and then you sit down and they bring you your order.  What wasn't cool was that there were 3 of us  and they had a bunch of tables open for only 2 people each.  So, literally, we stopped the line - for half an hour, waiting for a 3+ table to open up.  They stopped taking orders, they didn't look for any other 2 person parties, they didn't bother to try to squeeze in 3 people at the 2 person tables (which I kinda was hoping they wouldn't do anyway, but for the sake of efficiency at other restaurants I've seen this done to get the lines moving).  Nor were there any prompts to get one of the larger parties to leave, even though they had already finished their food, had their plates cleared, and continued to talk and take out their mapquest maps even while clearly people were waiting to sit down and eat.  I've seen restaurants, like in New York, rush people out all the time.  Maybe even a semi-apologetic but firm, hey guys, don't want to rush you but there is a wait so could you move this along, please...? would have been great.  But none of that happened, instead the entire crowd waited painfully while we waited for our table.  Maybe the sadistic part of me was a little grateful for that but in no way do I think that was even necessary.  The staff also did nothing to make us feel better or more comfortable just a semi-apologetic excuse from the cashier as we waited.

Then finally a table opened up, we sat down.  I asked the waitress when our order was going to arrive and she told us our order was just put in.  She explained that orders are put in after we're seated.  I think my jaw hit the ground.  I asked how long that was going to take as we had a half hour left on our meter.  She said - oh well, you should go put more money in your meter, and left.

When the food arrived, it was good.  I ordered the eggs florentine with green onions, which was good.  The home fries were okay.  We tried not to let the last hour and a half destroy our spirits.  We really, really tried.  In the end, though, we wound up measuring the food to the wait - and given that it was part of our overall experience, I think it's fair to make adjustments to this review as far as how the food fared against such a wait.  No food deserves an almost two hour or more wait.   And given that the staff did nothing for us in the painful half hour, like offer us a little appetizer, give us a little certificate for another dining experience here, stand up for all the customers waiting by trying to get the diners who were finished to move along, or offer a sincere apology (and I mean that by having exhausting other alternatives on their end) - I really have little incentive to come and try out their food, again.  Yeah, I get they are a mom and pop store - and maybe they don't have the means to be throwing out gift certificates every time there's a little fuck up like they do at Starbuck's.  But we're also not in the dark ages where we can't appreciate a little more time and effort put into customer service.  

Two stars.
author: Lorraine D.

description:
looking for a *decent* korean joint? read my nxt review...

***

again, the hype... you think by reading, not skimming, but reading over 20 *SOLID* 5-star reviews and having ppl ALL over the stinkin continent rave about this place will not only stop you from drooling but to be superly eager to give this place a try... 

*shakes head*  go figure...

mama's = OMG, *hands down* a tourist trap like no tomorroooo... 

as if you didn't know, i'm a youth leader at church ... and one of my girls is currently going through a bit of a rough time, and to lessen the pain, and to spend quality // sisterly time, i treated her to any place of her choice ...  

i pick her up and we get to mama's by 9... yes, by 9 and there's STILL* a line out the door? goodness! peek foto~

mama's...

def a great choice, by YELP standards ...  i have to admit, it was pretty good, but it wasn't definitely worth the long ass line we had to wait ... on a positive note, we had a lot to talk about so it made our line move rather quickly...

the place is super small, yet it has a cozy feel to it ... hmm.... i'm trying to think of ONE word to describe this place ... give me a minute ... 

you walk in, you're greeted by this host who is extremely welcoming and friendly, and then you are faced with this line where the guys take your order -- cool thing is, you get to see them make the goodies, right in front of you -- and then, you pay up @ front... hey, at least you know it's freshly made. the ingredients - definitely good quality, and fresh. =D

i got their eggs florentine for $9.25 ... it was pretty tasty, but then again, it's a generic breakfast dish which you can't screw up on... you know how it is, you always want to fall back and order a safety dish.. my lil sis got the shrimp benedict w/avocado and tomato for $11.50... the shrimps were hella tiny, but they sure weren't cheap with their avocado. seems like every other person in the restaurant ordered some type of florentine dish.  i liked mine better and she initally liked hers, but ended up eating half of mine (later saying that mine was better), so i ended up eating half of hers, which wasn't a big deal...

with a line like this, save your quarters for the meter parking and your time/energy some place else... *no pun intended*

yay, i got that one word my brain was itching to fart out: it's ch, ch ch, charming~ (like that charming bear toilet paper commercial where the bears shake their bootays... !!! )
author: Jennifer S.

description: This place is fantastic.  Yes, the wait is long but once you get inside it's worth it.  The anticipation probably makes the food taste that much more satisfying once you finally get it. Based on the other yelp reviews I got the Monte Cristo which was awesome. I tried the french toast sampler and the florentine benedict which were great as well but in my opinion nothing as special as the Monte Cristo.  Definitely a place to try if you live in the Bay Area, but go on a day you're not busy.  The line is long and you might want to fit in a nap when you leave.
author: Cameron S.

description:
two words: mamas.
 its was everythi9ng we were told about  and more! yes theres a line, but it adds to the mamas magic, the line wasnt that crazy for us, maybe 40 minutes, but my gosh the food, oh, the food! my lovely girlfriend ordered the pancakes with fresh fruit, oh man well put pictures up soon, each pancake was at least an inch thick, and so fluffy and just so good. 
      i ordered the chocolate cinnamon french toast and it killed! bannanas, strawberrys, blueberrys, oh my! my lady got some orange juice, bomb. there was no ice in it but somehow it seemed perfect like mama knew what was up and knew that OJ didnt need ice, anyway, eat at mamas, but not on monday, they dont exist on mondays.
author: Truman S.

description: I have lived in the neighborhood since 1995 and for years I have eaten at Mama's...it's just OK. Now for the last 2+ years there seems to have been this crazy trend for people to wait up to 2+ hours to eat at this place. Seriously? It's not that good. Really, it's not. You would think that by the reviews on Yelp, these people have never had french toast before. It's bread dipped in an egg batter. It's french toast. But then again, anything is going to taste fantastic after waiting in line for over 2 hours. Believe it or not (and I shouldn't give this away) but there is an IHOP 4 blocks down the hill and their french toast is as good, if not better than Mama's) I believe that Mama's has turned one stretch of our neighborhood into a horrible tourist/transplant infested mess. Out of towners smoking and talking loudly while staring through the window at the people inside Mama's eating their overpriced crab benedict. Are these the same people who camp out in front of KMART or Best Buy all night after Christmas to save $20 on a DVD player? I laugh everytime I walk past these poor souls in line as I head over to Original Joe's. I laugh even louder after I have eaten my breakfast at Original Joe's and hour and a half later and the same people are still waiting in line for french toast. Enjoy the long wait! I'll be the one walking by fully satisfied after a hearty breakfast pointing and laughing.
author: James H.

description:
it's definately a popular destination for tourists, so always expect a crowd on any day of the week. it's always worth the wait though.

once you get in, they put you in a queue where you can watch the pastry chef and the brunch chefs work. all the fresh ingredients are laid out for you to drool over. they have you order and find you a place to sit.

eggs benedict - traditional and done right
crab benedict - soft and delightful
washington square omelette - my favorite omelette
any french toast - fresh white wheat or baguette for the bread and fresh fruit
apple pan dore - sliced sourdough baguette french toast with apple slices and powdered sugar to top it off
monte cristo - french toast with turkey ham and cheese melted and stuffed inside
slim joe burger - yum

enjoy!
author: Dennis L.

description: 5 stars for the food, 2 stars for the wait.  The breakfast food here is actually really really good.  Usually breakfast food is pretty straight forward and hard to screw up.  This place is actually really good.  The wait is ridiculous.  Its an interesting business problem to solve though -- they could make more $ if they expanded but so much of their business is based on the weekend crowd.  Maybe they should buy up the upstairs and rent it as commercial during the week and brunch on the weekend?  Anyway, I digress.  Great place- but you're going to be waiting a LONG time.  And since everyone else is waiting right in front of you, you feel compelled to eat faster.
author: J L.

description: I came here one Sunday morning with my ex and a compadre of ours after a late night of drinking.  The ex drank a little too much and just sat there looking queezy, nibbling on a piece of dry white toast while we stuffed our faces.  We were so enthralled with the food here that we just kept munching away, asking her to please pass the jam, butter and other condiments throughout.  Its not that I'm insensitive, its just that it was so damn good....
author: Rick H.

description: This place is worth standing in line in the rain 30 minutes prior to opening. The "low fat" French toast, side of ham bigger-than-my-head, and friendly service make it worth the challenge to get in!
author: Vicki L.

description:
first spot I'm hitting when I'm back in the city is MAMA's. 

pout* I want some mama's french toast so badly.

all you locals who drive by...walk by... hell is within a 30mile radius of this place please stop taking it for granted get your butts in the absurd line and order French Toast and an omelette for good measure and for me. =*( i miss mama's.
author: Melissa T.

description: If you like lines, Mama's is for you!  If you like telling people that you went to Mama's in spite of the long lines, then Mama's is for you!  If you want a decent breakfast with no lines, then go to any one of the City's zillion other breakfast joints that is just as good as Mama's and you'll be fine.  I went here on a rainy work day under the assumption that the line would be shorter--WRONG!!!  It was at least as long as usual--I don't get it.  Eggs Benedict was OK, but nothing better than I've had a million other places.  In summary, if you are a lemming, you will love waiting in line at Mama's.  If you are hungry and want decent food, you're just as well off going to Mo's right down the street which has a decent Benedict, great potatoes and there's never a line.
author: John S.

description:
best breakfast joint in san francisco so far

forget about going on weekends unless you wanna wait in line for 2 hours
author: Thömas F.

description:
There are many things that are well-worth the wait, but Mama's breakfast just isn't one of them.  The food is good, don't get me wrong.  But sometimes I think the time invested and group-think positively correlate to great reviews, creating 4-5 star momentum.

But take away the long ass lines and to me, you have a pretty good breakfast.  If you're going to wait this long, there better be something spectacular on the other side - it was only a pretty good breakfast.
author: Michael C.

description:
Played hooky from work yesterday and headed up to city in search of some great grub and fun.  I couldn't wait to try the breakfast at this cute little place after reading so many great reviews.  Lucky for my friend and I being that it was a Thursday, the line wasn't bad.   So embarrassingly funny though...while we waited, I was peering through the window to see what everyone else was ordering for ideas and eyeing the yummy dishes they were throwing out from the kitchen.  This one guy was forking a good dose of the french toast into his mouth when he caught me drooling.  hahaha  Sorry dude, it's a bad habit I have..watching people eat!  

So, you can imagine how starving we were when it was time for us to order.  Btwn 2 girls...we ordered the Monte cristo, eggs benedict and a trio of their most popular french toast served with fresh fruit on top - the kugelpuph, cinnamon, and the banana nut.  The tables next to us and people in line were starring at our food - I think they were either amused or amazed at how much food we had ordered considering each dish alone would have fed 2 slightly hungry people.  Okay, so I had the Monte cristo with potatoes.  Gawd...definitely hit the spot.  With all the other options on the menu and being that I'm a huge fan of breakfast foods...I had a winner!  My friends eggs benedict was just okay.  I took one bite and it was a bit too rich for me.  She tried the Monte cristo and agreed it was the bomb!  Okay, onto the trio of french toast.  I could only have a small bite of each but they were all good.  My fav was the kugelpuph which is their house made brioche filled with nuts, raisins and cinnamon.   

Make sure you go hungry and bring some buddies.  Our eyes were definitely bigger than our tummies!  ;)*
author: Diana L.

description:
Food here is simply delicious! The ingredients are FRESH! I love eating their Monte Cristo, digging in their amazing house-made jam. Their omelets are also really good. Even though the food is awesome, I rarely go there. Here are my reasons:

1) Long line, at least one hour wait. The restaurant is tiny; it holds about 40 people. Don't bother if you plan to go during the weekend. 

2) Cash only.  It doesn't make sense not taking credit card since average tab per person including drink (coffee, juice or smoothies) is going to be around $20. 

3) I just don't like that I have to pay for the food before I get to get it.  

4) It's pricey!
author: Ed W.

description: This place is amazing brunch, but if you come on the weekend prepare to wait in line at least 45 mins to get the table.
author: Sasitorn O.

description: After reading reviews, I made sure to drop by Mama's on an off hour so I was spared the long wait. But after having the french toast, I think I'd be willing to brave the lines! Not too eggy and still warm. My boyfriend enjoyed his corned beef hash and happy it wasn't from a can. Unfortunately for him, though I'd snatched his sourdough toast and they made for a tasty boysenberry sandwich. By the end of the meal, I was eyeballing the menu and have decided I will have the kugelpuph next time!
author: Nathalie L.

description: There's nothing wrong with the food here but it's nothing special either. We went to Mama's with two friends who were in town and were all looking forward to trying it because it receives such rave reviews. But, the food simply wasn't worth the hour+ wait in line. If I'm going to wait in line for an hour, I'd much prefer to go to Dottie's!
author: Sydney L.

description: Waiting in line for about 40 minutes in the HOT BLAZING SUN was no fun. But Mama's, oh Mama's, you really did make the wait well worth it. Everything flowed so quick and smoothly after we were seated. I ordered the Washington Square Omelette and the bf ordered an omelette with crab and avocado, I believe. And of course we also ordered the waffles. The food was DELISH!! We took pictures before and after our meal and geeez, we are such FATASSES.
author: Kathryn C.

description:
I first heard of this place a few years ago from my close friend.  We decided to go check it out and see what all they hype was about.  Both she and I were early birds so we got there at 8 am on the dot, but I couldn't believe it...there were already a good 10 people in front of us already!  Luckily, we got in with the first wave of customers. whew. You don't want to see me hungry...

I got the lox bagel platter which was quite delicious.  While it was definitely on the pricier side, the salmon was super fresh along with the tomatoes and cucumber that came with it. My friend ordered the french toast and it was so pretty! Almost too good to eat..keyword there is almost bc she devoured it pretty darn quickly.  Everything there looked super fresh and gorgeous...like it came out of a magazine.  

I'm a fan of the mom and pop atmosphere that mama's has, but at the same time..I can't decide if it has become a little to posh for my liking.  Once, I came back with an old friend to catch up.  We had literally JUST finished our food and we were sitting there finishing up our conversation.  However, that conversation was cut short because one of the servers had approached us and asked us if we could finish our conversation elsewhere bc there was a line of people waiting for a seat.  While I understand that they are busy, there have limited seating capacity, but I also feel like I should have the right to sit there and at least digest a little before I am herded out the door.  

Overall: you are paying for good food and beautiful presentation and  good food and beautiful presentation is what you get.
author: Winnie S.

description: Food was good. The only downside is the long wait. It is ridiculously long. The line won't move until each party gets seated.
author: Wing W.

description: Ok....Where do I start.....Whew!...The best monte cristo you will ever taste. As well as the omelets that are so delicious as they slide down your throat with every spicy bite....A MUST!!! for everyone visiting the Bay Area.
author: Randall M.

description: Queued for 2 hours and went into a very nice cafe, breakfast was well worth the wait,  great ambience, good service, and would revist
author: Thom K.

description: Just like everyone else, we had to wait.  Showed up about 2pm on Sunday and it was an hour before we got to the inside line and ordered our food.  I was ordered to get the banana nut french toast.  I added a side of bacon - which is practically worth the wait in itself.  Probably the best bacon I've had in memory.  My friend had the Northern Italian omelette.  The eggs were ok, but the filling was amazing.  The french toast was also ok (very dense and not typical french toast by any means), but the raspberry jam I dunked it in was better.  I think I ate half the jar.  We split the blueberry sour cream cake as a start (which was awesome because it came out right away, before our food - and tasted amazing).  WHEN I go back, I think I'll go for the Monte Cristo but like I said, I was ordered to get the french toast.
author: Jody B.

description: Went for the second time today. This is a real feat since we rarely go somewhere twice with so many places to try. OOOOHHHHH it was good. The wait is negligible compared to the quality of food and service. Both times going here we had a very nice waitress that took good care of us even though it was so busy. The eggs benedict is wonderful. The omelettes divine and my new personal favorite is there Monte Cristo which melts in you mouth. They have a level of freshness in their food that sets it apart from any breakfast joint that I know. For breakfast in the city I recommend mama's first.
author: Johnny J.

description: Just three words...OMG!  I always take my out of town friends here and its never a let down.  Just be ready for a 45-hr. wait.
author: LIVE to E.

description: Yummy food, but not sure it's worth an hour wait.  The last couple times I tried to take out of town friends there, the wait was prohibitively long and we went elsewhere... I guess you can't argue with success.
author: Rose Q.

description:
I finally understand what they big hype is about with Mama's.  I've lived in the city for a year and I definitely dihonored since yesterday was the first time I experiened Mama's.  The wait wasn't that bad, it wa a beautiful Saturday morning in the city, sunny and so clear that you could see both bridges atop Russian Hill.  After 45 minutes and 30 picutres later (I'm trigger happy and my sister won the Photography Award in High School so she is legit) we finally got to place our order and sit down.  We got the corner table near with the bench near the cooks and I must say it is the most comfotable seat in the house not to mention you have the view of Washington Square.  Just lovely.  I had the Northern Beacher Omlette which encased Ortega Chiles, tomatoes, cheddar and jack cheese.   Obvi, I ordered a side of bacon.  My Mom got the Eggs Benedict and she is still raving about the Hollandaise sauce right now.  My sister Mio ordered the Bagel and Lox dish and cleaned her plate.  So did Miki, she slurped down her Nelson's Ranchero.  Of course brunch is not brunch without a Mimosa and a Bloody Mary.  The smoothie was a hit too.  Everyone working there had a fat smile on their face.  I'm sure I would too, they must all take home a fat tip.

Bottom line:  I would have waited twice as long.
author: Shiho F.

description: Went here and waited hour and a half before being seated.  I had the french toast sampler and it was ok but my wife has the crab/brie/avocado omelette, which was very good.  Recommend for one time visit but not worth the wait.
author: Lucas J.

description: Food is amazing! Waited outside for an hour and then got inside and waited for another 20 mins. But the food was so damn good! Well worth the wait.
author: Bryan C.

description: So as you can see from their rating and the number of reviews that Mama's has received, it's definitely worth checking out. I'll spare you and not write an astronomically long essay about this place (although I would honestly love to).  In short, it's incredible food, friendly service, everything is deliciously home-made, and it's decor is nothing short of charming.  It can be a bit pricey depending on what you order, and the line is almost always long, but with every bite you will thank yourself for waiting in the heat/rain/fog for the experience that awaits you.
author: Whitney H.

description:
We visit San Francisco frequently and decided it was time to stand in line (only 45 minutes due to morning rain; sometimes up to 2 hours or more) and have the breakfast that everyone talks about. Once we were invited inside, we were placed in another line that goes past the kitchen headed toward a cash register where we were told to order and pay for our meal (cash or debit, no credit cards) and wait for a table to open up. One opened up and we were directed to seat ourselves. The drinks we ordered were unceremoniously dropped off at our table. We asked for a bowl of fruit to tide us over until breakfast arrived (there is one cook with some helpers preparing food for about 20 tables, so the wait at the table was lengthy).  A bowl of fruit was brought -- along with a bill that was expected to be paid upon receipt, before our main meal was brought. This was a real put-off.  When our food did arrive, it was luke warm. At this point  - now an hour and twenty minutes into the ordeal - we did not have the patience to send it back.  I had Florentine Benedict and my husband had the Crab Benedict. Both were pretty much unacceptable. The Hollandaise sauce tasted like yellow-colored paste - not a even a hint of tangy lemon or and echo of rich butter to be found anywhere on the plate. Honestly, I am an average home cook and I can create a better Hollandaise from scratch at home. I was inclined to scribble down my recipe on a napkin and hand it to the cook. 
Truly, I felt embarrassed for them for what was supposed to be "the best breakfast in town." The poached eggs were overcooked so that the yolks were not runny, but chalky-cooked. And don't forget, only luke warm. The fried potatoes that came with the meals were dark brown, almost burnt, and dripping in whatever grease they were cooked in. They didn't even taste like potatoes and were not seasoned in any discernable way.  We also ordered sides of Italian sausage (hey, it's North Beach!) and we were greeted with a greasy and again overcooked mess on a plate. And throughout the entire time we were seated, our small water glasses were refilled once.  It's like they couldn't get your cash and get your out of there fast enough. At the end of the meal, we decided to leave a very small tip  (less than 5 percent) on the table for the limited and less than stellar service we received. It was memorable, but not in the way restaurants want to be remembered. We also made a family pact never to waste our precious San Francisco vacation time at Mama's again.
author: S. M.

description: Mama's is definitely the best breakfast in town. Minus one star for the horrendous wait. Plus one star for the waiter knowing exactly what I wanted to order before the words even came out of my mouth. This place is awesome and I would come here every  weekend for brunch if I didn't have to wait in such a long long line.
author: Lauren Y.

description:
We went to Mama's on a Tuesday morning around 8:30, which was probably a good idea considering how long the lines can get. Indeed, I've walked by this place on a Sunday and the line was nearly around the block!
Inside is small and homey, with provencal inspired tablecloths and curtains. You order and pay for your food at the counter, and then you are seated at a table. There was no wait for us.
I ordered the french toast sampler plate, which included the cranberry orange, banana nut, and apple french toast. The plate included an assortment of fresh berries and bananas. I also ordered a soy latte which was brought out in a tall glass. The coffee/milk creation had resulted in a separation of layers, which looked impressive. Not to mention tasty! 
The french toast was delicious, and the portions huge. I should mention that they provide us with a pitcher of jam and syrup. I'm more of a jam kind of person, so I seasoned my toast with the berry concoction rather than going the traditional syrup route.
I was not able to finish my breakfast, but no worries, packed it up in a box and brought it to work for a friend. 
I would give this place 4.5 stars (not 5 since the service was a bit on the slow side). Definitely try and go during the week if you have a chance!
author: Kate A.

description: Best all around breakfast place EVER! I mean, nothing is bad here, everything on the menu is amazing (some places only a couple of things are good), here you can put your money on literally ANYTHING! I really love their monte cristo sandwich, benedicts (vegetarian and regular), and french toasts. I also try to get the dungeness crab omelette with brie and avocado when it's the special of the day (I don't usually eat seafood, but this I am willing to eat!) Everything is made to order. Their freshly baked goods (blueberry lemon muffin is my favorite) and their homemade jams are AMAZING! If you get there at 8am, there's no line, but if you come later, you will have to wait in line for an hour, sometimes more. But I assure you, it is worth the wait!!!
author: Cristina D.

description: Holy Molie! It takes a lot for me to really really like a breakfast place.  It takes a lot for me to be able to distinguish breakfast foods from any old cafe.  However, Mama's was soooo delicious.  Their pancakes were so fluffy and the fruit on top was just the right amount.  Their Florentine Scramble Omlette was perfection and their potatoes are YUM.  I can do without the wait, but whattya gonna do?  YUM!
author: Ivy S.

description: Mama's is sheer breakfast indulgence. From the fresh berry coffee cake, to the apple pandore french toast, to the crab benedict, to the fabulously perfect Monte Cristo...there is no better place to call home for breakfast, than Mama's.
author: Brittany T.

description: We have had brunch here numerous times, but the last visit impressed me the most. Maybe it was a weekday so we didn't have to wait for an hour? The french toast sampler we ordered? Or the perfectly cooked omelette?The only thing I can pick about is the coffee which is a little bland for my taste. But overall it's as good as it gets!
author: Chuck W.

description: The best dollar pancakes and syrup hands down! But that line, the long wait, the small sitting area is totally ludicrous. They should renovate and open the 2nd floor to hold more people.
author: Rosanne A.

description: The gold standard of breakfast in San Francisco.  I've never had anything not exceptional.  Do go on a weekday morning a half hour before it opens and I think they are closed on Mondays.  Do NOT bring a toddler with you they will not make it through the wait in one piece.  I brought my husband on our first trip.  He would NEVER wait in line for a meal.  After that meal he waited in line once a week, patient as could be.  He was a changed man.
author: Pamela I.

description: The French Toast were very yummy we had the sampler French toast and the original eggs Benedict were good! Next time I will try the Prosciutto Eggs Benedict. All of the food was served hot and in a timely manner. The waiting time was about  an hour which was a big downer.  All of the portions were good sizes!
author: Angie S.

description: Decent breakfast in a nice location (tucked away from Columbus on the corner of Wash. Sq. Park) with a light, comfortable (though not exactly spacious) interior.  Most importantly, they make a pretty good breakfast.  However, as most other yelpers have already pointed out, there's almost ALWAYS a line, and the food really isn't worth more than a 10-15 minute wait, tops.  Always wondered why they don't put tables outside on the sidewalk?
author: Ryan W.

description: Always a favorite. My husband and I woke up at 5 AM and drove from LA to SF, got there by 11:00 AM, checked into the hotel then beelined for Mama's. For the first time, there was no line, (Friday noon). We always enjoy their food here. Where else can you get a french toast made with homemade cranberry walnut bread! And a tasty tasty crab omelette.
author: Macelle A.

description:
Mama's is good choice for breakfast, especially when an out-of-towner is visiting San Francisco, since it's such a scene.  If you get there any time after it opens (as opposed to being there right when it opens), prepare to wait around 45 minutes before you're admitted to the exclusive club that is Mama's.

The food is solid breakfast fare: pretty good pancakes, decent eggs benedict, and a good selection of breakfast sausages.  The coffee was tasty, as was the orange juice.  The servers (if you can call them servers: although they bring you your food, you order at the counter before you sit down) are pleasant, and the food came quickly after ordering.  

Overall, Mama's is a nice experience.  It isn't as good as some breakfast restaurants I've tried, but it's definitely among good company.
author: Andrew D.

description: I loveeeeeee Monte Cresto!! Can't wait to go back again!!!
author: Athicha P.

description: My wife and I went to Mama's on the recommendation of a fellow Yelper, and it is as good as it was billed.  We went on a fine. sunny weekday at around 9 am, stood in line (as apparently is always the case), and walked by all the fresh delectables while cooks prepared dish after dish until we got to order.  Then we got to sit and soak up the sun, the great, positive energy, and the really delicious breakfasts we ordered.  An all-around great outing and definitely one of my favorite breakfast spots in the city.
author: Bob H.

description: It's true what the reviews say: Make sure you bring a book or a good friend to talk to because the wait is about 45 minutes to get in the door and another 15 minutes before you order up front. The place isn't huge but definitely popular for those weekend brunchers, especially with the line wrapping around the restaurant. I think my expectations were high but I thought breakfast to be homey but nothing spectacular- Banana bread french toast was okay (literally banana bread..i think i would've preferred toast) - a bit on the heavy side but tasty when topped with fresh fruit. The Italian omelette was delicious, especially with the cured ham and stringy cheese. I wouldn't mind coming back and trying the dungeness crab benedict or trying the other famous breakfast place, Dottie's. 3.5 stars.
author: Jenny L.

description: It's breakfast food, no need for hour-long waits on weekends, but good for the experience I suppose.
author: Nish N.

description: The food was fine, but after waiting in line for what feels like a century I was too pissed off to enjoy my meal (and so were my friends).  I don't recommend coming here with an empty stomach.  Maybe next time, I'll come at a more optimal time, but I can't say for sure if there will be a next time.
author: Lily T.

description: Some people don't realize this: the berry jam on the table is homemade and CHRONIC. make sure whatever you order comes with toast so you can test it out. and don't go here unless you have tons of time to wait and tons of change for the meter parking in North Beach because nothing ruins breakfast like a $40 ticket.
author: Natalie K.

description: This weekend I went to try Mama's.  I heard from a friend that this place is really good.  So went there instead of Luna Park because of the time of hours of operation.  So we wait in line for about 40 minutes.  I ordered Shrimp Benedict with Tomatoes and Avocado and my first bite I can already taste the fishy-ness of the shrimp.   Overall dish was nice but the fishy-ness of the shrimp made me dislike the dish.  My friend said the his over-easy eggs were over cooked and the city potatoes were over cooked too.  Reading all these reviews, having to stand in line, and drive from San Jose for this was not worth the time.  And across the street we had the Pizza Focaccia bread.  The bread was good but it was just tomato sauce and green onion.  I gave it 3 stars too!
author: G C.

description:
There are so many reasons I think Mamas is THE BEST breakfast in the city. As a brunch hobbyist, I'm very impressed that EVERYTHING is homemade. I mean, the baker makes cakes and breads right in front of you. If you're a local and go often enough, you may be offered 1 of their fine coffee cakes on the house, because you ARE special to them & they appreciate your willingness to eat in the same small space as the hoards of tourists who listen to their hotel people. Being a creature of habit, I LOVE the crab benedict (or shrimp, if I go too late and they run out of it), momlettes, chocolate cinnamon french toast with berries (CRAZY good), and the egg white scramble w/ mushrooms and green onions (but be sure to ask for butter on your toast with this dish, if that's your preference...they'll keep it off, thinking you are concerned about your health, or something...very considerate). Bacon and fresh OJ goes with everything...highly recommended.

BRING LOTS OF CASH...they don't take credit and feature above-avg. prices.

Now, to address what many find to be a frustration...the incredibly LONG lines on Sat/Sun. They open at 8...arrive at 7:45 with a cup of coffee, newspaper, and comfortable shoes...lean against the wall for up to 30 min. The most important tip: arrive with only ONE dining companion (parties of 4 or more make it difficult for everyone to be seated...honestly, I saw a party of 15 once and that will discombobulate the restaurant for hours, so please dine here responsibly). That simple. Alternatively, go during the week, when there are no lines to speak of...I mean, if you're going to take a mental-health day, this is not a bad place to get back on the road to recovery.
author: Julia C.

description: So many people are willing to wait an hour plus to eat here because it's good.
author: Lauren L.

description:
Have you ever wondered what a cloud would taste like?  Come to Mama's and find out!

As a devout foodie, this is my mecca.  At least once a year, I make the journey for Mama's fluffy cloud-like pancakes, their unique delicious Italian-inspired omelettes, and their heavenly Monte Cristo sandwich (its a ham, turkey, swiss sandwich dipped in egg batter, pan-fried, and served with jelly/jam).  You might be wondering, does this guy eat all of this?  The answer is yes, the first time I visited, I ordered everything I just listed above.  After a 45-60 minute wait in line (which is the average wait time for weekends) and seeing all the wonderful entrees, I couldn't help myself.  Additionally, they have some of the best seafood breakfast specials around.  From fresh crab egg benedicts, to shrimp omelettes, to specialty french toast sets, I feel like I died and gone to breakfast/brunch heaven every time I get to this place.  This place still maintains its hidden gem charm (homey, down-to-earth, and outstanding service), but just with a lot of people.

Although I have tried many places before I came to Mama's and even more afterwards, its places like this that make me keep exploring what's out there.  Thank you Mama's for the wonderful job you do!

*Tips (everything on the menu is very good, so here are just non-food tips):
- Weekdays are far less busy.  If you got the time, swing on in, grab a paper, and enjoy.
- The wait can be long on weekends.  The place is small too, so large parties usually have to sit apart.
- Cash only, be prepared.
- If you can't find parking near Washington Square, head east on Filbert Street (towards Mason Street), there usually is parking around there.  Its also where the parking lots are located.
author: Herman N.

description: Best breakfast in the city - hands down!!  Despite the lengthy waits (today I waited for almost an hour) the food is always good and the people that work there are really friendly.  Gotta try the eggs florentine (or benedict) and they have literally the best pancakes I have ever had in my life!!  HUGE portions, so come with an empty stomach.
author: Stephanie W.

description: my bf and i went and had the dungeness crab benedict and the fruit waffle. it was OK. my bf really liked the dungeness crab benedict.. i thought it was a little fishy. but yeah. i gotta order somehting else next time.
author: Cindy L.

description: The place is ok.  It's good, but just ordinary good.  It's not worth standing in line for such a long time.  The place is pretty fun to eat at.  Cute decorations and such.  The staff is just normal people, not overly nice or anything.  Overall it was just a regular breakfast joint.
author: Melanie S. K.

description: One of the best brunches I've ever had.  I had the "Mama's Children's Favorite" omelette - tomatoes, mushrooms, green onions and cheddar.  Cooked to perfection.  The side roasted potatoes and sourdough toast were also delicious.  We had to wait awhile but it was worth it.  Service was outstanding and will definitely go back next time I'm in SF!
author: Angie C.

description: I love Mama's! It's me and my husband's breakfast spot! Everything on the menu is yummy! You do have to wait in line to be seated, as it is always packed, especially on a Sat. or Sun. morning - but it's worth it! My husband and I like to head here at 2:00 PM on a random Wednesday, when most people are at work. My fav. would be the pancakes, simple but sooo good! Gotta try it!!!
author: Christine L.

description: The Monte Cristo is TDF (to die for).  I have yet to find one as yummy as Mama's.  The wait is long, yes,  but enjoy people watching and grab a newspaper to help pass the time.
author: Emily W.

description: Yum, Yum, and  Yum some more! It might seem intimidating with a line coming out the front door, but don't let that stop you. The wait is absolutely worth it! Once you are inside and order the service is great. They are always checking on you, refilling glasses, helping you with whatever you need! I ordered the North Beach Eggs Benedict which came with proscuitto and tomatoes. I have never liked a breakfast so much EVER! My Uncled ordered banana pancakes which were deelish, and they have homemade jam on the table that you absolutely have to try! 5 stars! i wish i lived closer!!
author: Bristol C.

description:
Amazing French Toast.  Got the French toast sampler, all 3 types were great.  Had to resist getting the chocolate cinnamon, but that's definitely the plan for the next time I go.  Per the waitresses suggestion, put the homemade jam (not sure what berry it was from) on the french toast.  Best decision I've ever made.

Very friendly service as well.

The guy at the register said that they're best known for the french toast, pancakes and the monte cristo sandwich.

Went at about 8:40 on a Sunday morning, took about 30 minutes to get in.  Not too bad, but expect to have to wait on the weekends unless you get there before it opens.
author: Edward W.

description: If you can get there at a non-peak time, it's best. The food really is delicious. The pancakes and french toast special items are creative without sacrificing a traditional taste, and they never disappoint. All the portions are startlingly generous, and once you're actually seated, food comes out really quickly. I had an omelette once (from the specials menu) that knocked my socks off: shrimp, avocado, havarti and tomatoes. Ahhhh. Yes, I suppose it's worth the wait. A little pricey, but less so than comparable places.
author: Megan W.

description: I would drop one person off to stand in line, then have the other person circle around to find parking.  Expect a 30-60 min wait depending on when you arrive.  Don't come after 2:35 PM.  I liked the crab benedict and crab omelette special.  They give you a lot of crab meat.  Also, don't forget the dollar size pancakes topped with berries (or french toast).  Their jam is superb.  when compared to dottie's, brenda's, etc. this place isn't that good
author: Rob C.

description: We were visiting San Fran and stopped by Mama's for breakfast. The line wasn't long because we got there early, but a few minutes later I looked behind me and the line went all the way around the outside of the building! Mama's live up to the hype though. Really loved their omelettes and their Monte Cristo ($9.50) is to die for!! Their fresh squeezed orange juice is the best orange juice I've ever had in my life.
author: Keo D.

description: After reading all the reviews, we decided to go for it on a Sunday morning and endure the one hour or so wait.  We decided to go for the crab omelette and french toast sampler with homemade jam.  The food was fresh and amazing.  This place makes eating breakfast a new experience.  Now I know why all these people are willing to wait in line.
author: Kevin J.

description: Besides Zazie, this is my other favorite place for brunch.  The people there are super friendly.  Hint: if you go enough, do get to know them.  If you go after 11am, expect at least a 30 min wait.  Monte cristo is my favorite item and they only make so many of them everyday.  I take all my out of town friends here or when I have leisure time to get a good brunch.  Bring cash and a paper to read in line.
author: Julia H.

description: Worth every minute of the wait!  the food is incredible and i haven't found a better breakfast.
author: Michelle M.

description:
this place gets my approval for a pretty good breakfast place. 

I had the eggs benedict ... it wasn't the best, but it beats a lot of the places i've tried in the city ... even though it was a bit runny.

Imo, if I had to wait in a line that long for typical breakfast, I'm going to Pork store.
author: Sam K.

description:
Breakfast mecca.  Eggs Benedict in almost any form and a split piece of coffee cake with your companion borders on the transcendent.  Great for capping off a nightlong, joyously enthusiastic, unexpected romp in the sack.

Not that I would know about such things.
author: James N.

description: I enjoyed my brunch at Mama's and am really glad I came to see what all the hype was about but because it was so build up I was hoping for more. We went on a week day so the line was a little shorter (30 minutes as a guess). My friends food was really good and mine would have been minus the ham being a little on the fatty side in the eggs benedict, but we both enjoyed our meals and were eyeing the 3 layered french toast at the table next to us. My complaint is that they put us at a very cramped table right at the opening of the door so i was never really able to relax during brunch with the hostess opening and closing the door letting the wind hit me and people constantly brushing my chair.  Overall a 3 stars but possibly would have been higher if i had been sat at a better table. 5 stars for the company I had and morning off of work!
author: Barbara C.

description:
I know you're supposed to love it, it's an institution and all that. 

And it was good, it really was, but worth lining up outside in the cold for - no, I think not. 

Went with a group of 7 (six out of towners (actually out of country'ers) who LOVED it + me). We got there at 7:40 and lined up to get a table. 

The food was good (I had the north beach omelet) and I liked the option of a hunk of warmed sourdough instead of the usual toast. Potatoes were quite undercooked. 

Others had the banana pancakes which looked great or the special of the day chorizo and eggs which looked like a passable huevos rancheros. 

It's a solid breakfast place, but I just can't get past they idea that I lined up in the cold to stand in another line to order.  All for an omelet that I could have gotten in my hotel restaurant. Maybe the french toast really is that good? 

My friends liked it so well that I'll probably end up here again when they return next year - and that'll be okay. 

Make the trip on my own - probably not.
author: Jon F.

description: expect about a 20 minute line...it's pretty good breakfast...i love the omolettes here...
author: Hen A.

description:
this place is absolutely amazing. i started coming here when i came to visit san francisco with my family. and regardless of the fact that no matter when you go, you have to wait on a line for maybe about 30 minutes, it is completely worth it. i believe the line usually forms before they even open.

go on the weekends and get a crab and brie omelette. its delicious and really amazing. 

its a pretty small little place and i think they make most of their own breads and pastries, but its cozy and again, it doesn't matter how crowded it is, its completely worth it. 

go here!
author: Georgia W.

description: Dined here last week with my friend Tree. LOVE this place!  4 stars instead of 5 because the whole ordering, waiting, sitting situation is a bit tedious.  Great service and tasty vittles!  I ordered the open face avocado and shrimp omelette.  And since it was a beautiful Wednesday morning and I didn't have to go to work, I had a Bloody Mary too! Yum!  There is a great park across the street.  We went there afterwards and played tug o war with a huge, German Shepherd named Bear.  All in all it was the start to a lovely day.  There will always be a line because Mama's rocks!  No worries!  It goes fast. If you are visiting SF or you live here, you have to try this place.
author: PictureGirl F.

description: I've only been here twice so my experience of the Mama's is limited. The pancakes I had on my first visit was good and above average. The coffee was fresh and welcomed on the cold San Fran morning. The long wait outdoors and close proximity of the tables left me with a bad vibe. The second visit was much better and the French toast was delicious. I was likely in a better mood being that it was a beautiful day with a surprisingly short line. I'm sure it also helped that I was there with a beautiful girl and that we had just scored a package of Focaccia from Liguria across the street.
author: Jerry L.

description: Love this place!! long line at times. The service is nice and the food is fabulous. The french toast is my fav. I get it all the time.
author: cecilia a.

description: I've heard this place is really busy early and you have to wait in line awhile, but the food is so worth it. I went there with a girlfriend (who was as indulgent and laid back as I am) after 12 pm and we didn't have to wait long and the french toast was amazing.
author: Michael E.

description: Probably the only place on the planet where it's worth it to wait in a one hour line for breakfast.  Magically delicious in every way.  I like the Swedish cinnamon french toast with two eggs sunny side up.  The chocolate-drizzled crumb cake is other-worldly.  The freshly squeezed orange juice is great too.  NOTE:  They accept debit cards and cash only.
author: Jason S.

description: Eggs Benedict with the perfect hollandaise sauce.  Fluffly pancakes with fresh, fresh strawberries and raspberries.  Cloud-like monte cristo that you dip into homemade jam.  Yes, I can feel my arteries clogging... but that's why I bring a jump rope so I can do some excercises why I'm in line.
author: Tangerine L.

description: Is it worth the wait? Of course not! Wake up: it's just breakfast! Then again, after a solid one hour wait and two XXL cappuccino's, my crab omelet is like a gift from heaven. Spoil your BF/GF/Mother/Date by doing the waiting on your own: success guaranteed.
author: Mike O.

description:
knowing full well about the lengthy lines, we decided to go to mama's anyway.  it was a gorgeous morning, and shockingly, the line only took us about 45 minutes to get through.  yes, that is a supposed short amount to wait in line here.  

we heartily ordered some coffee cake, coffee, a dungeness crab omelette, and a waffle "sampler"... and it was all good!  okay, not just good, it was delicious.  everything was quality, and even the service admist the hustle and bustle was great.

bottom line: mama's is worth it... just good luck with the parking!
author: Jill k.

description: Finally went to Mama's for the first time - even though I've lived in the city for more than 5 years!  it was a really gooooood breakfast, but frankly not good enough to wait in line for 2 hours.... I mean, come on -breakfast is breakfast. It's pretty simple.  Although I have to say their Pan Dore (thin sourdough frenchtoast with lemon-butter sauce and sliced apples) was one of the better breakfast dishes I've had.... I probably won't go back here on a weekend, but if I'm ever out and about (and not working) on a weekday I would definitely hit this up.
author: A B.

description:
After reading many reviews in which the reviewers deducted stars for the long wait, I felt the need to write my own review. Yes, this restaurant only holds roughly 40 guests and this means that you are promised to wait at least 30 minutes to one hour to be invited into the restaurant, but the majority of Mama's guests know this fact ahead of time. From personal experience, the wait in line is worth it! The staff members are friendly, both times I was a guest the owner was in view and offered samples of fresh baked breads to all those standing in line to order. The food is fantastic and made fresh practically in front of you. The price is above average for breakfast foods, however you must remember that you get what you pay for! If you want a larger seating area, with cheaper prices, I am sure that you can find a large, impersonal, commercial diner somewhere else. If you want a small, family run business that serves fantastic food, go to Mama's!

Florentine Scramble was fantastic & the Monte Cristo was to die for.
author: K Y.

description: Cute little restaurant on the corner in Washington square.  You order at the counter and then you have a server which I always thought was weird.  Is it table service or is it counter service?  Anyways, gets really busy for breakfast.  I had a plate of different kinds of french toast with fresh berries on top which was really good.
author: Elaine K.

description: OMG...this is my all time most favorite place for breakfast. only thing that annoys me is the the insanely long line on the weekend and parking. parking sucks. its totally worth the wait tho. everything ive tried has been delish. from the dollar size pancakes to the eggs benedict...everything is a must try at least once. the juices are all oh so fresh also and the staff is all wonderful. oh how i miss mamas cooking. literally.
author: Tuan D.

description: Killer breakfast!  Fantastic and fluffy omlettes and great breakfast bread.  Long yuppy line and dumb shits who linger at their table long after eating their food.
